Praefatio.	Preface.
Postquam compleui uobis o Filii, librum hunc, qui est postremus scientiae in medicina cum complemento ipsius, et consecutus sum finem in eo, ex expositionibus eius, et ipsius declarationibus, uisum est mihi, ut compleam ipsum uobis cum hoc Tractatu qui est pars operationis, id est, chirurgiae cum manu.	After I have completed for you O Sons the book which is the ultimate science in medicine with its complement and having reached the end of it from its expositions and declarations, it appeared to me that I should complete it for you with this Treatise, which is a part of practical application, that is surgery using hands.
Quoniam operatio cum manu prostrata est in regione nostra, et tempore nostro priuata omnino: donec fortasse periit scientia eius, et abscissum est uestigium eius: et non remanserunt ex ea, nisi descriptiones paruae in libris antiquorum, quas mutauerunt manus: et accidit eis error et haesitatio, donec clausae sunt intentiones eius, et elongata est uis ipsius: Visum est mihi, ut uiuificem eam cum ordinatione huius Tractatus in ea secundum uiam ex positionis, et declarationis, et abbreuiationis: et ut ueniam cum formis ferramentorum Cauterii, et reliquorum instrumentorum operis: cum fit ex declarationis additione, et ex properatione eius quod est necesse.	Since surgical practice with the hand has been neglected in our region and our time: until perhaps its science perishes and its trace is completely cut off; and there remains of it nothing but small descriptions in ancient books which have been distorted by later hands, and upon which error and hesitation occur, until its intentions are obscured and its vision prolonged - It seemed to me that I should revive it with the ordering of this Treatise on surgical practice according to the way of exposition, declaration and abbreviation; and so that I may come to know the forms of cautery instruments and other tools of surgery by means of addition in their description and of their necessary preparation.
Caussa autem propter quam non inuenitur bonus artifex eius cum manu sua in hoc nostro tempore, est: quia ars medicinae est longa, et oportet auctorem eius exercitari ante illud in scientia anatomiae, quam narrauit Galenus, donec sciat iuuamenta membrorum, et ipsorum formas, et eorum coniunctionem, et separationem, et habeat cognitionem ossium, et neruorum, et lacertorum, et numerum ipsorum, et eorum egressionem, et uenarum pulsatilium, et quietarum, et locorum exitus earum.	The reason why a good practitioner of this surgery with his own hand is not found in our time is: because the art of medicine is long and its author must be trained beforehand in the science of anatomy which Galen described until he knows the structures of members and their forms, and how they are joined together or separated; and has knowledge of bones and nerves and muscles and their numbers, and knows how they move, and of veins - both those that pulse and those at rest - and where they emerge.
Et propter illud dixit Hippocrates, quod nomen cum nomine est multum, et cum opere est paucum, et praecipue in arte manus.	And for this reason Hippocrates said that a name is great with a name, but small with a deed, and especially in the art of hand surgery.
Nos uero iam diximus de illo in introitu huius libri.	We have indeed said this about it in the introduction to this book.
Quoniam qui non est sciens, quod diximus de anatomia, non euacuatur, quin iam cadat in errorem, quo interficiuntur homines: sicut ego uidi multos ex illis, qui formantur de hac scientia, et iactant se de ea absque scientia, et sine experimento.	For those who are not knowledgeable about what we have said regarding anatomy, they will not be cleared of error, in which people are killed; as I myself have witnessed many among them who are trained in this science and boast of it without knowledge or experience.
Quod est, quia uidi medicum stolidum secuisse apostema scrophulosum in collo mulieris, et incidit quasdam arterias in collo: quare fluxit sanguis mulieris, donec cecidit mortua inter manus eius.	What happened is because I saw a foolish physician cut a scrofulous abscess on a woman's neck and he severed some arteries in her neck; thus the woman's blood flowed until she fell dead between his hands.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui praesumpsit ut extraheret lapidem uiro, qui processerat in aetate, et lapis erat magnus.	And I witnessed another physician who presumed to extract a stone from an aged man and the stone was large.
Peruenit ergo ad eum, et extraxit ipsum cum frusto uesicae.	It therefore reached him, and he extracted it with a fragment of bladder.
Quare mortuus est uir in tertio die.	Thus the man died on the third day.
Et ego quidem iam uocatus fueram ad extrahendum ipsum: et uidi ex magnitudine lapidis, et dispositione infirmi, quod moriretur.	And indeed I had already been called to extract it; and upon seeing the size of the stone, and considering the patient's condition, I knew that he would die.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui accipiebat stipem apud quendam Ducum terrae nostrae propter medicinam: et accidit eunucho nigro, qui erat apud ipsum, fractura in crure eius prope calcaneum: et properauit medicus cum ignorantia sua, et strinxit fracturam super uulnus cum puluinaribus, et astellis strictura forti, et non dimisit uulneri expirationem.	And I witnessed another physician who was taking a fee from one of the Dukes of our land for his services; and it so happened that a black eunuch, who belonged to him, suffered a fracture in his leg near the heel: and the doctor hastened with his ignorance and bound up the fracture over the wound with plasters and tight bandages, and he did not allow any release for the injury.
Deinde absoluit eum secundum desyderia sua.	Then he discharged him according to his desires.
Postea dimisit eum diebus aliquot, et praecepit ei, ne solueret ligamentum: et stetit sic donec apostematum est crus eius, et ipsius pes, et peruenit ad perditionem.	Afterwards he let him go after a few days and instructed him not to loosen the bandage; and he remained like that until an abscess formed on his leg and foot, and it resulted in his ruin.
Vocatus sum ergo ad eum: et properaui ad soluendum ligamentum: et consecuta est tranquillitas, et euasit a doloribus suis.	I was called upon and hurried to release the ligament; thus tranquility ensued, and he escaped his pains.
Verumtamen corruptio iam confirmata erat in membro: et non potui refraenare ipsam.	However, the deformity had already set in firmly on his limb; I was unable to rectify it.
Pon ergo cessauit corruptio perambulare in membro, donec periit.	He consequently ceased walking due to the deformity on his limb until it perished.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui perforauit apostema cancerosum: et ulceratum est post dies, donec magnificata est malicia eius cum domino ipsius.	And I saw another physician, who pierced an abscess filled with cancerous matter; it became ulcerated after a few days until its malignancy was magnified before its owner's eyes.
Quod est, quia quando est cancer purus ex humore melancholico, tunc non oportet ut perueniatur ad eum cum ferro omnino, nisi sit in membro quod toleret, ut abscindatur totum eius.	This is because when cancer is pure and comes from a melancholy humour, it ought not to be approached with the iron at all unless it is on a limb that can tolerate having its entirety cut off.
Et propter illud o Filii, necesse est uobis, ut sciatis, quod operatio cum manu diuiditur in duas diuisiones: scilicet, operationem cui associatur salus: et operationem, cum qua est periculum in pluribus dispositionibus.	And for this reason, my sons, you must know that surgical work is divided into two branches: namely, operations which are associated with a cure; and operations where there is risk in numerous situations.
Et ego iam excitaui in omni loco huius libri, in quo uenit operatio, in qua est terror et timor.	And I have already aroused you everywhere in this book to where the operation involves dread and fear.
Quare necesse est uobis, ut caueatis illud, et dimitatis ipsum: ut non inueniant stolidi uiam ad loquendum, et dehonestandum.	It is necessary for you to beware of that and avoid it so that the unlearned do not find a way to speak about it and bring dishonour upon it.
Accipite ergo mensuram cum sollicitudine et protectione, et infirmos uestros cum facilitate et firmitudine, et utimini uia meliore perducente gratia Dei ad salutem et successionem laudabilem: et dimittite aegritudines terribiles difficilis sanationis: et tollite animas uestras ab eo quod facit uos timere, ut ingrediatur super uos haesitatio in fide uestra et commodo uestro.	Therefore take the measure with care and protection and your patients with ease and firmness; and go by a better way, leading to healing and laudable succession through God's grace; and abandon those dire diseases which are hard to cure; and remove from yourselves what makes you afraid so that hesitation does not come upon you in faith and gain.
Est enim magis remanens ad gloriam uestram, et sublimius in mundo isto, et postremo ad quantitates uestras.	It is indeed more conducive to your glory, and loftier in this world, and ultimately to your status.
Galenus enim iam dixit in quibusdam suis admonitionibus.	Galen has indeed said as much in some of his admonitions.
Non medicetis aegritudinem malam: ne nominemini medici mali.	Do not treat an evil disease, lest you be called bad doctors.
Iam autem diuisi hunc Tractatum secundum tria Capitula. ¶	I have now divided this Treatise into three Chapters.
Capitulum primum.	Chapter One.
De Cauterio cum igne, et Cauterio cum medicina acuta, capitulatum, et ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum, et ferramentis Cauterii: et omni quod necessarium est in operatione. ¶	On cauterization with fire and with sharp instruments, systematic and ordered from head to toe, the shapes of the instruments and tools used for cauterization, and everything that is necessary for such operations.
Capitulum secundum.	Chapter Two.
De sectione et perforatione, phlebotomia et uentosis, et uulneribus: et extractione sagittarum, et similibus illius: et totum capitulatum, ordinatum formis instrumentorum. ¶	On cutting and piercing, bloodletting and boils, wounds; on extracting arrows and the like; likewise ordered and systematic regarding the shapes of instruments.
Capitulum tertium.	Chapter Three.
De restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus illius: capitulatum, ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum.	On restoration and dislocations, curing twists and the like; likewise ordered from head to toe and systematic regarding the shapes of instruments.
Soli Deo Gloria.	To God alone be glory.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis.	The Surgical Book of Al-Zahrawi (Albucasis).
Pars I.	Part One.
¶ De Iuuamento, et Nocumento Cauterii: et quibus complexionibus conueniat, et quo tempore: et si cum ferro, uel auro.	On the harm of cauterization; on which constitutions it suits, and when; whether with iron or gold.
Caput I.	Chapter One.
Sed Ante Quidem Quam rememorer operationis cum eo, oportet ut dicam qualitatem Iuuamentorum eius, et Nocumentorum ipsius: et in qua complexione exhibeatur.	But before recalling the operations with it, one should speak of its qualities and harms; on which constitutions it is to be used.
Dico ergo, quod sermo de qualitate iuuamenti Cauterii, et nocumenti eius, est sermo prolixus, et subtilis, scientia, et secretum occultum.	I say, therefore, that a discourse on the quality of cauterization and its harmful effects is an extensive, subtle matter, a science, and a hidden secret.
Etiam locuta fuit in eo multitudo sapientum, et dissenserunt in eo: et mihi quidem sufficit parum ex sermonibus eorum, timens prolongationem.	A multitude of wise men also spoke on it, and they disagreed among themselves; for me, a little from their discourses suffices, fearing prolixity.
Dico ergo, quod Cauterium confert uniuersaliter omni complexioni, quae est cum materia, et absque materia: excaeptis duabus complexionibus, quae sunt complexio calida absque materia, et complexio sicca absque materia.	I say, therefore, that cauterization universally suits all constitutions, whether with or without material; except for two constitutions, which are the hot constitution without material and the dry constitution without material.
In complexione autem calida et sicca cum materia dissenserunt.	However, they disagreed about the hot and dry constitutions with material.
Quidam enim dixerunt, quod Cauterium iuuatiuum est in ea.	Some said that cauterization is beneficial for them.
Et dixerunt alii contrarium illius, scilicet quod Cauterium non est conueniens in aegritudine, quae est ex caliditate et siccitate: quoniam natura ignis est caliditas: et inconueniens est, ut sanetur ex agritudine calida et sicca, cum calido et sicco.	And others said the opposite, that cauterization is not suitable for an illness arising from heat and dryness; since the nature of fire is heat, it is unsuitable to heal a hot and dry illness with something hot and dry.
Et dixit ille qui dicit contrarium illius: quod per Cauterium fit iuuamentum in omni aegritudine calida et sicca, quae accidit in corporibus hominum: quoniam quando tu comparas corpus hominis, et humiditates eius, ad complexionem ignis, inuenis corpus hominis frigidum.	And he who said the opposite stated: cauterization benefits all hot and dry illnesses that occur in human bodies; for when you compare a human body and its humors to the constitution of fire, you find the human body cold.
Et ego quidem dico per sermonem eius: quia ex perimentum iam detexit mihi illud aliquotiens.	And I say, from his discourse: because experience has already proven this to me several times.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut ueniat super illud, nisi qui iam probatus est, et exercitatus in capitulo Cauterii exercitio ultimo, et cognouit diuersitatem complexionum hominum, et dispositionem aegritudinum in se ipsis, et caussas earum, et accidentia ipsarum, et spacium temporis earum.	However, one should not attempt it unless he is already proven and practiced in the last chapter's exercise on cauterization practice, and has knowledge of the variety of human constitutions and the disposition of illnesses in themselves, their causes, incidents, and duration.
Ex reliquis autem complexionibus non est super uos timor: et praecipue in aegritudinibus frigidis et humidis.	Among other body types, there is no need for concern; especially with cold and damp illnesses.
Iam enim conuenerunt omnes medici super eas: et non dissenserunt in iuuamento cum Cauterio in eis.	For all physicians have indeed agreed upon them; and they do not dissent on the usefulness of cauterization for these.
Et scitote filii, quod ex secreto curationis per Cauterium cum igne, et bonitate eius super Cauterium cum medicina comburente est: quoniam ignis est simplex, cuius actio non peruenit, nisi ad membrum quod cauterisatur: et non nocet membro alio coniuncto cum eo, nisi nocumento paruo.	And know, my children, that from the secret of cure by cauterization with fire, its goodness is superior to that of cauterization with burning medicine; for fire is simple, whose action does not reach unless to the member which is cauterized: and it harms no other member joined to it, save for a small injury.
Medicinae uero comburentis actio peruenit ad illud quod elongatur ex membris: et fortasse facit accidere in membro aegritudinem difficilis sanationis, et fortasse interficit.	However, the action of burning medicine reaches that which extends from the members: and perhaps it causes to happen in the member a difficult-to-heal illness, and perhaps it kills.
Ignis autem propter subtilitatem suam et bonitatem substantiae suae, non facit illud, nisi superfluat.	But fire, because of its subtlety and goodness of its substance, does not do this, unless it is excessive.
Iam uero innotuit nobis illud per experimentum, propter longitudinem seruitutis et studii cum arte, et stationem super ueritatem rerum: et propter illud excusor a longitudine sermonis.	It has already become apparent to us through experimentation, due to the length of our service and study with this art, and our standing on the truth of things: and I am absolved from the length of my speech because of that.
Et si non esset, quia non licet huic libro meo, afferrem uobis secretum occultum in igne, et qualitatem operationis eius in corporibus expulsionis suae, qua expellit aegritudines sermone philosophico demonstratiuo, qui acueretur a mentibus uestris.	And if it were not for the fact that it is not permitted to reveal in this my book the hidden secret of fire and the quality of its operation in bodies by means of expelling illnesses, which it demonstrates with philosophical reasoning that would sharpen your minds.
Et scitote filii, quod ipsi dissentiunt in tempore, in quo conuenit fieri cauterium, et ponunt melius tempus ueris.	And know, my children, that they themselves disagree on the timing, at which it is appropriate to perform a cauterization, and place greater value on the proper time with truthful reasoning.
Et ego dico, quod cauterium conuenit in omni tempore: propterea, quod nocumentum accidens propter tempus submergitur in iuuamento, quod attrahitur cum cauterio.	And I say that a cauterization is appropriate at any time: for this reason, that the harm of an accident due to timing is submerged in the benefit which is drawn with cauterization.
Et praecipue si cauterium est propter dolores ex doloribus necessariis, fortibus, festinis, qui non tolerant tarditatem: propterea quod timetur ex eis, quod accidat malicia quae est maior, quam paruum nocumentum intrans propter tempus.	And especially if cauterization is done because of pains arising from necessary injuries, strong and severe ones that do not tolerate delay: for this reason, there is a fear that the worse harm will occur rather than a minor injury caused by delaying treatment.
Et non cadat in mentibus uestris o filii illud, quod non extimant, nisi uulgus et stolidi medici, scilicet quod illi aegritudini quae sanatur per cauterium, non est reditio semper: et ponunt illud consequens, et res non est sicut putant: propterea quod cauterium non est, nisi loco medicinae, quae alterat complexionem, et exiccat humiditates quae sunt caussae, quare accidunt dolores.	And do not let it occur to your minds, o sons, that which only the laymen and foolish physicians do not consider, namely that for illnesses which are healed by cauterization there is not always a relapse: they regard this as its consequence but it is not so; for cauterization serves no purpose other than in place of medicine, altering the body's constitution and drying up the moist humours which cause pain.
Verumtamen cauterium superfluit super medicinam per uelocitatem ualetudinis suae, et uirtutem suae operationis, et uehementiam dominii sui: et possibile est, ut redeat aegritudo hora aliqua temporis secundum complexionem infirmi, et locationem aegritudinis suae, et uirtutem eius: et quod praeparatur in corpore eius ex aggregatione superfluitatum in eo: et quod peruenit ad ipsum in acquisitione sua ex cibis, et similibus illis ex caussis, nisi fit aegritudo, in qua administratur cauterium.	However, cauterization surpasses medicine because of the speed with which it heals, and its powerful mode of operation, and the intensity of its control; and it is possible that there may be a relapse after some time according to the patient's constitution, and the location of their illness, as well as its severity, and what has been prepared in their body from an excess of humours within them, or what has reached them through acquisition from food, or similar causes unless they fall ill with something which requires cauterization.
Aegritudo subtilis in membro paucarum superfluitatum, et humiditatum, sicut cauterium dentis, propter dolorem, et similia illi, possibile est enim, ut non redeat in eo ille dolor.	A subtle illness in a limb which is caused by an excess of humours and moistness, such as the cauterization of a tooth due to pain, or similar cases may not relapse.
Sed illud fit in paucis.	But this occurs in few cases.
At uero sermo uulgi iterum, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, est sermo rectus: non ad illud quod ipsi intendunt in illo: quoniam ipsi credunt, quod non est curatio quae conferat cum medicina, neque cum alio post occasum cauterii.	However, the layman's saying that cauterization is medicine's last resort is correct, but not as they intend it; for they believe there to be no cure which can match medicine or any other treatment once cauterization has been applied.
Res autem est econtrario illius, et intentio, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, non est, nisi quod quando nos administramus modos curationis in aliqua aegritudinum, et non conferunt illae medicinae: deinde administramus in fine rei cauterium, et confert: tunc inde cadit, quod cauterium est postremum mediciuae, non secundum intentionem quam intelligunt uulgus et multistolidorum medicorum.	However, the reality is the opposite of that, and the intent, which is that cauterization is the last resort in medicine, it is not so unless when we apply methods of treatment for some illnesses and those medications are ineffective; then we perform cauterization as a last resort, and it works: from this comes the saying, 'cauterization is the last resort in medicine,' but not according to the intent that the general public and many foolish doctors understand.
Antiqui autem dixerunt, quod cauterium cum auro est melius, quam cauterium cum ferro: et non dixerunt illud, nisi propter aequalitatem auri, et sublimitatem substantiae suae: et dixerunt, quod non facit pus locus cauterii.	The ancients said that cauterization with gold is better than cauterization with iron, and they did not say this except because of the equality of gold and the loftiness of its substance; and they said that the site of cauterization does not produce pus.
Verum non est illud absolute: quoniam ego iam probaui illud, et inueni, quod ipsum non facit illud in quibusdam corporibus absque aliis.	But that is not absolutely true, for I have already proven it and found that it does not do so in some bodies without others.
Et cauterium cum ipso est bonum, et melius quam cum ferro, sicut dixerunt.	And cauterization with gold is good, and better than with iron, as they said.
Verumtamen quando tu ignis cauterium in igne ex auro, non declaratur tibi, quando ignitur secundum quantitatem quam uis, propter rubedinem auri: et quando properat ad ipsum frigus, et si addis super ipsum ignitionem, liquescit in igne, et uertitur in laminas.	However, when you heat the cautery over fire made from gold, it does not indicate to you when it has been heated according to the amount that you desire due to the redness of the gold; and when it quickly becomes cold, and if you add more ignition to it, it melts in the fire and turns into flakes.
Quare cadit artifex ex illo in occupationem: et propter illud fit Cauterium cum ferro apud nos uelocius et propinquius, ex rectitudine ad operationem.	That is why the artisan falls short with it for the task; and because of this, cauterization with iron among us is faster and more immediate in terms of preparedness to perform the procedure.
Et ego quidem iam ordinaui hoc Capitulum in Cauterio, secundum capitula: et ordinaui ea a capite usque ad pedes: ut alleuient quaerenti illud quod uult ex eo.	And I indeed have already arranged this chapter on cauterization according to topics, and I have arranged it from head to toe so as to facilitate the search for whoever wants something from it.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Caput in commissura coronali.	The manner of cauterizing the head is at the coronal suture.
Caput II.	Head, second degree.
Confert hic cauterizatio ad dominium humiditatis et frigiditatis super cerebrum: quae duae sunt caussae sodae, et multitudinis fluxus humorum ex capite ad partes oculorum et aurium, et multitudinis somni, et doloris dentium, et doloris gutturis: et uniuersaliter omnis aegritudinis, quae accidit ex frigiditate, sicut paralisis, et sodae, epilepsiae, et apoplexiae, et similia illis ex aegritudinibus.	This cauterization is applicable to the dominance of moisture and coldness over the brain: which are two causes of headaches, and the multitude of fluid flowing from the head towards the eyes and ears, and the abundance of sleepiness, toothache, and throat pain: and universally for all illnesses that occur due to coldness, such as paralysis, fainting, epilepsy, apoplexy, and similar diseases.
Modus cauterizationis est, ut praecipias infirmo: ut euacuetur in primis cum medicina solutiua mundificante caput tribus noctibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod exigit uirtus infirmi, et eius aetas, et consuetudo eius.	The method of cauterization is to instruct the patient to first evacuate their head with a cleansing, dissolving medicine for three nights or four, according to how strong the patient is, and his age, and what he is used to.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radi faciat caput suum cum nouacula.	Then instruct him to scrape his head with a razor.
Deinde fac eum sedere inter manus tuas quadratum, ita quod iam posuit manus suas super pectus suum.	Then make him sit between your hands in the shape of a square so that he has already placed his hands on his chest.
Deinde pone radicem palmae tuae super radicem nasi sui inter oculos suos.	Then place the root of your palm over the root of his nose between his eyes.
Vbicumque ergo peruenerit digitus tuus medius, signa locum illum cum incausto.	Wherever your middle finger reaches, mark that place with the cautery.
Deinde igni Cauterium Oliuare: cuius haec est forma.	Then fire the olive oil cautery, which is of this form.
Deinde pone ipsum super locum signatum cum incausto, descensione, qua constringatur manus tua paulatim, et tu reuolues ipsum.	Then place it over the marked spot with the cautery, pressing down in a manner that your hand becomes constricted gradually, and you roll it around.
Deinde leua manum tuam uelociter, et aspicias locum.	Then remove your hand quickly, and look at the spot.
Quod si uides iam detegi ex osse quantitatem capitis alkiel, aut quantitatem zeuherbi, tunc eleua manum tuam.	If you see that an amount of bone the size of a chickpea or the size of a stinging nettle has already been burnt away, then lift your hand up.
Et si non, itera manum tuam ferro ipso, aut cum alio ab ipso si infrigidatur: donec uideantur ossa, quae dixi tibi.	If not, repeat with your hand using the same iron, or another one if this one has cooled down: until you see the bones I mentioned to you.
Deinde sume aliquid ex sale, et solue illud in aqua, et imbibe in ipso cotum, et pone super locum: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Then take some salt, dissolve it in water, soak the dressing in it, and place it on the wound: leave it for three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, et dimitte illum super locum, donec destruatur eschara ignis.	Then place the soaked dressing on butter, and leave it on until the fire-wound scab is destroyed.
Deinde cura illud cum unguento tetrapharmacon, usquequo sanetur.	Then treat it with the four-herb ointment until it is healed.
Iam dixerunt, quod quanto uulnus plus remanet apertum, emittit pus: quare est melius et magis iuuatiuum.	They already said that the more a wound remains open, the more it discharges pus: which is better and more beneficial.
Et dixerunt quidam eorum, ut cauterizetur cutis usque ad os: et teneatur Cauterium, donec aduratur quiddam spissitudinis ossis.	And some of them said to cauterise the skin down to the bone: and hold the cautery there until something thick from the bone burns.
Deinde radatur post illud quod adustum est ex osse, deinde curetur.	Then scrape after what has been burnt of the bone, then treat it.
Et dicunt alii, quod oportet ut cum cauterio perueniatur ad ultimum, donec imprimat in os impressionem for tem, ita quod cadat os, quod fit sicut forma kirate: aut instrumentum quod mulieres ponunt infuso alphabeti parui: et extimant, quod exspirantur ex hoc loco uapores capitis, et dimittatur uulnus apertum tempore longo.	And others say that one must reach with the cautery to the end, until it leaves an impression on the bone like a seal stamp: or a tool that women use for putting small letters; and they believe that vapours of the head will escape from this place, and the wound should be left open for long time.
Deinde curetur, donec consolidetur.	Then treat it until it becomes solid.
Mihi autem non uidentur hae duae species Cauterii omnino nisi in quibusdam hominibus secundum uiam timoris.	But to me, these two types of cauterisation seem suitable only for some people with a tendency towards fear.
Et dimittere ipsum, apud me est melius cum salute ipsius.	And letting it be, in my view, is better for their health.
Debilitatur enim caput ex solutione continuitatis ipsius naturalis: sicut testificati sumus in reliquis membris: et praecipue quando caput infirmi debile est natura: et species quidem Cauterii prima est magis salua et melior apud me, et ea utor: operare ergo cum ea in salute.	For the head becomes weak due to the dissolution of its inherent continuity; as we have witnessed in other body parts; especially when by nature an ill person's head is frail; and I find the first type of cauterization safer and better, so I use it; therefore work with it for healing.
¶ De modo cauterizandi capitis in dolore totius capitis.	On the method of cauterizing the head in cases of total headache.
Caput III.	Head: Three.
Quando in toto Capite accidit dolor chronicus: et prolongatur illud in infirmo, et utitur hyeris, et cochiis, et caputpurgiis, et oleis, et empleumatis.	When a prolonged chronic pain occurs all over the head; and it is treated with herbs, leeches, clysters, oils, and embrocations.
Et praecipue si iam cauterizatum est cauterio uno, quod narrauimus, et non confert ei aliquid ex illis: tunc considera.	And especially if it has already been cauterized once with the type we described and none of those treatments help; then consider this.
Nam si caput infirmi est fortis creationis natura, et non est debile, et inuenit frigus uehemens: tunc cauteriza cum cauterio alio sub illo parum.	For if the patient's head is of a strong build by nature and not weak, but feels excessive cold; then cauterize it with another type of cautery underneath to a lesser degree.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio, do nec pertranseat cutis, et discooperiatur ex osse quantitas, quam narrauimus.	Then cauterize it over the entire horn of its head with a cautery that does not penetrate through the skin and reveals an amount of bone as we described.
Et cauteriza ipsum cauterio uno in occipitio capitis sui, in loco qui nominatur uas: et est locus in quo ponitur uentosa: et eleua matum tuam in hoc, et non discooperias os.	And cauterize it with one type on the occipital bone of its head, in a place called vas, which is where the windpipe is located; and raise your hand here, and do not reveal the bone.
Infirmus enim inuenit propter illud dolorem uehementem, et diuersum a dolore reliquorum cauteriorum capitis omnium.	For the patient feels a severe pain from it, different from the pains of all other types of cauterization of the head.
Et ego dicam hoc Cauterium in loco suo: et oportet quod sit cauterium, quo cauterizantur cornua capitis, et occiput eius subtilius cauterio, quo cauterizatur medium capitis.	And I will call this the Cautery of its Place; and it should be a cautery that is finer than the one used to cauterize the horns of the head and its occipital bone when cauterizing its centre.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in hemicrania, tam cum medicina adustiua, quam cum ferro.	On the method of cauterization for hemicrania, both with burning medicine and with an iron.
Caput IIII.	Chapter Four.
Quando accidit in parte capitis dolor et soda, aut extenditur dolor usque ad oculum, et euacuatur cum medicinis mundificantibus caput, et administratur reliqua curatio, quam dixi in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert illud totum: tunc cauterizatio in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterizatio cum medicina acuta comburente: aut cum ferro.	When there is pain and swelling on the head, or when the pain extends to the eye, and it is evacuated with cleansing medicines for the head, and the rest of the treatment that I mentioned in the sections on diseases does not help completely; then cauterization of this condition should be done in two ways: either by cauterization with burning medicine, or with an iron.
Cauterium autem cum medicina acuta comburente, est, ut accipias dentem unum allii, et excortices ipsum, et abscindas extremitates eius ex duobus lateribus.	Cauterization with burning medicine is done by taking one alum, scraping it and cutting off its ends on both sides.
Deinde scinde locum doloris in tempore cum phlebotomo lato, donec fiat in eo locus sub cute, in quo dens capitur.	Then cut the painful spot at an opportune time with a broad lancet until there is made in it beneath the skin a place into which the tooth can be fitted.
Intromitte ergo eum in ipso sub cute, donec occultetur: deinde stringe super ipsum cum puluillo constrictione decenti, et dimitte ipsum quantitate quindecim horarum deinde solue eum, et extrahe allium, et dimitteuulnus duobus diebus, aut tribus: postea pone super ipsum cotum submersum in butyro, donec locus efficiat pus: deinde cura ipsum cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	Insert it into the skin so that it is hidden; then bind over it with a compress of suitable tightness and leave it for fifteen hours; then release it, take out the tooth, and allow the wound to rest two or three days. Afterwards, apply to it, an ointment soaked in butter until the spot forms pus; afterwards treat it with ointment until it is healed.
Et si uis fac illud cum quibusdam medicinis comburentibus, quas ego scripsi in tractatu duodecimo, de Medieinis adurentibus.	And if you wish to do it with some burning medicines that I have written about in the twelfth treatise on caustic medicines.
Cauterizatio uero eius cum ferro, est secundum hunc modum.	Cauterization with an iron is done in this way.
Igni Cauterium, cuius forma haec est.	With the cautery fire whose form is thus:
Et nominatur Clauilis: quoniam forma capitis eius est sicut forma claui, in quo est quiddam curuitatis, et in medio eius est quaedam eminentia parua.	The clavicle is so named because the shape of its head is like that of a nail, which has a certain curvature, and in its middle there is a small eminence.
Deinde pone ipsum super locum, et retine manum tuam: et tu reuolue ferrum paulatim cum uelocitate: et sit quantitas quae aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, sicut medietas eius.	Then place it on the site and hold your hand; you roll the blade gradually with speed, and let the amount that is cauterized by its thickness be like half of (the skin).
Et eleua manum tuam, ut non aduratur arteria, quae est inferius, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	Raise your hand so that the artery below is not cauterized, for a bleeding will occur.
Deinde imbibe cotum in aqua salis, et pone super locum, et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus: deinde pone cotum cum butyro: postea cura cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	Then soak a compress in salt water and place it on the site for three days; then apply a compress with butter; afterward treat it with an ointment until it is healed.
Et si uis, cauteriza hanc hemicraniam cum extremitate cultellari secunda Cauterii.	And if you wish, cauterize this temple with the second knife-like extremity of the Cauterium.
Et caue ab incisione arteriae in hac hemicrania, non antiqua proprie.	And beware of cutting an artery in this temple, not one that is old.
¶ De modo cauteriezandi in hemicrania antiqua.	On the method of cauterizing an old temple.
Caput V.	Chapter 5.
Quando curas hemicraniam, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione praecedente, et quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio: et uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei quod diximus ex cauterio primo cum medicina, aut cum cauterio cum igne, tunc oportet ut ignias Cauterium cultellare, donec albificetur postquam signas super locum doloris cum linea, cuius longitudo sit medietas digiti, aut quasi illud: et depone manum tuam uice una, et stringe eam donec incidas arteriam, et peruenias usque ad os.	When treating a temple with what we have said from the previous treatment and what we mentioned in the divisions of illnesses, and the treatment does not work; and you see that it is insufficient for the illness what we previously stated about cauterizing with medicine or cauterization by fire, then it is necessary to use the knife-like Cauterium until it whitens after you mark on the site of pain a line whose length is half a finger, or something like that; and remove your hand once, and press it until you cut the artery and reach the bone.
Verumtamen necesse est tibi, ut caueas a continuatione mandibulae, quae mouetur apud masticationem, ne aduratur latus, aut neruus qui mouet ipsam, unde accidat spasmus.	However, you must be careful to avoid the continuation of the jawbone, which moves during chewing, lest the side or the nerve that moves it be burned, causing a spasm.
Et esto super custotiam, et cautelam de fluxu sanguinis arteriae, quae abscisa est.	And remain above the cost, and take care of the arterial blood flow, which has been cut off.
In abscisione enim eius est timor, et praecipue ei qui ignorat illud quod facit, et non est studiosus, nec expertus: et dimittit operationem cum eo in primis.	Indeed, its cutting off is feared, and especially by him who does not know what he is doing and is neither studious nor experienced; and he abandons the operation with him first.
Et ego ueniam cum rememoratione regiminis fluxus sanguinis accidentis ex arteria secundum modum suum, et in loco suo huius libri.	And I will come with the recollection of the treatment for accidental arterial blood flow according to its manner and in this book's place.
Quod si uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei hoc Cauterium, et uides corpus infirmi tolerans cauterium in medio capitis, sicut narrauimus, cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	If you see from the illness that it is not sufficient for him with this cautery, and you see the patient's body tolerate the cautery in the middle of the head, as we described, treat the wound until it is healed.
Et si uis, administra Cauterium, quod diximus in capitulo extractionis arteriae cum Cauterio habente duos cultellos.	And if you wish, administer the cautery that we said in the chapter on extracting an artery with a cautery having two knives.
Est enim cauterizatio melior hac et magis conferens.	This cautery is better and more effective.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Aurium.	On the method of cauterizing for ear pain.
Caput VI.	Chapter 6.
Quando accidit in Aure dolor a frigore, et curatur cum solutiuis, et reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione, et non remouetur dolor, tunc igni Cauterium: et est illud quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma est haec.	When pain occurs in the ear due to cold and is treated with solutions and other treatments we mentioned before, but the pain does not go away, then cautery by fire; this is called a puncture whose form is as follows...
Deinde puncta cum eo post eius ignitionem in circumitu auris totius, sicut reuoluitur: aut in circumitu utriusque, si simul dolor est in utrisque.	Then puncture with it all around the ear as it revolves; or all around each one if pain is present in both simultaneously.
Et elonga te cum Cauterio a radice auris parumper, postquam signaueris loca cum encaustro: et sit cauterii quantitas decem punctorum in omni aure, et quasi illa.	And extend yourself with the cautery from the root of the ear for a short while, after you have marked the places with the encaustrum; and let the amount of cauterization be ten points in every ear, and so on.
Deinde cura loca, donec sanentur.	Then care for the places until they heal.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tortura.	The way of cauterization in Torture.
Caput VII.	Chapter 7.
Tortura quae curatur cum cauterizatione, non est nisi ex speciebus, quae accidunt ex phlegmate, secundum quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum.	The torture which is cured by means of cautery is only of that kind which happens through the phlegm, as we have said in the divisions of diseases.
Et deuita cauterizationem speciei, quae accidit ex exiccatione, et spasmo nerui.	And turn aside the cautery from that kind which happens through drying out and a nerve spasm.
Quando curas hanc speciem torturae cum hyeris, et caputpurgiis, et gargarismis, et non confert curatio tua, tunc oportet ut cauterizes infirmum tribus Cauteriis: uno apud radicem auris, et secundo parum inferius a timpore suo, et tertio apud coniunctionem duorum labiorum.	When you treat this kind of torture with ipecacuanha, emetics, and gargles but your treatment does not work then it is necessary that you cauterize the sick person three times; once at the root of the ear, and a second time just below the tympanum, and thirdly where the two lips meet.
Et pone Cauterium tuum ex contrario partis infirmae.	And place your cautery on the opposite side of the sick part.
Quoniam mollificatio non accidit, nisi in parte quae apparet sana.	Because softening does not occur unless it happens on that part which appears to be healthy.
Et forma cauterizationis est, ut cauterizes ipsum Cauterio in directo extremitatis auris superioris sub cornu capitis parum: et alio in timpore: cuius longitudo sit secundum longitudinem pollicis.	And the form of the cautery is such that you cauterize with a cautery the upper end of the ear under the horn of the head slightly, and another on the tympanum; whose length should be according to the length of the thumb.
Et depone manum tuam cum cauterio, donec comburatur quantitas medietatis spissitudinis cutis.	And leave your hand with the cautery until half of its thickness has been burnt.
Et haec est forma Cauterii, et est species ex cultellari, cuius forma praemissa est: uerumtamen non est subtilior ea parum, sicut uides: et oportet ut sit cultellus in eo superfluae grossitudinis parum.	This is the form of a cautery, and it is made from a lancet with the aforementioned shape; however, it should not be too delicate, as you can see, and there must be a little superfluous thickness to the blade.
Deinde cura loca, cum eo quod praecessit: donec sanetur.	Then treat the wound as described previously until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Apoplexia antiqua.	The method of cauterising an old stroke.
Caput VIII.	Chapter 8.
QUando antiquatur Apoplexia, et curas eam cum eo quod diximus, et non confert medicatio tua, et infirmus non habet febrem, tunc cauteriza eum quatuor cauteriis super omne cornu capitis sui, et cauterio in medio capitis, sicut diximus, et cauterio in occipitio capitis, secundum quod praecessit: et modus cauterii sit secundum quod praecessit.	When an old stroke is treated and you have taken care of it as described but your treatment does not work, and the patient has no fever, then cauterise them with four cauteries on each corner of their head, one in the middle of the head, and another at the back of the head, as explained previously; apply cautery according to the method outlined above.
Etiam cauterizatur cum Cauterio super os stomachi: et est magis ultimum.	The stomach bone is also treated with cautery, which is generally the final step in treatment.
Deinde curetur, cum eo quod praecessit.	Afterwards it should be treated as previously described.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Obliuione.	The method of cauterising amnesia.
Caput IX.	Chapter 9.
Oportet ut in potu dentur in primis infirmo hyerae magnae, et pillulae mundificantes cerebrum.	The patient must first be given fresh drinks and pills to cleanse the brain.
Deinde rade caput infirmi totum, et pone super occipitium eius emplastrum de synapi descriptum in tractatu emplastrorum: et pone ipsum aliquotiens.	Next, shave the patient's head completely and apply to their occipital bone a plaster of mustard seed as described in the section on plasters; repeat this several times.
Ipsum namque est modus Cauterii: et fac illud secundum ordinem eundem, quem dixi illic.	This is the method of cautery; apply it as previously described with the same order.
Si ergo sanatur per illud, bonum est.	If they heal through this method, then that is good.
Si non: tunc fac ei cauteria tria in posteriori parte capitis sui, quae sint descendentia a superiori parte capitis usque ad inferiorem partem oculi: et pone inter omne cauterium grossitudinem digiti.	If not, then make three cauterizations on the back of their head, which are descending from the top of the head down to the bottom part of the eye; and leave a finger's width between each cautery.
Deinde cura Cauterium, cum eo quod praecessit.	Then treat the cauterization, along with what has preceded it.
Si autem uis additionem, et infirmus est tolerans illud: tunc fac ei Cauterium in medio.	If however you wish to add more and the patient is able to tolerate it: then make a cauterization on the middle of the area.
Quod si uis additionem: tunc cauteriza ipsum super duo cornua.	If you wish to add more, then cauterize it above two corners.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: sitque Cauterium oliuare secundum formam, quae praemissa est.	Then treat it until it is healed; let the cauterization be anointed with oil according to the form which has been described before.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Paralisi, et mollificatione.	A paragraph on the method of cauterization for paralysis and softening.
Caput X.	Chapter 10.
Oportet ut procedas in mundificatione capitis cum hyeeris, et cum eo quod diximus.	It is necessary that you proceed with the cleansing of the head with hyssop, and with what we have said.
Deinde rade caput infirmi: postea cauteriza ipsum cauterio in medio capitis, et cauterio super omne cornu capitis, et cauterio super posterius ipsius, et tribus super spondiles colli.	Then shave the patient's head; afterwards cauterize it with a cautery on the middle of their head, and a cautery above each corner of their head, and a cautery behind them, and three over the vertebrae of their neck.
Si autem indiges in aegritudine mollificatione corporis pluribus illis, et infirmus est tolerans, et aegritudo est fortis: tunc cauteriza ipsum quatuor cauteriis super spondiles dorsi, et ultima cum cauterio, donec comburatur ex cute plurimum eius, et eleua manum tuam.	If however you need to soften the patient's body with more cauteries, and they are able to tolerate it, and their illness is severe: then cauterize them with four cauteries over the vertebrae of their back, and the last one with a cautery until most of its surface blisters out of their skin, and lift your hand upwards.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: et sic cauterium Oliuare.	Then treat it until it is healed; anoint the cauterization with oil thusly.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Epilepsia.	The method of cauterization for epilepsy.
Caput XI.	Chapter 11.
Non Cauterizatur epilepticus, nisi ille cuius epilepsia est ex phlegmate.	An epileptic is not cauterized unless their epilepsy is caused by phlegm.
Oportet ergo ut mundifices cerebrum eius in primis cum hyeris, et cum reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione: quando infirmus est magnus, aut est tolerans in accaeptione medicinarum.	Therefore, it is necessary that you first clean their brain with hyoscyamus, and with the rest of the treatment we described in the division: when the patient is strong or tolerant to accepting medicines.
Si autem est puer, qui non tolerat medicinas, tunc administratur gargarisma, et masticationes mundificantes cerebrum, ante illud diebus multis cum bonificatione ciborum.	But if it is a child who does not tolerate medicines, then give them mouthwashes and chewing cleansers for the brain, before that on many days with good food.
Deinde rade caput eius, postea cauteriza ipsum Cauterio uno in medio capitis, secundum quod praecessit in modo: et cauterio alio in occipitio eius, et super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio.	Then shave his head, then cauterize it with one cautery in the middle of the head, as preceded in the method: and another on his occipital bone, and over every horn of his head.
Quod si infirmus fuerit fortis, et fuerit tolerans, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauteriis, quae dixi in habente paralisim, et mollificationem corporis super spondiles colli, et spondiles dorsi: et sit Cauterium oliuare secundum modum qui praecessit.	If the patient is strong and tolerant, then cauterize them with the cauteries that I mentioned for one having paralysis, and a softening of the body over the cervical vertebrae and dorsal vertebrae: and let the cautery be olive oil according to the method which preceded.
Si autem infirmus est puer, tunc pone cauterium subtile, secundum hunc modum.	But if the patient is a child, then place a fine cautery, according to this method.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Melancholia.	The method of cauterization for melancholia.
Caput XII.	Chapter 12.
Quando caussa melancholiae sunt humiditates corruptae, et phlegma grossum, tunc cauteriza ipsum Cauteriis, quae diximus in habente paralisim.	When the cause of melancholia is corrupted moistures, and thick phlegm, then cauterize them with the cauteries that we mentioned for one having paralysis.
Et si caussa melancholiae est superfluitas decliuis ad melancholiam, et est corpus infirmi humectum, tunc da ei in potu quod mundificet cerebrum eius, secundum quod praecessit in diuisione: deinde rade caput infirmi, et fac postea tortellam decenter factam ex lino, sicut circulum.	And if the cause of melancholia is an excess of black bile towards melancholia, and the patient's body is moist, then give them to drink what cleanses their brain, as preceded in the division: then shave the patient's head, and afterwards make a decently made linen cap like a circle.
Deinde pone ipsam in medio capitis: et infirmus sedens quadratus teneatur ab omni parte.	Then place it on the middle of the head: and let the patient sit square and be held from every part.
Deinde praesenta linimentum.	Then present the ointment.
Et est dignius ex butyro ouium antiquo.	And it is more worthy from old egg butter.
Et calefac ipsum super ignem calefactione temperata mensura, quam toleret digitus, quando intromittitur in ipsum.	And warm it over the fire with tempered heat to the extent that a finger could bear when inserted into it.
Deinde euacua ipsum in medio capitis eius in circulo, et dimitte ipsum donec infrigidetur.	Then evacuate it onto the middle of their head in a circle, and leave it until it cools down.
Fac illud infirmo omni hebdomada semel, cum reliquo regimine eius bono, donec sanetur.	Do this for the patient once every week with the rest of their good regimen until they are healed.
Aut si uis, cauteriza ipsum faciendo puncta parua plurimum eius, praeter quod teneas manum cum cauterio: imo sit odorando.	Or if you wish, cauterise it by making many small holes in it, except for what you hold with your hand holding the cauterising iron: and let [the patient] be fasting.
Haec enim species cauterii humectat cerebrum cum qualitate.	For this type of cautery moistens the brain with its quality.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, aut adipe gallinae.	Then place over it a poultice soaked in butter, or chicken fat.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aqua descendente ad oculum.	A way of cauterising that descends to the eye in water.
Caput XIII.	Chapter 13.
Quando declaratur tibi principium aquae in oculo per signa, quae dixi in diuisione, tunc incipe et pota infirmum, cum eo quod mundificet caput eius.	When you ascertain that water is coming from the eye through the signs I mentioned above, then begin and make the patient drink with something that will clean their head.
Et custodi ipsum ab omnibus humiditatibus, et fac eum sedere in balneo, in ieiunio diebus aliquot.	And protect them from all moisture, and make them sit in the bath, fasting for a few days.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radat caput suum, et cauteriza ipsum in medio capitis sui.	Then instruct them to shave their head, and cauterise it on the middle of their head.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super duo timpora duobus cauteriis, si est incaeptio descensus aquae in duobus oculis simul: aut ex latere uno, si est incaeptio aquae in oculo uno: et abscinde cum cauterio omnes uenas et arterias quae sunt sub cute: et sint cauteria in ea longa in latitudine timporum: et caue a fluxu sanguinis.	Then cauterize it over the two temples with two cauteries if there is an onset of watery discharge from both eyes simultaneously, or from one side if there is watery discharge from one eye; and cut through all veins and arteries that are under the skin with the cautery; and let the cauteries be as long as the width of the temples: and beware of a flow of blood.
Quod si uides aliquid ex eo, tunc abscinde eum statim cum quacumque medicina est possibile: et ego ueniam cum sapientia, quae est in extractione arteriarum, et abscisione earum, et cautela a fluxu sanguinis.	If you see anything coming out of it, then cut it off immediately with whatever medicine is possible; and I will come with wisdom regarding the extraction and cutting of arteries, and caution against a flow of blood.
Et quandoque cauterizatur in ceruice, sub duobus ossibus, duobus cauteriis ultime productis.	And sometimes it is cauterized on the neck, under two bones, with two extremely hot cauteries.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lachrymis antiquis.	The method of cauterizing for excessive weeping.
Caput XIIII.	Chapter 14.
Quando lachrymae oculorum sunt antiquae, assiduae: et sunt super uenas, et arterias quae sunt in manifesto capitis exterius, uerificatur quod illud est ex superfluitatibus frigidis, phlegmaticis: tunc cauteriza cauterio eodem quod narraui in incaeptione aquae descendentis, cauterio in medio capitis, et duobus cauteriis super duo timpora, et duobus cauteriis in ceruice sub duobus ossibus.	When the tears of the eyes are old and persistent, and they appear over veins and arteries that are visible on the exterior of the head, it is confirmed that this is due to an excess of cold and phlegmatic humours; then cauterize with a single cautery as I have described for the onset of watery discharge, with one cautery in the middle of the head, two cauteries over the temples, and two cauteries on the neck under two bones.
Et si indiges additione, tunc cauteriza ipsum in omni latere caute oculi, super extremitatem supercilii cum cauterio paruo.	And if you require additional treatment, then cauterize it on every side of the eye with caution, at the end of the eyebrow with a small cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in foetore Nasi.	The method of cauterizing for nasal odour.
Caput XV.	Chapter 15.
Quando tu medicaris illud, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert medicatio: tunc propera, et da in potu infirmocochias tribus noctibus: deinde rade caput eius, et cauteriza ipsum cauterio medio, cum cauterio oliuari.	When you treat it with what we have described for the division of treatments, and treatment is not forthcoming; then proceed swiftly, and give him a decoction made from crushed garlic in broth three times at night: thereafter shave his head, and cauterize it with a medium-sized searing iron heated with oil.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio clauili duobus cauteriis, super duo supercilia sub capillis parum.	Then cauterize it with two clavicle-shaped cauteries, above the eyebrows slightly beneath the hairline.
Et custodite ab arteria, ne incidas eam.	And guard against the artery, lest you cut it.
Et haec est forma cauterii Clauilis.	And this is the shape of the clavicle cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in mollificatione Palpebrae.	On the method of cauterizing a softened eyelid.
Caput XVI.	Chapter 16.
Quando mollificatur Palpebra oculi ab aegritudine, aut humiditate: tunc cauteriza Palpebram cauterio uno, cum hoc cauterio lunari.	When the eyelid of an eye softens due to disease or moisture, then you should cauterize the softened part with one cautery, using this lunar cautery.
Et si uis, cauteriza ipsum supra duo supercilia parum duobus cauteriis in omni parte: et elongentur a duobus timporibus: et sit longitudo omnis cauterii, secundum longitudines supercilii: et non ultimes manum tuam cum cauterio, imo secundum quantitatem quod aduritur tertia palpebrae.	And if you wish, cauterize it above the eyebrows slightly with two cauteries on each side; let them extend beyond the temples by a little bit and make every cautery of the same length as the eyelid; do not remove your hand holding the cautery until one-third of the eyelid has been burned.
Et haec est forma cauterii secundum hunc modum cauterii lunaris.	And this is the shape of the cautery for this lunar method of cauterization.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Palpebram cum pili inuersantur pungentes oculum.	On the method of cauterizing an eyelid with reversed eyelashes that irritate the eye.
Caput XVII.	Chapter 17.
Cauterium in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum igne: aut cauterium cum medicina comburente.	The cautery in this case is of two kinds; either a fire-cautery or a caustic-medicine cautery.
In cauterio autem cum igne, praecipe infirmo ante illud, ut dimittat pilos suos, si est ex illis qui mundant eos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	For the fire-cautery, instruct the patient beforehand to remove his hair if he is one of those who cleanses himself by shaving until it grows out and becomes even in length.
Si autem pungunt eum apud ortum suum: tunc constringe oculos eius cum uitta, ut non moueantur, donec nascantur.	If, however, they irritate him at the root, then bind his eyes with a cloth so that they do not move until new eyelashes grow in their place.
Cum ergo nascuntur et aequantur, tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo: deinde signa super Palpebram oculorum eius cum encaustro, signo quod sit secundum figuram folii myrti: et sit principium signi prope pilos.	When they are born and equalized, then place the patient's head in your lap; next, mark above the eyelids of his eyes with cautery, a mark that is shaped like a myrtle leaf; and let the beginning of the mark be near the eyelashes.
Deinde pone cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum.	Then place over the eye a poultice soaked in egg white; or use a mucilage of psyllium.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	Then apply fire with the following instrument.
Deinde cauteriza super figuram, quam signasti paulatim in uicibus multis, donec comburatur superficies cutis, quae est sicut figura folii myrti, totam apparentem proprie.	Then cauterize gradually over the shape you marked with many touches of the iron, until the skin surface which appears just like a myrtle leaf is completely burned away.
Et signum sanitatis operis tui est: ut si uideas Palpebram oculi iam contrahi, et pilos eleuari apud puncturam oculi.	And you will know your work is healthy when you see the eyelid of the eye already contracting, and the eyelashes rising at the wound of the eye.
Eleua ergo manum tuam tunc: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Therefore lift your hand then; and let him go after three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur eschara.	Then place over the patient a poultice with butter until the scar is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then treat him with an ointment until he is healed.
Quod si redeat aliquod ex pilis post horam, et mollificetur palpebra: tunc itera Cauterium super illum locum, sicut fecisti in primis.	If any of the eyelashes grow back after this time and the eyelid becomes soft again; then repeat the cautery on that spot as you did at first.
Si autem pili sunt in inferiori: tunc cauteriza ipsam, donec eleuetur ad locum suum naturalem: et aequetur ut non pungant pili oculum.	However if the eyelashes are on the lower lid; then cauterize it until it is lifted to its normal place and equalized so that the lashes do not poke the eye.
¶ De modo cauterizandi cum medicina comburente in eodem casu.	On the way of cauterizing with caustic medicine in this case:
Caput XVIII.	Chapter 18.
Est ut praecipias infirmo, ut dimittat pilos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	Advise the patient to leave the hairs [after an operation], until they grow back and become even.
Fac ex charta de panno formam folii myrti.	Make a piece of cloth in the shape of a myrtle leaf.
Deinde accipe ex sapone cognito, et ex calce non imbibita ex unoquoque pondus uncia I aut quasi illud: deinde tere ea simul contritione bona, et fac illud cum festinatione, ut non infrigidetur.	Take an ounce of known soap and the same amount of un-soaked lime; then grind them together well, and do this quickly so that it doesn't get cold.
Deinde ex pande ex eo super chartam quam fecisti sicut formam folii myrti, et pone ipsum super palpebram oculi unius, aut duorum.	Then spread some of it on the piece of paper you made in the shape of a myrtle leaf, and place it over one or both eyelids.
Et pone sub oculo cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: et caput infirmi sit in sinu tuo.	Place a soaked poultice, dipped in egg white, under the eye; and let the patient's head rest on your lap.
Et pone digitum tuum indicem super medicinam, et preme ipsum parumper.	Put your index finger on the medicine and press it gently.
Et tu moueas ipsum quotiens sentit infirmus mordicationem medicinae: quoniam inuenit eius mordicatio sicut ignis.	And move your finger whenever the patient feels a stinging sensation from the medicine; for its sting is like fire.
Dum ergo perseuerat hoc quod ipse inuenit mordicatio, tunc dimitte medicinam, et moue ipsam cum digito tuo.	While you persist with this which the patient finds stinging, then stop applying the medicine and move it away with your finger.
Cum ergo quiescit mordicatio, tunc remoue medicinam, et ablue oculum cum aqua.	When the stinging sensation subsides, then remove the medicine and wash the eye with water.
Et considera tunc, si uides palpebram eleuari, sicut eleuatur apud contractionem cum igne, aut cum incisione, est bene: et si non, tunc itera super ipsam ex medicina super locum, in quo non imprimit medicina, et non denigrat, donec aequetur operatio tua, et contrahatur oculus.	Then observe if you see the eyelid swelling like it does when exposed to fire or cut; and if not, then repeat on it some medicine in an area where the medicine hasn't yet been applied and isn't discoloured, until your procedure is even and the eye contracts.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur cutis adustionis.	Then place on it a poultice with butter until the burnt skin is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento diaphinicon, aut alio, donec sanetur.	Treat it then with diaphanicon ointment, or another, until it is healed.
Et necesse est tibi apud operationem, ut custodias ultima custodia, ne in oculum cadat aliquid ex medicina.	And during the procedure, you must take care to protect the patient's last barrier [i.e., eye], lest any of the medicine falls into it.
Quod si mollificatur palpebra post dies, et pugnat ex capillis aliquid in oculo, tunc itera medicinam super illum locum, qui mollificatur ex palpebra proprie, sicut fecisti in primis.	If the eyelid softens after a few days and something irritates the eye from the eyelashes, then repeat the medicine on that place which is softened by its own eyelid, as you did initially.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Treat it until it is healed.
Et haec est forma folii myrti.	And this is the shape of a myrtle leaf.
Et scias, quod oculi hominum diuersificantur in magnitudine, et paruitate.	And you should be aware that human eyes vary in size and smallness.
Ergo secundum illud sit consideratio tua: et non occultatur uia rectitudinis illi, cui est studium de hac arte.	Therefore, according to that, let your consideration be thus: the path of righteousness is not hidden from him who has a zeal for this art.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Fistula lachrymali.	On the method of cauterizing a tear duct fistula.
Caput XIX.	Chapter 19.
Quando curas Fistulam, cum eo quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc, oportet ut cauterizes ipsam secundum hunc modum.	When you treat a tear duct fistula with what we said in the divisions of ailments, and your treatment does not bear fruit, then it is necessary that you cauterize it according to this method.
Praecipe infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo, et teneat caput eius minister inter manus suas taliter, ut non moueatur, neque agitetur cum capite suo.	Instruct the patient to place their head in your lap and have an assistant hold their head between their hands so that it cannot move or be shaken.
Deinde pone Cotum infusum in albugine oui, aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum eius: deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	Next, place a sponge soaked in alum, or in psyllium mucilage on their eye; then take up the cautery with this shape.
Sit concauum, sicut forma cannae pennae uulturis ab extremitate una, cum qua fit Cauterium: et si uis sit penetrans usque ad extremitatem aliam, et si uis sit sursum sic tenta.	It should be hollow like the shape of an eagle-feather quill at one end, with which the cautery is done; and if you want it to penetrate all the way through to the other end, or upwards, then temper it thus.
Verumtamen hoc concauum est melius ad opus tuum.	Indeed this bowl is better for your purpose.
Deinde exprime fistulam, si est aperta, et extrahe ex ea saniem, et exicca ipsam: et si non est aperta, tunc aperi eam, et extrahe pus eius.	Next squeeze the abscess, if it is open, and extract its foul matter, then dry it out; but if it isn't open, then you must open it, and extract its puss.
Deinde pone tunc super eam Cauterium, quod fit ignitum ualde.	Then place over it the hot cautery iron.
Et tene cum eo manum tuam parumper apud Cauterium ab oculo, ad partem nasi, ut non erret manus tua, aut inquietetur infirmus: et ponas Cauterium in adipe oculi, et corrumpas ipsum.	And hold your hand for a moment over the cautery iron from beyond the eye, towards the nose, so that you don't miss with your hand nor disturb the patient; then place the hot iron on the eye's fat and destroy it.
Si ergo peruenis in principio Cauterii tui usque ad os, erit bene.	If therefore you make an incision with your cautery iron right down to the bone then all will be well.
Et si non: tunc itera Cauterium semel, aut bis, si indiges illo: et dimitte illud tribus diebus.	And if not then repeat the cautery once or twice as you need; and remove the iron after three days.
Deinde pone Cotum cum butyro, et cura ipsum cum unguento exiccatiuo, donec sanetur.	Then place on it a poultice with butter and care for it with drying ointment until it is healed.
Quod si praeterierint ei quadraginta dies, et non sanatur: tunc pone super ipsum medicinam acutam corrosiuam, donec detegatur os: et rade ipsum secundum quod uenit in capitulo suo.	But if after forty days it is not healed then place on it a sharp corrosive medicine until the bone shows; and shave it according to what came before in this chapter.
Et est modus alius Cauterii fistulae, quem quidam primi dixerunt.	And there is another method of cautery for abscesses which certain ancients have described.
Intende ad locum fistulae, et finde ipsum: deinde pone in ipsam fissuram camahan subtile, id est, Cannulam subtilem, cuius forma haec est.	Note the position of the abscess and find it; then place into its crack a thin rod, that is, a fine cannula, whose form is thus: [shape follows].
Et funde in ipsum quantitatem drachmae ex plumbo liquefacto, et tene manum tuam cum Canna retentione bona, et non moueatur infirmus omnino, ut non currat, uel perueniat plumbum liquefactum ad oculum eius.	And pour into it a drachma-sized quantity of molten lead; and hold your hand with the cannula securely, so that the patient doesn't move at all, lest the melted lead run or reach his eye.
Et oportet ut ponas super oculum infirmi cotum infusum in albumine oui, aut in aqua.	You should place a poultice infused in egg white over the patient's eye, or in water.
Plumbum enim comburit locum fistulae, et sanat ipsam sanatione mirabili.	For lead burns the area of the fistula, and heals it with a wondrous cure.
Quod si sanatur fistula, cum eo quod diximus ex Cauterio, et curatione, est bonum.	If the fistula is healed with what we have said about cauterization and treatment, it is good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est administrare foramen nasi, et reducere fistulam ad cursum nasi, secundum quod ueniet in loco suo sibi proprio.	And if not, it is necessary to administer a nasal passage, and redirect the fistula towards the path of the nose, according to what will come to its proper place.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fissuris Labiorum.	On the method of cauterizing fissures on the lips.
Caput XX.	Chapter 20.
Multotiens accidunt in Labio fissurae, quae nominantur Pili, et praecipue in labiis puerorum.	Fissures often occur on the lips, which are called cracks, especially on the lips of children.
Cum ergo tu curas has fissuras, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio, tunc igni cauterium paruum cultellare, secundum hanc formam.	When you treat these fissures as we have said in the section on illnesses, and it does not provide a cure, then apply a small cautery knife with fire, according to this form.
Et sit concauitas eius secundum subtilitatem cultelli.	And let it be hollowed out like the sharpness of the knife.
Deinde pone ipsum ignitum festinanter in ipsis fissuris, donec perueniat cauterium ad profundum fissurarum.	Then place this ignited [knife] swiftly into the very fissures until you reach the depth of the cracks with the cautery.
Deinde cura ipsum cum caeroto, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with a caustic [ointment], until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fistula Oris.	On the method of cauterizing an oral fistula.
Caput XXI.	Chapter 21.
Quando accidit apostema in radice gingiuae, aut in palato, aut in radicibus dentium: deinde facit pus, et rumpitur: postea antiquatur, et currit pus, et fit fistula: deinde curas ipsam, et non confert in ea curatio, tunc oportet ut ignias cauterium secundum quantitatem, quod capiat in fistula.	When an abscess occurs at the root of the gums or on the palate or at the roots of teeth: it then causes pus and breaks open; later, it heals over, but still runs with pus, thus forming a fistula; you treat this, yet no cure takes place, so you must apply a cautery ignited according to its size such that it fits within the fistula.
Deinde intromitte ipsum ignitum in foramine fistulae, et tene manum tuam, donec perueniat ferrum ignitum ad profundum eius, et ultimum eius: fac illud semel, aut duabus uicibus.	Insert the heated iron into the hole of the fistula and hold your hand there until the hot metal reaches its deepest point and end; do this once or twice.
Deinde cura ipsum post illud, cum eo quod diximus de curatione usquequo curetur.	Then treat it afterwards with what we have said about treatment until it is cured.
Si ergo abscinditur sanies, et sanatur, erit bonum.	So if the pus is drained and heals, it will be good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est detegere locum, et auferre os corrupum secundum quod ueniet in capite suo.	And if it does not, then it is necessary to expose the place and remove the corrupted bone according to what comes at its head.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Gingiuis, et Dentibus mollificatis.	On how to cauterize in gingivitis and softened teeth.
Caput XXII.	Chapter 22.
Quando mollificatur gingiua propter humiditates, et mouentur dentes, et curas eam cum medicinis, et non confert: tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	When the gums are softened due to humidity and the teeth move and you treat it with medicine but it does not help, then place the patient's head on your lap.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma ueniet post haec, ita ut ponas Cannulam super dentem: et intromitte in ea Cauterium ignitum festinanter: et tene manum tuam parumper, donec sentiat infirmus calorem ignis iam peruenisse ad radicem dentis.	Then use the fire cautery whose form will come later so that you place the cannula over the tooth and quickly insert into it the heated cauterium: and hold your hand a moment until the patient feels the heat of the fire has now reached the root of the tooth.
Et eleua manum tuam: deinde itera Cauterium aliquotiens, secundum quod uis.	And raise your hand; then repeat the cautery several times according to what you want.
Deinde impleat infirmus os suum aqua salis, et teneat ipsam hora una: et exspuat ipsam.	Then let the patient fill their mouth with saltwater solution and hold it for an hour before spitting it out.
Dens enim motus firmatur, et gingiua mollificata stringitur, et siccatur humiditas corrupta.	For the loose tooth is made firm, the softened gum tightened and dried up, and the corrupted humidity healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Dentium.	On how to cauterize for toothache.
Caput XXIII.	Chapter 23.
Quando dolor dentis est propter frigiditatem, aut in ipso est frigus, aut uermis, et non confert curatio cum medicinis: tunc Cauterium in ipso est secundum duos modos: aut Cauterium cum butyro: aut cauterium cum igne.	When toothache is caused by coldness, either there is actual cold or worms, and treatment with medicine does not help, then cauterization on the tooth itself is performed in two ways: either cautery with butter or cautery with fire.
Cauterium autem eius cum butyro est, ut accipias butyrum uaccinum, et bullias ipsum in cochleari ferreo, aut in uenera.	The cautery with butter involves taking fresh butter and boiling it in an iron spoon or a small pot.
Deinde accipe cotum, et inuolue ipsum super extremitatem tentae.	Next, take a woolen cloth and wrap it around the end of a stick or probe.
Deinde submerge ipsum in butyro bullito: et pone ipsum super dentem dolorosum festinanter, et tene ipsum donec infrigidet: deinde itera ipsum aliquotiens, donec perueniat uirtus ignis ad radicem dentis.	Then immerse the cloth in the boiling butter and quickly place it on the painful tooth, holding it there until it cools. Repeat this several times until the heat reaches the root of the tooth.
Et si uis, submerge lanam, aut cotum in butyro frigido, et pone ipsum super dentem dolentem: et pone super ipsum ferrum ignitum, donec perueniat ignis ad profundum concauitatis dentis.	If you wish, you can also dip the wool or cloth in cold butter and place it on the aching tooth, then put a heated iron on top of it until the heat reaches deep into the cavity of the tooth.
Cauterizatio autem eius cum igne est, ut intendas ad cannulam aeris, aut cannulam ferri.	The cautery with fire involves using an iron or brass pipe.
Et sit in corpore eius quiddam grossitudinis, ut non perueniat acuitas ignis ad os infirmi.	If the pipe has a thick wall, this prevents the sharp heat from reaching the patient's bone.
Deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma ueniet: et pone ipsum super illum dentem: et tene manum tuam, donec infrigidetur Cauterium.	Next, apply the cautery with fire to the tooth and hold your hand there until the cautery cools down.
Fac illud aliquotiens, nam dolor remouebitur, aut in illo eodem die, aut die alio.	Repeat this procedure several times; the pain will be removed either that same day or on another day.
Et oportet in impressione illius Cauterii, ut impleat infirmus os suum buyro bono, et teneat ipsum hora una: deinde exspuat ipsum.	The patient should fill their mouth with good butter after the cautery mark and hold it there for an hour before spitting it out.
Et haec est forma Cauterii.	And this is the form of cautery.
Cauteriza cum quacumque extremitate uis secundum quod est possibile: et haec est forma Cannulae.	Scorch with whatever end you wish according to what is possible: and this is the form of the cannula.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Strophulis.	On the method of cauterizing with hot irons.
Caput XXIIII.	Chapter 24.
Quando Strophulae sunt a phlegmate, et ab humiditatibus frigidis, et non sunt obedientes digestioni per mecicinas, et uis digestionem earum uelociter: tunc igni Cauterium concauum, cuius forma est haec.	When hot irons are affected by phlegm and cold dampness, and do not respond to treatment with medicines, and you wish to rapidly facilitate their resolution: then use a concave cautery of this shape.
Habens duas extremitates apertas, ut egrediatur fumus apud Cauterium ab extremitate altera: et pone ipsum ignitum super ipsum apostema semel, et secundo, si indiges illo, donec perueniat ad profundum apostematis.	Which has two tight ends so that the smoke escapes from one end of the cautery: and place it alight on top of the swelling once, and a second time if you need to, until you reach the bottom of the swelling.
Quod si apostema est paruum: tunc pone Cauterium secundum quantitatem apostematis.	But if the swelling is small: then place the cautery according to the size of the swelling.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super ipsum cotum infusum in butyro, donec remoueatur quod combussit ignis.	Then leave it for three days, and apply to it lard infused with vinegar until that which was burned by the fire is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento dentis, donec sanetur forma cannulae.	Then treat it with tooth-powder ointment until the form of the cannula is restored.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in raucedine uocis, et constrictione anhelitus.	On the method of cauterizing with hoarseness of voice, and tightness of breathing.
Caput XXV.	Chapter 25.
Quando uincunt humiditates super cannale pulmonis, et praecipue quando illud est cum frigiditate complexionis, tunc oportet ut euacuetur infirmus in primis cum medicinis solutiuis.	When dampness is affecting the bronchial tubes, and especially when it comes with a cold constitution, then the patient must first be cleared out by means of liquefying medicines.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum in nocrati apud radicem gutturis in loce depresso: et caue, ne peruenias cum Cauterio ad guttur, neque in cute, nisi quiddam eius.	Then scorch it at night close to the base of the throat in a hollow place: and be careful not to reach with the cautery into the throat itself or anywhere on the skin except that spot.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cauterio alio apud iuncturam colli in ultimo spondili eius ultimando: et sit Cauterium clauile secundum modum, qui praecessit.	Then cauterize it with another cautery near the neck joint at the last of his vertebrae ending here; and let this be a claw-shaped cautery according to the method, which preceded earlier.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with what has been done before until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aegritudinibus Pulmonis, et Tussi.	On the method of cauterizing for lung disease and cough.
Caput XXVI.	Chapter 26.
Quando Tussis et aegritudo Pulmonis sunt ab humiditatibus frigidis, et infirmus non habet febrem, neque phthisim, et aegritudo antiqua: tunc cauteriza ipsum duobus cauteriis supra furculam in locis depressis, lenibus, uacuis.	When cough and lung disease are due to cold humours, and the patient has no fever or consumption, nor an old illness: then cauterize him with two cauteries above the collar-bone in hollow places, gentle, empty ones.
Et cauterio alio in medio pectoris inter duas mammillas: et sit cauterium cannulae secundum formam quae praecessit.	And with another cautery in the middle of the chest between the two nipples; and let this be a pipe-shaped cautery according to the form which preceded earlier.
