Et caue, ne comburas neruum qui est illic, et accidat super infirmum malicia alia.	And be careful not to burn the nerve that is there, lest another evil happen to the patient.
Et scias, quod quando ex arteria fluit sanguis, tunc non est possibile abscindere ipsum: praecipue quaudo arteria est magna, nisi cum uno quatuor modorum.	And know that when blood flows from the artery, it is not possible to stop it unless by one of four methods.
Aut cum cauterio, sicut diximus.	Or with a cautery, as we have said.
Aut cum extractione, quando non est extracta.	Or by extraction, when it has not been extracted.
Nam quando extrahitur, contrahuntur extremitates eius, et abscinditur sanguis.	For when it is extracted, its ends contract and the bleeding stops.
Aut ligetur cum filo ligatione forti.	Or it may be tied with a strong ligature.
Aut ponantur super ipsum medicinae de proprietate, quarum est abscindere sanguinem, et stringatur cum puluinari constrictione decenti.	Or place on it some medicines which have the property of stopping blood, and bind it with a suitable compress.
Qui autem administrat abscisionem eius cum ligamento, et strictura cum panno, aut positione rerum comburentium, et similium, non confert ei penitus, nisi raro.	He who accomplishes the stopping of blood by means of a ligament and a compress, or by the application of burning substances and the like, should never apply them to him completely except rarely.
Si autem accidat alicui illud, et non sit ei praesens medicus, neque medicina: tunc incipiat cum positione digiti indicis super orificium uenae ipsius, sicut narrauimus, et constrictione eius ualde, donec obsessus sit sanguis a superiori parte uulneris, et super arteriam.	If it happens to someone and there is no doctor present nor medicine: then begin with the placement of the index finger on the vein's opening, as we described, and its strong compression until the blood is blocked from the upper part of the wound and above the artery.
Et digitus non remoueatur, desuper ipsum cum aqua frigida uehementis frigoris semper, donec congeletur sanguis, et ingrossetur, et abscindatur.	And the finger should not be removed from it but placed above with very cold water until the blood clots and thickens, then cut off.
Et interim consideret in eo, quid indiget ex cauterio, aut ex medicina.	And meanwhile consider what it requires from cauterization or medicine.
¶ Partis Primae Finis.	End of the first part.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis Pars II.	Book of Surgery by Albucasis, Book II.
¶ De Incisione, Perforatione, et Phlebotomia in uulneribus, et his similibus.	On incision, perforation, and bloodletting with regard to wounds and similar issues.
Iam Diximus in Capitulo Primo, omnem aegritudinem in qua conueniens est cum igne cauterium et medicina comburente, et occasiones eius, ipsius caussas, et instrumenta eius, et formas cauteriorum.	We have already spoken in the first chapter about every illness that requires a burning cautery and medicinal fire, along with its opportunities, causes, instruments, and types of cauterization.
Et posui illic capitula a uertice usque ad pedem.	And I have placed there chapters from head to foot.
Et ego procedam in hoc capitulo illa eadem uia: ut alleuietur super quaerentem quaesitum eius.	And I will proceed in this chapter along the same path so that the seeker may find what they are looking for.
Et antequam incipiam illud, oportet ut addiscatis o filii, quod in hoc capitulo est ex terrore illud quod est in capitulo primo de cauterizatione.	And before I begin that, my sons, you must learn that what is in this chapter regarding fear differs from the first chapter on cauterization.
Et propter illud oportet, ut sit cautela in eo uehementior, quoniam in operatione quae est in hoc capitulo, multotiens cadit euacuatio cum sanguine, cum quo stat uita apud apertionem uenae, aut incisionem super apostema, aut apertionem exiturae, aut curationem uulneris, aut extractionem sagittae, aut incisionem super lapidem, et illis similia: ex quibus omnibus associatur tremor, et timor, et cadit in pluribus eorum mors.	And because of this it is necessary for there to be greater caution, since in the operation which is described in this chapter, there frequently occurs an evacuation with blood, together with which stands life at the opening of a vein or incision on a boil, abscess, wound, arrow extraction, or stone cutting, and those similar: from all of which arises trembling, fear, and death falls upon many.
Et ego moneo uos, ne cadat super uos illud in quo est haesitatio, nam quandoque cadunt ad uos in hac arte modi hominum cum modis infirmitatum.	And I advise you not to fall into uncertainty over that which is doubtful, for sometimes such kinds of people come before you with such kinds of ailments.
Ex eis enim est qui irascitur cum aegritudine sua, et est leuis apud eum mors: propter uehementiam eius quod inuenit ex infirmitate sua et longitudine eius maliciei.	For amongst them are those who become angry when suffering from illness and for whom death is a light matter because of the severity of what they experience through their ailment and the long duration of its evil.
Et cum aegritudine est ex timore quod significat mortem.	And when illness arises from fear that signifies death.
Et ex eis est, qui dat tibicensum suum, et ditat te cum eo, sperans sanitatem, et aegritudo eius est perniciosa.	And amongst them is he who offers you his flute-player, enriching you with him in the hope of health, while his sickness is destructive.
Non ergo oportet ut consentiatis ei qui uenit ad uos ex eis, cuius modus est talis.	Therefore, it should not be that you agree with him who comes to you from amongst them whose manner is such.
Et sit cautela uestra uehementior, quam cupiditas et uestra rapacitas.	And let your caution be more severe than your greed and avarice.
Et non praesumatis super aliquid ex illo, nisi post scientiam certam, quae uerificat apud uos illud ad quod peruenit successio laudabilis.	And do not presume about anything concerning him unless after certain knowledge which verifies to you that for which his worthy lineage has arrived.
Et utimini in curatione omnium infirmorum uestrorum, prognosticatione et indicatione de eo ad quod conuenienter sit salus.	And use for the treatment of all your patients prognosis and indication regarding that which is appropriate for health.
In illo namque est uobis adiutorium super acquisitionem famae et gloriae, et memoriae et laudis.	For in it lies your aid regarding the achievement of fame and glory, memory and praise.
Inspiret uobis Deus o filii, intellectum suum, et non auferat uobis directionem et inspirationem: quoniam illud est in manu eius.	May God inspire you, O sons, with His understanding and not withhold from you guidance and inspiration, for that is in His hand.
Et ego quidem ordinaui hoc Capitulum distinguendo per capitula, secundum quod praecessit in capitulo Cauterii, a ceruice usque ad pedes: ut alleuietur uobis quaesitum quod uultis ex eo, et quo indigetis.	And indeed I have arranged this Chapter by dividing it into chapters as previously mentioned in the chapter on cauterization from the neck down to the feet so that your search for what you wish and need out of it may be lightened.
¶ De curatione Aquae quae aggregatur in capitibus puerorum.	The treatment for water accumulation on children's heads.
Caput I.	Chapter 1.
Scias, quod haec infirmitas multotiens accidit pueris apud partum: aut quando stringit obstetrix caput pueri absque leuitate.	You should know that this condition often happens to children at birth or when the midwife grips the child's head without caution.
Et quandeque accidit etiam ex caussa occulta quae non scitur.	And whenever it happens, there is also an unknown hidden cause that cannot be known.
Et ego quidem non uidi hanc aegritudinem in aliis quam in pueris: et ad omnem quem ex eis uidi properauit mors: propter illud ergo uisum est mihi dimittere operationem in ea.	Indeed, I have not seen this sickness anywhere but in children, and among those whom I saw all rushed into death; for that reason, it seemed to me best to abandon any treatment of such a condition.
Et ego quidem uidi ex eis puerum, cuius caput impletum erat aqua, et caput magnificabatur in omni die, donec non poterat sedere super seipsum, propter magnitudinem capitis sui: et humiditas augmentata fuit, donec mortuus est.	And I have seen a child among them whose head was filled with water and his head kept growing every day until he could not sit upright due to the size of his head; moisture kept accumulating until death.
Et haec quidem humiditas, aut aggregatur inter cutem et os: aut aggregatur sub osse super sifac.	And this moisture may gather either between the skin and bone or beneath the bone above the skull.
Et operatio in illo, si est humiditas inter cutem et os, et apostema est paruum, tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis fissura una in latitudine: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo nodi, donec currat humiditas.	And for the treatment of this condition, if there is moisture between the skin and bone, and the abscess is small, then you should make an incision on top of the head running across its width; let the length of the incision be about two finger widths until the moisture drains out.
Et haec est forma spatumilis.	And this is the shape of a spatula.
Si ergo humiditas est magis augmentata, et apostema est maius, tunc pone eas duas fissuras, secundum formam hanc.	If then the moisture is more accumulated, and the abscess is larger, you should make two such incisions.
Et si humiditas est sub osse, et signum eius est, quod uides commissuras capitis apertas ab omni parte: et aqua deprimitur quando comprimis eam manu tua ad interiora, et non occultatur tibi illud: tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis tribus fissuris, secundum hunc modum.	And if the moisture is beneath the bone, and its sign is that you see openings on top of the head from every side; and water is pressed down when you press it with your hand towards the inside, but it does not hide itself: then you should make three incisions on top of the head like this.
Et post incisionem extrahe humiditatem totam.	And after making an incision, extract all moisture.
Deinde stringe fissuras cum pannis et puluillis.	Then close the wounds with cloths and plugs.
Deinde embroca illud desuper cum uino et oleo usque ad diem quintum.	After that, anoint it from above with wine and oil until the fifth day.
Deinde solue ligamentum, et cura uulnus cum tentis, et unguentis.	Then loosen the bandage, and treat the wound with sutures and ointments.
Et non dimittas stringere caput cum aequalitate.	And do not fail to keep the head bound tightly with its counterpart.
Et ciba infirmum omni cibo sicco paucae humiditatis, usquequo confortetur membrum, et sanetur.	Feed the patient dry food of little moisture until the limb is strengthened and healed.
Et modus alius incisionis est, ut consideres ubi apparet magnitudo apostematis, et collectio aquae.	Another method of incision is to note where the swelling appears large and water collects.
Quoniam quandoque est in occipitio plus, aut in sincipite, aut in dextra, aut in sinistra.	For sometimes it is greater at the back of the head, or on the forehead, or to the right, or left.
Ascende ergo cum incisione ubi apparet tibi apostema et impletio aquae: et scinde illud secundum quod tibi possibile est.	Thus ascend with your incision to where the swelling and water collection appear, then split it as seems best to you.
Et obserua, ne incidas arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis, et moriatur infirmus ex illo fluxu cum euacuatione humiditatis.	Take care not to cut an artery, lest the patient bleed out and die from that evacuation of moisture.
¶ De incisione Arteriarum quae sunt post aures.	### On Incision of the arteries found behind the ears.
Caput II.	Chapter two.
Quando accidunt alicui catarri ad oculos, aut ad pectus, et antiquatur illud, et non confert curatio medicinarum: tunc magis ultima curatio est in illo, incisio harum duarum arteriarum.	When someone has catarrh to the eyes or chest and it is not relieved by medicinal treatments, then this ultimate cure remains only for them - incision of these two arteries.
Oportet ergo quando uis incidere eas, ut radat infirmus caput suum.	When you wish to make such an incision then the patient should lean their head back.
Deinde frica locum cum panno aspero, ut appareant arteriae.	Then rub the spot with a rough cloth to make the arteries visible.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum, cum quolibet panno suo.	Then the patient should tighten their neck with each of their cloths.
Deinde considera, ubi pulset uena.	Then consider where the vein pulses.
Et loca utriusque sunt loca quae sunt post aures depressa: et raro occultatur, nisi in quibusdam hominibus.	And the places of both (veins) are the sunken areas behind the ears: and it is rarely hidden, except in some people.
Deinde signa cum encaustro super utraque: et incide utramque cum spatumili utrimque acuro, incisione perueniente ad os: et fiat illud per latitudinem capitis.	Then mark with encaustic on both (veins): and cut both (veins) with spatums on either side using a needle, the incision reaching to the bone: and let it be done across the width of the head.
Et si uis, intromitte spatumile sub arteria, et incide eam ad superiora cum incisione.	And if you wish, insert the spatums under the artery, and cut it above with an upward incision.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quasi duo digiti iuncti.	And let the length of the incision be about two joined fingers.
Nam quando inciditur uena, egreditur sanguis egressione pulsatili, qui salit ad interiora saltu frequenti.	For when the vein is cut, blood flows out in a pulsating manner, which jumps into the interiors with frequent leaps.
Si autem arteria non apparet sensui, tunc oportet ut mensures ab aure quantitatem spacii trium digitorum.	But if the artery does not appear to the touch, then you should measure from the ear a space of three fingers' breadth.
Deinde signa cum encaustro, et finde usque ad os.	Then mark with encaustic, and find (the artery) until you reach the bone.
Et illud quod oportet emittere ex sanguine, est VI uncia et fortasse emittis ex eo plus, aut minus.	And the amount of blood that should be let out is six ounces, and perhaps you emit more or less from it.
Totum illud secundum quantitatem quae apparet tibi ex uirute infirmi et repletione arteriae eius.	All of that according to the amount which appears to you of the patient's strength and the fullness of their artery.
Deinde considera ad uulnus.	Then consider the wound.
Tunc si remanet ad os ex sifac aliquid, tunc incide illud, ut non accidat apostema calidum: tunc stringe uulnus cum liciniis ex panno lini.	Then if anything of it remains reaching to the bone, then cut that, so that a hot abscess does not occur: then bind the wound with linen cloths.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Treat it then with ointment until it is healed.
¶ De extractione arteriarum, quae sunt in timporibus.	On the extraction of arteries which are in temples.
Caput III.	Chapter 3.
Quando accidit homini hemicranea antiqua, aut catarri acuti propter humiditates acrimoniales, et caliditate in lacertis timporum, aut soda antiqua, uehemens, et similia illis: et medicatur cum modis curationis medicinae, et non confert illud: tunc experti sumus in his aegritudinibus extractionem arteriarum ex timporibus, aut cauterizationem earum, sicut narrauimus.	When a person suffers from an old headache or acute catarrh due to acrid moistness and heat in the arteries of the temples, or from old, severe, or similar sodden humours: And if it is treated with medical remedies but does not yield to them: Then we have found in these ailments that the extraction of arteries from the temples or their cauterisation is efficacious as we have described.
Et modus operationis in extractione earum, est, ut radat infirmus pilos qui sunt in timporibus, et intendat ad arteriam apparentem in timpore.	And the method of operating on such an extraction is for the patient to shave off the hair which is on his temples and concentrate on the artery which appears therein.
Ipsa namque ostenditur tibi ex pulsu suo, et raro occultatur nisi in paucis hominibus, aut uehementia frigoris.	For it shows itself to you by its pulse; rarely is it hidden except in very few people or severe coldness.
Quod si occultatur tibi, tunc stringat infirmus caput suum cum quolibet panno suo: deinde frica locum cum panno aspero.	If it is hidden from you then the patient should bind his head with any cloth; afterwards rub that place with a rough cloth.
Aut uapora locum cum aqua calida, donec appareat tibi apparitione manifesta.	Or bathe the place with warm water until it appears to you clearly.
Deinde accipe spatumile, quod paulo ante formaui.	Then take the spatula which I formed just now.
Deinde excoria cum eo cutem cum facilitate, donec peruenias ad arteriam.	Afterwards scrape with it the skin gently until you reach that artery.
Deinde proiice in eam uncinum, et extrahe eam ad superiora, donec extrahas eam ex cute, et facias eam euadere ex tunicis quae sunt sub ea ab omni parte.	Then throw into it a hook and extract it upwards until you have extracted it from the skin; then make it escape out of any garments which are underneath.
Si autem arteria est subtilis: tunc inuolue eam cum extremitate uncini.	If however the artery is thin; then wrap it with the tip of the hook.
Deinde incide ex ea partem secundum quantitatem qua elongentur extremitates eius, et contrahantur, et non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	Then cut away a portion of it according to the extent by which its ends extend, and they are pulled back without causing any loss of blood.
Nam si non inciditur, et si non abscinditur, non ascendit sanguis penitus.	If it is not cut, nor if it is severed, the blood does not stop flowing entirely.
Deinde euacua ex sanguine ana VI unci, usque ad .III.	Then extract six ounces of blood from it until three remain.
Quod si arteria est magna: tunc oportet ut liges eam in duobus locis ex filo duplo, forti, ex serico: aut ex chordis alhohod, ut non properet ad ipsam putrefactio ante consolidationem uulneris, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	If the artery is large, you should tie it in two places using double-threaded silk string or strong chords of aloe wood so that corruption does not quickly set into its substance before wound healing and blood loss occurs.
Deinde incide superfluitatem, quae est inter duo ligamenta.	Then cut away the superfluity which is between the two ligatures.
Fac illud in illa hora, aut post horam aliam.	Do this at that hour or one hour later.
Et si uis, cauteriza eam cauterio usque ad os, cum cauterio cultellari: donec incidantur extremitates eius, et stabit loco eiusdem operis.	And if you wish, cauterise it with the knife-shaped cautery until reaching its bone, so that its ends may be excised and it will remain at this same place.
Et est melius opus, nisi si infirmus habet febrem, autest calefactae complexionis.	And the outcome is better unless the patient has fever or they have a hot constitution.
Quoniam cauterium est ex eis, quae iuuant ad finiendas humiditates.	Because the cautery is among those things which help to end moistness.
Ergo est melius iuuamentum.	Therefore it helps more effectively.
Et oportet post extractionem arteriarum, ut impleatur locus cotto antiquo: et ponantur super ipsum puluilli decenter facti.	And after the removal of arteries, the place should be filled with old tallow and decently made crumbled poultices placed over it.
Et post solutionem curetur cum medicinis siccis, quae faciunt nasci carnem, et cum liciniis, donec sanetur.	And after the discharge, it should be treated with drying medicines which promote flesh generation as well as dressings until healing occurs.
Quod si interim dum operaris accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, tunc propera ad abscindendum eum cum cauterio, aut ut impleas locum cum zegi: et stringe manum tuam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	If in the meantime while operating a flow of blood from an artery occurs, then hasten to sever it with the cautery or fill up its place with egg white and squeeze your hand until the blood is severed.
Quod si nihil ex illis est tibi praesens, tunc pone super locum digitum tuum, donec congeletur sanguis.	If none of these are present to you at this moment, then place your finger on the wound until the blood freezes.
Et embroca locum cum aqua uehementis frigoris, donec quiescat acuitas, et stringatur secundum quod oportet.	Wet the place with ice-cold water until the sharpness subsides and it tightens as needed.
Et ex eo quod est leuius et facilius extractione arteriae, est, ut cauterizes uenam cum hoc cauterio habente duos cultellos: sitque acuitas duorum cultellorum similis almagdatem.	And for that which is lighter and easier to remove by means of the artery, you should cauterize the vein with this cautery having two knives; and let the sharpness of the two knives be similar to that of almagdate.
Verumtamen sunt multo minoris acuitatis, quam duo cultelli.	However, they are much less sharp than two knives.
Quoniam si sunt acutae, sicut duo cultelli, properat utrisque frigus: et non incidunt carnem cum uelocitate.	Because if they were sharp like two knives, it would hasten both the cold; and they wouldn't cut into the flesh quickly.
Cum ergo in eis est aliquantulum grossitudinis, tenetur in eis calor ignis, et abscinditur caro uelociter: cum hoc ergo opus est melius omni opere, et leuius, et facilius.	Since there is a bit of thickness to them, some heat from the fire is retained within them, and they cut through flesh quickly; with this it's best to use this approach for every operation that requires speed, ease, and gentleness.
Et sit spacium quod est inter duos cultellos quantitas grossitudinis digiti, postquam tu signas duo loca cum encaustro: et depone utrosque ignitos ualde, donec perueniant ad os, et incidant uenam in duobus locis: ut elongetur quod est inter extremitates eius.	And let the space between the two knives be a thickness equal to that of your finger, after you mark both places with encaustic; and place each one red hot until they reach the mouth, and cut into the vein in two spots: so as to lengthen what is between its ends.
Nam non consolidantur cum hoc cauterio penitus.	For it doesn't fully consolidate with this cautery.
Et haec est forma cauterii.	And this is the shape of the cautery.
¶ De cura cursus lachrymarum acutarum assiduarum ab oculis.	On the treatment for frequent sharp pain in the eyes.
Caput IIII.	Chapter IV.
Quando sunt lachrymae assiduae, et est cursus earum ex uenis, quae sunt super craneum capitis exterius: et non confert in eis aliquid curationis medicinae cum medicinis, et uides faciem infirmi iam rubere, et sentit in fronte sua deambulationem, sicut est deambulatio formicarum: et oculi eius sunt extenuati, humidi, ita quod iam corrosi sunt pili eorum cum corrosione: et calefactae sunt palpebrae eius ex acuitate lachrymarum: tunc antiqui indiguerunt in curatione earum hac operatione, et denominauerunt eam curationem, cum Ense.	When tears are frequent and their course is from veins that are on the outside of the head; and you have not tried any cure with medicine or remedies, and see that the patient's face has now turned red, and they feel a crawling sensation on their forehead like ants crawling: and their eyes are exhausted, moist, so much that already their lashes are corroded by corrosion: and their eyelids are heated from the sharpness of tears; then the ancients required this operation for their cure, and named it *a cura cum ensi*, or "treatment with a sword".
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere pilos qui sunt in fronte sua.	And it is essential to advise the patient to shave the hair from their forehead.
Deinde incide in fronte tres fissuras aequedistantes secundum longitudinem frontis: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo digiti, et fissura una sit aequedistans longitudini nasi in medio frontis, et secunda secundum longitudinem parumper a motu lacertorum, et tertia a parte altera: et caue ab incisione arteriarum quae sunt in duobus lateribus: et elonga manum tuam a continuatione duarum mandibularum, et sit spacium omnis incisionis quantitas trium digitorum coniunctorum: et sit tibi frustum spongiae praeparatum, aut panni siccati multi, cum quibus exsicces sanguinem.	Then make three incisions on the forehead, evenly spaced according to the length of the forehead; let the length of each incision be about two fingers long, and have one incision equidistant from the nose in the center of the forehead, a second along the length slightly away from the movement of the eyebrows, and a third on the other side. And beware that you do not cut any arteries on either side, and stretch your hand out from the connection of the two jaws, and let the entire space of the incision be equal to three fingers put together: also have for yourself a piece of prepared sponge or many dry cloths with which to dry up the blood.
Deinde intromitte spatumile duarum acutarum extremitatum, cuius mox sequens est forma.	Then insert a spatula of two sharp ends, whose subsequent shape is as follows: [diagram not included].
Ab incisione quae est a parte timporis, usque ad incisionem secundam: et excoria cum eo totam cutem, quae est inter duas incisiones, cum sifac, quod est super os.	From the first incision near the temple to the second incision, scrape away all skin that lies between the two incisions, along with the bone above the eye socket.
Deinde fac illud etiam ab incisione media usque ad incisionem secundam.	Then do likewise from the middle incision to the second one.
Deinde extrahe hoc spatumile, et intromitte in incisionem primam iterum instrumentum aliud, quod nominatur cultellare acutum, ab una parte lene, non acutum ab altera parte.	Then withdraw the spatula, and reinsert another tool into the first incision, which is called a sharp knife, blunt on one side but sharp on the other.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form: [diagram not included]
Et pone latus eius acutum uersus carnem annexam cum cute, et latus eius lene uersus os: et impelle ipsum, donec perueniat ad fissuram mediam: et abscinde cum eo omnia uasa, quae descendunt a capite ad oculos: praeter quod continuetur incisio usque ad illud quod apparet de cute.	Position the sharp side of its edge towards the attached flesh and skin, and the blunt side towards the bone; push it in until you reach the middle incision, and sever with it all those vessels that descend from the head to the eyes: except for what continues with the incision up to where skin is visible.
Deinde fac illud in fissura media usque ad fissuram aliam.	Then do likewise at the middle incision down to the other one.
Et postquam currit ex sanguine quantitas aequalis, exprime loca ex frustis sanguinis coagulati.	After some quantity of blood has drained out evenly, squeeze those places from pieces of clotted blood.
Deinde pone in omnem fissuram licinium ex cotto ueteri, et pone super eos puluillos imbibitos in uino, et oleo, aut aceto.	Then put linen rags soaked in old wine on every crack, and place over them little pads moistened with wine or oil, or vinegar.
Et uide ut non accidat apostema calidum.	See to it that no hot abscess occurs.
Et in die tertia solue ligamentum, et administra infusionem multam cum aqua tepida.	On the third day, loosen the bandage and apply plenty of wash with warm water.
Deinde cura illud ex unguento basilicon, et reliquis quibus curantur uulnera: usquequo sanetur.	Then treat it with healing ointment of basil and other things that are used to heal wounds until it is healed.
¶ De cura lachrymarum acutarum et catarrorum ad oculos ex interioribus capitis.	On the treatment of sharp pains in the eyes, also of catarrh from an internal head cold.
Caput V.	Chapter 5.
Quando accidunt alicui catarri acuti, acres, assidui: et uides oculos eius extenuatos, paruos, et iam debilitatus est aspectus eorum: et palpebrae ulceratae, et cadunt pili ex eis, et in profundo capitis est dolor acutus, laedens, et sternutatio consequens: tunc sume ex istis accidentibus, quod illae materiae, et catarri non ueniunt, nisi ex uenis multis.	When someone has severe, sharp and persistent catarrh and you see their eyes tired, small, and the sight of them already weakened; and the eyelids ulcerated, with hairs falling out from them, and deep in the head there is a sharp, painful sensation followed by sneezing: then take from these symptoms that those substances [the discharges], and catarrhs do not come except from numerous veins.
Et melior curatio in eis est haec.	And the best treatment for them is this:
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere frontem suam.	And it is that you prescribe to the sick person to shave his forehead.
Deinde incide in eam fissuram unam in medio frontis, aut alterius parumper per latitudinem, et incipe cum fissura a timpore sinistro ad timpus dextrum: et sit incisio usque ad os: et elonga manum tuam a lacertis timporum, qui mouentur apud masticationem: donec quando detegitur os: et exsiccabis totum sanguinem cum spongia.	Then make in it one crack in the middle of the forehead or slightly across its width and start with the fissure from the left temple to the right temple, and let the incision be up to the bone; and stretch out your hand from the muscles of both temples which move when chewing until you feel the bone: and dry all blood with a sponge.
Tunc separa inter duo labia fissurae cum cotto ueteri, aut cum liciniis ex lino.	Then separate the two lips of the wound with a swab of old linen, or with strips of new linen.
Deinde stringe desuper cum puluillis: et imbibe puluillos cum uino et oleo, ut non accidat apostema calidum.	Then compress from above with swabs; and moisten the swabs with wine and oil, so that a hot abscess does not occur.
Et quando soluis illud, et uides quod apostema calidum iam imminuitur: tunc oportet ut frices os, donec incipiat in eo nasci caro.	And when you uncover it, and see that the hot abscess is now diminished; then you must rub the bone until flesh begins to grow on it.
Deinde cura ipsum cum regimine exiccatiuo quod facit nasci carnem: sicut si accipias ex farina tritici partes duas, et ex colophonia quatuor partes: et praepares ex eis emplastrum, et administretur ad natiuitatem carnis in istis uulneribus.	Then treat it with a drying regimen that makes flesh grow; for example, take two parts wheat flour and four parts colophony, prepare a plaster from them, and apply it to the birthplace of flesh in these wounds.
¶ De cura eius quod cadit in Aurem.	On the treatment for that which falls into the ear.
Caput VI.	Chapter 6.
Omne Quod in Aurem cadit, est una quatuor specierum: aut lapis mineralis, aut simile lapidi, sicut ferrum, et uitrum: aut est ex planta, sicut est cicer, et fabae: aut est res fluxibilis, sicut aqua, et acetum, et eis similia: aut aliquod animal.	Everything that falls into the ear is one of four kinds: either a mineral substance, or similar to stone, such as iron and glass; or it is from a plant, like chickpeas and beans; or it is a liquid, such as water and vinegar, and things like them; or it is an animal.
Quando ergo cadit in aurem lapis, aut genus lapidis ex eis quae non adduntur, neque crescunt in aure, expone Aurem soli: si ergo uides lapidem, tunc distilla in Aurem aliquid ex oleo uiolato, aut sisamino.	When therefore a stone or stony substance falls into the ear from among those which are not added to and do not grow within the ear, expose the ear to the sun; if you then see that it is a stone, then instil into the ear some of either violative oil or sesame oil.
Deinde administra extractionem eius, et fac sternutare cum condisi, et opila nares apud aduentum sternutationis, postquam tu ponis in circumitu auris frusta ex pannis, aut lana, et extendis aurem ad superiora.	Then apply the procedure for extracting it and make them sneeze with mustard seed; plug their nostrils as they sneeze, after you place around the ear a pad made of cloth or wool, and stretch out the ear upwards.
Multotiens enim egreditur cum hac cura.	For often it comes out with this treatment.
Si autem non egreditur, tunc administra extractionem eius cum Gesti, id est, Pizigarolis subtilibus: cuius forma est haec.	If it does not come out, then perform its removal with a gesture, that is, with delicate pincers; whose form is this.
Si ergo egreditur cum gesti, est bonum.	If it therefore comes out with the gesture, it is good.
Et si non, tunc administra extractionem eius cum uncino caeco subtili paucae duplicationis.	And if not, then perform its removal with a delicate blind hook of little curvature.
Si ergo non egreditur per illud, tunc fac cannulam ex aere, et intromitte extremitatem cannulae in foramen auris multum, et opila quod est in circumitu cannulae cum caera mollificata cum oleo, ut non sit uento uia nisi cannulae: deinde extrahe cum uento tuo attractione forti.	If therefore it does not come out through that, then make a copper tube, and insert the end of the tube into the ear hole deeply, and apply what is in the circumference of the tube with soft wax softened with oil, so that there is no way for the wind except through the tube; then extract it with your strong attracting breath.
Multotiens enim egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus.	For many times indeed it comes out with that which we have narrated.
Si autem non egreditur hoc modo: tunc accipe ex helkalimbat, aut ex uisco, id est, gluten praeparato, cum quo capiuntur aues, rem modicam: et pone ipsum in extremitate radii postquam tu inuoluis super eam cotum decenter positum: deinde intromitte ipsum in foramen auris cum facilitate, postquam tu exiccas aurem ab humiditate.	If however it does not come out this way: then take from helkalimbat, or from viscum, that is, prepared glue, with which birds are caught, a small amount: and place it at the end of a stick after you wrap around it a piece of skin positioned eccentrically: then insert it into the ear hole easily, after you dry the ear from moisture.
Si ergo non egreditur cum omnibus quae narrauimus, tunc propera ad scindendum, antequam accidat apostema calidum, aut spasmus.	If therefore it does not come out with all that we have narrated, then hasten to cut it open, before a hot abscess or spasm occurs.
Et modus fissurae est, ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis in cephalica: et extrahe ei ex sanguine secundum mensuram uirtutis eius.	And the mode of the cut is such that a weak flea first bites on the head: and extract from it blood according to the measure of its strength.
Deinde fac sedere infirmum inter manus tuas, et conuerte aurem eius ad superiora, et finde fissuram paruam in radice auris apud adipem eius in loco depresso ipsi: et sit fissura lunaris figurae, donec peruenias ad lapidem: deinde aufer eum cum eo, quod est tibi possibile ex instrumentis.	Then make the weak one sit between your hands, and turn its ear upwards, and find a small cut in the root of the ear near its fat in a depressed place on it: and let the cut be moon-shaped until you reach the bone: then remove it with what is possible for you from instruments.
Deinde sue fissuram ab hora tua cum uelocitate, et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then sew up your incision with speed and tend it until it is healed.
Quod si res cadens in aurem est ex uno granorum, quae crescunt, et inflantur: tunc administra extractionem eius.	If an object has fallen into the ear due to one of the grains that grow and swell, then administer its removal.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc accipe spatumile tenue, subtile, secundum hanc formam.	But if it does not yield to your extraction, then take a thin, fine spatula like this:
Et administra cum eo abscisionem illius speciei ex granis, quae cadunt in aurem, et non facias illud, quando tu cogitas, quod illud granum iam humectatum est per uaporem auris, donec ponis ipsum frusta multa: deinde extrahe ea cum uncinis, aut cum gesti subtili, aut cum suctione, sicut diximus, nam extractio eius alleuiatur.	And administer with it the removal of that type of grain which falls into the ear and do not attempt it when you think that the grain has already been softened by the vapour of the ear until you have tried many times; then remove them with hooks, or with a thin probe, or with suction, as we have said, for their extraction is facilitated.
In aqua autem quae ingreditur in aurem, oportet ut utatur infirmus sternutatione cum condisi in primis: et iam impleuit aurem suam cum aliquanto cotto ueteri: et est iacens super illam aurem, in qua est aqua.	In the case of water which enters the ear, the patient must use sneezing as treatment at first; and already he has filled his ear with some old oil; and he is lying on that ear in which there is water.
Si ergo egreditur per illud, est bonum.	Therefore if it comes out by itself, it is good.
Et si non: tunc accipe lapides multos, secundum longitudinem digiti, tenues, lenes, et calefac eos cum igne parumper, et intromittat infirmus ex eis unum in foramen auris suae: et saliat super pedem suum unum ex illa parte, et percutiat cum lapide alio super lapidem qui est in aure.	And if it does not, then take many pebbles the length of a finger, thin and soft, and warm them with fire for a while, and let the patient introduce one of these into his ear-hole: and let him jump on one foot from that side, striking with another pebble against the pebble which is in the ear.
Non ergo cesset facere illud cum lapide et lapide, donec egrediatur tota aqua.	So do not cease doing this with pebble and pebble until all the water comes out.
Et iam egreditur aqua ita, ut accipias ex parpyro, aut ex iunco unum, et intromittas extremitatem eius unam in aurem: et accendas extremitatem alteram cum igne, donec comburatur plurimum eius.	And now the water comes out to such an extent that you may take a straw or a reed and introduce one end of it into the ear; and light the other end with fire until most of it is burnt.
Deinde itera iuncum alium, et fac illud multotiens, donec egrediatur tota aqua: et extrahe ipsam cum cannula secundum quod praemissum est in lapide.	Repeat with another reed and do so many times until all the water comes out; then extract it along with the tube as mentioned before for the stone.
In extractione autem animalis intrantis in eam, si est parui corporis, ut pulex, et ei simile, cura ipsum sicut dixi in diuisione.	When extracting an animal that has entered it, if it is a small body, such as a flea, and similar to it, take care of it as I said in the division.
Sed si est corporis magni, quod appareat sensui: tunc administra extractionem eius cum gesti, et uncinis: et res eius est facilior omnibus, quae tenentur in aure.	But if it is a large body that can be felt: then carry out its extraction with forceps and hooks; and its removal is easier than all those things which are held in the ear.
In extractione autem uermis generati in aure, quando curas eum cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et in tractatu distilationum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut aspicias aurem in sole.	When extracting a worm born in the ear, when you treat it with what we said in the division and in the treatise of distillations, and your treatment does not succeed; then you must look at the ear in the sun.
Si ergo apparet illic aliquid ex uermibus, tunc extrahe illud cum gesti, aut cum uncinis subtilibus.	If something of the worm appears there, then extract it with forceps or with fine hooks.
Si autem non apparet illic aliquid, tunc accipe cannulam, cuius haec est forma, stricta inferius, ampla superius: et intromitte extremitatem subtilem in aurem secundum quantitatem quod tolerat eam infirmus: deinde suge cum ea suctione forti.	But if nothing of it appears there, then take a tube whose form is narrow at the bottom and wide at the top; and introduce the fine end into the ear as much as the patient can tolerate; then suck hard with it.
Fac illud multotiens, donec egrediantur omnes uermes.	Do so many times until all the worms come out.
Si autem non obediunt tibi ad exitum, tunc opila circumitum cannulae cum caera, sicut dixi in lapide.	But if they do not obey you to come out, then apply some wax around the tube with a wick, as I said for the stone.
Quod si non egrediuntur cum eo quod diximus: tunc administra distillationes quas iam experti sunt antiqui in interfectione uermium: et inuenies illud in tractatu distillationum.	If they do not come out with what we have said, then carry out the distillations which the ancients have already experienced in killing worms; and you will find it in the treatise of distillations.
Et sit effusio tua qua effundis olea et medicinas in aurem cum hoc instrumento, cuius forma depicta est hic.	And your infusion which you pour the oil and medicines into the ear with this instrument, whose form is depicted here.
Sicut uides fac ipsum ex argento, aut aere, inferius strictum, in quo sit foramen paruum, amplum superius.	You can see that it should be made from silver or bronze, with the lower part narrow and having a small hole, the upper part wide.
Sit ergo ut impellens quod est in concauitate cannulae, sit ex aere decenter factum.	Let it therefore be made of bronze, off-centre to the part that is inside the cavity of the tube.
Et si uis, accipe radium, et inuolue in extremitate eius cottum inuolutione decenti: deinde proiice oleum, aut succum, aut quod uis ex istis medicinis in cannulam: et ipsa sit in aure: deinde intromitte radium cum cotto desuper, et exprime ipsum manu tua compressione temperata, donec impellatur oleum in concauitate auditus, et sentiat ipsum infirmus interius: et illud quod infunditur in aurem, sit iam calefactum cum igne parumper: et caue ne sit res quae distillatur in eam frigida ualde: medicinae enim non tolerant illud.	And if you wish, take a stick and wrap around its end a little cotton with an appropriate number of windings; then pour oil or juice or whatever remedy you like from among these medicines into the tube; let it be in the ear; next insert the stick with the cotton above it, and express it by compressing it with your hand using moderate pressure until oil is forced into the cavity of the ear and the patient feels it inside; and let what is poured into the ear already have been warmed up a little with fire: and beware that nothing which is distilled into it be very cold: for remedies do not tolerate that.
¶ De cura opilationis accidentis Auri.	### Treatment of the Accident of Earwax ###
Caput VII.	Chapter 7.
Quandoque egrediuntur quidam infantes ex uentribus matrum suarum non perforati.	Sometimes children come out of their mothers' wombs unpierced.
Et iam accidit etiam quibusdam hominibus opilatio in meatu Auris a uulnere, aut carne nata in ea.	And it also happens that earwax accumulates in some people due to injury or the growth of flesh there.
Et haec opilatio quandoque fit in profundo foraminis Auris, quam non consequitur uisus: et quandoque accidit ad exteriora foraminis parum, et consequitur eam uisus.	And this earwax sometimes forms deep inside the hole of the ear, beyond sight; and it occasionally happens near its outer edge where vision can reach it.
Illa ergo quae accidit in profundo Auris, et quam non comprehendit aspectus, est in pluribus dispositionibus difficilis sanationis.	That which occurs deep inside the ear, beyond sight's reach, is difficult to cure in many cases.
Et in illa quam consequitur uisus, oportet ut ponas Aurem infirmi in sole, et aspicias in ea: tunc si uides opilationem apparentem, aperi eam cum spatumili subtili, cuius forma est haec quae sequitur, sit extremitas eius in qua sit quaedam latitudo parua, cuius quaedam pars sit acuta: et reliquum spatumile sit duarum laterum lenium: ut non laedat aurem.	And for that which vision can reach, you should place the patient's ear in the sun and look inside; then if you see any visible wax, open it with a fine probe of this shape, whose end has some width with one part sharp; and let the rest of the probe be two smooth sides: so as not to hurt the ear.
Si ergo opilatio est a carne nata in meatu auris: tunc tene eam cum uncino subtili, et incide eam cum facilitate uehementi, donec auferatur tota caro.	If the obstruction is born of flesh within the ear canal, then grasp it with a fine hook and cut it away easily until all the flesh is removed.
Quod si opilatio est in profundo auris: tunc accipe radium subtilem, lenem, et calefac ipsum cum igne parumper: deinde mitte ipsum in meatum auris.	If the obstruction is deep within the ear, take a fine, soft rod and heat it slightly over a flame; then insert it into the ear canal.
Si ergo senseris opilationem cum eo, quod inuenit infirmus cum grauitate auditus, conare apertionem eius cum facilitate: et caue, ne uulneres neruos auris.	If you perceive the obstruction along with what the patient describes as a heaviness of hearing, attempt to open it easily; and take care not to injure the ear's nerves.
Deinde pone in aurem licinium secundum quantitatem amplitudinis foraminis, quod inuoluisti in unguento aegyptio: fac illud aliquot diebus, donec sis securus de consolidatione uulneris.	Then place in the ear a linen plug according to the size of the opening you wrapped in Egyptian ointment; do this for several days until you are sure the wound is healed.
Aut accipe licinium, et infunde ipsum in aqua rosata, et pulueriza super ipsum zegi tritum, et utere ipso.	Or take linen and soak it in rosewater, then sprinkle over it some powdered frankincense, and use this.
Quod si uides aurem iam apostemari: tunc oportet ut extrahas licinium, et permittas ipsum cum licinio alio, quod inuolues in caeroto quod sit factum cum oleo rosato, donec sedetur apostema calidum: deinde cura ipsum usquequo sanetur.	If you see the ear starting to fester, then remove the linen and leave it with another which you wrap in a poultice made from oil and rosewater until the abscess cools; then treat it until it heals.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis: tunc submerge spongiam, aut pannos in aqua frigida, et pone super eam aurem: et utere reliqua curatione, quae abscindit fluxum sanguinis praedicta in tractatu distillationum.	If there is bleeding, then soak a sponge or cloth in cold water and place it over the ear; and use the remaining treatment which stops blood flow as described previously in the section on distillations.
¶ De cura Altheli palpebrarum.	On treating sore eyelids.
Caput VIII.	Chapter 8.
Isti Althelil qui accidunt in Palpebris oculi, quandoque sunt humidi, et sunt sicci.	These sore eyelids which occur on the eye, sometimes are wet and sometimes dry.
Oportet ergo ut teneas eos cum tenaliis: aut cum uncino, et incidas eos cum spatumili a radicibus suis.	So you must hold them with forceps; or with a hook, and cut them away with a spatule from their roots.
Deinde pone super loca zegi tritum.	Then place ground galbanum on the wound.
Si autem ex eis fluat sanguis, tunc cauteriza eos cum cauterio lenticulari subtili.	If any of them ooze blood, then cauterize them with a fine lens-shaped cautery.
Et cauterizare eos, est melius post incisionem.	And it is better to cauterize them after the operation.
Multotiens enim redeunt quando remanet ex radicibus suis aliquid.	For they often recur when some of their roots remain.
Et quando cauterizantur cum igne, comburuntur illae radices, et non redeunt.	And when they are cauterized with fire, those roots are burned, and they do not recur.
¶ De cura Grandinum palpebrarum oculi.	On the treatment of eyelid cysts.
Caput IX.	Chapter 9.
Multotiens accidit in palpebris aliquid quod assimilatur Crandini in fortitudine sua, et sua duricie, et propter illud nominatur Grando: et est aggregatio humiditatis grossae in palpebra superiore, et palpebra inferiore.	It often happens that something occurs in the eyelids which resembles a cyst in its strength and hardness, and on account of this it is called a cyst; and it is a collection of thick moisture in the upper or lower eyelid.
Operatio ergo in eis est, ut consideres tunc, si est Grando procedens in eo, quod apparet de palpebra, et mouentur ad omnem partem, et res eius est facilis.	The operation for them is as follows: you should then consider whether the cyst which appears from the eyelid and moves in all directions is proceeding in it; and its consistency is soft.
Finde ergo super eam fissura per latitudinem.	Therefore, make an incision above it across the width [of the eyelid].
Deinde excoria eam ab omni parte cum facilitate, donec euadat.	Then scrape it out from all sides with ease until it comes out.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncino, et abscinde ipsam.	Then snatch it away with a hook, and tear it off.
Si autem non praeparatur tibi abscisio eius, nisi postquam tu penetras palpebram cum incisione parumper, tunc nocet infirmo illud in aliquo.	But if its tearing away is not prepared for you unless after you penetrate the eyelid with an incision to some extent, then it harms the patient in some way.
Quod si fissura est magna: tunc aggrega ipsam cum sutura: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	But if the incision is large, then gather it with a suture; and treat it until it is healed.
Et si est parua, non superueniet tibi malum ex ea.	If it is small, no harm will come to you from it.
Vnguentum enim restaurat ipsam, et incarnat eam.	For the ointment restores it and fleshes it out.
Et si grando est decliuis ad interiora auris uersus superficiem intrinsecam, tunc inuersa palpebram, et suspende grandinem cum uncino: praeter quod indigeas incisione, et preme eam ab omni parte.	And if the hailstone is sloped towards the inner surface of the ear, then turn over the eyelid and hook out the hailstone with a crochet-hook; besides which you must make an incision and press it from every side.
Quod si elongatur palpebra per incisionem, non nocet illud in aliquo.	If the eyelid is stretched by means of an incision, that will not do any harm.
Deinde ablue oculum post incisionem grandinis, cum aqua salsa: et cura locum cum eo quod incarnat, donec sanetur infirmus.	Then wash the eye after removal of the hailstone with salt water; and treat the place with something that fleshes it out until the patient is healed.
¶ De cura Axirnath palpebrarum.	On the treatment of eyelid swelling.
Caput X.	Chapter 10.
Axirnath est adeps qui generatur in tunicis palpebrae superioris: et plurimum quidem accidit illud pueris: et ipsum grauat oculos eorum, et accidunt eis catarri in matutinis, et non possunt intueri lumen solis, propterea, quod lachrymae properant ad eos, et propter illud uides eos discumbere super facies suas semper, et super eas dormiunt, et sunt palpebrae eorum sub superciliis humidae, quas iam cooperuit inflatio: et eminentia quidem Axirnath apparens est oculo, et quando tu premis locum cum digitis tuis, sentis Axirnath inter eos.	Axirnath is the fat that forms under the eyelids; it happens most often to children. It weighs down their eyes and causes them to have morning cataracts, so they cannot look at sunlight because tears run into their eyes. That's why you see them lying on their faces all the time and sleeping with their faces downwards: the moisture from their eyelids runs beneath their eyebrows, which already are swollen; Axirnath is a protuberance that appears in the eye, and when you press it with your fingers you feel Axirnath between your fingers.
Et modus operationis eius est, ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	The mode of treatment is that the patient should put his head on your lap.
Deinde accipe pannum lini, et praepara in eo licinia, et fac ex illo licinio circulum secundum quantitatem quod continet Axirnath ab omni parte.	Then take a linen cloth and prepare some lint within it; make out of this lint a circle to the size that matches Axirnath from every side.
Deinde pone eum super eam, et preme cum digitis tuis ab omni parte, ut aggregetur Axirnath in medio circuli.	Place him on it and press with your fingers from all sides so that the navel gathers at the center of the circle.
Deinde finde in medio illius humiditatis cum spatumili incidente fissuras per latitudinem, et non sit fissura maior illa quae fit in phlebotomia in profundo.	Then find at the center of that moisture with a spatula striking cracks across its width, and let no crack be larger than that which forms during deep phlebotomy.
Aut oportet ut findas cutem totam, donec peruenias ad Axirnath in pluribus enim dispositionibus procedit Axirnath ex fissura secundum formam frusti pinguedinis albae.	Or you should split the skin entirely until you reach the navel because in many conditions the navel proceeds from a crack according to the shape of a white piece of fat.
Extrahe ergo eam cum panno, quem infiltrasti inter digitos tuos ad exteriora: et tu reuoluis manum tuam ad dextram et sinistram, donec dispergatur: et caue, ne addas in fissura, ut non peruenias cum spatumili ad oculum, et laedas eum.	Extract it therefore with a cloth that you have moistened between your fingers towards the outside and rotate your hand to the right and left until it is dispersed: take care not to add any into the crack lest you reach the eye with the spatula and injure it.
Si autem non appareat tibi Axirnath in principio fissurae, tu addas in fissura parum cum facilitate, donec procedat Axirnath.	But if the navel does not appear to you at the beginning of the crack then you should add a little gently into the crack until the navel proceeds from it.
Deinde extrahe eam, sicut diximus.	Then extract it as we have said.
Deinde submerge pannos in aceto et aqua, et pone eos super locum, et stringe eum cum puluillis.	Submerge the cloths in vinegar and water then place them on the site and compress it with pads.
Et ex hominibus sunt qui terunt salem, et ponunt ipsum in concauitate fissurae, ut liquefiat quod remansit ex illa humiditate.	There are people who rub salt into it and place it in the hollow of the crack so that what remains of that moisture melts away.
Deinde cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then treat it until it heals.
Si autem accidat in loco apostema calidum, tune cura ipsum cum emplastris sedatiuis, donec sanetur.	But if a hot abscess should occur then treat it with soothing poultices until it heals.
¶ De modis Ataxmir oculi, id est, cum palpebra mollificatur oculi, unde fit ut rugetur sicut non debet.	On the ways of eyelid drooping, that is when the eyelid softens so it creases improperly.
Caput XI.	Chapter Eleven.
Quando nascuntur in palpebris oculi pili additi praeter cursum sub pilis naturalibus, et antiquantur: tunc ipsi nocent oculo, et faciunt accidere modos aegritudinum, sicut lachrymas assiduas, et mollificationem palpebrarum, et albuginem, donec fit illud caussa destructionis oculi.	When there grow on the eyelids of the eye extra hairs beyond the normal course underneath the natural hair, and they become too long: then these harm the eye, and cause ailments to occur such as frequent tears, softening of the eyelids, and whiteness, until it becomes a cause for destruction of the eye.
Et Ataxmir quidem oculi curatur secundum quatuor modos.	Ataxmir's eye indeed is cured according to four methods.
Aut per cauterium cum igne.	Or by fire-cauterization.
Aut cum medicina acuta, secundum quod praemissum est in capitulo cauterii.	Or with an acute medicine, as mentioned previously in the chapter on cauterization.
Aut curatur Ataxmir per incisionem et suturam.	Ataxmir is also cured by incision and suture.
Aut per cannas, secundum quod ego dicam.	Or with tubes, as I will explain.
Oportet ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	It is necessary to place the patient's head on your lap.
Deinde conuerte palpebram oculi manu tua sinistra.	Then turn the eye's eyelid with your left hand.
Si ergo conuertitur, bonum est.	If it is turned then that is good.
Et si non: intromitte acum in eam, in qua sit filum ab inferiori parte palpebrae, et fac penetrare acum cum filo desuper, et sit illud prope pilos ipsos, id est, prope marginem palpebrae, in quo nascuntur pili: et trahe filum ad superiora cum palpebra, et conuerte eam cum radio.	And if it is not turned: introduce the needle into it with a thread attached from its lower part of the eyelid and make the needle penetrate together with the thread from above, and have that be near the hair itself, that is, near the edge of the eyelid where the hair grows; then pull the thread upwards along with the eyelid, and turn it back using a rod.
Deinde finde in interiori parte palpebrae sub pilis additis cum spatumili incidente a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus.	Then find the inner part of the eyelid underneath the extra hair using an incision from the larger lacrimal to the smaller one.
Deinde extrahe filum, et pone sub palpebra puluillum paruum ex cotto, aut panno: deinde signa super palpebram cum encaustro, quod sit sicut figura folii myrti.	Then extract the thread and place a small piece of cotton or cloth underneath the eyelid; then mark over the eyelid with cauterizing iron in the shape of a myrtle leaf.
Verumtamen oportet, ut fit figura secundum quantitatem et eleuationem palpebrae: quoniam iam diuersificatur illud in hominibus.	However, it is necessary that the shape be made according to the size and elevation of the eyelid; for this varies already among men.
Ex eis enim est, qui indiget ut incidatur ex palpebra quantitas magna, secundum quantitatem quae mollificatur a palpebra.	For some of them require that a large portion be cut from the eyelid according to the size which is softened by the eyelid.
Deinde cum spatumili finde super duas lineas quas signasti, et incipe a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus, et sit fissura una prope pilos naturales, sicut est grossitudo radii.	Then when you have placed the spatulate end over the two lines which you marked, begin from the greater tear duct to the lesser tear duct and let there be one incision near the natural hairs, like the thickness of a spoke.
Deinde intromitte uncinum in uno duorum angulorum cutis.	Then introduce the hook into one of the two corners of the skin.
Deinde excoria ipsam totam.	Then scrape away all of it.
Deinde aggrega cum sutura duo labia, cum acu et filo lana subtili: et absterge sanguinem, et fac adhaerere quod superfluit ex filis super duo supercilia, cum quibusdam rebus inuiscantibus, si uis facere illud: et si non, non cures.	Then bring together the two lips with a suture, using a needle and fine woolen thread; wipe away any blood, and make adhere that which is superfluous of the threads over both eyebrows, with some sticky substances if you wish to do so; but if not, take no care.
Deinde dimitte suturam et fila usque ad tres dies, aut quatuor: postea cura illud.	Then leave the suture and threads for three or four days; afterward tend to it.
Et si uis, dimitte uulnus absque sutura, et cura ipsum cum eo, quod exsiccat et constringit.	And if you wish, leave the wound without suture, and tend to it with something that dries and contracts.
Nam palpebra eleuatur apud sigillationem uulneris et aggregationem eius: sed futura est melior.	For the eyelid is raised at the wound's sealing and its bringing together; yet it will be better still.
Hunc modum curandi Ataxmir docuerunt antiqui.	This method of treatment ancient physicians taught to Ataxmir.
Verumtamen in eo est sollicitudo super infirmum, et est ex bona operatione, et non est in eo timor.	However there is concern for the patient; and it is of good skill; nor is fear within him.
Et modus alius est in Ataxmir etiam: et est, ut signes super palpebram figuram, quae sit sicut figura folii myrti, sicut narrauimus.	And there is another method to Ataxmir also; it is that you mark upon the eyelid a shape which is like the form of a myrtle leaf, as we have described.
Deinde eleua palpebram cum tribus uncinis separatis, aut aggregatis, secundum formam hanc quae sequitur, deinde incide quod superfluit cum forficibus paruis, secundum hanc formam, cum aequalitate incisionis.	Then lift the eyelid with three separate or combined hooks, following this form, then cut away the excess with small scissors, following this shape, with equal cutting.
Si autem non est tibi possibile tenere uncinum, et non aequatur illud: tunc accipe acum in qua sit filum, et intromitte ipsum in medio figurae: et intromitte filum aliud prope lachrymale maius, et filum secundum prope lachrymale minus: et aggrega inter digitos tuos fila cum aequalitate.	But if it is not possible for you to hold the hook, and it does not even out: then take a needle in which there is thread, and insert it into the middle of the figure; and insert another thread near the larger lachrymal, and a second thread near the smaller lachrymal: and gather together between your fingers the threads with equal force.
Deinde eleua manum tuam eleuatione aequali: et eleua cutem super quam est signatum cotum, sicut narrauimus.	Then raise your hand with an equal elevation; and lift the skin over which the tumor is marked, as we have described.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then bring together the two lips of the wound with a suture; and take care of it until it heals.
Si uero accidat apostema apud incisionem tuam, aut fissuram tuam: seda illud apostema cum caeroto, et his similibus, ex unguentis sedantibus.	But if an abscess occurs near your incision or your opening, subdue that abscess with a poultice and similar things, from soothing ointments.
Et quandoque accidit palpebrae etiam, ut conuertantur pili eius.	And sometimes it happens to the eyelid as well, that its hairs turn inward.
Oportet ergo ut utaris in ea quod diximus in incisione: sed sutura utrisque magis est artificialis.	It is therefore necessary that you use on it what we have said about incision; but suture is more of an art.
¶ De cura Ataxmir cum cannis.	§ On the treatment of Ataxmir with reeds.
ET Est, ut conuertas palpebram, et scindas fissuram quae est deintus, secundum quod narraui.	And it is necessary that you turn the eyelid back, and split open the opening which is inside, as I have described.
Deinde arte fac duas cannas, aut duo ligna subtilia: quarum longitudo sit secundum longitudinem palpebrae, et latitudo earum sit minor latitudine spatumilis: et tu iam incidisti in extremitatibus utriusque ab utrisque partibus ubi tenes fila.	Then make two reeds or two slender sticks with art, whose length is according to the length of the eyelid, and their width should be less than a spatula; and you have already cut at each end from both sides where you hold the threads.
Deinde aggrega utramque cum subtilitate super illud quod superfluit ex palpebra oculi, et stringe duas cannas ab utrisque partibus strictura forti, et dimitte eam diebus aliquot.	Then gather each [part] with precision over that which protrudes from the eyelid of the eye, and tighten the two tubes from both sides with a strong ligature, and leave it for several days.
Cutis enim stricta morietur, et denigrabitur, et putrefiet, donec cadet per se.	For the skin will die, darken, and rot until it falls off by itself.
Si ergo tardatur, tunc incide eam cum forficibus.	Therefore if you delay, then cut it with scissors.
Deinde cura eam, donec sanetur.	Then treat it until it heals.
Cum ergo consolidatur, eleuatur palpebra: et non pungunt pili.	When therefore it is strengthened, lift the eyelid: and do not pluck out the hairs.
Et haec est forma duarum cannarum, quas facies secundum hanc figuram, et quantitatem in longitudinem et latitudinem.	And this is the form of the two tubes, which you will make according to this figure, and size in length and width.
¶ De eleuatione pilorum pungentium in oculo cum acu.	On removing hairs that irritate the eye with a needle.
Caput XII.	Chapter 12.
Operatio in illo est, ut accipias acum subtilem, et intromittas in eam filum ex serico subtile, lene.	The operation in this case is that you take a fine needle, and insert into it a thin, soft silk thread.
Deinde aggreges extremitates eius, et nodes utramque nodo subtili ualde: et sit longitudo filorum palmus unus.	Then gather its ends, and tie each one with a very fine knot; and let the length of the threads be one palm's width.
Deinde compone in Alinxotati filum aliud subtile sub eo in breui, et noda extremitates eius si uis.	Then tie underneath it another fine thread that is short, and knot its ends if you like.
Deinde ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo, et sit prope solem ut declaretur operatio: quoniam est operatio subtilis, uel minuta.	Then have the patient place their head in your lap, and let it be close to the sun so that the operation may be revealed; for this is a precise or delicate operation.
Deinde intromitte acum cum alinxotati in radicem palpebrae, et fac eam penetrare in palpebram festinanter, donec extrahas eam desuper pilum naturalem.	Then insert the needle with its thread into the root of the eyelid, and make it penetrate the eyelid quickly until you extract from above a natural hair.
Deinde trahe pilum usque supra alinxotati: et intromitte in alinxotati illum pilum: si est unus, aut duo, aut tres, non plures.	Then draw out the needle above the splint; and introduce into the splint that needle; be it one or two or three, no more than this.
Deinde trahe manum tuam cum eo, donec egrediatur pilus cum alinxotati in palpebra cum pilo naturali.	Then draw out your hand with it until the needle emerges from the eyelid together with the natural eyelash.
Si autem trahatur alinxotati, et non egrediatur pilus cum ea: trahes alinxotati ad inferiora, cum filo quod tu composuisti in ea, donec egrediatur alinxotati ex foramine superiori, et uideas eam uisione oculi: tunc enim trahes alinxotati, et filum: et extrahe utraque, et claude oculum: et dimitte ipsum clausum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec adhaereat pilus loco suo, et nascatur super ipsum caro.	But if the splint is drawn and the needle does not emerge with it; draw out the splint downwards, with the thread you have attached to it, until the splint comes out of the upper opening, and see it with your eye: then draw out the splint and the thread, close up the eye and leave it shut for two or three days, until the eyelash adheres in its place and flesh grows over it.
Quod si pilus est breuis, tunc aut associa ei pilum longum ex pilis naturalibus, et eleuatur cum eo: aut dimitte ipsum, donec elongetur post spacium, et tunc eleua ipsum.	If the eyelash is short then either attach to it a long artificial hair and raise that with it; or leave it alone until it grows longer, and only then lift it up.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae accidit in palpebra superiori.	On the treatment of an abscess which occurs on the upper eyelid.
Caput XIII.	Chapter 13.
Quando accidit oculo haec Alxatrati, nominatur Leporina.	When this abscess happens to the eye, it is called leporina.
Et haec Alxatrati est aut naturalis, aut accidentalis.	And this abscess is either natural or accidental.
Accidentalis ergo fit ex consolidatione uulneris, aut sectionis, aut cauterii, et similium illis.	An accidental one forms from the congealing of a wound or incision, or a burn, or something similar to those.
Et modus operationis in ea est, ut tu findas illam consolidationem, et ut separes labia eius, et ponas in eo quod est inter ea licinium ex lino, et liges eam, donec sanetur.	The method of treating it is to open up the congealed material and separate its lips; you should then put between them a little flaxen wick and bind it until it heals.
Et non oportet, ut utaris in curatione eius rebus quae exiccant et constringunt: nam si tu facis illud, redit Alxatrati deterior quam fuit: imo utere in ea rebus quae mollificant, sicut foenumgraecum: et embroca cum aqua, in qua cocta sit althea, semen lini: et unguento dyaquilon, quod liquefactum sit cum aliquo ex oleis: et inuolue cum eo licinium, et cura cum eo.	And you must not use in its treatment things that dry and constrict; for if you do so the abscess will return worse than it was before: rather use things which soften it, such as fenugreek; and an ointment mixed with water in which marshmallow has been cooked, flax-seed and diaquilaon which has been liquefied with some oil: bind this on with a wick and treat with it.
Et thesaurus curationis tuae est, ut coneris omni ingenio, ut non consolidetur, secundum formam quae fuit in primis.	The treasure of your treatment lies in ensuring that you consider every type of mind so that it does not solidify into the same form as before.
Et haec quidem operatio quam diximus, non est nisi quaedam rectificatio Alxatrati, ut non redeat forma loci secundum quod fuit omnino.	This operation we described is simply a correction of the Alxatrata so that the form of the place does not return to what it was entirely.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae fit in palpebra inferiori, et est rugatio uel contractio sursum ad dextrum et sinistrum.	On treating Alxatrata which occurs on the lower eyelid, and is a wrinkling or contraction upwards to the right and left.
Caput XIIII.	Chapter 14.
Haec Alxatrati quae fit inferius, est quae uere nominatur Alxatrati.	This condition which occurs on the lower eyelid is truly called 'Alxatrata'.
Et est naturalis, et est accidentalis.	And it is natural, and it is accidental.
Et accidentalis fit ex uulnere, aut fissura, aut cauterio, et illis similibus.	It occurs accidentally from a wound or tear, by burning with a hot iron, or similar things.
Et uia operationis in ea est, ut accipias acum, in qua sit filum duplum, et tingas eam in carnem, et facias eam penetrare a lachrymali sinistro usque ad lachrymale dextrum, donec perueniat filum in duabus extremitatibus carnis.	The way to operate on it is to take a needle with double thread and dip it into the flesh; then make it pierce from left to right of the tear duct until the thread comes out at both ends of the flesh.
Deinde extende carnem ad superiora cum acu, et incide eam cum spatumili lato.	Then raise the flesh upwards with the needle and cut it through lengthwise with a wide lancet.
Si ergo redit figura palpebrae secundum quod oportet, est bonum.	If then the form of the eyelid returns as it should be, that is good.
Et si non, accipe radium, et pone ipsum in fissuram, et conuerte cum eo palpebram: et finde duas fissuras in latere interiore palpebrae, et sint extremitates duarum fissurarum ex duobus angulis incisionis, donec concurrant et fiat ex eis angulus: donec quando aggregantur fiat figura earum haec figura, et est litera lauda graeca.	If not, take a splint and place it in the tear; then turn the eyelid with it. Make two incisions on the inside of the eyelid between its two corners so that they meet to form an angle like this: [draws Λ]. When joined together, their shape is the Greek letter lambda (Λ).
Deinde aufer illam carnem per quantitatem, quod est latus eius acutum inferius, ab eo quod sequitur palpebram.	Then remove that flesh in an amount equal to the acute inferior edge of his eye from what follows the eyelid.
Deinde aggrega partes separatas: sue eam cum filo lanae.	Then join together the separated parts, suturing them with woolen thread.
Deinde cura eas cum eo quod diximus, de medicinis mollificantibus, et liciniis, donec sanentur.	Then treat them with what we have said about softening medications and linen dressings until they are healed.
Et si Alxatrati accidat ex fissura, et sutura, aut cauterio: tunc oportet ut findas fissura plana sub pilis palpebrarum, etiam secundum quod praecessit.	And if an abscess occurs from a split or suture, or from cauterization, then you must open the split with a plain scalpel under the eyelashes, likewise what has preceded.
Deinde separa inter duo labia cum licinio, secundum quod diximus.	Then separate between the two lips with linen as we have said.
Et summa sermonis de cura Alxatrati, quando est desuper, aut inferius, est, ut currat in ea operatio, secundum quod praeparatur ex forma Alxatrati.	And the main point about treating an abscess when it is above or below is to carry out that operation as prepared according to the form of the abscess.
Ipsa namque est multarum diuersitatum in forma: et artifex prudens praeparat ingenium cum quocunque modo est possibile ei, donec redire faciat figuram ad formam naturalem, aut prope eam, et ipsemet infirmus, secundum quod conuenit ei ex operatione et instrumentis in plurimis dispositionibus.	For it has many varieties of form: and a prudent practitioner prepares his skill according to whichever mode is possible for him until he restores the figure to its natural shape or close to it, and himself being infirm as befits him from the operation and the instruments in most arrangements.
¶ De adhaerentia palpebrae oculi cum coniunctiua, aut cornea.	On adhesion of the eyelid to the conjunctiva or the cornea.
Caput XV.	Chapter 15.
Quandoque accidit haec consolidatio multis hominibus, ita ut consolidetur palpebra superior cum albedine oculi, et prohibeat ipsum ab operationibus suis naturalibus.	Sometimes this adhesion occurs to many people such that the upper eyelid adheres to the white of the eye and prevents it from its natural movements.
Oportet ergo quod intromittas extremitatem radii sub palpebra, et eleues eam sursum: aut extendas eam cum uncino: deinde incide adhaerentiam cum spatumili subtili, quod non sit cum acuitate incisionis spatumilium, imo sit obtusum parumper: ut non inquietetur infirmus apud operationem, et remoueatur spatumile, et laedat oculum cum acuitate sua: et sit incisio tua quasi tu excories illam adhaerentiam cum facilitate, donec quando redit palpebra secundum formam suam naturalem, et sanetur adhaerentia tota.	You should therefore introduce the end of a needle under the eyelid and lift it up; or extend it with a hook; then cut through the adhesion with a blunt spatula that is not sharp like spatulas usually are but rather somewhat dull: so as not to disturb the patient during the operation, and for the spatula not to be removed and injure the eye with its sharpness; and let your incision be like you would scrape off that adhesion gently until when the eyelid returns to its natural shape and the whole adhesion is healed.
Funde tunc in oculum aquam salsam, cum aqua ablue ipsum: aut distilla in ipsum ex sief facto, ex ziniar dissoluto cum aqua.	Pour some saltwater into the eye and wash it out with water; or drip onto it a mixture of saffron dissolved in water distilled from sieved henbane.
Deinde separa inter palpebram et oculum cum licinio lini: et pone super oculum lanam infusam cum albugine oui: et post diem tertium utere sief, et cum solidatiuis, donec sanetur.	Then separate between the eyelid and the eye using a strip of linen; place over the eye some wool soaked in the white of an egg; after three days use henbane and poultices until it is healed.
¶ De incisione ungulae et eminentiae carnis lachrymarum.	On the excision of ingrown nails and flesh mounds on the eyelids...
Caput XVI.	Chapter 16.
Scias, quod ungula est secundum duos modos.	Know that an ingrown nail is of two types.
Aut est neruosa: et est similis sifac duro, subtili.	It may be horn-like; like hard, thin potsherd.
Aut est non neruosa, similis humiditati congelatae albae: quae quando tangit cam ferrum, aut conaris capere eam cum uncino, abscinditur, et non figitur in ea uncinus.	Or it may be non-horny, like white frozen moisture; when this touches iron or you try to pick it up with a hook, it breaks and is not pierced by the hook.
Et utraeque species non incipiunt, nisi a lachrymali maiore, usquequo uadit paulatim, donec cooperit uisum, et prohibet lumen, et motum oculi.	And neither type begins except from the larger eyelid, gradually growing until it covers sight and hinders movement of the eye.
Et modus operandi in incisione eius est: ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	The method for excising it is as follows: have the patient put their head in your lap.
Deinde aperi oculos eius, et eleua palpebram manu tua.	Then open his eyes and lift up the eyelid with your hand.
Deinde collige ungulam cum uncino paucae duplationis, et extende eam ad superiora.	Then gather the nail using a double-pronged hook, extending it upwards.
Deinde accipe acum, et intromitte in eam pilum ex pilis equi, et bouis, aut uaccae: et sit filum forte, et duplica extremitatem acus parumper, et fige eam in medio ungulae: et penetra eam cum acu, et liga cum filo ungulam, et extende eam ad superiora: et excoria cum pilo latus ungulae quod sequitur pupillam, ac si tu serres eam cum pilo usque ad postreimnum eius.	Next, take a needle and insert into it some horsehair, cattle hair or goat hair; let the thread be strong, double over the needle's end somewhat, then fasten it to the middle of the nail; pierce through with the needle, tie up the nail with the thread, extending it upwards: scrape away the side of the nail that follows after the pupil, as if you were plucking it with hair all the way back.
Deinde incide residuum in radice lachrymalis cum spatumili subtili, aut cum forficibus paruis: et dimitte carnem lachrymalis naturalem, ut non accidat ex incisione eius cursus lachrymarum assiduus.	Then make an incision into the remaining part at the root of the lacrimal sac with a thin spatula or with small scissors; and leave the natural lacrimal flesh untouched so that you do not cause, as a result of its incision, a continuous flow of tears.
Et quandoque extenditur ungula cum uncino solo: aut cum filo, sicut diximus.	And sometimes the claw is extended with only one hook; or with thread, as we have said.
Deinde excoriatur cum spatumili leni, cuius haec est forma.	Then scrape it with a gentle spatula that looks like this [shape].
Et caue, ne tangat spatumile tunicam corneam, et accidat in ea ruptura, et perforetur pupilla.	And be careful not to let the spatula touch the corneal layer so that you do not cause a rupture in it, and the pupil is perforated.
Deinde post incisionem, proice in oculum aliquid salis contriti, aut ex sief facto ex ziniar, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Then after the incision, throw into the eye some ground salt or something made from zinjar and leave it there until the next day.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod oportet, usquequo sanetur.	Then take care of it with what is required until it heals.
Quod si ungula est non neruosa, et non potes intromittere in eam acum, neque figitur in ea uncinus, tunc multotiens curatur haec species ungulae cum medicinis, et sanatur sicut narraui in diuisione.	If the claw is not nervous and you cannot insert a needle into it or hook it, then this type of claw is often treated with medicines and heals as I have described above.
Quod si uis incidere eam, tunc aperi oculum infirmi, et accipe spatumile subtile, lene, debilis acuitatis, secundum hanc formam.	If you want to incise it, then open the sick eye and take a thin spatula that is gentle and blunt, with this shape [shape].
Et rade ungulam desuper rasione cum subtilitate.	And scrape away the claw above with a razor very carefully.
Quod si uides quod ipsa rarificatur et confringitur, et imprimit in eam rasio, tunc distilla ex hora tua in oculum ex sief facto ex ziniar, aut ex sief rubeo, aut sale trito: et opila oculum usque ad diem alium.	If you see that it becomes thinner and breaks under the razor, then drop into the eye from your vessel something made from zinjar or red medicine or ground salt; and bandage the eye until the next day.
Deinde itera super ipsam operationem, donec remoueatur totum eius.	Then repeat this procedure on it until all of it is removed.
Nisi contrarium sit tibi in oculo apostema calidum: tunc enim dimitte ipsam, et cura apostema, donec sanetur.	If there is no pus in your eye and it is warm, then leave it alone and treat the inflammation until it heals.
