Deinde itera operationem super ipsam cum rasione, donec sanetur.	Then repeat the procedure on it with the same method until it is healed.
Eminentia autem carnis lachrymalis, si nocet in oculo nocumento magno, suspendatur cum uncino, et incide ex ea partem eius: et non ultimes incisionem, ut non accidat cursus lachrymarum.	However, if the bulging tear duct flesh is causing significant harm to the eye, it should be suspended with a hook and cut from it its portion; do not go beyond this incision lest there be damage to the tear ducts.
Deinde stilla in lachrymale sief rubeum, aut factum ex ziniari, donec sanetur.	Then put drops into the tear duct of red saffron, or made from cornflower, until it is healed.
¶ De incisione Alguardenic, et carne nata in oculo.	On the incision for Al-Guaradi's disease and flesh born in the eye.
Caput XVII.	Chapter 17.
Nascitur quandoque in quibusdam oculis hominum caro rubea composita, uel superposita, donec cooperit pupillam, aut appropinquat, aut stringit super palpebras, et fortasse conuertit palpebras ad exteriora: et assimilatur rosae balaustinae.	Sometimes a red flesh grows or forms in certain human eyes until it covers the pupil, or approaches it, or contracts above the eyelids; and is like a wild pomegranate.
Et operatio in ea etiam est, ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And there is also an operation for it: the patient must put their head on your lap.
Deinde aperi oculos eius, et collige illam carnem totam cum uncinis conuenientibus ad illud: et tene illud cum forcipe uno, aut gesti.	Then open his eyes and gather all that flesh with appropriate hooks; hold it with a pair of forceps or pincers.
Deinde incide carnem in primis, donec finiatur totum eius cum incisorio.	Then cut the flesh first until its entirety is finished with a scalpel.
Et caue ab oculo, ut non laedas ipsum apud operationem: et sit incisio tua qua ipsam incidis, aut cum spatumili, quod narrauimus in incisione ungulae: aut cum forficibus paruis, cum quibus colligitur asebel, secundum quod ueniet forma eius post hoc capitulum.	Beware of the eye during this operation so that you do not harm it; let your cut be either with a knife or a chisel, which we mentioned in the nail incision: or with small scissors like those used to trim hoofs according to what will come after this chapter.
Cum ergo completur incisio tua, et remouetur tota alguardenici, tunc imple oculum ex sale contrito: aut distilla in eum puluerem rubeum, et similia illi ex medicinis corrosiuis: et pone super oculum deforis cottum cum albugine oui: ut securetur ab apostemate calido.	When your incision is complete and all of the cataract has been removed, fill the eye with crushed salt; or distill into it red powder, and similar corrosive medicines; then place on top of the eye a fresh sheep's bladder (inside out), so that it may be sealed from the hot pus.
Quod si remanet ex alguardenici aliquid, et dominatur tibi sanguis calidus, et times apostema calidum: tunc dimitte oculum, et cura ipsum cum eo quod sedat apostema.	If there is any cataract remaining and you have hot blood and fear a hot pus, then leave the eye alone, and treat it with something that will ease the swelling.
Deinde itera super ipsum cum operatione, donec sanetur.	Next, operate on it again until it is healed.
Et similiter fac cum carne addita quae accidit in oculo ex hac specie.	Do likewise with additional flesh that may happen to occur in the eye from this kind of injury.
Verumtamen oportet, ut alienes curationem omnis oculi debilis ex uia naturali, aut ex uia accidentali, operando cum ferro: et non intromittas manum tuam in aliqua harum operationum, donec uideas, quod illud membrum est tolerans illam operationem.	However, when it comes to treating any eye disease that occurs naturally or accidentally and requires an iron instrument for surgery: do not put your hand into any of these operations until you have seen whether the member can endure such a procedure.
¶ De collectione Sebel ex oculo.	On extracting Sebel from the eye.
Caput XVIII.	Chapter 18.
Sebel sunt uenae rubeae quae texuntur super oculum, et prohibent uisui operationem suam: et debilitant oculum cum longitudine dierum.	Sebel are red veins that grow on the eye, impeding its sight and weaken it over time.
Necesse est ergo tibi in primis, ut consideres, si oculus in quo est Sebel, est fortis, et non est in eo aegritudo aliqua, praeter Sebel: tunc collige Sebel eius.	You must first determine whether the eye with Sebel is strong and otherwise healthy apart from these veins; then collect its Sebel.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo.	And it is right to instruct the patient to lay their head on your lap.
Deinde suspende illas uenas cum uncino uno, aut duobus secundum prudentiam tuam: et sit uncinus subtilis duplationis, secundum hanc formam, aut sint duo uncini gradat in corpore uno, secundum hanc formam.	Then lift the veins with one hook or two according to your judgment; let the hooks be fine and doubled over like this form, or two joined on a single body as here.
Deinde collige cum forficibus subtilibus illas uenas cum subtilitate, et absterge sanguinem hora post horam, donec uideas illas uenas remoueri ex oculo, et resoluuntur: et caue ne laedas oculum cum extremitatibus spatumilis.	Then carefully collect with fine scissors those veins, and wipe away the blood every hour until you see those veins move out of sight and dissolve; be careful not to injure the eye with the tips of the forceps.
Et sit operatio tua in meridie coram sole, et sis firmus in operatione tua ualde: ut non incidas nisi illas uenas.	And let your procedure be done at midday in the sun, and be very firm in your operation; so that you cut only those veins.
Et cum tu expleueris, tunc distilla in oculum sief uiride, aut rubeum: ut sua acuitate corrodat quod remansit ex sebel.	And when you have finished, then distill into the eye either green or red ointment so that its sharpness may dissolve what remains of the sebaceous matter.
Si autem non est tibi possibile colligere illud totum in illa hora, tunc emplastra oculum cum eo, quod sedat dolorem oculi: et dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sedetur dolor eius: et securetur ab apostemate calido: deinde itera super ipsum secundum modum eundem, donec sanetur.	But if you cannot collect all of it in that hour, then apply to the eye a plaster with something in it to relieve the pain; and leave it there for several days until its pain is settled; and let it be bound by a warm poultice; afterwards repeat on it the same procedure until it is healed.
Et haec est forma forficis.	And this is the form of the scissors.
¶ De reductione Arissati ad nasum.	On reducing arietta to the nose.
Caput XIX.	Chapter 19.
Nominant medici Arissati Fistulam, quam curas cum cauterio, aut cum medicina acuta comburente, secundum quod praecessit eius narratio.	Physicians call Arietta a fistula which you treat with the cautery or with caustic medicine according as its history may have preceded.
Et si non sanatur, tunc non est ingenium in ea: nisi ut findas super apostema apud natiuitatem eius, et extrahas totam humiditatem quae est in eo et pus, donec detegatur os.	And if it is not healed then there is no skill in it unless you make an incision over the abscess at its origin and extract all of the moisture that is in it along with the pus until bone is exposed.
Cum ergo detegitur os, et uides in eo corruptionem, aut nigredinem, tunc rade ipsum cum instrumento, cuius forma est haec.	When therefore bone is exposed and you see on it signs of decay or blackness then scrape it with an instrument whose form is this:
Et nominatur Asperi capitis.	And it is called asperation of the bone.
Fiat ex ferro indo, et sit caput eius rotundum sicut azir, quod sit punctatum punctatione limae, aut punctatione aliskilferi punctatione subtili: et pone ipsum super locum corruptum ossis.	The tool should be made of hardened iron, and its head should be round like a whetstone, marked with fine grooves either by a file or an engraver's tool; place it on the damaged bone.
Deinde reuolue ipsum inter digitos tuos, et tu preme manum tuam parumper, donec scias quod illa corruptio iam rasa est: et fac illud aliquotiens.	Then roll it between your fingers, and press your hand for a moment until you feel that the damage has been smoothed away; do this several times.
Deinde restaura locum cum medicinis exiccatiuis stipticis.	Then restore the area with drying, astringent medicines.
Si ergo consolidatur locus, et nascitur in eo caro, et abscinditur cursus saniei: et remanet quadraginta diebus, et non renouatur, et non apostematur, et non accidit in eo accidens: tunc scias quia iam sanatus est.	If the area becomes firm and flesh grows there, and the course of the infection is cut off, and it remains so for forty days without any renewal or swelling, nor does anything untoward happen to it; then you may know that it has now healed.
Et si non, tunc non est in eo ingenium, nisi reducere fistulam ad foramen nasi, secundum hanc formam.	And if not, then there is no other treatment except to bring the fistula back out through the nostril, following this pattern.
Et est, ut detegas ab osse secundo cum ferro, aut cum medicina acuta: et cum detectum est os, tunc accipe terebrum secundum hanc formam, sit extremitas ferrea, triangulata: et lignum eius sit pyramis extenuata usque ad extremitatem, sicut uides.	And it is done by exposing the second bone with a sharp iron or medicine; and when you have exposed that bone, take an auger like this one, its tip being of iron, triangular in shape; and its wood should be like a pyramid, tapering to the end as shown here.
Deinde pone illud super os ipsum: et sit illud prope lachrymale: et elonga manum tuam ab oculo parum.	Then place it over that bone, close to the tear duct; and extend your hand a little away from the eye.
Deinde reuolue manum tuam cum terebro, donec penetret os, et sentiat illud infirmus: per hoc quod inuenit uentum exire ex eo, quando tenet manum suam super nasum suum.	Then turn your hand with the auger until it penetrates the bone and feels weak; through this you will know that air is escaping from it when they hold their hand over their nose.
Ergo tunc restaura locum cum medicinis stipticis exiccantibus, sicut docui te.	So then restore the area with astringent drying medicines as I have taught you.
Cum ergo nascitur caro, et induratur locus: tunc materia quae effundebatur ad exteriora, redit ad nasum: est ergo leuius illud super infirmum.	When flesh grows and the area hardens, then any matter that used to escape outwards now returns to the nose; so it is lighter over the weak spot.
¶ De reductione eminentiae Oculi.	The treatment for a protruding eye.
Caput XX.	Chapter 20.
Quando eminet Oculus cum totalitate sua, et non accidit in uisu nocumentum, neque diminutio: tunc oportet ut soluas infirmum: deinde phlebotomes eum: postea ponas uentosas in ceruice absque scarificatione, sed cum suctione.	When the eye bulges with all its parts and there is no damage to vision or diminution of sight, then one must cure the weak person by first bleeding them; afterwards place cups on their neck without scarring but using suction.
Deinde pone super Oculum linimentum quod fit ex acacia, et aloe, et olibano, et sarcocolla.	Then apply to the eye a poultice made of acacia, aloe, frankincense, and storax.
Deinde stringe Oculum desuper super emplastrum cum puluillis multis.	After that compress the eye from above with many soft feathers.
Et modus puluillorum est: ut accipias pannos lenes, multos, et duplicetur omnis pannus ex eis super quatuor: fac ex eis multos: deinde pone eos unum super alium, secundum quantitatem qua indiget Oculus: deinde stringe super ipsos cum panno duro strictura forti.	And the method of applying the feathers is as follows: take many soft cloths and fold each one four times; make a stack of these then place them on top of each other according to how much the eye requires; finally, secure them firmly with a hard cloth bandage.
Et itera uentosas cum suctione sine scarificatione.	And repeat the cups with suction without scarring.
Deinde aufer uentosas, et dimitte oculum strictum die et nocte.	After that remove the cups and leave the eye bandaged day and night.
Si autem ligamentum iterum mollificatur, tunc oportet ut stringatur multum: deinde aufer ligamentum post diem et noctem, sicut diximus.	But if the bandage softens again then it must be tightened repeatedly; afterwards remove the bandage after a day and night as I've said.
Si ergo uides oculum iam redisse uuae tunicae, est bonum: et si non, tunc itera emplastrum, et puluillos, et stricturam, et uentosas, donec sanetur.	When you see the eye has returned to its proper skin it's good; if not then repeat the poultice and feathers and bandage and cups until cured.
¶ De incisionie Vuae tunicae.	The treatment for a cut of the skin's membrane.
Caput XXI.	Chapter 21.
Quando accidit disruptio in tunica Vuea, deinde eminet et procedit extra palpebras sicut granum Vuae, et foedatur forma hominis propter illud, et uis incidere illud: tunc operatio in eo est, secundum quod narro: et est, ut intromittas acum in radice Vuae ab inferiori ad superiorem partem.	When there is a rupture of the membrane of the skin and it protrudes outside the eyelids like a grain of wheat, disfiguring the appearance of the person and requiring an incision to be made then surgery on that is as follows, which I will describe: you should insert a needle at the base of the membrane from below towards above.
Deinde intromitte acum aliam in qua sit filum duplum a parte lachrymalis, et fac eam penetrare: et dimitte acum primam secundum dispositionem suam.	Then insert another needle into which is placed double thread from the tear duct side, and make it penetrate; and remove the first needle according to its position.
Deinde incide locum fili dupli, et liga cum eo partem Vuae in circumitu acus: et stringe eam multum.	Then cut the place of double thread and tie it to a portion of the eyelid around the needle; then tighten it greatly.
Deinde extrahe acum, et pone super oculum lanam infusam in albugine oui: et dimitte eum, donec cadat filum cum Vua.	Then extract the needle and place over the eye wool soaked in white of egg; then leave it until the thread falls out with the eyelid.
Deinde cura oculum cum eo, quod confortat ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	Then treat the eye with that which strengthens it until the wound heals.
Et quandoque stringitur Vua ab omni parte cum circulo ex panno, donec addat oculus eminentiam magnam.	And sometimes the eyelid is tightened from all sides with a circle of cloth until the eye becomes greatly prominent.
Deinde perforetur cum spatumili subtili, quod perueniat ad profundum oculi, et currat humiditas albuginea, et descendat oculus, et ingrediatur statim: deinde stringe eum, donec sanetur.	Then the eye should be pierced with a fine spatula that reaches down to the depth of the eye; let moisture run into the white of the eye and the eye shall return in immediately; then tighten it until the wound heals.
¶ De curatione Alcomnati.	On the cure of alcomania.
Caput XXII.	Chapter 22.
Haec Aegritudo quae nominatur Alcomnati, non, est nisi sanies, quae aggregatur in oculo, similis aquae descendenti, et non est ipsa.	This illness which is called alcomania is nothing but pus that accumulates in the eye, like water running down, and it itself is not water.
Et modus operandi in ea est, ut facias sedere infirmum super sedem praeparatum, uel directum.	And the manner of operating on it is to make the patient sit on a prepared seat or upright.
Deinde accipe caput eius manibus tuis a partibus duabus, et moue ipsum, donec uideas saniem peruenire ad inferiora oculis tuis.	Then take his head in both your hands and move it until you see the pus reach below his eyes.
Deinde figatur, et non descendat, et absoluatur lumen: et uideat infirmus res sicut uidebat: et si non descendit inferius, scias quia est aqua.	Then it is tied up so that it does not fall and the eye is cleared; and the patient sees things as he used to see them: and if it has not fallen below, know that it is water.
Si autem non praeparatur descensus saniei cum eo quod diximus, tunc fac sedere infirmum inter manus tuas.	If, however, the descent of pus is not prepared with what we have said, then make the patient sit between your hands.
Deinde accipe spatumile subtile, et finde cum eo supra panniculum corneum parumper apud continuationem coniunctiuae cum tunica cornea in corona, donec egrediatur sanies.	Then take a thin spatula, and scrape with it over the hard crust for a little while near where the connective tissue joins the hard crust until pus appears.
Cum ergo egreditur, tunc distilla in oculum aquam calidam in qua miscuisti mel: aut aquam in qua iam bullisti foenumgraecum et mel: deinde curetur cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	When it appears, then drop into the eye warm water in which you have mixed honey; or water in which you have already boiled fenugreek and honey; then treat with the remaining treatment until it is healed.
¶ De cura aquae, quae descendit in oculo, uel cataracta.	On the treatment of water that descends into the eye or cataract.
Caput XXIII.	Chapter 23.
Iam Diximus species aquae in diuisione, et quae conuenit ad perforandum sermone declarante et exponente, tunc accipe illud idem secundum sanitatem.	We have already spoken about the types of water in the section, and what is suitable for boring; now take that same according to health.
Tunc ergo oportet ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas quadratum, oppositum lumini, prope solem: et liga oculum eius sanum, et stringe eum ualde: deinde palpebram oculi eius manu tua dextra, si oculus in quo est aqua, est oculus sinister: aut manu tua sinistra, si oculus est dexter.	Then you must make the patient sit square between your hands opposite a light near the sun; and tie his healthy eye shut, pulling it tight; then with your right hand hold down the eyelid of his eye if it is the left eye that has water in it; or with your left hand if it is the right eye.
Deinde accipe manu tua dextra almagda, si oculus est sinister: aut manu tua sinistra, si oculus est dexter.	Then take in your right hand an almond if it is the left eye; or in your left hand if it is the right eye.
Deinde pone extremitatem almagda prope coronam per grossitudinem radii in ipsa albedine oculi apparente lachrymalis minoris: deinde impelle almagda cum uirtute: et tu reuoluis cum eo manum tuam, donec penetret in albuginem oculi: et sentias, quod almagda iam peruenit ad rem uacuam.	Then place the end of the almond near the edge where the white of the eye appears around the size of a spoke; then push with force on the almond; and you turn your hand with it until it penetrates the white of the eye: and feel that the almond has now reached an empty space.
Et oportet, ut sit mensura itineris almagda ad profundum, mensura spacii quod est a pupilla usque ad finem nigredinis: et est corona oculi.	And it is necessary for the length of the needle to reach the depth [of the wound], and its width should be from the pupil to the end of the black part, which is the iris.
Uidebis enim ea in ipsa pupilla uisione oculi, propter claritatem tunicae corneae.	You will see them in the pupil itself due to the clarity of the cornea.
Deinde pone almagda usque ad locum in quo est aqua.	Then place the needle up to the spot where the water is.
Deinde preme ipsum inferius uice una post aliam.	Then press it downwards with force, one after another.
Si ergo descendit aqua statim, tunc infirmus uidet illud super quod aperit uisum suum statim, et almagda in oculo suo.	If the water then descends immediately, the patient will see what is opened before his sight and the needle in his eye.
Deinde quiescas paululum.	Then rest for a short while.
Si ergo descendat aqua, tunc depone eam secundo, praeter quod egrediatur almagda.	If the water descends again, then remove it for a second time, except that the needle is withdrawn.
Quando ergo figitur, et non ascendit: tunc extrahe almagda cum facilitate: et tu reuoluis manum tuam paulatim.	When it stops moving, but doesn't rise, then extract the needle with ease, and you turn your hand little by little.
Deinde dissolue in aqua aliquid ex sale claro gemmae: et ablue cum eo oculum deintus.	Then dissolve some clear rock salt in the water, and wash the eye thoroughly with it.
Deinde pone extra oculum totum stuppam, aut lanam infusam oleo rosato, et albugine oui: et liga cum eo oculum sanum.	Then place over the eye a whole piece of linen cloth or woolen material steeped in rose oil and white of egg; bind the sound eye with it.
Nos autem, et illi qui sunt nostri temporis, ponimus super eum ciminum tritum cum albumine oui.	We, however, and those of our time, place over it powdered cumin with white of egg.
Quod si non obedit tibi almagda ad introitum in oculum propter duriciem suam, quoniam ex hominibus est, cuius oculus est durus ualde: tunc oportet ut accipias spatumile, quod nominatur Alberid, cuius haec est forma.	If the needle doesn't yield to you in entering the eye because of its hardness; for it is made of iron, whose eye [i.e., sight] is very hard; then you must take a spatula called an *alberid*, which has this form.
Pefora ergo cum eo ipsam coniunctiuam tantum, et non ultimes manum tuam in foramine: et non est nisi ut facias uiam ad almagda locum subtilem.	Pierce therefore only its joint, and do not push your hand into the hole; it is enough to make a path towards the almond-shaped spot.
Deinde intromitte almagda, secundum quod diximus.	Then introduce the almond-shaped instrument as we have described.
Et apud complementum operis tui, praeparetur infirmo dormitorium decenter factum, in quo dormiat super dorsum suum in domo tenebrosa: et prohibeatur ab omnibus motibus, et a tussi: et pone cibum eius illud quo lenitur natura eius: et non moueat caput suum dextra, neque sinistra omnino.	And when your work is complete, prepare for the patient a decently made bedroom in which they can sleep on their back in a dark room; prohibit any movement or coughing; provide them with food that soothes their nature; and ensure they do not move their head to the right or left at all.
Et sit ligamentum secundum dispositionem suam usque ad diem tertium.	And let the bandage remain in place according to its arrangement for three days.
Deinde solue illud in illa domo tenebrosa, et experire uisum eius: et fac eum uidere res.	Then loosen it in the dark room and test his vision; make him see things.
Deinde reduc ligamentum usque ad diem septimum.	Then replace the bandage until the seventh day.
Et non oportet ut faciat illud in hora curationis, aut post incisionem statim: imo oportet, ut alienes illud: propterea quod aqua ascendit uelociter per aspectum uehementem.	It should not be done at the time of treatment or immediately after the incision; instead, it must be avoided because water rises quickly through a strong current.
Si autem accidit apostema calidum: tunc oportet ut soluas oculum ante septimum: et rectifica illud cum eo quod sedat apostema, donec sedatur: tunc absolue ipsius uisum, et pone super faciem eius orale quo regatur uisus eius sub eo diebus aliquot, ipso existente in illa domo tenebrosa.	But if a hot abscess occurs, then you should loosen the eye before the seventh day; and treat it with something that will calm the abscess until it is calmed; then restore his vision and place an eye mask over his face to regulate his sight for several days while he remains in the dark room.
Deinde egrediatur a domo gradatim, et conuersetur in casis suis.	Then they should leave the house gradually and return to their homes.
Et scias, quod in zaltea non excusatur discipulus a uisione aliquotiens: tunc enim audeat super operationem.	And you should know that a student is not exempt from vision training at the zaltea; for then he will dare to perform operations.
Et iam quidem peruenit ad nos quidam ex illis qui sunt de Alayrach, qui dixit, quod factum fuit in Alayrach magdan perforatum, quo sugitur aqua.	And now a certain person from Alayrach has reached us who said that there was a woman in Alayrach with a perforated stomach from which water is drawn.
Verum ergo non uidi aliquem in terra uostra, qui fecerit illud: neque legi illud in aliquo ex libris antiquorum: et est possibile, ut sit illud nouum.	But therefore I have not seen anyone in your land who has done this; nor have I read it in any of the books of the ancients: and it is possible that it is new.
Et istae sunt formae specierum ex magda, ut stet super ea qui ea ignorat.	And these are the forms of appearances from a woman, as she stands upon it who is ignorant of it.
Fiant ex aere proprie: et sint extremitates eorum cum hac eadem subtilitate triangulatae, et extremitas acuta.	Let them be made from pure brass; and their ends should have the same triangular delicacy, with an acute point.
Formae magda.	The form of a woman.
¶ De cura Carnis natae in naso.	On the treatment of nasal polyps.
Caput XXIIII.	Chapter 24.
Quandoque nascuntur in naso Carnes diuersae additae, ex quibus est aliquid quod assimilatur scorpioni multorum pedum: et ex ea est caro cancerosa, lapidea, fusci coloris: et ex ea est quae est caro lenis, non fusci coloris.	Sometimes there grow in the nose various polyps, one of which resembles a many-legged scorpion; and from this arises a polyp that is hard like a stone, dark coloured, cancerous; and from it also arises one that is soft, not dark coloured.
In ea ergo quae ex istis carnibus est lenis, non fraudulenta, neque cancerosa, oportet ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas oppositum soli, et aperi nares eius, et proiice uncinum in illas carnes: deinde trahe eas ad exteriora, et incide quod comprehendisti ex eis cum spatumili subtili acuto a parte una, donec scias quod caro tota iam ablata est.	For the soft polyp, which is neither deceitful nor cancerous, you should make the patient sit between your hands facing the sun, and open his nostrils; then throw a hook into those polyps; next draw them out, and cut what you have seized of them with a thin sharp scalpel on one side until you know that all the flesh is now removed.
Quod si remaneret aliquid ex ea cuius abscisio non est possibilis: tunc rade illud cum uno instrumentorum subtilium cum facilitate, donec non remaneat ex eo aliquid.	But if anything of it should remain which cannot be removed; then shave it with one of the delicate instruments with ease until nothing remains of it.
Si autem sanguis tibi dominatur, aut accidat apostema calidum: tunc oppone ei per id quod oportet: aut est ex apostematibus malignis, tunc propera cauterizando eum, donec abscindatur sanguis, et auferantur omnes carnes.	If blood dominates you or a hot abscess develops, then oppose it with what is necessary: if it is one of the malignant abscesses, proceed to cauterize it until the blood stops flowing and all flesh is removed.
Deinde proiiciatur in nasum post incisionem acetum, et aqua, aut uinum.	Then after the incision, vinegar should be thrown into the nostril followed by water or wine.
Si autem aperitur nasus, et procedat ex eo humiditas usque ad palatum, tunc scias quia iam sanus est.	If the nostril opens up and moisture begins to come out of it all the way to the palate, then you will know that they are already healthy again.
Si uero non penetrat humiditas, secundum quod oportet, tunc scias quod intra ipsum est caro nata in superioribus ossibus naris, ad quae non peruenit cum incisione instrumentum.	If the moisture does not penetrate as it should then you will know that flesh has grown within its depths around the upper nasal bones which the instrument did not reach with the incision.
Tunc ergo oportet, ut intromittas filum lini cui sit quaedam grossitudo, et noda in eo nodos multos: et pone inter omnem nodum quantitatem digiti, aut minus: et ingeniet infirmus, ut mittat extremitatem unam fili in nasum cum radio, aut cum quo possibile est ei postquam fecerit ipsum simile azer: et trahat odoratum suum, donec perueniat usque ad caassum, et egrediatur super guttur suum.	You should then introduce a piece of linen thread of a certain thickness with many knots along it and leave between each knot the length of a finger or less: and have the sick person put one end of the thread in their nose as far as possible after you make it similar to an arrow: and they pull on its smell until it comes out at their throat.
Et multotiens quidem faciunt simile huic Attomi pueri in scholis: et est res facilis ei, qui uult.	And many children do something similar to this as a trick in school: and it is an easy thing for whoever wants to do it.
Deinde pone duas extremitates fili, extremitatem unam quae egreditur super nasum, et alteram quae remansit in naso.	Then take the two ends of the thread: one that comes out over the nose and another which remains within it.
Deinde ac ministra serraturam carnis cum nodis qui sunt in filo.	Then take the flesh clamp and fix its teeth to the knots on the thread.
Fac illud donec scias quod carnes iam sunt cum nodis fili.	Do this until you know that the flesh is now attached to the knots of the thread.
Deinde extrahe filum: et pone in nasum post abstersionem sanguinis licinium quod imbibisti in unguento aegyptio: fac illud tribus diebus, aut plus, donec unguentum corrodat totum quod remansit ex carnibus.	Then pull out the thread and put into the nose after washing away the blood lint that you have soaked in Egyptian ointment: do this for three days or more until all of the remaining flesh is eaten away by the ointment.
Deinde pone in fine rei in nasum cannulam de plumbo, diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	Then place a lead pipe in the end of the thing into the nose for several days until it heals.
Si autem indiget curatione quae exiccet, utere illa.	If however it requires treatment that dries it up, use this.
Ad caputpurgium faciendum, cum quo distillantur olea, et aliae medicinae in nasum, fac illud ex argento, aut aere: quod sit simile lampadi paruae, apertum sicut conchula: et meatus eius similiter.	For making the nasal douche with which oils and other medicines are distilled into the nose, make it out of silver or brass; let it be similar to a small lamp, open like a seashell; and its nozzle likewise.
Et si uis fac cannulam clausam, sicut canna.	And if you wish make the pipe closed, like a cane.
Et conchula instrumenti ad caputpurgium faciendum, sit plena, detecta: cui sit manubrium in postremo eius, cum quo teneas ipsam, quando calefacis in ea oleum, aut quod uis ex succis, et rebus fluxibilibus.	And the small seashell of the instrument for making a nasal douche should be full and open: it should have a handle at its end with which you hold it when heating oil or whatever liquid in it that you want.
Et haec est forma instrumenti.	And this is the shape of the instrument.
¶ De cura Thelul nasi.	On the treatment of nasal polyps.
Caput XXV.	Chapter 25.
Multotiens nascitur in extremitate nasi Thelul, et magnificatur, et augmentatur cum diebus, donec foedus fit aspectus eius.	Many times there appears at the end of the nose a polyp that grows larger with time until it disfigures its appearance.
Et propter illud oportet, ut in cidas illud in principio apparitionis eius, et eradices totum eius.	And because of that it is necessary to attack it at the beginning of its appearance and eradicate all of it.
Deinde pone super locum, aut cauterium, aut medicinam comburentem quae stat loco eius.	Then put over the place either a caustic substance or a burning medicine that stays in its place.
Si ergo tardatur incisio eius, donec magnificetur, tunc considera, si est lapideum, durum, fusci coloris, pauci sensus: tunc non tangas ipsum cum ferro: quoniam apostema est cancerosum.	If therefore you delay its excision until it grows larger, then consider whether it is of stony hardness and dark-coloured with little sensation; then do not touch it with the iron, for it is a cancerous ulcer.
Multotiens enim uidi, qui incidit hmoni apostema, et accidit ex eo malicia magna super illum qui ipsum habebat.	Many times I have seen someone who cuts out such an ulcer and a great harm befalls the one who had it.
Et si apostema est lenis tactus, non fusci coloris, et uides quod incisio possibilis est in toto eius, tunc euacua infirmum, et incide ipsum sine timore, absque pauore: et cura locum cum eo quod exiccat et constringit, donec sanetur.	If the abscess is soft to the touch, not dark in color, and you see that incision is possible throughout it, then evacuate the patient's fluids, and make the incision without fear or hesitation: treat the area with a drying and constricting agent until it heals.
¶ De sutura nasi, et labii, et auris.	On sewing together the nose, lip, and ear.
Caput XXVI.	Chapter 26.
Scias Quia quando accidit solutio continuitatis in una harum cartilaginum, parum confert in ea operatio, nisi in quibusdam hominibus.	Know that when there is a break of continuity in one of these cartilages, surgery will not be of much help, except in some people.
Oportet ergo quando accidit alicui aliquid ex illo, ut consideres, si est uulnus recens cum sanguine suo: et tunc aggrega duolabia uulneris cum sutura: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Therefore, when something like this happens to someone, you should consider whether it is a fresh wound with its own blood; and then bring together the two lips of the wound with a suture; afterwards treat it until it heals.
Et si solutionis continuitatis labia iam separata sunt, et facta est unaquaeque pars sana: tunc oportet ut excories omnem partem a cute sua apparente, donec sanguinetur.	And if the lips of a break in continuity are already separated and each side has healed over, then you must scrape away all the tissue down to the bleeding flesh.
Deinde aggrega duo labia cum sutura, et stringe ea, et pulueriza super ipsum sanguinem draconis, et olibanum trita: et pone supra pulueres frustum emplastri diafinicon, et alicuius alterius ex emplastris consolidatiuis: et dimitte ipsum ligatum duobus diebus, aut tribus.	Afterwards bring the two lips together with a suture and tighten them; sprinkle over it powdered dragon's blood and ground frankincense; put on top of these powders a piece of fine wax plaster, and another of the harder consolidating plasters; leave this bound up for two or three days.
Deinde solue ipsum, et permuta medicinam: et dimitte ipsum, donec abscindantur fila per se.	Then remove the bandage and change the dressing; leave it until the threads come away by themselves.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Afterwards treat it with an ointment until it heals.
Modus autem suturae est, ut aggreges solutionem continuitatis, aut cum acubus, sicut narrauimus in sutura uentris: aut aggrega solutionem cum filo, sicut feci te scire.	The method of sewing is that you bring together the break in continuity either with needles as we described for the abdomen; or bring it together using thread as I have made you aware.
¶ De extractione nodorum labiorum.	On the extraction of lip nodules.
Caput XXVII.	Chapter 27.
Multis Quidem hominibus accidunt plaerumque in interioribus labiorum suorum apostemata dura similia granis herbi: et quaedam eorum minora, et maiora.	Hard nodules resembling grains of grass often occur for many people on the inner parts of their lips; some are smaller while others are larger.
Ergo oportet ut conuertas labium, et findas super omnem nodum eius, et suspendas ipsum cum uncino, et incidas ipsum ab omni parte.	Therefore, you must turn back the lip and cut above all of its nodules; suspend it with a hook and then slice through it on all sides.
Deinde impleas locum post incisionem zegi trito, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Next fill the place after incision with ground gallic nettle until it stops bleeding.
Deinde colluatur cum aceto, et curetur locus cum eo, in quo est stipticitas, usquequo sanentur uulnera.	Afterwards it should be washed with vinegar; the wound site is to be treated with an astringent until the wounds heal.
¶ De incisione carnis natae super gingiuam.	On the excision of excess flesh over the gums.
Caput XXVIII.	Chapter 28.
Multotiens nascitur super gingiuam caro addiat, quam antiqui nominant abuluss.	Many times excess flesh grows over the gums; this is what the ancients call abuluss.
Oportet ergo ut suspendas eam cum uncino: aut teneas eam cum forcipibus, et incidas eam apud radicem suam, et dimittas saniem currere, aut sanguinem.	It is necessary to hook it or grab with forceps and cut at its base; allow blood (or pus) to run from the wound.
Deinde pone super locum zegi tritum, aut alios pulueres stipticos, exiccatiuos.	Afterwards apply ground gallic nettle or other drying astringent powders to the wound.
Quod si redit illa caro post curationem, nam multotiens redit, tunc incide eam secundo, et cauteriza ipsam: ipsa namque non redit post cauterium.	If this flesh returns following treatment, as it often does, then cut away a second time and cauterize; for it will not return after being burnt.
¶ De rasione Dentium cum ferro.	On tooth extraction with an iron tool.
Caput XXIX.	Chapter 29.
Quandoque aggregantur in superficiebus Dentium ab interiori et extetiori parte, et inter gingiuas cortices asperi, turpes, et quandoque denigrantur, et citrini fiunt, et uirides, donec peruenit ex illo corruptio ad gingiuam, et foedi fiunt dentes per illud.	Sometimes rough, ugly layers of enamel accumulate on the inner and outer surfaces of teeth and between the gums; sometimes they darken and become yellow and green until corruption reaches the gum from it, making teeth foul-looking.
Oportet ergo ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas, et caput eius in sinu tuo, et rade molam et dentem, in quo apparent tibi cortices, et res similis arenae: donec non remaneat ex eis aliquid, et similiter fac de nigredine, et uiriditate, et citrinitate, et aliis donec mundentur.	Therefore, you should make the patient sit between your hands and rest his head on your lap; then scrape away the enamel as well as any part of it that looks like grit in a millstone; do this until no trace is left, and treat blackness, yellowness and greenness similarly until they are cleaned off.
Si ergo auferatur quod in eis est a principio rasionis, bonum est: et si non, tunc itera super eos rasionem die alio, secundo, et tertio, donec ad ultimum perueniat studium in eo quod uis.	If you remove the cause of these conditions early on, that's good; if not, repeat your treatment every day for two or three days until finally you reach where it is you want to get at.
Et scias, quod dens indiget rasoriis diuersarum formarum, multarum figurarum: secundum quod praeparatur operationi tuae: proptera, quod rasorium quo raditur dens ab inferiori parte, est aliud a rasorio quo raditur inter dentes, secundum formas alias.	Also be aware that you will need scalpels of different shapes and sizes for preparing the tooth before your treatment; since the scalpel used to scrape off its lower surface is not the same as the one used to clean between teeth, given their differing forms.
Et istae formae rasoriorum sint apud te praeparatae, quas uides.	And have these various types of scalpel ready for use as you see fit.
¶ De extractione doloris Dentium.	On toothache extraction.
Caput XXX.	Chapter 30.
Oportet ut cures Dentem a dolore suo cum omni ingenio, et tardes in eradicatione eius.	You must relieve the tooth of its pain with all your skill, but be slow to extract it.
Non est enim quod uicem eius suppleat quando eradicatur: quoniam est substantia sublimis: donec quando non est excusatio de eradicatione eius, tunc oportet quando cogitur infirmus eradicare ipsum, ut firmetur, et certificetur apud te dens dolens.	For once it is extracted, there can be no replacement; so significant a thing is lost; unless there's simply no other option but to extract it, then you should strengthen and reassure the patient about the offending tooth when forced to pull it out.
Multotiens enim decipit infirmum dolor, et putat quia est in dente saha et eradicat ipsum: deinde non recedit dolor, donec eradicetur dens infirmus.	Frequently, pain deceives the sick person, and they think that the ache is in a healthy tooth and pull it out; then the pain does not subside until the sick tooth is pulled.
Nos enim iam uidimus illud ex operatione phlebotomatorum.	For we have already seen this from the practice of blood-letters.
Cum ergo certificatur apud te dens dolens ipsemet, tunc oportet ut scarifices in circumitu dentis cum spatumili, in quo sit quiddam uirtutis, donec soluatur gingiua ab omni parte: deinde moue ipsum digitis tuis, aut cum forcipibus subtilibus in primis paulatim, donec concutias ipsum.	So when the sick tooth is certified by you, then it is necessary that you sacrifice at the vicinity of the tooth with a spatula having some virtue, until the gum is loosened from every part; then move the tooth with your fingers or with thin forceps especially little by little, until you shake it.
Deinde loca tunc in eo forcipes magnos locatione bona, et caput infirmi inter genua tua: quod iam bene tenuisti, ita quod non moueatur: deinde trahe dentem secundum rectitudinem, ut non frangas ipsum.	Then place large forceps in a good position there, and put the head of the sick person between your knees; which you have held well so that it does not move; then draw the tooth according to its straight line so as not to break it.
Si ergo non egreditur, tunc accipe aliquod illorum instrumentorum, et intromitte ipsum sub eo ab omni parte cum facilitate, et conare motionem eius, sicut fecisti in primis.	If it does not come out then take one of those instruments and insert it under the tooth from every part gently, and try its movement as you did before.
Si autem dens est perforatus, aut corrosus: tunc oportet ut impleas illud foramen panno: et stringas ipsum cum extremitate radii subtilis, ut non frangatur in hora constrictionis tuae super ipsum cum forcipibus.	But if the tooth is perforated or corroded then it is necessary that you fill that hole with cloth; and bind it with the end of a thin stick so that it does not break at the time of your tightening over it with forceps.
Et oportet, ut exquisite agas cum scarificatione in circumitu gingiuae ab omni parte multum.	And you must take great care with the scarification around the gum from every part.
Et custodi fortitudinem tuam, ut non frangas ipsum, et remaneat pars eius, et redeat super infirmum ex ea malicia quae sit maior dolore eius primo.	And guard your strength so as not to break it and leave a part of the tooth which will return to the sick person with an evil pain greater than at first.
Et caue, ne facias illud quod ignorantes faciunt phlebotomatores in festinatione sua, et audacia ipsorum super eradicationem eius, praeter quod administrent illud quod narrauimus.	And beware of doing what ignorant blood-letters do in their haste and boldness over pulling it out, besides administering what we have narrated.
Multotiens enim faciunt euenire super homines infirmitates magnas, quarum difficiliores sunt ut frangantur, et remaneant radices eius omnes, aut quaedam earum: aut ut extrahant ipsum cum quibusdam ossibus mandibulae: sicut testificati sumus multotiens illud.	They often inflict upon people serious injuries that are difficult to treat; either because some or all of the roots remain after it is broken, or when they remove it along with certain jaw bones - we have witnessed this many times.
Deinde colluatur post eradicationem eius cum uino, aut cum aceto et sale.	It should then be boiled after its removal with wine or vinegar and salt.
Quod si accidat fluxus sanguinis ex locis (multotiens enim accidit) tunc tere aliquid ex zegi, et imple cum eo locum: et si non, cauteriza ipsum si non confert tibi zegi.	If there is any bleeding from the wound (which often happens), grind some zegi and fill the wound with it; if this does not work, cauterise it instead - unless you do not have any zegi available.
Formae forcipum subtilium quibus mouetur dens in primis, sint longarum extremitatum, breuis manubrii, grossi, ut non duplicentur quando cum eis premitur super dentem: sint sicut uides grossorum manubriorum, donec quando stringis cum eis, non dent seipsas, neque duplicentur: breuium extremitatum, et sint ex ferro indo, aut ex faled decenter facti, directarum extremitatum: et in eorum extremitatibus sint dentes, quorum quidam ingrediantur in quosdam, et stringant constrictione decenti, forti.	The handles of the dental forceps should be long and short-handled, with thick heads so that they do not bend when pressed against a tooth; you can make these thicker at the handle to prevent them from crossing over each other as you close them: make the ends of the handles broad as well, such that even if you clamp down on them very hard, they will not cross over or damage one another. The ends should be made out of good iron and not cheap steel; the heads should have teeth which lock together tightly without slipping when clamped down with force.
Et quandoque fiunt extremitates sicut forma oris auis quae nominatur ciconia, et sunt fortis constrictionis.	And sometimes the heads of the handles are made in the form of a bird's beak, like that of a stork, with a strong, firm grip.
¶ De eradicatione Dentium, et extractione ossium mandibularum fractorum.	On the removal of teeth, and extraction of fractured jaw bones.
Caput XXXI.	Chapter 31.
Quando remanet apud eradicationem Dentis qui frangitur aliquid, tunc oportet ut ponas super locum cotum cum butyro die uno, aut duobus diebus, donec mollificetur locus: deinde intromitte ad ipsum algasti, aut forcipes: quorum extremitates assimilantur ori auis quae nominatur ciconia.	If any fragments remain after a broken tooth is removed, pack the site with butter for one or two days to soften it; then insert either an alum plug or forceps whose ends are shaped like a stork's beak into this softened area and extract.
Forma autem haec est forcipum.	This is the form of the forceps.
Sint extremitates eorum factae sicut lima deintus: aut sicut aliskilfegi.	Their ends should be made like a rasp inside; or like the claw of a cat.
Si ergo non obedit tibi ad exitum cum istis forcipibus, tunc oportet, ut caues super radicem, et detegas carnem totam, et intromittas instrumentum quod nominatur Palanca parua, cuius forma est haec.	If therefore it does not obey you at the exit with these forceps, then it is necessary for you to hollow out over the root, and remove all of the flesh, and insert the instrument which is named small Palanca, whose form is this.
Sit breuis extremitatis, grossae parumper: et non sit imbibitum, ut non frangatur.	Let the end be short, somewhat thick; and let it not be sharp so that it does not break.
Si ergo egreditur radix per illud, est bonum: et si non, iuuare oportet cum istis instrumentis aliis quorum formae sunt istae.	If therefore the root exits through it, that is good; and if not, you should help with these other instruments whose forms are these.
Forma primi triangulatae extremitatis, in qua est quaedam grossitudo.	The form of the first is triangular at its end, on which there is some thickness.
Forma triangulatae extremitatis subtilis.	The form of the second is triangular at its end, but thin.
Etiam iuuatur cum hoc instrumento habente duos ramos, cuius haec est forma.	It may also be aided with this instrument which has two branches, whose form is this.
Et cum aliis instrumentis et ferramentis quae praecesserunt in rasione dentium.	And with other instruments and tools that have been mentioned previously in relation to teeth.
Etiam sit iuuamentum cum hoc instrumento quod assimilatur uncino magno, huius formae, triangulatae extremitatis tortae, in qua est quiddam grossitudinis, ut non frangatur: et sit non imbibitum.	There is also assistance with this instrument which resembles a large hook, of this form, twisted triangular end, on which there is some thickness so that it does not break; and let it be blunt so that it does not sharpen.
Et scias, quod instrumenta dentium sunt multa: et similiter reliqua instrumenta non computantur, et artifex prudens, subtilis in arte sua inuenit per se ipsum instrumentum, secundum quod significant ei operatio et aegritudines ipsae.	And know that there are many instruments for teeth; and similarly the other instruments are not counted, and a wise craftsman, skilled in his art invents by himself an instrument according to what is indicated by the operation itself and the illnesses themselves.
Quoniam ex agritudinibus sunt ad quas non dixerunt antiqui instrumentum, propter diuersitatem specierum earum.	Because for diseases to which the ancients did not say any instruments, due to the diversity of their species.
Si autem frangatur os ex mandibula, aut ex aliis ossibus oris, aut putrefit: tunc perscrutare super ipsum in loco suo cum eo quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis et forcipibus quae dixi in extractione radicum, et iuuare cum gesti, cuius forma est haec.	If a bone of the jaw or any other bones of the mouth breaks or becomes infected, then examine it carefully where it is located and use whatever tool suits its extraction from among the instruments and forceps that I mentioned in the section on tooth extraction; this one has the following form.
Sit in eo quiddam grossitudinis paulatim, ut stringatur, uel teneatur cum eo os, et non fugiat et uadat, donec egrediatur os: et restaura locum cum medicinis conuenientibus ad illud.	Place a thick material in it gradually so that the bone is clamped or held fast and does not fall out or slide until the bone comes out; then restore the site with suitable medicines for such an injury.
Si autem in osse est putredo parua, tunc rade ipsum a putredine sua, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	If there is some decay on the bone then remove it along with its decay; treat it until it heals.
De serratura Dentium eminentium super alios.	On the removal of prominent teeth above others.
Caput XXXII.	Chapter 32.
Quando Dentes eminent non secundum cursum suum naturalem, foeda fit per illud forma: et praecipue quando accidit illud in mulieribus, et puellis, scilicet uenalibus.	When teeth grow out of their normal path and direction, it becomes a deformity; especially when this occurs in the case of women and girls with fine features.
Oportet ergo ut consideres.	Therefore, one must take into account the following...
Nam si dens est natus post dentem alium, et non locatur, uel est possibilis eius serratura, neque limatura ipsius: tunc eradica ipsum: et si est annexus cum dente alio, tunc incide ipsum cum isto instrumento, cuius haec est forma.	If a tooth is born after another and does not have its own place, or if it cannot be extracted or filed; then remove it instead by cutting into it with this instrument...
Est simile rostro paruo, et fit ex ferro indo, acutae extremitatis ualde.	It is like a small beak; its end is made of hard iron, very sharp.
Et sit incisio tua qua ipsum incidis in diebus multis, et propter duriciem dentis, et ut non commoueatur alius ex dentibus.	And let your incision on it be over many days; this is due to the hardness of the tooth and so that others may not be shaken out by it.
Si autem est eminens expositus limaturae suae: tunc lima ipsum cum lima ex indo, cuius forma est haec.	If the prominent tooth is exposed to filing then file it with this iron file; its form is as follows...
Sit totum ex indo, et manubrium eius minutorum punctorum ualdae, sicut lima cum qua fiunt acus: cum quo limetur dens paulatim in diebus multis cum facilitate, ut non commoueatur dens, et cadat: deinde leni ipsum, in fine rade ipsum cum quibusdam rasoriis.	The tooth shall be removed entirely with a tool of gold; its handle should have fine points like the file used to make needles - which is how it will gradually reduce the tooth over many days easily so that the tooth isn't shaken and falls out, then ease it gently and finally scrape it with small scalpels.
Quod si est dens, ex quo frangatur pars, et laedit linguam: tunc oportet ut limes eum etiam, donec auferatur asperitas illius fractionis, et aequetur: et applanetur, et non laedat linguam, neque corrumpat sermonem.	If it is a tooth from which part has broken and damages the tongue, then you must also file it until its roughness from that break is removed and becomes even; smoothen it, so that it will not hurt the tongue or corrupt speech.
¶ De retatione Dentium cum filis auri.	On removing teeth with gold wire.
Caput XXXIII.	Chapter 33.
Quando accidit Dentibus anterioribus concussio et commotio a percussione, aut casu: et non potest infirmus stringere super illud quod comedit ut non cadat: et curasti eos cum medicinis stipticis, et non ualuit curatio: tunc ingenium in eis est, ut stringantur cum filo auri: quoniam argentum fit uiride, et putrefit post dies: sed aurum nunquam mutatur.	When the front teeth suffer from concussion and shaking due to a blow or fall; and when the patient is unable to chew on them for fear of losing their food; and if you have treated them with astringent medicines without success, then it's time to bind these teeth together using gold wire. Silver will turn green and rot within days, but gold never changes.
Et sit filum medium in subtilitate et grossicie secundum quantitatem quod capiat inter Dentes.	The wire should be of a thickness and thinness according to the size that fits between teeth.
Et forma quidem retationis est, ut accipias filum, et intromittas duplum eius inter duos dentes sanos: deinde texeas cum duabus extremitatibus fili inter dentes motos, siue unus sit, aut plures, donec peruenias cum tela usque ad dentem sanum alterius partis.	The technique is to take the wire and insert half of it between two healthy teeth; then weave its two ends among the loose tooth or teeth until you reach with your thread up to a sound tooth on the other side.
Deinde itera texturam usque ad partem a qua incaepisti: et stringe manum tuam cum subtilitate et sapientia, donec non remoueatur prorsus: et sit constrictio tua qua stringis filum, apud radices dentium, ut non euadat.	Then repeat the weave until you reach back to where you started; and tighten your grip with skill and wisdom so that it's not at all removable: your tightening of the wire should be at the roots of the teeth so as not to come out.
Deinde incide extremitates fili superfluentes cum forficibus: et aggrega utrumque, et conuerte eas cum gesti: et occulta ipsas inter dentem sanum et dentem motum, ut non laedat linguam: deinde dimittatur ita strictum dum remanet.	Then cut off the excessive gum with scissors: gather both together and turn them over with forceps; hide them between a healthy tooth and one that has been moved so as not to harm your tongue, then leave the thread tight while you do this.
Si autem soluitur, aut inciditur, stringe eos cum filo alio, et stabit cum eo taliter tempore toto.	If it loosens or is cut, tighten them with another thread and this will keep them in place during the whole process.
Et haec est forma Dentium, et figura retationis duorum dentium sanorum, et duorum dentium motorum, sicut uides.	And this is the arrangement of teeth, showing the positioning of two healthy teeth and two moved teeth as you can see.
Et quandoque fit, ut redeat dens unus, aut duo post casum urriusque in locis suis, et retentur sicut narrauimus, et remaneant: et non facit illud nisi artifex, prudens, et expertus.	And sometimes it happens that one or two teeth return after falling out and are retained in their places as we have described; they remain like this unless the skilled and experienced dentist removes them.
Et quandoque aptatur aliquod ex ossibus uaccinis: et fit ex eo sicut forma dentis, et ponitur in loco, ex quo munitur dens et stringitur, sicut diximus: et remanet, et seruitur cum eo tempore longo.	And sometimes some bone splinters are fitted and made into the shape of a tooth; it is placed where the missing tooth was located and secured as we have said before; it remains like this for a long time.
¶ De incisione ligamenti quod accidit sub lingua, et prohibet loquelam.	§ On cutting the ligament under the tongue which prevents speech.
Caput XXXIIII.	Chapter 34.
Quandoque ligamentum hoc quod accidit sub lingua, est aut naturale, cum quo nascitur homo, aut accidentale, a uulnere quod iam consolidatum est.	Sometimes this ligament under the tongue is either natural, with which one is born, or accidental from an injury that has already healed.
Et operatio in eo est, ut aperias os infirmi in capite eius in sinu tuo, et eleua linguam eius: deinde incide illud ligamentum neruosum per latitudinem, donec soluatur lingua a retentione sua.	The procedure for this is to open the mouth of the patient and place it in your lap; then lift their tongue; next cut through that sinewy ligament until the tongue is freed from its restraint.
Quod si in eo fuerit quiddam duriciei et nodationis, et fuerit illud ex consolidatione uulneris: tunc proiice in illud uncinum, et finde illud per latitudinem, donec incidas ligamentum, et soluatur nodatio.	If there is any hardness or knotting within it and this comes from the healing of a wound; then thrust a hook into it and move it sideways until you cut through the ligament and free up that knot.
Et caue, ne sit fissura in profundo carnis, et incidas arteriam illic, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And take care that there is no fissure deep within the flesh, and you do not cut into an artery there, causing a flow of blood.
Deinde colluatur in uestigio incisionis cum aqua rosata, aut cum aceto, aut aqua frigida.	Then it should be washed around the track of the incision with rosewater, or vinegar, or cold water.
Deinde pone sub lingua licinium ex lino, quod teneat infirmus in omni nocte: ut non consolidetur secundo.	Then place under the tongue lint from linen that the patient should hold through every night so it does not heal a second time.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis, tunc pone super locum zegi tritum.	If, however, there is a flow of blood, then place on the spot ground ginger.
Si uero uincit te sanguis, tunc cauteriza locum cum cauterio lentiginoso, quod conuenit ad illud: deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	If blood prevails over you, then cauterise the spot with a lunar cautery suitable for this; afterwards treat it with the rest of the treatment until it is healed.
¶ De extractione Ranulae quae fit sub lingua.	On the extraction of a ranula which forms under the tongue.
Caput XXXV.	Chapter 35.
Quandoque accidit sub lingua apostema quod assimilatur Ranae paruae, prohibens linguam ab operatione sua naturali: et fortasse magnificatur adeo, donec implet os.	Sometimes there happens under the tongue a boil resembling a small frog, hindering the tongue from its natural movement; and perhaps it grows so much that it fills the mouth.
Et operatio in eo est, ut aperias os infirmi coram sole: et considera apostema.	And the operation for this is to open the patient's mouth towards the sun, then examine the boil.
Si ergo uides ipsum fusci coloris, aut nigri, durum, cui non inuenit infirmus sensum: tunc non tangas ipsum, quoniam est cancer.	So if you see it is dark or black in colour, hard and without sensation to the patient's touch then do not touch it for it is a cancer.
Et si est decliue ad albedinem, in quo est humiditas, tunc proiice in ipsum uncinum, et incide ipsum cum spatumili subtili, et libera ipsum ab omni parte.	And if it slopes towards whiteness with some moisture then thrust into it a curved hook and cut it out with a sharp spoon-shaped instrument and remove it whole.
Quod si uincit te sanguis in hora tuae operationis, tunc pone super ipsum zegi tritum, donec abscindatur sanguis: deinde redi ad operationem tuam, donec extrahas ipsum cum complemento eius.	If blood prevails over you during your work then place on it ground ginger until the bleeding is checked; then return to your work until you remove it and all of its covering.
Deinde colluatur cum aceto et sale: et cura ipsum reliqua curatione conueniente ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then it should be rinsed with vinegar and salt: and treat it with any other suitable treatment until it is healed.
¶ De curatione apostematis duarum Amigdalarum.	On the treatment of an abscess of the two tonsils.
Caput XXXVI.	Chapter 36.
Quandoque accidunt inter guttur godad, id est, glandulae, quae similantur algodad, quae accidunt deforis: et nominantur duae Amigdalae: quas quando curas cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non sanantur, tunc considera.	Sometimes there occur between the throat and jaw, that is, glands which resemble cotton, which happen outside; and they are called two tonsils: when you treat them with what we have said in the section on division, and they do not heal, then consider this.
Si ergo est apostema durum, fusci coloris, pauci sensus: tunc non tangas ipsum cum ferro.	If therefore it is a hard abscess, of a dark colour, with little feeling: then do not touch it with the iron.
Et si est rubei coloris, et radix eius est grossa: tunc non tangas ipsum etiam cum ferro, timens fluxum sanguinis, imo dimitte ipsum, donec maturetur.	And if it is of a red colour, and its root is thick: then do not touch it either with the iron, fearing an outflow of blood, rather leave it until it ripens.
Et tunc aut perforabis ipsum: aut rumpetur per se.	And then you will either pierce it through; or it should burst by itself.
Et si est albi coloris, rotundum, et est radix eius subtilis: tunc oportet ipsum incidi.	And if it is of a white colour, round in shape, and its root is thin: then you must cut into it.
Et operatio in ipso est, ut consideres ante operationem suam, si quieuit apostema eius calidum quiete completum, aut imminuitur quadam diminutione: tunc ergo fac sedere infirmum coram sole, et caput eius sit in sinu tuo: et aperi os eius, et accipiat seruiens inter manus suas, et premat linguam eius inferius cum instrumento, cuius haec est forma.	And the operation on it is, that you consider before its treatment, if the abscess has become quiet while warm and complete, or diminished to some extent: then make the patient sit facing the sun, and let their head be in your lap; and open their mouth, and have someone take this instrument between their hands and press the patient's tongue down with it, which is of this shape.
Fiat ex argento, aut aere, quod sit subtile sicut cultellus.	It shall be made of silver or brass, which should be thin like a knife.
Cum ergo premis cum eo linguam, et ostenditur tibi apostema, et cadit super ipsum uisus tuus: tunc accipe uncinum, et fige ipsum in amigdalam, et extrahe eam ad exteriora quantum potes, praeter quod trahas cum ea aliquid ex tunicis.	When therefore you press with it on the tongue, and the abscess is shown to you, and your sight falls upon it: then take a hook, and fix it into the tonsil, and draw it out as far as you can towards the exterior, except that you do not pull anything of the tunic with it.
Deinde incide eam cum instrumento, cuius haec est forma quae sequitur.	Then cut it with an instrument that has this shape which follows.
Assimilatur forficibus: uerumtamen extremitates eius sint curuatae, ita quod orificium cuiusque earum est in directo alterius acute: unde cura ut sit ex ferro indo, aut alfuled imbibitum.	It resembles scissors; however, its ends are curved so that the opening of each is at a right angle to the other and is sharp; hence ensure it is made from iron or hardened bronze.
Si autem non est praesens hoc instrumentum, tunc incide ipsum cum spatumili, cuius haec est forma.	If however this instrument is not present, then cut it with a spatuli whose form is thus.
Sit acutum a parte una, non acutum a parte altera.	It should be sharp on one side but not sharp on the other.
Et postquam incidis amigdalam unam, incide alteram secundum hanc eandem speciem incisionis.	And when you have cut one tonsil, cut the other in exactly the same way.
Deinde post incisionem gargarizet infirmus cum aqua frigida, aut cum aceto et aqua.	Then after cutting, have the patient gargle with cold water or vinegar and water.
Si autem accidat ei fluxus sanguinis, gargarizet cum aqua in qua bulliti sunt cortices granatorum: aut folia myrti, et similia illis ex stipticis, donec abscindatur fluxus sanguinis: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	But if there is bleeding have the patient gargle with water in which boiled gallnut bark; or myrtle leaves and similar astringents until the blood flow ceases; then treat it until it heals.
Et quandoque nascuntur in gutture apostemata alia, praeter amigdalas duas.	And sometimes there appear other abscesses in the throat besides the two tonsils.
Incide ergo ea secundum quod dixi in incisione duarum amigdalarum aequaliter.	Cut them then as I have said for cutting of the two tonsils equally.
Et ego quidem iam medicatus fui mulierem ex apostemate, quod natum erat inter guttur eius, quod trahebat ad fuscedinem, pauci sensus, quod iam fere clauserat guttur: et mulier respirabat a meatu stricto, et iam prohibuerat ei comestionem, et potum aquae: et iam peruenerat ad mortem, si remansisset uno die, aut duobus diebus.	For my part I have treated a woman for an abscess that had formed in her throat which was causing difficulty breathing and loss of sensation to the point that her throat was almost closed; and she could only breathe through a narrow opening, and was already unable to eat or drink water: and by now would have died if left another day or two.
Et apostema tantum ascenderat, quod emiserat duos ramos, donec exierant super duo foramina nasi.	The abscess had risen so high that it had sent out two branches until they came out at the top of her nostrils.
Properaui ergo festinanter, et fixi in unum eorum uncinum.	I therefore hurriedly made a stitch with one of those hooks.
Deinde traxi ipsum, et tracta ex eo est portio magna.	Then I pulled it out, and a large portion came away from it.
Deinde abscidi eam, ubi comprehendi ex foramine nasi.	I then cut that off where I found the hole of the nose.
Deinde feci illud ei quod processit ex foramine nasi altero.	Then I did to it what came out from the other nostril.
Deinde aperui os eius, et pressi linguam eius: et postea fixi uncinum in ipsum apostema: deinde abscidi ex eo partem eius, et non cucurrit ex eo nisi sanguis paucus: absolutum est ergo guttur mulieris, et incepit statim bibere aquam, deinde accepit ex cibo.	I then opened her mouth and pressed down on her tongue; and afterwards I fixed a hook into the abscess, then cut off part of it, and no more came from it except for some blood; so the woman's throat was healed, she immediately drank water and then took food.
Non ergo cessaui incidere ex illo apostemate multotiens tempore longo: et apostema succedebat loco eius quod incidebam, donec prolongatum est nimis et cum ea illud.	Therefore I did not cease cutting out from the abscess many times over a long period; and an abscess would form in place of that which I had cut away, until it was extended too far and along with her.
Ingeniaui ergo, et cauterizaui apostema inter guttur.	I therefore devised something, and I cauterized the abscess between the throat.
Stetit ergo ab additione: deinde ambulaui a parte, et non sciui quid fecit Deus cum ea post me.	I therefore refrained from adding anything further; then I went away from her side, and did not know what God would do with her after that.
¶ De incisione apostematis uuulae.	On cutting out an abscess of the uvula.
Caput XXXVII.	Chapter XXXVII.
Quando descendit catarrus ad uuulam, et apostematur, et est long: tunc ipsa nominatur perpendicularis: et si est in inferiori parte grossa, rotunda, tunc ipsa nominatur uua.	When a catarrh descends to the uvula and becomes abscessed and elongated, then it is called "perpendicular"; and if it forms on the lower part of the uvula as a thick, round mass, then it is called a "tuba".
Quando curatur cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio: et uides quod apostema calidum quieuit ab ea, et est subtilis: tunc oportet ut incidas eam.	When you treat it with what we have said above and the treatment does not take effect; and you see that there is an abscess which has gone away from her heat but remains soft; then you ought to cut this out.
Et quae ex ea est aggregata rotunda, et non est ei longitudo, et est sanguinea, aut fusci coloris, aut nigri, et non est ei sensus: tunc oportet ut deuites incisionem eius.	And if it has formed a round mass and there is no length to it, and its colour is red or dark brown or black, and it lacks feeling; then you should make an incision in it.
In ea enim est timor super infirmum.	For there is fear over the sick person.
Oportet ergo quando uides eam secundum modum quem dixi ex albedine, et longitudine sua, ut facias sedere infirmum coram sole: et premas linguam eius cum instrumento, cuius praecessit narratio: deinde fige uncinum in uuam, et trahe eam inferius: et incide eam cum uno duorum instrumentorum quae dixi in incisione duarum amigdalarum.	Therefore, when you see it according to the manner that I have described regarding its colour and length, you should make the sick person sit facing the sun; then press their tongue with an instrument as previously mentioned; next, fix a hook into one ear and pull it downwards; finally, cut it with one of the two instruments I mentioned for incising two tonsils.
Et oportet ut non incidas ex ea, nisi illud quod additur super naturalem terminum sine additione.	And you should not cut anything from it unless what is added beyond the natural end without being included.
Nam si tu incidis ex ea plus, laedes uocem et sermonem.	For if you cut more from it, you will damage their voice and speech.
Deinde post incisionem utere eo quod narrauimus in incisione duarum amigdalarum: et cura eam, donec sanetur.	Then after the incision, use what we described for incising two tonsils; and treat it until it is healed.
Si autem terretur infirmus ab incisione: tunc oportet ut utaris ingenio in cauterizatione eius absque timore et pauore.	However, if the sick person is afraid of the incision, then you should use skill in cauterizing it without fear or anxiety.
Et modus cauterii in ea non est, nisi cum aqua acuta: et est, ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	The method of cauterizing it does not involve anything but cold water; you should place the sick person's head in your lap.
Deinde preme linguam eius cum instrumento quod diximus.	Then press their tongue with the instrument that we mentioned earlier.
Deinde accipe ex aqua quam dixi tibi in capitulo cauterizandi, et confice cum ea calcem non extinctam, et pone eam non spissam, neque subtilem, et imple ex ea concauitatem huius instrumenti, cuius haec est forma.	Next, take some of the water that I told you about in the chapter on cauterizing, and make a paste with it using unquenched lime; ensure it is neither thick nor thin, and fill the hollow of this instrument with it, which has this shape:" (at this point the original text includes an illustration).
Sit extremitati eius in qua ponitur medicina concauitas, sicut concauitas cochlearis radii.	The end of it should have a concave shape, like the concavity of the handle of a spoon.
Et pone instrumentum cum medicina super uuulam ipsam: et infirmus sit iacens super latus suum, ut currat saliua ex ore eius ex intrinseca medicina, ut non descendat ex ea ad guttur ipsius aliquid, et laedat ipsum.	Place the instrument with the medicine on top of that wound; and let the patient lie on their side so saliva flows out from their mouth away from the medicine inside it so nothing runs down into their throat to hurt them.
Deinde tene manum tuam cum medicina.	Then hold your hand with medicine in it.
Et tu ex primas eam super uuulam quantitate medietatis horae, donec uideas eam iam denigratam, et sedatam mordicationem medicinae.	And keep it there for half an hour until you see the wound turning black and the medicine calming down from its initial agitation.
Et si uis ut accipias cotum, et inuoluas ipsum super extremitatem radii, et infundas cotum cum medicina, et intromittas radium cum coto in cannulam desuper, donec adhaereat cotum super uuulam.	And if you wish to use a plug then wrap it with lint around the end of the radius and dip this lint-plug into medicine before inserting the radius (with lint-plug attached) into its tube until the lint plug adheres well onto that wound.
Fac illud multotiens, donec consequaris quod uis de cauterizatione uuae.	Do this many times over until you achieve the desired degree of cauterization for that wound.
Deinde dimitte eam: ipsa namque arescit et cadit post tres dies, aut quatuor.	Then let it be; for within three to four days it will dry up and fall off by itself.
Quod si indiges ut iteres medicinam, itera ipsam: et post cauterizationem absterge in circumitu uuae cum coto imbibito in butyro, et mundifica cum eo quod est in circumitu eius ex medicina: et colluatur cum aqua frigida.	If you need to apply more medicine then do so; and after the cauterization has been done clean around that wound with a lint-plug soaked in butter and wipe off any remaining medicine from its surroundings, then wash it all down with cold water.
Et curetur extrinsecus cum embrocis, et deintus cum gargarismis, donec sanetur.	It should be treated from outside by means of poultices as well as internally with mouthwashes until it has completely healed up.
Haec ergo species curationis est salubrior incisione et longinquior a timore.	This kind of treatment is healthier than cutting (i.e., the lancet) as well as less frightening to be around.
Et quandoque curatur uuula etiam cum eo quod est subtilius quam cauterium et incisio: curatur enim cum suffumigatione, secundum hunc modum.	And sometimes a wound is even healed by means of something finer than either cautery or incision; it is healed with the aid of fumigations in this way.
Sume calamentum, et hyssopum, et origanum, et rutam, et sseah, et chamomillam, et abrotanum, et similia eis ex herbis: et aggrega ea omnia, aut quaedam eorum in olla, et submergantur cum aceto, et bulliant: et olla sit lutata cum luto decenter: et sit in medio ollae foramen, super quod componatur instrumentum concauum secundum hunc modum.	Take calamentum, hyssop, oregano, rue, seah, chamomile, abrotanum, and similar herbs; gather all of them or some of them in a pot, submerge them with vinegar, and boil; the pot must be glazed with decent clay; there should be a hole in the middle of the pot on top of which is placed an instrument shaped like this.
Fiat ex argento, aut aere: et intromittatur extremitas, in qua est granatum, in os infirmi, donec ascendat uapor ad uuulam super cannulam, donec obscuretur uuula multum.	It shall be made of silver or bronze; the end with the pomegranate design is to be inserted into the patient's mouth until the vapor rises to the small bowl above the tube until the bowl becomes very cloudy.
Deinde itera super ipsam multotiens, donec arescat.	Then repeat over it many times until it dries.
Et caue, ne facias hanc curationem in principio aduentus apostematis.	And beware not to make this cure at the beginning of an abscess's appearance.
Plaerumque enim addit in apostemate: et non oportet ut facias illud nisi apud declinationem apostematis eius calidi.	For it often adds to the abscess; one should not do this unless at the decline of an abscess's warmth.
Si autem non est praesens tibi hoc instrumentum, tunc accipe cannam, et compone in extremitate eius corticem oui: ut non comburatur os infirmi: quoniam cortex oui prohibet uaporem comburere os: et haec est ex bona curatione cum salute.	If this tool is not available to you, then take a tube and place goat skin at its end so the patient's mouth will not get burnt as the goat skin prevents the vapor from burning; this is an excellent cure with success.
¶ De extractione spinarum, et ossium de gula.	On extracting splinters and bones from the throat.
Caput XXXVIII.	Chapter 38.
Multotiens adhaeret in gutture os, aut spina piscis, aut aliud.	Often there gets stuck in the throat bone, or fish spine, or another object.
Oportet ergo ut extrahas quod ex eis est apparens super quod cadit uisus, postquam premis linguam cum instrumento apud solem, et declaratur tibi quod est in gutture.	One should therefore extract what is visible of it above that which falls on sight after you press the tongue with an instrument towards the sun and identify to yourself what is in the throat.
Et quod non apparet tibi et occultatur in gutture, oportet ut facias uomere infirmum antequam digeratur cibus in stomacho.	And if it is not apparent to you and is hidden in the throat, you must make the patient vomit before food is digested in the stomach.
Fortasse enim egredietur res annexa per uomitum.	Perhaps it will come out through vomiting.
Aut deglutiat infirmus frustum napi, aut radicem lactucae, aut deglutiat buccellam panis sicci: aut accipiat frustum spongiae marinae siccae lenis: et liga ipsum in filo, deinde deglutiat ipsum.	Or the patient should swallow a piece of turnip, or a lettuce root, or they should swallow a mouthful of dry bread; or take a piece of dry, soft sponge seaweed and tie it up with thread before swallowing.
Cum ergo peruenit ad locum ubi sunt spinae, aut os, et extrahitur, tunc egreditur.	Once it reaches the place where there is a thorn or bone, and it comes out, then it will be removed.
Si ergo non egreditur cum eo quod diximus: tunc utere instrumento ex plumbo secundum hanc formam.	If therefore, it does not come out with what we have said, then use a lead instrument in this form.
Sit grossius quam Radius parumper, et in extremitate eius sit curuitas, quam intromittat in guttur suum cum facilitate: et ipse habeat caput suum eleuatum sursum.	It should be thicker than a spoke by a little bit and at its end it should have a curve that can easily be inserted into the throat when their head is raised upwards.
Et caueat a tactu suae epiglotis, ut non accidat ei tussis, et impellat cum eo os, aut spinam, aut intromittat ipsum medicus manu sua.	And be careful not to touch their epiglottis so that it does not cause them to cough and push the bone or thorn with it, or let the doctor insert it by hand.
Verum quod infirmus intromittat, hoc est melius: propter scientiam suam de loco rei annexae: et impellat inferius, aut trahat manum suam cum instrumento sursum, totum illud secundum quantitatem quae praeparatur ei, donec egrediatur.	However, it is better for the patient to insert it themselves because of their knowledge about where the object is located; and they should push downwards or pull upwards with their hand while holding the instrument until it comes out.
¶ De extractione Sanguisugae.	On extracting leeches.
Caput XXXIX.	Chapter 39.
Quando medicatur sanguisuga cum eo quod dixi in diuisione ex curatione cum medicinis, et non confert, tunc considera in gutture infirmi coram sole, siue apud solem postquam premis linguam eius cum instrumento quod narraui tibi.	When a leech is treated with what I have mentioned in the section on treatment using medicine and it does not improve then look at the patient's throat in front of the sun or towards the sun after you press their tongue down with the instrument that I described to you.
Si ergo cadit uisus tuus super sanguisugam, extrahe eam cum uncino paruo, aut cum gesti subtilibus decenter.	If your sight falls upon a leech, remove it with a small hook or with thin tweezers deftly.
Quod si non est possibile cum eis: tunc accipe cannulam concauam, et intromitte eam in guttur infirmi usque prope guttur: deinde intromitte in concauitatem cannulae ferrum ignitum cum igne.
