If it is not possible with these [tools]: then take a hollow tube, and insert it into the throat of the patient close to the esophagus; next, insert into the cavity of the tube a red-hot iron with fire.
Fac illud multotiens: et abstineat infirmus ab aqua tota die.	Do this several times, and let the patient refrain from drinking water all day.
Deinde accipiat uitreatam plenam aqua frigida, et aperiat os eius in ea: et colluat os suum cum ea, et non deglutiat ex ea aliquid: et moueat aquam una hora post aliam cum manu sua.	Then he should take a cup filled with cold water and open his mouth into it; let him gargle his mouth with it but not swallow any of it; then move the water around in his mouth once an hour for another hour with his hand.
Sanguisuga enim ilico cum sentit aquam cadit.	For the leech will immediately drop off when it senses water.
Si autem non egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus, tunc suffumiga infirmum cum cimicibus, aut cum asa cum instrumento quod narraui in suffumigatione uuulae.	But if it does not come out with what we have described, then fumigate the patient with bedbugs or leeches with the instrument I mentioned for fumigating a cold.
Fac illud multotiens, quoniam ipsa cadet.	Do this several times, since it will fall off.
Et modus operationis in suffumigatione est, ut accipias ollam, in qua sint prunae uiuae cum igne: et olla sit cooperta cum coopertorio, in cuius medio sit foramen: et componatur in illo foramine extremitas instrumenti.	And the method of operating with fumigation is such that you take a pot containing live plums over fire; and let this pot be covered by a lid where there is a hole in its middle, and let an end of the instrument be fixed into it.
Deinde proiice suffumigationem, et ponat infirmus os suum in extremitate cannulae, et claudat os suum, ut non egrediatur suffumigatio, donec scias quod suffumigatio iam peruenit ad sanguisugam.	Then direct the fumigation and let the patient put his mouth on an end of the tube and close his mouth so that no smoke escapes until you know that the smoke has reached the leech.
Nam sanguisuga statim cadet.	For the leech will immediately drop off.
Quod si non cadit, tunc itera suffumigationem multotiens.	If it does not fall out, then repeat fumigation many times.
Et toleret infirmus sitim, et comedat salsa, et allia, et non bibat aquam.	And let the patient bear thirst, eat salty things, garlic, and onions, but not drink water.
Necesse est ergo ut egrediatur cum hoc regimine.	It is necessary that he depart with this regimen.
Et haec est forma instrumenti cum quo extrahitur sanguisuga ex gutture, quando cadit super ipsam uisus.	And this is the form of the instrument with which the leech is removed from the throat, when it falls upon it with its eye.
Est simile forcipibus, sicut uides: nisi quia est ei haee curuitas quae intromittitur ad guttur.	It is like a pair of forceps, as you see; except that it has this curve which is inserted into the throat.
Et extremitas eius similis ori auis quae nominatur ciconia, in quo est asperitas limae: quando comprehendit aliquid, non dimittit ipsum omnino.	And its end is similar to the beak of a bird called a stork, in which there is the roughness of a file; when it grasps something, it does not release it at all.
¶ De apertione Apostematum, et eorum sectione, et cura in genere.	### Concerning the opening of abscesses, their incision, and care in general.
Caput XL.	Chapter 40.
Apostematum species sunt multae, multorum modorum, secundum quod uenit rememoratio eorum, scilicet unius, et unius in hoc libro: et sunt diuersae in perforatione eorum, et sectione ipsorum ex duobus modis.	There are many types of abscesses, of many forms, according to the manner in which they come about; this will be discussed further when we treat of one kind herein; and there are differences as regards the manner in which they should be lanced or opened with two methods.
Quorum unus est ex specie apostematis in seipso, et eo quod comprehendit ex humiditatibus.	One of these is of the kind of abscess within itself which contains moisture.
Et modus secundus est propter loca, in quibus accidit ex corpore.	The second method concerns the places on the body where they occur.
Quoniam apostema accidens in capite, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in ano: et apostema accidens in loco carnoso, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in iuncturis: et unicuique eorum est iudicium suum ex operatione.	Since an abscess occurring on the head is different from one that occurs in the anal region; and since an abscess in soft tissue is different from one which arises at a joint, each of these requires its own judgment as to treatment.
Et ex apostematibus sunt quae non oportet ut perforentur, nisi post maturationem saniei in eis, et complementum eius: et ex eis sunt, quae oportet ut perforentur, dum sunt cruda, et non maturantur secundum complementum.	And from inflammations are those which should not be punctured unless after the maturation of pus in them and its completion; and among them are those that must be punctured while they are raw and do not mature according to their completion.
Sicut apostemata quae sunt propinqua iuncturis.	Such as inflammations that are near joints.
Quoniam apostema quando accidit prope iuncturam, et prolongatur esse eius, donec putrefit quod est in circumitu eius fortasse corrumpuntur ligamenta, aut nerui illius iuncturae: quare est caussa propior contractionis illius membri.	Because an inflammation when it occurs near a joint, and its duration is prolonged until what is inside it putrefies, perhaps the ligaments or nerves of that joint are corrupted; this is the cause for the closer proximity of the contraction of that limb.
Aut est apostema apud membrum principale: quoniam si tu tardas perforationem eius, donec maturetur, nocebit uel illi, uel per illud membro principali.	Or it is an inflammation in a principal limb; because if you delay its puncturing until it matures, it will harm either that limb or the principal member.
Aut est prope anum, perfora ergo ipsum immaturum: et non oportet, ut perfores, apostema crudum, non completae digestionis, nisi quod est prope anum, ut non putrefiat profundum, et longetur ad interiora ani, et fiat fistula, aut fiat in termino eius quod non sanatur.	Or it is near the anus, therefore puncture it while it is immature; and you should not puncture a raw inflammation that has not completed digestion unless it is near the anus so as to prevent the putrefaction of its depth and prolonging towards the interior of the anus, and for there not to be a fistula or non-healing in its termination.
Oportet ut scias horam perforationis apostematis, quod maturatum est secundum complementum: et est apud sedationem doloris, recessionem febris, et diminutionem rubedinis, et pulsationis, et acuitatem capitis apostematis: et reliqua signa.	You must know the time of puncturing an inflammation that has matured according to its completion; and this is at the relief of pain, reduction of fever, and decrease in redness, throbbing, and sharpness of the head of the inflammation; as well as other signs.
Et oportet, ut facias eandem perforationem in inferiori loco apostematis, et uehementioris eminentiae: et sit perforatio uadens in longitudine corporis, si apostemata sunt in partibus manuum et pedum, et locis lacertorum, et chordarum, et neruorum, et arteriarum, et ad ultimum in omnibus locis aequalibus, quibus non est reflexio.	And you must make the same puncture at the lowest point of the inflammation and its most prominent peak; and let the puncturing go along the length of the body if inflammations are in parts of hands or feet, and places of forearms, cords, nerves, arteries, and finally all equal locations that do not have a reflex.
In illis autem quae reflectuntur, uade cum perforatione secundum illud membrum.	Go with a suture along that member according to its perforation.
Quando uero apostema est in locis carnosis: tunc melius est ut dimittas perforationem eius, donec confirmetur eius digestio, sicut diximus secundum complementum.	When however the abscess is in fleshy parts: then it is better that you leave its opening alone until its discharge has been completed as we have said according to what follows.
Quoniam si tu perforas ipsum ante illud, prolongatur cursus uirus ex eo, et est multae sordis et sordiciei, et fortasse indurantur labia eius, et profunditas eius.	For if you open it before this, the course of the pus from it is prolonged and there is much dirt and nastiness, and perhaps its lips will harden and its depth increase.
Et quaedam apostemata perforantur secundum latitudinem corporis apud necessitatem: aut secundum illud quo indiget membrum.	And some abscesses are opened according to the width of its body for what is needed or according to that part which requires it.
Et oportet, ut administres in apostematibus paruis perforationem paruam, et in apostematibus magnis perforationem amplam: aut sectiones multas per similitudinem magnitudinis apostematis.	And it is necessary that you make a small opening for small abscesses and a large one for large ones or several cuts according to the size of the abscess.
Et sunt ex apostematibus, in quibus oportet ut concauetur cutis: et incidatur quando iam facta est sicut pannus, et facta est in termino, quod iam mortua est: sicut illud quod accidit in multis, ut dubelet, et bubonibus.	And there are abscesses in which it is necessary to cut away the skin and incise when already formed like a cloth and has reached its limit because now it is dead such as happens with many ulcers and swellings.
Et ex eis sunt quae secantur sectione habente tres angulos.	And of these some are incised by an incision having three angles.
Et ex eis est, ex quo inciditur sicut figura folii myrti.	And there is one of them which is incised in the shape of a myrtle leaf.
Sicut apostema inguinum.	Like an abscess of the groin.
Et ex eis sunt in quibus administratur sectio rotunda, et sectio lunaris: et similes eis ex sectionibus.	And among them there are those in which you make a round incision or a lunar one and incisions similar to these.
Illud uero cui non est caput, sicut sunt apostemata lenia superficialia, oportet ut perfores ipsum perforatione superficiali, uel plana tantum.	That which has no head like soft superficial abscesses must be opened by a superficial or flat incision only.
Et oportet, quando apostema est grossum, et iam collegit saniem multam, et perforas ipsum, ut non properes et extrahas pus totum in illa hora: imo extrahe ex ipso partem eius.	And when the abscess is large and has already collected a lot of pus, and you puncture it, do not rush to extract all the pus at that moment; instead, remove only a portion from within.
Deinde opila apostema usque ad diem alium.	Then neglect the abscess until another day.
Deinde extrahe quiddam ex pus iterum.	Then extract something from the pus again.
Fac illud multotiens secundum gradationem, donec egrediatur: praecipue si infirmus est debilis uirtutis, aut mulier praegnans, aut puer paruus, aur senex decrepitus: spiritus enim animalis ab animali multotiens resoluitur cum egressione saniei: et fortasse moritur infirmus, et tu non percipis.	Do this many times in stages until it is gone; especially if the patient is weak and feeble, or a pregnant woman, or a small child, or an old decrepit man: for frequently the animal spirit of one animal dissipates along with the discharge of pus; and perhaps the patient may die without you realizing.
Caue ergo hoc capitulum cautela magna.	Therefore, exercise great caution in this chapter.
Et post perforationem tuam, qua ista perforas apostemata, oportet ut abstergas uulnus: et considera.	And after your puncture of the abscess with this instrument, you must clean the wound; and take note.
Si ergo est uulnus apostematis paruum, aut est sectio plana, tunc administra licinia ex lino, aut coto antiquo.	If the wound of the abscess is small or it is a flat cut, then apply lint made from linen, or old cotton.
Et si est apostema magnum, et fissurae perforationis multae sunt, oportet tunc ut intromittas in omnem fissuram licinium, donec perueniant adinuicem.	But if the abscess is large and there are many punctures, then you must insert lint into each puncture until they meet one another.
Et si in apostemate abscidisti partem cutis, aut in circumitu concauasti eam: tunc oportet ut impleas eam coto ueteri, aut sicut quando texitur pannus, aut raditur lanugine lini absque humiditate: et stringe ipsum usque ad tertium diem.	And if in the abscess you have cut away a piece of skin or you have scooped it out around its edges, then you must fill this with old cotton, or like when you weave cloth, or scrape with linen wool without moisture; and bind it tight until the third day.
Deinde proiice ipsum, et cura illud cum eo quod oportet ex unguento, donec sanetur.	Then wash it clean and take care of it with whatever ointment is required until it heals.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis in hora tuae operationis, tunc administra aquam frigidam, et acetum, postquam imbibitur in eis pannus: et ponis ipsum super locum fluxus sanguinis multotiens.	If there is a flow of blood during your operation, then apply cold water and vinegar, after soaking a cloth in them; place it on the bleeding site multiple times.
Si autem perseuerat fluxus sanguinis, tunc oportet ut administres regimen, et curationem, et pulueres, quae narraui in locis multis huius nostri libri, et ex diuisione.	If the bleeding persists, you must apply a diet, treatment, and powders that I have described in many places throughout this book and its sections.
Si autem est in tempore hyemis, et locus apostematis est multorum neruorum: tunc oportet ut infundas puluillos cum uino, et oleo calidis: et ponas eos super loca.	If it is winter time and the site of abscess involves many nerves; then you must apply small poultices made with warm wine and oil on these areas.
Et si fuerit in aestate, et loca sunt carnosa: tunc oportet ut ponas puluillos imbibitos in aqua, et oleo, aut eum uino et oleo, et totum illud frigidum.	And if it is summer and the areas are fleshy; then you must apply poultices soaked in water and oil or wine and oil, making sure everything is cold.
Donec quando erit dies tertius, sicut diximus, tunc oportet ut soluas apostema, et abstergas ipsum, et administres in curatione eius quod ei conuenit, donec sanetur.	Keep doing this until the third day, as mentioned before, then you must open the abscess, clean it and apply treatment suitable for it until it is healed.
Hoc est ergo quod necessarium est ex cognitione curationis apostematum uniuersaliter.	This, therefore, is what is necessary for the general knowledge of abscess treatment.
Secundum semitam uero distinctionis, iam dixi de omni apostemate, qualiter est uia ad curationem eius capitulatim singulariter.	Following the path of this book's structure, I have already described every type of abscess and how to treat each one in detail.
¶ De sectione apostematum quae accidunt in cute capitis.	## On the treatment of abscesses that occur on the skin of the head.
Caput XLI.	Chapter 41.
Accidunt in cute capitis apostemata parua, et sunt ex speciebus Nodorum, quos continent tunicae, quae sunt eis sacci: quasi ipsa sint hausolati gallinae.	Abscesses that occur on the skin of the head are small and similar to nodules; they contain cysts which resemble chicken pouches.
Et ipsorum species sunt multae.	And there are many types of these abscesses.
Ex eis sunt pingues: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditatem similem limo: et ex eis quae continent humiditatem similem frisatis et pultibus: et eis similibus, et ex eis sunt, quae sunt lapidea dura.	Among these are the fatty tumors; and among them are those which contain moisture resembling mud; and among them are those containing moisture like mincemeat and poultices; also such as resemble these; and there are among them hard stony ones.
Et in sectione omnium, et ipsorum extractione non est timor, dum apud ipsorum sectionem non facit contrarietatem arteria.	And in the operation on all these growths, and their removal there is no danger provided that during the operation upon them the artery does not present an obstacle.
Et operatio in sectione eorum est, ut experiaris ea cum instrumento, cuius forma uenit post haec, quod nominatur Intromissum, donec scias quid contineat.	And the operation in their excision consists of exploring them with an instrument whose form is given below and which is called a trocar until you know what they contain.
Nam si est illud quod continet humiditas, tunc seca ipsum sectione secundum longitudinem sectione superficiali: secundum hanc formam.	For if it contains moisture then cut it open by an incision lengthwise along the surface in this manner.
Et incipe cum sectione ex linea b. ad lineam, g. Cum ergo euacuatur humiditas, tunc excoria kistin quae continet illam humiditatem, et non dimittas ex ea aliquid penitus.	And begin the incision from line b to line g. When therefore the moisture is evacuated then scrape out the cyst which contains that moisture and do not leave any of it behind.
Multotiens enim redit, si remanet ex ea aliquid.	For it frequently returns if any part of it is left behind.
Deinde submerge cotum in unguento aegyptio, si est praesens: et si non, in aqua et sale: et imple cum eo uulnus, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Then immerse the wound in Egyptian ointment if it is available; and if not then in water and salt; and fill with it the wound, and leave it till the next day.
Ipsum enim corrodet quod remansit ex kisti.	For it eats away what remains of the cyst.
Deinde itera super ipsum cotum cum aegyptio secundo, et tertio, et si indiges illo, donec confidas quia non remanserit ex kisti aliquid, tunc enim cura uulnus cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then repeat over it the Egyptian ointment a second and third time; and if you require it then continue till you are confident that there is no part of the cyst remaining: then treat the wound with any sort of ointment until it heals.
Quod si apostema continet nodum pinguem: tunc seca ipsum secundum hanc formam, sectione habente formam crucis: et proiice uncinos inter duolabia sectionis, et excoria ipsum ab omni parte: et conare uirtutem tuam in extractione tunicae quae continet ipsum.	But if the abscess contains a fatty tumour then cut it open in this form with an incision having the shape of a cross; and throw hooks between the lips of the incision, and scrape it out on all sides: and endeavour your strength at extracting the capsule which contains it.
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi arteria, tunc fac illud quod narrabo tibi post.	If however the artery presents an obstruction to you, then do what I shall tell you after this.
Et similiter fac in apostemate, si est lapideum, ex sectione, et curatione eadem, secundum quod diximus.	And do likewise for an abscess if it is of the stony type, by incision and cure with the same treatment as we have said.
Et sectio super apostema lapideum est facilior: quoniam est pauci sanguinis et humiditatis.	And the incision above a stony abscess is easier because there is little blood or moisture.
Et quandoque sunt quaedam horum apostematum quae sunt in capite in quibusdam hominibus, cum quibus penitus non est humiditas.	And sometimes there are certain of these abscesses which occur on the head in some people where moisture is completely absent.
Quod est: quia ego secui super apostema in capite mulieris uetulae, et inueni apostema sicut lapis solidus et durus, asper, albus, qui non poterat frangi: et si percuteretur cum eo aliquis proiiciendo, uulnerat ipsum.	This is because I incised an abscess on the head of a woman, an old lady, and found that the abscess was like a solid hard stone, rough, white, which could not be broken; indeed if anyone struck it with their finger they would wound themselves.
In aliis uero apostematibus accidentibus in capite, praeter haec scilicet apostemata quae accidunt in capitibus puerorum, et apud radices aurium, sectio eorum omnium sit sectio superficialis.	However, with other types of abscesses occurring on the head except these types that occur on children's heads and at the roots of their ears, the incision should be a shallow one for all such cases.
Vel pone perforationem eorum semper ab inferiori parte eorum, ut alleuietur cursus saniei ad inferiora.	Or make the perforation of them always from their lower part so that you may ease the course of the pus downwards.
Deinde cura ea cum eo quod conuenit eis ex curatione.	Then cure it with whatever is suitable to their treatment.
¶ De sectione Strophularum in collo.	On the incision of goitres on the neck.
Caput XLII.	Chapter 42.
Multotiens acccidunt ista apostemata in collo, et sub assellis, et inguinibus: et quandoque accidunt in reliquo corpore.	These abscesses often occur on the neck, under the shoulders and hips, but sometimes they are found elsewhere in the body too.
Et super illa quae ex eis accidunt in collo, sunt unum, et multa: et generantur ab inuicem: et omnis Strophula ex eis est intra tunicam propriam ei, sicut est in nodis et apostematibus capitis, sicut narrauimus.	Those of this type which occur on the neck can be a single growth or several; they breed from one another and each goitre among them has its own membrane like a skin just as is seen with knots and abscesses in the head, as we described earlier.
Et species harum Strophularum sunt multae.	There are many types of these tourniquets.
Et ex eis enim sunt lapideae: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates: et ex eis sunt malignae, quae non obediunt curationi.	And some of them are made of stone; others contain moisture; yet others are malignant and do not respond to treatment.
In illa ergo quam ex eis uides bonae dispositionis in tactu, cuius manifestum est propinquum colori cutis, et mouetur ad omnem partem, et non est annexa cum neruis colli, neque cum guidegi, neque cum arteria, neque est profunda: oportet ut seces eam sectione superficiali a superiori parte ad inferiorem partem corporis ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. et excoria eam ab omni parte: et extende duo labia cutis cum uncino, aut cum uncinis multis, si indiges illo, sicut diximus in apostematibus capitis, et extrahe eam paulatim.	Therefore, for that one among them which you see to be of a good disposition on touch, whose colour is close to that of the skin, and it moves with every part, and is not attached to the nerves of the neck nor to the muscles nor to the artery, nor does it lie deep: it ought to be cut by a superficial incision from the upper body to the lower body along the line b. to g., and scrape it all over; and stretch out two lips of skin with a hook or many hooks if you need them, as we said in head abscesses, and extract it gradually.
Et est super cautelam, ut non incidatur uena, aut neruus.	And caution must be taken not to cut into any veins or nerves.
Et sit spatumile non acutum ualde: ut non addat tibi manum tuam cum incisione, aut inquietet infirmum, et incidas quod non est necesse.	And let the knife be not too sharp, so that it does not give you difficulty in cutting and disturb the patient and cut into what is unnecessary.
Si autem incidis uenam, aut arteriam, aut prohibet te ab operatione, tunc pone in uulnus zegi tritum, aut quosdam pulueres qui abscindunt sanguinem, et stringe uulnus, et dimitte ipsum, donec quiescat acuitas apostematis, et mollificetur uulnus: uel incipit et uult putrefieri.	But if you cut into a vein or artery and it prevents you from operating then apply to the wound some caustic rubbed down to powder, or certain powders which check blood, and bind up the wound and let it alone until the severity of the abscess has subsided, and the wound softens; otherwise it begins to decay.
Nam sanguis abscinditur tuncia Redi ergo ad operationem tuam, donec compleas.	For blood is checked by caustic substances; so return to your operation until you have finished it.
Deinde inquire digito tuo indice, si remansit aliquid ex Strophulis aliis paruis: ergo incide eas, et munda eas.	Then feel with your index finger whether there remains anything of the other small tourniquets; therefore cut them and clean them.
Quod si est in radice Strophulae uena magna: tunc oportet ut non incidas illam Strophulam ex radice sua: imo oportet ut liges eam cum filo duplato forti, et dimittas eam donec cadat per se absque nocumento.	But if there is a large vein at the root of the tourniquet then you ought not to cut that tourniquet from its root but rather you should tie it with strong doubled thread and leave it until it falls off by itself without causing harm.
Deinde imple uulnus coto ueteri, quod iam submersisti in unguento aegyptio.	Then fill the wound with cotton that you have already soaked in Egyptian ointment.
Deinde cura ipsum.	Then treat yourself.
Si inciditur Strophula tota, tunc oportet ut aggreges labia duo uulneris: et suas ipsum statim, postquam uides quia prorsus non remansit superfluitas.	If the entire strophulus is cut off, then you should bring together the two lips of the wound and sew them immediately once you see that there is no more superfluity remaining.
Si autem uides quod remansit superfluitas propter magnitudinem Strophulae, tunc oportet ut intendas ad incidendam radicem eius, et extrahendam eam: et administra suturam quam diximus.	But if you see that there is superfluity remaining because of the size of the strophulus, then it's necessary to aim at cutting its root and extracting it, and then administer the suture we described.
Et quae ex Strophulis continet humiditates, perfora illam perforatione superficiali: ut appareat tibi locus maturitatis eius: et pone perforationem ab eo quod sequitur inferius corporis, sicut diximus.	And for those strophuli that contain moisture, pierce it with a shallow puncture so its maturity site becomes apparent to you; and place the puncture below what follows from the body, as we described.
Deinde administra post perforationem licinia cum unguento, et similia eis, ut corrodat quod remansit ex corruptione, donec quando uides uulnus iam mundatum esse: tunc cura ipsum cum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	Then administer lint dressed with ointment and similar to it after the puncture, so that what remains of the corruption is corroded away until you see the wound now cleansed; then treat yourself with generative flesh-forming ointment until it's healed.
¶ De sectione Epiglotis ab apostemate intra guttur accidente.	On the excision of the epiglottis from an abscess inside the throat that occurs.
Caput XLIII.	Chapter 43.
Dixerunt antiqui hanc sectionem in Epigloti, et non uidi aliquem in terra nostra, qui eam fecerit: et haec est scriptura sermonis eorum.	The ancients called this excision of the epiglottis, and I have not seen anyone in our land who has performed it; and here is their description of the operation.
In habentibus autem synanchiam, oportet ut deuitetur sectio Epiglotis: cum non fiat iuuamentum per illud: propterea, quod omnes uenae et pulmo sunt infirmi.	In those with synanche, the excision of the epiglottis should be avoided as it is of no benefit due to all the veins and lung being compromised.
In illis uero qui habent apostema calidum in ore, aut gutture, aut duabus amigdalis, quando non est aegritudo in cannali, oportet uti sectione Epiglotis, ad fugiendum ex perditione quae fit ex praefocatione.	However, for those with a hot abscess in the mouth or throat or on both tonsils but without illness of the gullet, the excision of the epiglottis should be performed to escape destruction from suffocation that may result.
Oportet ergo quando uolumus illud, ut secemus Epiglotim sub tribus circulis Epiglotis, aut quatuor, sectione parua per latitudinem, in eo quod est inter duos circulos per quantitatem, quod sit sectio in sifac, non in cartilagine: et iste quidem locus est conueniens sectioni, quoniam est priuatus carne, et uasa sanguinis ab eo sunt longinqua.	We should therefore, when we wish to do so, cut the epiglottis under three or four circles of the epiglottis, with a small incision across its width, at the point between two circles in length, which is an incision into the soft tissue and not into the cartilage; and this indeed is a suitable place for the incision, since it lacks flesh, and blood vessels from there are distant.
Quod si medicator est timidus, tunc oportet ut extendat cutem gutturis cum uncino.	If the physician is timid, he should then stretch out the skin of the throat with a hook.
Deinde findat cutem, donec quando peruenit ad cannalem: deuitet uas sanguinis, si uidet ex eis aliquid.	Then he should slit the skin until he reaches the canal; let him avoid blood vessels if he sees any of them there.
Deinde secet sifac quod narrauimus: et significatur super sectionem cannalis ex phlegmate quod egreditur ex ea, cum eo quod disrumpitur, et abscisione uocis.	Then he should cut the soft tissue as described; and the incision of the canal is indicated by the flow of phlegm that comes out from it along with what has been ruptured, and the loss of voice.
Et dimitte uulnus apertum tempore aliquo.	And leave the wound open for some time.
Cum ergo remouetur hora in qua timetur praefocatio, aggrega duo labia uulneris cutis, et sue ipsam solam absque cartilagine.	When therefore the hour is removed at which suffocation is feared, bring together the two lips of the skin wound and stitch it solely by itself without the cartilage.
Deinde administra medicinas quae faciunt nasci carnem, usquequo sanetur.	Then apply medicines that cause flesh to grow until it is healed.
Inquit Albucasis.	Albucasis says so.
Summa huius sermonis quem narrauimus, expositio non est, nisi quando uident, quod aliquod horum apostematum iam opilauit guttur infirmi: et sublimatus est infirmus super mortem, et uult intersecari anhelitus eius: uadunt ad secandum Epiglotim, ut respiret infirmus super locum uulneris quadam respiratione, et saluetur a morte: et propter hoc praeceperunt dimittere uulnus apertum, donec consumatur malicia aegritudinis, et est malicia eius tribus diebus, et quasi ipsa: tunc ergo praecaeperunt suere uulnus, et curare ipsum, donec sanetur.	The sum of this speech we have related is not an explanation unless they see that one of these abscesses has already filled the throat of the sick person; and the patient is raised up to death, and wishes to be cut through in his panting: they proceed to cutting the epiglottis so that the patient may breathe on the place of the wound with a certain breath, and may be saved from death. And for this reason they have ordered the leaving open of the wound until the malignancy of the illness is consumed; and its malignancy is three days, or almost itself: then therefore they have ordered to stitch the wound, and to cure it until it is healed.
Et illud quod uidi per me ipsum est, quod una ancilla accaepit cultellum, et misit cum in guttur suum, et incidit cum eo partem cannalis pulmonis.	And what I witnessed was that one female servant took a knife and thrust it into her throat, thereby cutting through a part of the pulmonary canal.
Et uocatus sum ad curationem eius, et inueni eam mugire, sicut est mugitus mortui.	I was called to treat her, and I found that she was moaning like the moan of a dying person.
Detexi ergo a uulnere, et inueni sanguinem qui egressus fuerat ex uulnere paruum.	I therefore examined the wound and found that very little blood had come out of it.
Confisus ergo sum, quod ipsa non absciderat uenam, neque guidegi: et uentus egrediebatur ex uulnere.	I was therefore confused because she had not severed the vein or artery: yet air was coming out of the wound.
Properaui ergo, et sui uulnus, et curaui ipsum, donec sanum est: et non accidit ancillae aliquid, nisi raucedo in uoce: et rediit post dies ad meliorem dispositionum suarum.	I therefore prepared some warm water and cleaned the wound until it was healthy; and nothing happened to the female servant except that she had a hoarseness in her voice, and after several days she returned with an improved condition.
Hinc ergo dico: quod in sectione Epiglotis non est timor.	From this I say therefore: there is no fear in the incision of the epiglottis.
¶ De sectione Herniae gutturis.	On cutting an oesophageal hernia.
Caput XLIIII.	Chapter 44.
Hoc Apostema nominatum Hernia gutturis, est apostema magnum, secundum colorem corporis: et est in mulieribus multum.	This abscess named Oesophageal hernia is a large one, according to the colour of the body, and it occurs much more frequently in women.
Et est secundum duos modos: aut enim est naturale: aut est accidentale.	It occurs in two ways: either naturally or accidentally.
In naturali certe non est ingenium.	Certainly it is not natural genius.
Accidentale uero est secundum duos modos: quorum unus est similis nodis pinguibus.	It is accidental, however, in two ways: one of which resembles fatty lumps.
Et modus alter, est similis apostemati quod fit ex nodatione arteriae.	And the other way is similar to an abscess that forms from arterial pulsation.
Et in ipso est timor, et non oportet ut praesumptio fiat ad ipsum cum ferro, nisi in eo quod est paruum: et tu proba ipsum, et inuestiga ipsum cum Intromisso.	And it carries risk, and one should not presume to operate on it with an iron instrument, unless for a minor procedure; and you must first try it out, and investigate its interior using the introducer.
Si ergo inuenis ipsum simile nodo pingui, et non est suspensum cum aliqua uenarum: tunc seca ipsum, sicut secantur nodi: et extrahe ipsum cum eo quod continet ex kisti, si est in kisti: et si non, tunc perscrutare totum eius.	If you find it similar to a fatty tumor and not suspended by any of the veins, then cut it out as tumors are cut; and remove it together with whatever contents there are from the cyst, if it is in a cyst; or otherwise, then explore its entirety.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod oportet ex curatione, donec sanetur.	Then treat the site with what is required for healing, until it is healed.
¶ De sectione super species Nodorum.	On excision of superficial tumors:
Caput XLV.	Chapter 45.
Nodorum multae sunt species, et ego iam dixi omnes species eorum in diuisione: et oportet ut narrem hic differentiam inter Nodum, et Exituram: cum sit dubitationem faciens.	There are many types of tumors and I have already said all their types in the classification; it is necessary for me to explain here the difference between a tumor and an excrescence since this causes doubt.
Dico ergo, quod cum Exitura est caliditas, et febris, et dolores uehementes, donec sedatur ebullitio superfluitatis, et completur putrefactio: tunc enim quiescunt febris et calor.	I say therefore that when there is an excrescence, there is heat and fever, with violent pains until the boiling overflow of corruption subsides and is completed; then indeed do the fevers and heat subside.
Cum Nodo uero non est caliditas, neque febris, neque dolores, et continet eos kistis sifachin, qui est eis saccus proprius, et est secundum colorem corporis: et est incaeptio eorum sicut cicer, et fit sicut batecha, et maior et minor.	But with a tumor there is no heat, nor fever, nor pains; and they are contained by a cyst or sac which is their own case, and is of the color of the body; and its inception is like a chickpea, and it becomes like batecha, and is both larger and smaller.
Et sunt secundum duas species: aut pingues: aut continent humiditatem.	And they are of two types: either fatty; or containing moisture.
Et colores humiditatis sunt multi, secundum quod dixi in diuisione.	And the colors of moisture are many, as I said in the classification.
Oportet ergo, quando peruenis ad curationem Nodi, ut experiaris eum, et inquiras ipsum in primis cum instrumento quod nominatur Intromissum, secundum quod ueniet forma eius in capitulo quod est post hoc.	You must therefore, when you come to treat a tumor, examine it and probe it first with the instrument called an introiterator, according to which its form will come in the chapter that follows this one.
Et modus inquisitionis apostematum, et Nodorum omnium est, ut accipias hoc instrumentum, et intromittas ipsum in humidiorem locum, quem inuenis in apostemate: et tu reuolue digitos tuos cum eo paulatim, donec scias quod instrumentum iam penetrauit cutem.	And the method of probing abscesses and all tumors is this: take up that instrument and insert it into the moistest spot, which you find in the abscess; then turn your fingers with it gradually until you know that the instrument has now penetrated through the skin.
Deinde ultima manum tuam secundum mensuram magnitudinis apostematis.	Then measure out your hand according to the size of the abscess.
Deinde extrahe Intromissum, et considera illud quod egrediur in uestigio eius.	Then withdraw the introiterator and consider what comes out in its track.
Si ergo egreditur humiditas currens, quicunque color sit: tunc seca ipsum sectione superficiali, secundum quod dixi in reliquis apostematibus.	If, therefore, moisture flows out of it, whatever its colour may be; then dry it by a shallow incision, as I have said about other abscesses.
Et si non egreditur humiditas in uestigio Intromissi, tunc scias quia est pinguis: seca ergo super ipsum sectione habente formam crucis, secundum formam hanc, sicut docui te: et suspende ipsum cum uncinis, et excoria cutem ab omni parte cum facilitate: et custodi kistin si potes super illud, ut extrahas ipsam sanam cum Nodo.	And if no moisture comes out in the track of the introiterator, then know that it is a fatty tumor; therefore dry it by an incision having the form of a cross, like this one, as I have taught you: and suspend it with hooks, and scrape off the skin all round gently: and keep a poultice over it if you can to draw out the disease with the tumour.
Si autem disrumpitur kistis apud operationem, et non est possibile extrahere ipsam sanam, multotiens enim accidit illud, tunc extrahe ipsam frustatim, donec non remaneat ex ea aliquid.	But if the poultice is burst at the operation and it is not possible to draw out the whole of the disease, which often happens, then cut away every bit of it till there remains nothing more of it.
Nam si remanet ex ea aliquid parum, aut multum, redit Nodus secundum plurimum.	For if any part, small or great, remains, the tumour returns for the most part.
Quod si uincit te, et remanet ex eo parum: tunc imple uulnus apud completionem tuam, quibusdam pulueribus corrosiuis acutis: et stringe uulnus, et pone supra ipsum quod sedet apostema calidum, et cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	If it gets the better of you and there still remains a bit of it; then fill up the wound at its close with some sharp corrosive powders: bind up the wound, and put on what sits over the abscess warm, and treat it by the rest of the cure till it is healed.
Si ergo est Nodus magnus, tunc sue duo labia eius, et cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat.	If it is a large cyst, then its two lips, and treat it with that which causes flesh to grow into it.
Si autem est tibi contraria uena pulsatilis, aut non pulsatilis: tunc propera, et imple locum zegi trito, et dimitte ipsum strictum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec putrefiat uulnus, et quiescat ebullitio sanguinis: deinde redi ad incidendum illud quod remansit ex Nodo.	But if a pulsating or non-pulsating vein opposes you, then hurry and fill the place with pitch that has been pounded; leave it tight for two or three days until the wound becomes rotten and the boiling of blood subsides; then return to cut what remains of the cyst.
¶ De foris instrumentorum pro sectione et perforatione.	The instruments necessary for cutting and piercing.
Caput XLVI.	Chapter 46.
EX Eis sunt formae Intromissorum, et sunt trium specierum.	Among them are probes, which are of three types.
Ex eis enim est magnum, et ex eis est medium, et ex eis est paruum.	Of these, there is one large, another medium-sized, and the third small.
Fiant ex ferro alfulud quadratarum extremitatum decenter, ut festinent introitum in apostemate.	They should be made of iron wires with square tips to facilitate their entry into the abscess.
Et istae sunt formae Experientium, et no, id est, perforantia: et unum eorum nominatur beris, idest, peforans: et sunt trium specierum.	These are the probes, that is, piercing instruments; and one of them is called beris, that is, the piercer, which is also of three types.
Ex eis enim est magnum, et medium, et paruum.	Of these, there is one large, another medium-sized, and the third small.
Conueniunt, ut inuestigentur per ea apostemata, et exiturae, et fistulae, et bubones ab eo quod inter ea est ex ossibus.	They agree to be used to investigate abscesses, ulcers, fistulas, and buboes by that which is made of bone among them.
Et aliis fiunt rotunda, tersa, lenia, sicut acus magnae quibus subsellia suuntur, ex citrino scilicet, aut ex aere, aut ferro, aut argento.	Others are made round, smooth, and soft like large needles with which cushions are stuffed: that is, from leather or brass or iron or silver.
Et meliora eorum sunt quae fiunt ex citrino.	And the best of them are those made from leather.
Et fiunt Experientia etiam de plumbo nigro, quae conueniunt ut per ea experiantur fistulae, quarum concauitate sunt reflexiones, ut reflectantur cum lenitate sua cum illis reflexionibus.	Probes are also made of black lead for use in exploring fistulas with rough surfaces to gently rub against those surfaces.
Et sunt iterum trium specierum.	And there are again three types.
Quoniam ex eis sunt longa, ex eis media, et ex eis breuia, secundum quantitatem amplitudinis fistulae et stricturae eius.	Because from them there are long ones, from them medium ones, and from them short ones, according to the quantity of the length of the fistula and its stricture.
Forma Vncinorum, et sunt multarum specierum.	The form of splints, and they are of many types.
Quoniam ex eis sunt simplices, scilicet quibus est curuitas una: et sunt trium specierum sicut uides, Magni, Medii, et Parui.	Because from them there are simple ones, that is to say those which have one curve; and they are of three types as you see, large, medium, and small.
Et ex eis sunt Vncini caeci: et sunt trium specierum.	And from them there are blind splints; and they are of three types.
Et ex eis sunt uncini habentes duas curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et ex eis sunt uncini habentes tres curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et omnes isti sunt necessarii in loco suo.	And from them there are hooks having two curves, and they are of three types; and from them there are hooks having three curves, and they also are of three types; and all these are necessary in their place.
Et istae sunt formae Scalpellorum, quibus secantur et excoriantur Nodi, et apostemata: et sunt trium specierum: quoniam ex eis est magnum, medium, et paruum.	And these are the forms of scalpels with which nodes and abscesses are cut open and skinned; and they are of three types, because from them there is a large one, a medium one, and a small one.
Eorum extremitates quibus fit sectio sunt acutae, extremitates aliae sunt non acutae: et non ponuntur taliter, nisi ut cum eis fiat iuuamentum in excoriatione Nodorum apud timorem incisionis uenae, aut nerui: et ut sanetur per ea infirmus, et inueniat tranquillitatem parumper ex adustione quam inuenit apud excoriationem apostematis.	Their cutting ends are sharp and their other ends are not sharp; and they are not applied like this unless with them help is provided in the skinning of nodes for fear of incision into a vein or nerve; and so that the sick person may be healed by means of them, and find some relief from the burning compared to what he finds when the abscess is skinned.
Istae sunt Magda, et sunt specierum trium.	These are scalpels of the large kind, and they are of three types.
Fiunt ex aere, et sunt similia Radio, cum quo fit alcohol: et in extremitate lata est puncta Spatumilis occultata: et in ea currit ad interiora, et ad exteriora quando uis, sicut uides.	They are made of copper, and they are like a tube with which spirits are made; and at the wide end there is hidden a needle's point; and in it runs within to without as you wish, as you see.
Forma Spatumilium quae absconduntur inter digitos apud perforationem apostematum: et non percipiunt ea infirmi: et sunt trium specierum, magnum, medium, et paruum.	The shape of splinters hidden between the toes due to the ulcerated perforations: and they are not perceived by the patient; these come in three types, large, medium, and small.
Fomae Ventosarum cum quibus abscinditur fluxus sanguinis: et sunt trium specierum, magnae, mediae, et paruae.	Shapes of tourniquets with which the flow of blood is cut off; they are three types: large, medium and small.
Fiant ex aere, aut citrino, rotundae, ad longitudinem parumper, sicut uides: et sint ad subtilitatem.	They shall be made of brass or bronze, rounded, slightly elongated as you see; they should be thin.
Et oportet ut sint istae species Ventosarum apud te magnae, et paruae: ut abscindas per eas sanguinem cum uelocitate apud necessitatem, et tunc quando non est tibi praesens medicina.	And you should have these types of tourniquets with you in large and small sizes; so that you can quickly stop the blood flow when needed, especially when no medicine is available.
Verumtamen non utaris eis in abscisione sanguinis in omni loco corporis, et non utaris nisi in locis carnosis: sicut lacertis cruris, et coxae, et lacertis brachiorum, et mammillarum, et uentris, et inguinum, et similibus eis, ex lacertis carnosis, humidis.	However, do not use them to stop blood flow from any part of the body; only in fleshy parts such as the calf of the leg, hip, forearm, breast, abdomen, groin and similar fleshy, moist areas.
Et quandoque fiunt ex eis instrumenta parua alia similia corticibus fisticorum, secundum suam formam: quibus abscinditur sanguis quando fluit ex loco phlebotomiae, aut apud incisionem uenae, aut arteriae: et quandoque fiunt ex eis rotundae secundum hanc formam.	Sometimes small instruments are made in the same shape from thin strips of wood resembling almond shells; with which blood is stopped when it flows out of a phlebotomy site or after an incision into a vein or artery. Sometimes they're also made rounded like this.
¶ De cura Mammillarum hominum quae mammillis mulierum assimilantur.	On the treatment of male breasts resembling those of women.
Caput XLVII.	Chapter 47.
Quandoque inflantur Mammillae quorundam hominum apud complementum somni (id est, cum incipiunt pollui in somno) donec similantur mammillis mulierum: et remanent apostemosae foede.	Sometimes the breasts of certain men swell at the completion of sleep (that is when they begin to ejaculate during sleep) until they resemble those of women; and they remain ulcerated, ugly and sore.
Qui ergo abhorret illud, oportet ut secet super mammillas sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Deinde excoria pinguedinem totam.	Therefore he who is disgusted by it should cut above the nipple with a crescent shaped incision in this form from b to g; then scrape off all the fat.
Postea imple uulnus ex medicamine incarnatiuo.	Then fill the wound with incarnative medicine.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Next, bring together the two lips of the wound with a suture, and take care of it until it is healed.
Si autem declinat mammilla ad inferiora, et mollificatur propter magnitudinem suam, sicut accidit mulieribus: tunc oportet ut findatur in duobus lateribus suis superioribus duabus sectionibus similibus figurae lunari, quarum unaquaeque continetur cum altera apud fines utriusque, donec sit linea maior continens minorem, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Postea excoria cutem quae est inter duo labia, et aufer pinguedinem, et administra quod diximus de sutura et pulueribus, quod est necessarium ex curatione, donec sanetur.	But if the breast droops downwards and softens because of its size, as happens to women: then it must be cut in two on its upper sides with two similar cuts in a moon-like shape, each one containing the other at either end, so that there is a larger line enclosing a smaller one, like this form from line b. to line g. Then scrape away the skin between the two lips and remove the fat, and apply what we have said about sutures and powders which are necessary for healing until it is healed.
Si autem non comples incisionem eius quod oportet te incidere, propter inquietudinem infirmi, aut propter fluxum sanguinis: tunc oportet ut impleas uulnus coto submerso unguento corrosiuo, et dimitte ipsum, donec corrodat illud quod remansit ex pinguedine.	But if you cannot complete the incision of what needs to be cut because of the patient's distress or bleeding: then you must fill the wound with a piece of corrosive ointment and leave it until it has eaten away any remaining fat.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it until it is healed.
¶ De perforatione apostematis, quod accidit sub Titillico.	On the perforation of an abscess which happens under the armpit.
Caput XLVIII.	Chapter 48.
Ista apostemata quae accidunt sub Titillico, sunt ex speciebus Strophularum dura, quae continet kistis, et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates.	These abscesses which happen under the armpit are hard in nature and contain a collection of pimples or contain moist humours.
Quae ergo sunt ex eis quae continent humiditates, oportet ut secentur sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam, ex linea b. ad lineam, g. cum ergo euacuatur totum quod est in apostemate ex sanie, tunc imple ipsum coto ueteri, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Those which are of the moist type must be cut open with a moon-shaped incision like this form from line b to line g. When all the pus has been drained from the abscess then fill it with an old piece of cloth and leave it until the next day.
Deinde auferatur cotum, et curetur cum unguento conueniente ad illud, donec sanetur.	The wound should then be cleaned and treated with an appropriate ointment until it is healed.
Quod si apostema fuerit ex specie nodorum Strophularum, tunc scinde super ipsum, sicut diximus in sectione super Strophulas aequaliter.	If the abscess is of the type known as strophulus, then it should be lanced over its surface, as we have said in the chapter on strophuli.
Si autem extenditur uulnus in hoc ut emittat pus, tunc administra in eo cauterium, secundum quod diximus in eo quod praemissum est.	But if the wound discharges pus, a caustic should be applied to it, as we said above.
¶ De sectione apostematis quod accidit propter Arteriam et Venam.	On the excision of an abscess which occurs between an artery and a vein.
Caput XLIX.	Chapter 49.
Quando disrumpitur Arteria, et consolidatur cutis quae est supra eam, tuno multotiens accidit inde apostema: et similiter accidit Venae etiam, ut accidat in ea apostema et inflatio.	When an artery is torn and the skin above it heals over, an abscess often forms; likewise with a vein, so that an abscess and swelling may occur therein.
Et signa quibus cognoscitur, quod apostema et inflatio sint propter Arteriam et Venam, sunt: quoniam, quando apostema est propter arteriam, est longum, aggregatum in profundo corporis: et quando impellis apostema digits tuis, sentis quasi sit ei stridor.	The signs by which it can be recognized that the abscess and swelling are due to an artery and a vein are these: when an abscess is due to an artery, it is long and deep in the body; and when you press the abscess with your fingers, there is almost a crepitation.
Et illud quod est propter Venam, est rotundum in manifesto corporis.	And that which is due to the vein is round on the surface of the body.
Et sectio super hoc apostema est error, et praecipue quod est sub ascellis, et inguinibus, et collo, et in locis multis corporis: et est magnum ualde.	The incision of this abscess is a mistake, especially that which occurs under the armpits, groins, neck and in many places on the body; it is extremely dangerous.
Oportet ergo ut deuitetur eius cura cum ferro, et quod ex eis etiam est in extremitatibus, aut in capite, oportet ut deuitetur.	It should therefore be treated without the use of the knife, and even those which are on extremities or the head ought to be avoided.
Super illud ergo quod ex eis est ex inflatione orificii Arteriae, finde in cute sectione in longitudine.	In that which is due to the swelling of an artery's orifice, make an incision lengthwise on the skin.
Deinde aperi sectionem cum uncinis, postea Arteriam: et libera eam ex tunicis, donec detegatur.	Then open the incision with hooks, afterward the artery: and free it from its sheaths until it is uncovered.
Deinde intromitte sub ea acum, et fac eam penetrare usque ad latus aliud, et stringe Arteriam cum filo duplo in duobus locis, secundum quod docui te in extractione duarum Arteriarum quae sunt in timporibus.	Then introduce beneath it a needle and make it penetrate to the other side; then ligature the artery with double thread in two places as I taught you for extracting two arteries that are in the temples.
Deinde punge locum, qui est inter duo ligamenta cum spatumili, donec egrediatur sanguis qui est in eo totus, et soluatur apostema.	Then prick the place between the two ligaments with a spatula until all the blood which is there comes out and the abscess is discharged.
Deinde administra curationem quae generat pus, donec cadant ligamenta: postea cura illud cum unguentis conuenientibus ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then apply a treatment that produces pus until the ligaments fall off; afterward treat it with suitable ointments until it is healed.
Quod si fuerit apostema propter sectionem Venae, tunc oportet ut teneas manu tua quod tibi possibile est ex apostemate cum cute.	If the abscess is due to a vein having been cut then you must hold with your hand as much of it as possible together with the skin.
Deinde intromitte acum sub loco quem tenuisti manu tua, et fac eam penetrare: et sit in ea filum duplum, donec extrahas ipsum ex latere altero.	Then introduce the needle under that place which you held with your hand and make it penetrate; and let there be on it double thread until you withdraw it from the other side.
Deinde liga cum ipso apostema ligamento bono: secundum quod dixi tibi in ligamento uuae, a duabus partibus cum duabus extremitatibus fili.	Then ligature the abscess with it by means of a good ligature; as I told you for single ligaturing, from two sides with the two ends of the thread.
Si autem times quod extrahatur filum, tunc intromitte acum aliam cum filo alio sub apostemate toto apud incisionem acus: preme, et stringe fila tua in quatuor locis.	But if you are afraid that the thread will be withdrawn then introduce another needle with another thread beneath the whole abscess near the wound of the first needle; press and ligature your threads at four places.
Deinde seca apostema in medio sui, donec quando egreditur quod in eo est: tunc incide superfluitatem cutis, et dimitte quod ligatum est ex ea.	Then slit the abscess down the middle until all that is inside comes out; then cut off the superfluous skin and leave what has been ligatured from it as it is.
Deinde pone super ipsum puluillum quem submersisti in uino, et oleo.	Then put over it a poultice which you have steeped in wine and oil.
Deinde administra curationem, quae fit cum liciniis et unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then administer the treatment, which is done with bandages and ointments, until it heals.
¶ De apostemate quod accidit ex torsione Neruorum.	The abscess that occurs from nerve torsion.
Caput L.	Chapter 50.
Sicut accidit apostema in Arteria et Vena, similiter accidit apostema in Neruis: quod accidit in eis percussio, aut accidit a labore superfluo, et similibus: et fit plurimum illis in locis adiutoriorum, aut calcanei, et in omni loco in quo mouentur iuncturae: et est apostema graue.	Just as an abscess occurs in arteries and veins, similarly, an abscess can occur in nerves; this happens when they are struck or due to excessive effort, and similar things; it most often occurs in the regions of the assistants' [muscles] or calves, and in every place where joints move: and it is a severe abscess.
Similatur color eius reliquo corpori, et est in pluribus dispositionibus absque dolore: et quando stringitur cum uehementia, sentit in eo infirmus simile stupori.	Its colour is similar to the rest of the body, and it appears in multiple shapes without pain; and when it is squeezed with force, one feels in it a numbness like giddiness.
Et non est apostema aggregatum in profundo corporis, imo est sub cute, et ipsum mouetur ad omnem partem, et non uadit ad anteriora, uel ante, neque retro ad posteriora.	And it is not an abscess collected deep within the body, but under the skin; and it moves to every side, and does not go forward or back towards the front, nor backwards towards the rear.
Quod ergo ex eis est in iuncturis, non oportet ut inuadatur cum ferro.	What then arises from them in joints should not be invaded with iron [a knife or blade].
Fortasse enim accidet contractio.	Perhaps contraction will occur.
In illo autem quod ex eis est in capite, aut in fronte, finde cutem cum spatumili.	However, for that which is from them in the head or forehead, lift up the skin with a spatula.
Si ergo est apostema paruum, tunc tene ipsum cum forficibus, et abscinde ipsum a radice.	So if it is a small abscess, then hold it with forceps, and cut it away from its root.
Et si est magnum, tunc suspende ipsum eum uncino, et excoria ipsum: deinde aufer ipsum, et aggrega uulnus cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	And if it is large, then lift it up with a hook and scrape it; afterwards remove it, and collect the wound with a suture; then treat it until it heals.
¶ De sectione apostematis, quod accidit in uentre.	On the incision of an abscess that occurs on the abdomen.
Caput LI.	Chapter 51.
Accidunt quibusdam hominibus multotiens in uentribus eorum, et in reliquis corporibus ipsorum, thelil, quae nominantur Fungalia, per similitudinem ipsorum cum fungis.	There occur to some people frequently in their bellies and other parts of their bodies swellings which are called 'fungus', on account of their likeness to fungi.
Quorum radix est subtilis, et ipsorum caput est grossum, et conuersa sunt labia eorum.	The root of which is fine and their head is thick, and their lips are inverted.
Et est ex eis paruum: et est ex eis quod magnificatur ualde.	And there is some that are small; and there is some which grow to an extraordinary size.
Et ego quidem iam uidi uirum, et in uentre eius erant duo thelil, quae erant magis quam rebus aliis similia fungis: non erat differentia inter ea, alba, minutae radicis, et inuersabantur labia eorum, et findebantur, et humiditas currebat ex eis semper.	And indeed I have seen a man in whose belly were two swellings which more resembled fungi than other things: there was no difference between them except that the one had a white root and was smaller; and their lips were inverted and they discharged pus, and moisture flowed from them continually.
Incidi ergo ea, et inueni in pondere unius quasi X et VIII uncia et in altero quasi VI uncia Et operatio in incisione eorum est, ut consideres tunc, si infirmus est humidus, et color thelil est albus, humidum, subtilis radicis: tunc incide ipsum cum spatumili lato, et sint in praesentia tua cauteria in igne.	So I cut them out and found that one weighed about ten ounces and the other six. And when operating on them you should note that if the patient is moist of constitution and the colour of the swelling is white and it has a moist fine root, then you should cut it with a spatulate knife an inch wide; and have ready some cauteries in the fire.
Multotiens enim expellitur apud sectionem eius sanguis multus: propera ergo si te uincit sanguis, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	For frequently much blood is discharged when it is cut into; so if the bleeding gets the better of you, then cauterize it at once.
Quod si uides infirmum pauidum et timidum ab incisione cum ferro, tunc accipe filum ex plumbo decenter factum, et stringe cum eo athelul: cuius modus est quem diximus, et dimitte ipsum duobus diebus.	But if you see the patient fearful and timid about being cut with an iron knife, then take a thread well made of lead and bind it around the swelling in the manner which I have described; and leave it on for two days.
Deinde adde in strictura plumbi.	Then add some caustic powder to the binding of lead.
Non ergo cesses stringere plumbum, quotiens imprimit in thelil, donec abscindatur, et cadat per se absque labore.	So do not cease binding with lead whenever it bites into the swelling until it falls off by itself without further trouble.
Si autem thelil grossae fuerit radicis, tunc in incisione eius est quiddam timoris et pauoris: praecipue quod est in uentre.	If, however, the root of the tumor is large, then there is some fear and dread associated with making an incision into it; this is especially true for tumors located in the abdomen.
Verumtamen possibile est, ut incidas medietatem eius.	However, it is possible to cut it in half.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum, ut non redeat.	Then cauterize it so that it does not return.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	Treat the wound until it heals.
Et caue ne praesumas incidere thelil quod est fusci coloris, pauci sensus, foedi aspectus: ipsum enim est apostema cancerosum: et ego ueniam cum rememoratione Cancri post hoc.	Also be careful not to rush into cutting a tumor that is dark in color, has little feeling, and looks ugly; for it is indeed a cancerous abscess, and I shall come back with a reminder of Cancer later on.
¶ De cura eminentiae Vmbilici.	On the treatment of an umbilical hernia.
Caput LII.	Chapter 52.
Fit eminentia Vmbilici ex caussis multis.	An umbilical hernia forms for many reasons.
Aut ex fissuris sifac, quod super uentrem est: et exit ex eo althub, aut intestinum, secundum quod accidit in reliquis rupturis.	It occurs either because of a tear in the fascia above the abdomen through which protrudes an omentum or intestine, depending on what happens in other hernias.
Aut ex sanguine qui fluit ex Vena, aut ex Arteria, secundum quod praemissum est.	Or from blood that flows out of a vein or an artery, as has been mentioned before.
Aut ex uentositate coartata in eo.	Or from air trapped within it.
Si autem est propter fissuram sifac, et exitum thirbi: tunc est color apostematis similis colori corporis: et est lene, absque dolore: et apparet diuersi situs.	If it is due to a tear in the fascia and has an exit for feces, then it is the colour of an abscess-like body and is soft, pain-free, and appears at various sites.
Et si est propter egressionem intestini, tunc est situs eius, cum eo quod narrauimus, uehementioris diuersitatis.	And if it is due to the exit of an intestine, then its location will be of a more violent variety, as we have described above.
Cum ergo tu premis ipsum digitis tuis, occultatur: deinde redit, et fortasse est cum eo sonitus: et magnificatur multum apud introitum balnei, et laborem uehaementum.	When you therefore press it with your fingers, it disappears; then it returns and is perhaps accompanied by a sound; and it grows greatly upon entering the bath and with violent effort.
Si uero est propter humiditatem, est lene, tunc non occultatur quando premis ipsum manu tua, neque constringium, neque additur.	If it is due to moisture, it is soft; then it is not concealed when you press it with your hand, neither constricted nor added.
Quod si est propter sanguinem, tunc cum istis signis apparet apostema ad nigredinem de cliue.	If it is due to blood, then with these signs an abscess appears blackening the skin.
Si autem est propter carnem natam: tunc est apostema graue, grossum, durum, et figitur secundum quantitatem unam.	If however it is due to born flesh: then it is a grave abscess, large, hard, and swelling according to its quantity.
Si uero est propter uentositatem, tunc tactus eius est lenis.	If it is due to moisture, then its touch is soft.
Et operatio in illo est, ut consideres tunc, si eminentia umbilici est propter sanguinem Arteriae, aut Venae, aut uentositatem: tunc oportet ut prohibearis a curatione eius.	And the operation on it is, as you should then consider, if the navel's swelling is due to arterial blood, venous blood or moisture: then you ought to be restrained from its cure.
Nam in illo est timor et pauor, sicut docui te in capitulo, in quo dixi apostemata propter arteriam et uenam.	For in it is fear and dread, as I taught you in the chapter where I spoke of abscesses due to arteries and veins.
Quod si eminentia umbilici est propter intestinum, aut zirbum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo, quatenus teneat anhelitum suum, et stet stans extensus.	If the navel's swelling is due to intestine or stomach: then you ought to advise the patient to hold their breath and stand stretched out.
Deinde signa cum encaustro in circumitu umbilici totius.	Then mark with caustic around the navel's whole circumference.
Postea praecipe ei, ut resupinetur inter manus tuas super dorsum suum.	Afterwards instruct them to lie on their back between your hands on their back.
Deinde circunda cum spatumili lato in circumitu umbilici super locum quem signasti cum encaustro.	Then surround with a broad spatula around the navel on the place you marked with caustic.
Postea extende medium apostematis ad superiora, cum uncino magno.	Afterwards extend towards higher parts from the middle of the abscess with a large hook.
Deinde liga eum in circumitu forti cum filo, aut cum chorda de serico ligamento firmo: et sit nodus ligamenti alenxotati.	Then bind him around firmly with strong thread or a silk cord: and let the knot of the binding be slack.
Deinde aperi medium apostematis extensum supra ligamentum.	Then open the middle of the abscess, extending above the ligament.
Si ergo inueneris ipsum iam captum a ligamento: tunc extrahe alenxotati, et intromitte in ipsum digitum indicem, et impelle intestinum ad interiora uentris: et si inueneris zirbum, tunc accipe ipsum cum uncino, et incide superfluitatem eius.	If you therefore find it already grasped by the ligament: then extract the ilex hook and insert your index finger into it, pushing the intestine towards the interior of the belly; and if you find a cecum, then take hold of it with a hook, and cut off its superfluity.
Si autem contraria est tibi arteria, aut uena: tunc circunda ipsum multum.	But if the artery or vein is facing away from you: then grasp it firmly.
Deinde redi ad operationem tuam.	Then return to your operation.
Et accipe duas acus, et intromitte in eis duo fila fortia: et intromitte duas acus in circumitu quem fecisti circa apostema in modum crucis, quas facis penetrare.	Take two needles and thread a strong thread through each; then insert the two needles into the circumference you made around the abscess, arranged like a cross, ensuring they penetrate [the skin].
Deinde stringe apostema in quatuor locis super acus: et si uis, aufer acus, et dimitte locum, donec putrefiat caro extensa: et cadat per se: aut incide ipsam quando subtiliatur et putrefit.	Then draw the abscess together at four points above the needles; and if you wish, remove the needles, leaving an open area until the extended flesh becomes necrotic, and it falls away of its own accord; or cut it away when it is softening and becoming necrotic.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod oportet ex unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with the appropriate ointments until it heals.
Quod si eminentia umbilici est ex carne nara in eo, aut ex humiditate: tunc oportet ut concaues apostema, sicut diximus.	If the umbilical hernia is made of flesh with an opening into it, or if it's fluid-filled; then you must make the abscess concave as we described above.
Et extrahas sanguinem, aut humiditatem, quam inuenis in eo.	And extract any blood or fluid that you find inside it.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod solidat locum.	Then treat the hernia with what is appropriate to solidify the area.
¶ De cura CANCRI.	On the treatment of cancer.
Caput LIII.	Chapter 53.
Iam diximus in diuisione species Cancri, et qualiter est uia ad curationem eius cum medicinis: et cauendum ab eo cum curatione eius cum ferro, ut non ulceretur: et diximus Cancrum generatum in matrice, et cautelam a curatione eius.	We have already discussed the different types of cancer and how to treat them with medications; and we advised caution when treating it with iron instruments so as not to cause an ulceration; and we spoke about cancers that originate in the uterus and precautions against treating them.
Et dixerunt antiqui, quod quandoque Cancer est in loco, ubi possibilis est eius eradicatio: sicut Cancer qui est in mammillis, aut in coxa, et eis similibus, ex membris locatis ad extrahendum totum eius: praecipue quando est incipiens paruus.	And the ancients said that sometimes cancer is located in a place where its eradication is possible; such as cancer found in the breasts or hip, and similar locations on parts of the body which are easier to remove entirely; especially when it is small and just beginning.
Quando uero antiquatur, et est magnus, non oportet ut appropinques ei.	When however it has become old, and is large, you should not approach it.
Ego enim non potui sanare ex eo aliquem: neque uidi alium ante me qui peruenerit ad illud.	I myself could not heal anyone of it; nor have I seen any other before me who has reached it.
Et operatio in eo, quando est locatus sicut diximus, est, ut praecedas, et soluas infirmum ex cholera nigra aliquotiens.	And the treatment for it, when located as we have said, is to proceed with purging the patient of black bile several times.
Deinde phlebotoma ipsum si inuenis cum repletione manifesta.	Then perform bloodletting if you find it with clear engorgement.
Deinde praepara infirmum praeparatione, in qua locetur cum operatione.	Then prepare the patient for treatment, which should be done with care.
Deinde proiice in Cancrum uncinos qui conueniunt ei.	Then apply hooks to pull out cancerous tissue.
Postea concaua ipsum ab omni parte cum cute, secundum perscrutationem, donec non remaneat aliquid ex radicibus eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere, et non abscindas ipsum uelociter, imo exprime loca, et absterge sanguinem grossum totum manu tua, aut cum quo possibile est ibi ex instrumentis.	Next, scoop it out from all sides with the skin, according to examination, until nothing remains of its roots: and allow blood to flow without cutting quickly but by squeezing the areas and wiping off thick blood with your hand or any other suitable tool available.
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi fluxus sanguinis grossi ex incisione arteriae, aut uenae: tunc cauteriza uenam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	If however the flow of thick blood from an artery or vein presents a problem, then cauterize the vein until the blood stops flowing.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with the remaining treatment until cured.
¶ De cura Hydropisis.	On the Treatment of Dropsy.
Caput LIIII.	Chapter 54.
Iam narrauimus in diuisione species Hydropisis, et qualiter fit aggregatio aquae: et signa omnis speciei, et curationem eius cum medicinis.	Now we have described in the division of types of dropsy, and how the accumulation of water occurs: and all signs of each type, and its cure with medicines.
Et illa quae curatur cum ferro, non est nisi species asclitis sola: et non approximatur cum ferro speciei timpanitis: neque speciei hyposarcae penitus: nam illud mortale est.	And that which is cured with iron is only the type of ascites; and it does not approach with iron for types tympanitis or hyposarcum, for this is mortal.
Quando tu iam medicatus es hanc speciem Hydropisis timpanitis cum medicinis, et non contulit medicatio tua: tunc considera.	When you have been already treated this type of dropsy tympanitis with medicines, and it has not yielded to your treatment, then consider.
Nam si infirmo iam consecuta est debilitas, aut est cum eo infirmitas alia praeter Hydropisim: sicut si sit cum eo tussis, aut uentris solutio, et similia illis: tunc caue ne mediceris ei cum ferro: quoniam est timor illud.	For if the patient has already developed weakness, or there is another illness besides dropsy, such as a cough, stomach problems, or similar; then beware of treating them with iron, for it is to be feared.
Si autem uides infirmum exuberantis uirtutis, neque est cum eo aegritudo praeter Hydropisim solam: et non est puer, neque senex: tunc modus operationis in eo est, ut tu eleues infirmum stantem inter manus tuas, et minister post ipsum exprimat uentrem eius manu sua impellendo aquam ad inferiorem partem pectinis.	But if you see a patient with abundant strength, no other illness besides dropsy alone; and they are neither young nor old: then the method of treatment is for you to lift them up while standing between your hands, while an assistant behind them presses on their stomach with their hand, forcing water downwards.
Deinde accipe spatumile spinosum, secundum hanc formam.	Then take a sharp spine, shaped like this.
Sit duarum partium acutarum, longum, acutae extremitatis sicut Spatumile.	It should have two pointed parts, be long, with the point like that of a spine.
Verumtamen in eo sit quiddam breuitatis paulatim, ut non pertranseas cum eo apud operationem usque ad intestinum, et laedas ipsum.	Yet let there be some shortening along it gradually so you do not pierce through to the intestine during treatment and injure it.
Deinde considera.	Then consider...
Nam si est generatio Hydropisis ex parte intestinorum, tunc oportet ut elongeris cum sectione ab umbilico quantitate trium digitorum, ad inferiora in directo eius supra pectinem.	For if the dropsy has originated from the intestines, then it is necessary that you make an incision three fingers long below the navel, leading downwards towards the pubic bone.
Si uero generatio Hydropisis est propter aegritudinem epatis: tunc sit sectio tua sinistra ab umbilico tribus digitis.	If the cause of hydropsy is disease of the liver then your cut should be three fingers to the left of the navel.
Et si generatio eius est propter splenem, tunc sit sectio in latere dextro: et non oportet etiam ut sit sectio in latere super quod uult iacere infirmus, ut non currant superfluitates ad illum locum debilem.	And if its cause is the spleen then your cut should be on the right side and it must also be on whichever side the patient wishes to lie, so that superfluities do not flow towards a weak place.
Deinde perfora cum instrumento cutem totam.	Then pierce the skin entirely with an instrument.
Deinde intromitte in illam sectionem, et eleua manum tuam cum Spatumili inter cutem, et sifac, quasi tu excories ipsum: et sit quantitas quae excoriatur quantitas unguis, aut circiter ilud.	Then insert into that incision and raise your hand with a spatula between the skin, and scrape as if you are flaying it; and let what is scraped off be the size of a fingernail or thereabouts.
Deinde perfora sifac, donec perueniat Spatumile ad locum uacuum: et est locus aquae.	Then pierce that which has been scraped until the spatula reaches an empty space; this is a place of water.
Deinde extrahe ipsum, et intromitte in foramen instrumentum, cuius haec est forma.	Then extract it and insert into the hole an instrument that is shaped like this: [diagram of an instrument].
Et est simile cannulae: fit ex argento, aut aere, aut aurichalco, lene, tersum: cui in inferiori parte sui est foramen paruum, et in lateribus eius sunt tria foramina, duo ab una parte, et unum a parte altera: et facia est extremitas eius incisa, secundum modum incisionis calami, sicut uides: in extremitate eius superiore est armilla.	And it is like a cannula; it is made of silver or brass or gilded bronze, soft and clean; there is a small hole at its lower end, and on its sides are three holes, two on one side and one on the other: and its end is cut in such a way as to resemble the incision of a reed, as you see; at its upper end is an annular ring.
Nam quando instrumentum peruenit ad aquam, tunc ipsa descendit statim super instrumentum, ergo euacua ex aqua in hora quantitatem mediam.	For when the instrument reaches water then it immediately sinks on top of the instrument; so evacuate from the water at once half a measure [of liquid].
Quoniam si tu euacuas ex ea plus quam oportet, in hora fortasse moritur infirmus per resolutionem spiritus sui animalis: aut accidit ei syncopis quae appropinquat morti.	Because if you evacuate more than is necessary then perhaps at that moment the patient will die due to loss of his animal spirit; or he will suffer a swoon which approaches death.
Verum euacua ex ea secundum quantitatem uirtutis eius, et secundum quod significant tibi dispositiones infirmi ex uirtute pulsus eius, et ex bonitate eius.	Indeed, evacuate from it according to the quantity of its strength, and according to what the dispositions of the patient indicate to you regarding the strength of their pulse and their good health.
Deinde extrahe instrumentum, et retine aquam.	Then extract the instrument, and retain the water.
Quod est, quia retinetur statim propter cutem quae retinet foramen quod est super sifac: de quo narraui, ut perfores ipsum secundum illum modum.	This is because it is kept immediately next to the skin which retains the hole that is over the fistula: of which I have spoken, so that you may bore it according to that manner.
Deinde itera instrumentum die altero, si uides infirmum tolerare illud: et extrahe etiam ex aqua quantitatem paruam.	Then repeat the use of the instrument on the second day, if you see that the patient can tolerate it: and also remove a small quantity from the water.
Fac illud diebus aliquot sine timore, et custodi te ab errore: donec non remaneat ex aqua nisi parum.	Do this for several days without fear, and guard yourself against error: until there remains of the water only a small amount.
Si autem times super infirmum, et dimittis ex aqua rem multam: tunc cura ipsum cum sepultura in harena calida, et sudore multo in balneo et sole, et expectet super sitim: et cura ipsum cum medicinis exiccatiuis, donec sanetur: et cauteriza super stomachum, et epar, et splenem, post extractionem aquae: secundum quod narraui in eo quod praecessit.	But if you fear for the patient, and let out a large amount of water: then treat it with burial in hot sand, and much sweating in the bath and the sun, and allow them to suffer thirst: and treat it with drying medications until they are healed: and cauterize over the stomach, flanks, and spleen after the extraction of water: according to what I have spoken about previously.
¶ De cura infantium qui nascuntur locis urinae eorum non perforatis.	On the treatment of children who are born with their urine passageways unperforated.
Caput LV.	Chapter 55.
Quando egreditur aliquis infantium ex uentre matris suae, et caput mutonis eius est non perforatum, aut est foramen strictum, aut in non suo loco.	When any child emerges from their mother's womb, and the head of their penis is unperforated, or has a narrow hole, or is in the wrong place...
Oportet ergo succurrere cum perforatione eius statim cum nascitur cum Spatumili subtili ualde, secundum hanc formam.	It is therefore necessary to assist with its perforation immediately upon their birth using a very fine spatulam, in this form... [sketch omitted]
Deinde pone in foramine clauum subtilem ex plumbo, et liga ipsum: et tene ipsum tribus diebus, aut quatuor.	Then place a fine leaden peg in the hole and tie it; keep it there for three or four days.
