Et signum cui accidit illud est, quod denigratur membrum, donec putetur: quod ignis combussit ipsum, aut putrefit post nigredinem: donec inciditur illa putredo usque ad illud quod sequitur illud membrum, et serpit in totum corpus.	And the sign that this has happened is when the limb turns black until it seems burnt by fire or rotten after turning black; it must be cut off where the rot reaches to prevent its spread throughout the body.
Propera ergo cum incisione eius, et similiter si caussa corruptionis est a percussione quorundam uenenosorum: sicut scorpionis marini, et uiperae, et rutellae, et similium.	Therefore, prepare for the incision of it, and similarly if the cause of the corruption is from the sting of certain venomous creatures such as the marine scorpion, viper, rutela, and similar animals.
Si ergo corruptio, aut percussio est in extremitate digiti, tunc incide digitum, et non des spacium corruptioni, ut incedat usque ad reliquam manum.	If the corruption or sting is at the tip of a finger, then cut off that finger and do not give space to the corruption so it does not spread into the rest of the hand.
Et similiter si accidit in manu, tunc incide eam ex radice focilis, et non des spacium corruptioni, donec capiat in focili brachii.	Similarly, if it happens to the hand, then cut off that hand at its root and do not give space to the corruption until it reaches the arm.
Et si inuadit in eo, tunc incide brachium apud cubitum in iunctura sua.	And if it invades that part then cut off the arm at the elbow joint.
Si autem pertransit corruptio, et uides eum circiter cubitum: tunc in illo est mors infirmi.	But if the corruption has spread beyond the elbow, then the patient is doomed to death.
Et administrare praeter illud ex curatione, est quantitas uirtus.	And treating that besides with curative measures is an exercise in futility.
Et similiter fac de pede, quando inuadit corruptio in digito, tunc incide ipsum apud unum nodorum: et si capit in pectine pedis, tunc incide pedem totum.	Similarly, if the corruption invades a toe then cut it off at one of its joints; but if it reaches the instep then amputate the entire foot.
Si autem ascendit ad genu, tunc incide crus apud iuncturam genu.	If it rises to the knee, then make an incision in the leg at the knee joint.
Quod si corruptio iam peruenit supra genu, tunc non est in ea ingenium, nisi dimissio, et relinquere infirmum morti.	If the corruption has already reached above the knee, then there is no skill [to be employed] but to give up and leave the sick person to die.
Et modus incidendi membrum, aut serrandi ipsum est, ut stringas ligamentum in inferiori, quem uis incidere: et stringe ligamentum aliud supra locum.	The method of making an incision into a limb or sewing it up is to tighten the sinew below where you wish to make the incision; and then tighten another sinew above that place.
Et extendat minister ligamentum unum ad inferiora: et extendat minister aliud ligamentum superius ad sursum.	And the attendant should stretch one of these sinews downwards; and the other attendant should stretch the upper sinew upwards.
Et tu separa carnem quae est inter duo ligamenta, cum Spatumili lato, donec detegatur caro tota.	And you separate the flesh which is between these two sinews with a broad spatule until all of it has been uncovered.
Deinde incidatur, aut serretur.	Then make your incision or sew it up.
Et oportet, ut ponas ab omnibus partibus pannum lini, et non tangat Serra locum sanum: et accidat infirmo laesio addita, et apostema calidum.	And you should place a piece of linen cloth around all the parts [of the wound] and do not let the needle touch healthy skin; this will otherwise cause added injury to the sick person and hot abscesses.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis interius dum operaris, tunc cauteriza locum uelociter: aut pone super ipsum quosdam pulueres abscindentes sanguinem.	If there is a gush of blood internally as you are working on it, then cauterise the place quickly; or put some styptical powders upon it.
Deinde redi ad medicationem tuam, donec compleatur.	Then return to your medicating until you have completed the task.
Deinde liga membrum uulneratum cum ligamento conueniente ei, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then bind up the wounded limb with suitable bindings, and take care of it until it is healed.
Et ego narro tibi quod accidit uiro in pede suo, hoc idem accidens quod narro tibi.	And I tell you that this same accident happened to a man in his foot.
Quod est, quia accidit in pede suo nigredo, cum adustione quae assimilatur combustioni ignis: et corruptio illa in primis accidit in digito suo, donec coepit pedem totum.	That is because his foot was afflicted by a blackening like a burn which resembles the effect of fire; and this corruption first began on his toe before it spread to take over the whole foot.
Properauit ergo uir ex seipso, postquam uidit corruptionem incidere in membro cum uehementia eius, quod inuenit ex dolore, et adustione eius: et incidit ipsum apud iuncturam, et sanatus est.	The man therefore prepared himself, after seeing that the injury was affecting his limb with its severity which he found through pain and burning sensation; it affected him at the joint, but then he healed.
Et postquam praeteriit ei tempus longum, accidit ei illa eadem corruptio in digito manus suae indice.	And after a long period of time passed, the same injury occurred to him in the index finger of his hand.
Venit ergo ad me, et conatus sum recuperare illam superfluitatem cum eo quod posui super manum ex medicinis post mundificationem corporis eius: et non repercussa est superfluitas, et coepit incedere in digitum alium: donec coepit coruptio in manum.	He came to me, and I tried to remove the excess with him by using medicines which I placed on his hand after cleaning his body; however, it did not drain away, and began to move into another finger until the injury affected his entire hand.
Vocauit ergo me, ad incidendum manum eius: et nolui illud, sperans ex me super repercussionem illius superfluitatis: et timui etiam super ipsum apud incisionem manus eius mortem.	He therefore called for me to amputate his hand; I refused to do it, hoping that the excess could be drained by me, and also fearing death in relation to an amputation of his hand.
Quoniam uirtus uiri erat super casum.	Since the man's condition was advanced.
Postquam ergo desperauit de me, reuersus est ad terram suam: et peruenit ad me de eo, quia properauit, et incidit manum suam totam: et sanatus est.	After he had lost hope in me, he returned to his land; and he reached out for help from me because he prepared himself and amputated his entire hand, and then healed.
Et non attuli hanc narrationem, nisi ut sit adiutorium super illud quod cadit de genere huius aegritudinis: et ut sit significatio qua significetur, et secundum quam agatur.	I have not related this account except as a guide for those who suffer from this type of injury; and to indicate what can be indicated, and how it should be treated.
¶ De cura Sinuum, et qualitate clisterizationis cum medicinis.	On the treatment of hemorrhoids, and the nature of enemas with medicines.
Caput XC.	Chapter 90.
Quando accidit apostema in quibusdam membris carnosis, et prolongatur spacium apostematis, donec collectionem facit saniei: deinde rumpitur, aut perforatur, et egreditur quod in eo est ex sanie, et remanet locus uacuus quasi sit uas: et cutis quae est super ipsum sicut pannus qui iam subtiliatus est: et non peruenit ad ultimum in corruptione sua, neque imprimit in os, neque in neruum, neque in ligamentum: meretur ut nominetur Sinus: et non nominatur Fistula: uerumtamen si prolongatur spacium eius, donec imprimat corruptio in aliquid horum membrorum, tunc nominatur Fistula, aut zuken.	When an abscess occurs in some fleshy parts and the duration of the abscess is prolonged until it forms a collection of pus; then it ruptures or perforates, and what is inside of it, from the pus, comes out leaving an empty space like a vessel, and the skin over it is like cloth that has been worn thin: if it does not reach its ultimate stage in terms of corruption where it affects bone, nerve or ligament, it should be called a hemorrhoid; but if prolonged until the infection reaches one of these parts, then it may be called an abscess or zuken.
Et cura eius est, ut incidas illam cutem totam sicut reuoluitur: et praecipue quando subtiliata est, et facta sicut pannus: et confidis quia non aaehaeret cum loco, propter corruptionem suam.	And its treatment is to cut that skin completely as it peels off; especially when it has thinned and become like a cloth; and you trust that it will not stick to the wound due to its own decay.
Si autem speras quod adhaereat cutis, et non consequitur ex eo corruptio illa ultima consecutione: et si in cute est spissitudo ex carne, tunc cura ipsum cum Clisteri: et est, ut consideres ad Sinum.	But if you hope that the skin will stick and it does not follow from this ultimate attachment; and if there is thickness of flesh in the skin, then treat it with enemas; and it is necessary to pay attention to the abdominal cavity.
Tunc si est magnus, et pus quod emittitur ex eo est foetidi odoris: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum medicamine aegyptio, quod est aceti, et olei, et ziniar, partes recipiens aequales, aggregentur in uase: et decoquantur super ignem, donec rubeat medicamen: et ueniat in spissitudinem mellis.	Then if it is large and the pus emitted from it has a foul odor; then enema it with Egyptian medicine, which consists of equal parts vinegar, oil, and ziniar, combined in a jar; boil them over fire until the medicine reddens; and becomes as thick as honey.
Deinde accipe ex eo quod tibi necesse est: et dissolue ipsum cum aqua et melle, et clisteriza cum eo Sinum: et stringe orificium eius, et dimitte medicinam in eo ad quantitatem duarum horarum.	Then take as much of it as you need; and dissolve it with water and honey, and enema the abdominal cavity with it; compress its opening, and leave the medicine in for about two hours.
Deinde extrahe ipsum cum expressione: fac illud diebus tot, donec mundificetur Sinus, et remoueatur foetor.	Then extract it with pressure; do this for as many days as necessary until the abdominal cavity is cleansed and the stench is removed.
Et quandoque clisterizatur cum aqua cineris, quando non est tibi praesens hoc medicamen: et est, ut accipias cinerem lignorum uitis, aut cinerem ex lignis ilicis: et proiicias super eam aquam.	And sometimes enema with water of ashes when this medicine is not available to you; and it is necessary to take the ash of grapevine wood, or the ash of holm oak wood; and throw it into the water.
Deinde cola eam, et clisteriza cum ea, donec confidas quod Sinus iam ablutus est.	Then mix it well, and enema with it until you trust that the abdominal cavity is now cleansed.
Quod si infirmo non est tolerantia super medicamen aegyptium, neque aquam cineris, tunc clisteriza ipsum cum aqua et melle, cui iam permixtum est aliquid ex ziniar contrito.	But if the patient cannot tolerate Egyptian medicine or ash water, then enema them with water and honey mixed with a small amount of crushed ziniar.
Aut clisteriza ipsum cum melle et uino permixtis, quoniam de proprietate mellis est, ut mundificet, et abluat: et uinum facit adhaerere Sinum, praecipue quando in uino est superfluitas stipticitatis et siccitatis.	Or use an enema made with honey and wine mixed together, since the nature of honey is to cleanse and wash away impurities; and the wine makes the membrane adhere - especially when there is excess astringency and dryness in the wine.
Cum facis illud aliquotiens, et confidis quod Sinus corruptio iam remota est: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum eo quod facit nasci carnem in eo.	When you have done this several times and are confident that the corruption of the membrane has been removed, then use an enema made with whatever promotes flesh growth.
Et est, ut accipias ex emplastro dyafinicon: et dissoluas ipsum cum oleo rosato, et uino stiptico: aut clisteriza ipsum cum quibusdam medicinis, et unguentis aliis, quorum proprietates scripsi in tractatu unguentorum.	And it is good to take some dyaphinion plaster and dissolve it with rose oil and astringent wine; or use an enema made with certain other medicines and salves whose properties I have described in the book on salves.
Quod si orificium Sinus est strictum, in quo non capit cannula clisteris: tunc amplifica ipsum cum ferro parumper: aut pone in ipso licinium inuolutum in unguento aegyptio, aut in unguento basilicon, donec amplificetur.	But if the membrane's opening is tight and will not admit the enema pipe, then stretch it a little with an iron instrument; or apply to it linen wrapped around a stick that has been dipped in Egyptian ointment, or in royal ointment, until it is stretched.
Et similiter si est orificium etiam amplum, tunc aggrega labia eius cum sutura: et dimitte ex eo quantitatem in quam ingrediatur clistere sine additione.	And similarly, if the opening is also wide, then draw its lips together with a stitch; and leave as much of it outside as the enema tube can enter without difficulty.
Et similiter si orificium eius ex quo currit pus, est eleuatum ad superiora: tunc seca ipsum in depressiori loco qui est in ipso, ut currat ex eo pus usque inferius: quoniam pus quando coartatur in profunditate Sinus, prohibet carnem generari in eo.	And similarly, if the opening from which pus flows is raised towards the top, then cut it lower down on its own surface so that the pus can flow out downward; for when pus is confined within the depth of the membrane, it prevents flesh from forming there.
Quod si non est tibi possibile secare Sinum circiter inferius eius secundum quod uis: tunc conare, ut praepares membrum praeparatione qua currat ex eo pus cum facilitate secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	But if you cannot conveniently cut the membrane just below where you wish, then try to prepare the member in such a way that the pus will flow out easily as it is prepared for you.
Conare, ut non retineatur in eo aliquid ex pus omnino: et accipe medicinas consolidatiuas quae ponuntur super signum, conuenientes ad illud quod uis.	Try to ensure that no pus is retained in it at all; and take the consolidating medicines which are applied to wounds, suitable for what you wish.
Et extende eas super pannum lini.	And extend them over a linen cloth.
Et sit pannus tantae quantitatis, qua fiat communicatio totius Sinus.	And let the cloth be of such quantity that it covers the entire bosom (breast).
Deinde incide cum forficibus in directo orificii Sinus foramen, amplius orificio Sinus parumper.	Then make an incision with the scissors along the edge of the breast opening slightly beyond the nipple.
Deinde extende ex unguentis lenibus super pannum alium, secundum quantitatem foraminis: et pone eum super ipsum positione longinqua ab orificio Sinus, ut alleuietur exitus pus ex eo: et non auferas pannum magnum, nisi post dies aliquos uice una.	Then spread another soft ointment on the cloth according to the size of the nipple hole; and place it over the breast in a position away from the nipple opening so as to ease the outflow of pus from it: and do not remove the large cloth unless after some days have passed.
Ille autem qui est super orificium Sinus, est ille quem remoues in omni hora, ut egrediatur quod aggregatur in eo ex pus: et ut scias, an illud quod currit ex eo uirus, est multum, aut parum: aut digestum, aut indigestum.	But the one that is over the breast opening, is the one you remove every hour, so that what has collected in it of pus may flow out: and so that you know whether the fluid flowing from it is a lot or a little; digested or undigested.
Et cum hoc iterum considera locum Sinus ipsius, an in ipso sentiat dominus eius dolorem, aut non sit in eo dolor, et an sit in eo apostema, aut non sit in eo apostema.	And when you re-examine the breast itself, consider whether its owner feels pain in it or not; and whether there is a boil on it or no boil.
Cum ergo protenditur medicatio tua taliter, et uides materiam quae egreditur super orificium Sinus, tunc scias, quod Sinus iam adhaeret, aut approximat adhaerentiae: tunc ergo solue ipsum in mane, aut in tertio die: et quando soluis uulnus, tunc permuta pannum alium, et renoua unguentum.	When therefore your treatment has progressed thus and you see the material which comes out over the breast opening, then you know that the breast now adheres or is close to adhering; then therefore remove it in the morning or on the third day: and when you are removing the wound, then change to another cloth and renew the ointment.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post spacium longum uirus subtile, tunc non desperes de adhaerentia eius, nam sanatio eius appropinquat, quoniam ex hominibus sunt qui tardant generationem carnis in uulneribus suis, et ex eis sunt qui agunt econtrario illius.	But if a refined fluid emerges from the breast after a long time has passed, then do not despair of its adhering, for its healing is approaching; because there are people who delay the growth of flesh in their wounds, and some act contrary to it.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post dies multos pus indigestum, tunc scias quod sinus non adhaeret.	But if undigested pus emerges from the breast after many days, then you know that the breast is not adhering.
Si ergo tardatur adhaerentia Sinus, et prolongatur res eius: tunc adde in exiccatione medicinarum, uerum faciant medici, ut sint medicinae in substantia sua humidae, et in uirtute sua siccae: sicut unguentum dyafinicon, quando additur in eo superfluitas additionis ex zegi.	If the adherence of the sinus is delayed and its condition prolongs, then add to the drying medications, but let the physicians ensure that the medicines are moist in substance and dry in virtue, such as dyaphyinicon ointment when excess fat is added to it.
Et ex magis ultimo quo curatur, est, ut accipias unguentum dyafinicon, et soluatur cum oleo rosato, et roretur super ipsum uinum antiquum aequale in substantia sua.	And from the very last part that is treated, it is such that you should take dyaphyinicon ointment and dissolve it with rose oil, and moisten over it an equal amount of old wine by substance.
Deinde confice ipsum cum eo, et utere ipso.	Then prepare it with that, and use it.
Et iam facit simile huic actioni, quando non est tibi praesens unguentum dyafinicon, mel, quando decoquis ipsum, donec ingrossetur, et uteris eo.	And it now acts similarly to this procedure, when dyaphyinicon ointment is not present to you, use honey, when you boil it until it thickens, and use it.
Aut accipe myrrham, et aloen, et olibanum: tere totum, et pulueriza illud super mel dum est super ignem.	Or take myrrh, aloe, and frankincense: pound everything, and powder it over honey while it's over the fire.
Deinde line super ipsum pannum, et stringe ipsum super Sinum: et line cum melle quod decoquisti, donec ingrossatum est: et pulueriza super ipsum species, et pone super ipsum pannum, et stringe eum.	Then spread over it a cloth and bind it on the sinus: and spread over it the honey that you boiled until it thickens: and powder over it spices, and put over the cloth, and bind it.
Et quandoque administratur in illo aristolochia longa, et radices lilii coelestis, et est lilium: et farina herbi, et centaurea.	And sometimes it is administered with long birthwort, and roots of heavenly lily, and lily: and herb flour, and centaurea.
Utere eis simplicibus, aut aggregatis, tere ea, et cribella ipsa: et pulueriza super mel quod narraui, et utere eo.	Use these simples, or aggregate them, pound them, and sieve them: and powder over the honey I described, and use it.
Quod si prolongatur res Sinus, et non sanatur hac curatione: tunc scias, quod in profundo eius est corruptio: aut iam facit impressionem in ossibus, aut in reliquis membris duris, aut ligamentis: tunc cura ipsum curatione Fistularum, secundum quod praemissum est.	But if the condition of the sinus prolongs and it does not heal with this cure, then know that there is corruption within its depth: or it now causes an impression in the bones, or other hard tissues, or ligaments: then treat it with the cure for Fistulas, as stated before.
¶ De cura Panaritii et unguis attritae, et incisione digiti additi, et sectione.	On treating panaritium, nail attrition, finger incisions and amputations.
Caput XCI.	Chapter 141.
Panaritium est apostema quod nascitur sub ungue pollicis manus, aut pedis: et fortasse nascitur in reliquis digitis.	A panaritium is an abscess that develops under the nail of the thumb or toe, and it may occur on other fingers as well.
Cum ergo prolongatur res eius, et negligitur curato eius, et apostematur apostemate calido: aut corrumpitur, et emittit pus, donec corrodit radicem unguis: et fortasse corrumpit eam totam, et fortasse peruenit corruptio ad os, donec est ei odor foetidus: et fit extremitas digiti lata, et fit color eius fuscus.	If it is left untreated and the condition persists, the abscess may become an aposteme that fills with pus; or it may rot and discharge pus until it eats away at the nail bed, potentially corrupting the entire finger, reaching the bone, causing a foul smell, turning the fingertip wide and discoloured.
Quando ergo tu curas ipsum, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut incidas cum ferro totam superfluitatem quae remansit ex ungue.	When you treat it as we mentioned earlier and the treatment does not take effect, then you must use a knife to cut away all of the remaining excess from the nail.
Deinde cauteriza uulnus post illud.	Then cauterise the wound after that.
Cauterium enim iuuatiuum est ualde.	Indeed, hot cauterisation is very beneficial.
Si uero os est sanum, et est unguis etiam sana, et additiones uacuae unguis iam comprimunt carnem ad interiora, et incipiunt pungere ipsam, et laedunt eam: tunc oportet ut ponas Radium subtilem sub angulo unguis quae pungit carnem, et impelle eam sursum: et incide eam carnem cum facilitate, et pone super illud quod remanet de carne ex medicinis comburentibus, corrosiuis, donec remoueatur totum eius.	However, if the bone is sound and both nail bed and root are healthy, but excess nail growth now presses against flesh deeper down, piercing it or hurting it, then you should place a thin probe under the corner of the nail that pierces into the flesh and push it upwards; cut this flesh away gently and apply to what remains of the flesh any burning, corrosive medicine until all is removed.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with ointments until it heals.
Si autem corruptio iam imprimit in os, tunc oportet ut incidas illud os, et extrahas ipsum: non enim sanatur unquam dum permanet in eo os corruptum.	If however the infection has already reached the bone, then you must cut away and remove that bone; for it will never heal so long as the infected bone remains.
Quod si uides corrosionem et corruptionem incedere in digitum, tunc incide eum in uno nodorum, secundum quod praemissa est eius rememoratio.	If you see decay and deterioration progressing into the finger, then cut it off at one of the joints, according to what has been previously mentioned.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then treat the wound until it is healed.
Si autem accidat ungui attritio, aut percussio: et contingit in ea dolor uehemens, tunc oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	However, if there is a nail injury or blow, and severe pain occurs, then it is necessary to bleed the patient first with cupping glasses.
Deinde seca unguem cum Spatumili acuto sectione transuersa de sursum ad uisum.	Then cut the nail with an acute spatule by making a cross-section from above downwards.
Et custodi, ne sectio perueniat ad carnem quae est sub ungue, nam tu facies accidere per illud super infirmum dolorem uehementem, et erit caussa ad natiuitatem carnis additae in loco.	Watch out that the cutting does not reach the flesh underneath the nail, for you will cause severe pain to occur in the patient, and it may result in an addition of flesh at the site due to growth of new tissue.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod sedat dolores.	Then treat the site with something that will relieve pain.
Digitus uero additus qui nascitur in quibusdam manibus hominum, fortasse est carnosus totus: et fortasse sunt in quibusdam eorum ossa, et fortasse est in eo unguis: et quidam eorum nascitur in radice iuncturae, aut est natiuitas eius in quibusdam nodis digiti.	However, the extra finger that appears on some hands of people may be entirely fleshy; and there are bones in some of them, and a nail is present in some: and some of them appear at the base of the joint, or their origin lies in the joints of the digit.
Ille ergo qui nascitur in quibusdam nodis digiti, non mouetur: et ille qui nascitur apud iuncturam digiti, fortasse mouetur.	The one that appears in the joints of a digit does not move; but the one that arises at the joint of two digits may possibly be movable.
Eius ergo qui ex eis est carnosus, sectio eius facilis est.	Therefore, the sectioning is easy for the one among them that is fleshy.
Quod est, ut incidas ipsum apud radicem suam cum Spatumili lato.	That is, cut it at its base with a broad spatule.
Eius autem cuius natiuitas est in radice iuncturae curatio, est difficilis.	However, the treatment of the one whose origin is at the base of the joint is difficult.
Abstine ergo ab incisione eius.	Refrain therefore from cutting it.
In illo uero qui nascitur in digito apud ultimum nodorum, tunc oportet ut incidas in primis carnem eius incisione rotunda usque ad os.	However, in the case of one born with an extra digit near the last joint, you must first cut their flesh with a round incision until you reach the bone.
Deinde serra os cum una illarum Serrarum conuenientium ad illud.	Then saw the bone using one of those saws suitable for this purpose.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	After that, treat it until it is healed.
Consolidatio autem quae accidit digitis adinuicem, multotiens accidit aut ex natiuitate hominis, id est, nascitur cum eo, aut a consolidatione uulneris, aut combustione ignis, et similibus.	However, the joining together of fingers which happens either because of birth defects, or from wound healing, or burns from fire, and similar conditions.
Oportet ergo ut seces illam consolidationem, donec redeant digiti secundum formam suam naturalem.	It is therefore necessary to cut this joining together of fingers until they return to their original form.
Deinde pone inter eos licinia, aut pannos infusos in oleo rosato: ut non consolidentur uelociter, et separa inter eos: aut pone inter eos laminam plumbi subtilem, donec consolidetur locus secundum quod oportet.	Then place between them strips of linen or cloth soaked in rose oil, so that they do not heal quickly and separate them; or place between them a thin sheet of lead until the wound has healed as it should.
Et similiter si accidat consolidatio quibusdam digitis cum palma, tunc seca illam consolidationem, secundum quod praeparatur et conuenit figurae membri.	And similarly if joining occurs between some of the fingers and the palm, then cut this joining as is prepared and appropriate for the shape of the limb.
¶ De incisione Vitium.	Concerning the treatment of disfigurements by incision:
Caput XCII.	Chapter 92.
Uites sunt Venae inuolutae, grossae, plenae superfluitatibus melancholicis quae accidunt in pluribus membris corporis: et plurimum euentus earum est in cruribus, praecipue in cruribus iter agentium et laborantium, et portantium.	There are twisted, swollen veins full of melancholy humours which appear on many parts of the body; and their outcomes most often occur in the legs, especially those of walkers and workers, and bearers of heavy loads.
Oportet ergo ut administres excussionem corporis ex cholera nigra aliquotiens excussione forti.	It is therefore necessary to administer several strong bleedings in order to remove the black bile.
Deinde phlebotoma patientis eas basilicam.	Then use leeches on the patient's veins.
Curatio uero earum cum ferro, est secundum duos modos.	The treatment of these conditions with iron is done in two ways.
Vnus eorum est, ut secentur, et extrahatur sanguis niger.	One way is to make incisions and extract the black blood.
Et modus alter est, ut eleuetur Vena, et extrahatur tota.	Another method is to raise the vein and remove it entirely.
Sectio uero eius est secundum hunc modum.	The incision is made in this way.
Embroca crus in primis cum aqua calida multum, donec resoluatur sanguis grossus faeculentus.	Soak the leg first with hot water until the thick, dirty blood dissolves.
Deinde stringe crus infirmi a superiori parte coxae eius, usque ad inferiorem partem genu cum uitta.	Then bind the patient's leg from the upper part of their hip to just below the knee with a cloth.
Deinde seca uenam in loco uno, aut duobus, aut tribus sectione ampla.	Then cut open the vein at one place or two or three places with broad incisions.
Deinde eleua, id est, extrahe sanguinem in manu tua ab inferiori parte cruris, usque ad sursum, et a superiori oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	Then raise it, that is, extract the blood with your hand from the lower part of the leg to above and let the patient's attendant first stop the bleeding with a cauterizer.
Deinde seca unguem cum usque inferius: donec egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uides sufficere, et quam tolerat uirtus infirmi.	Then cut the nail down to the quick until you see that enough blood has come out and as much as the patient can tolerate.
Postea liga eam: et praecipe ei, ut abstineat a cibis generantibus choleram nigram: et itera euacuationem et phlebotomiam, quando implentur Venae, et nocet illud infirmo.	After that bind it and tell the patient to avoid foods which produce black bile; repeat the evacuation of the bowels and bloodletting when the veins fill up again and harm the patient.
Eleuatio autem eius est secundum hunc modum.	Its raising is done in this way.
Rade crus infirmi, si in ea sunt pili multi.	Shave the patient's leg if there is much hair on it.
Deinde intromitte ipsum in balneum: aut embroca ipsum in crure eius cum aqua calida, donec rubeat, et exuberentur Venae: aut exercitetur exercitio forti, si non est ei praesens balneum, donec calefiat membrum.	Alternatively put the patient in a bath or else soak their leg with hot water until it reddens and the veins stand out or let him exercise vigorously with strong movement if no bath is available until his limbs are warm.
Deinde seca cutem in directo uenae sectione per longitudinem: aut in ultimo eius apud genu, aut in inferiori parte eius apud calcaneum.	Then cut the skin with a straight incision along the vein's length: either at its end near the knee or on its lower part near the heel.
Deinde aperi cutem cum uncinis, et excoria uenam ab omni parte, donec appareat sensui: et est apud apparitionem eius, quod uides eam rubeam ad nigredinem decliuem.	Then open the skin with hooks and scrape the vein from all sides until it becomes apparent to the touch; you will know that this is so when you see it become red, gradually turning black.
Cum ergo uadit ex cute, uides eam albam quasi sit chorda.	As such, once it has come out of the skin, you see that it is white like a cord.
Deinde intromitte sub ea Radium, donec quando eleuatur et egreditur de cute: suspende eam cum uncino caeco, leni.	Then insert a rod under it until you see that when raised, it comes out of the skin; suspend it gently with a blunt hook.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam prope illam sectionem tribus digitis.	Then make another incision close to that first incision, three fingers away from it.
Deinde excoria cutem a superiori parte uenae, donec appareat.	Then scrape the skin above the vein until it becomes apparent to the touch.
Deinde eleua eam cum Radiis sicut fecisti, et suspende eam cum uncino alio, sicut fecisti in primis.	Then raise it with rods as you did before, and then suspend it with another hook just like what was done first.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam, aut sectiones plures, si indiges illo.	Then make another incision or more incisions if you need to do so.
Deinde eleua, et incide ipsam ultima sectione apud calcaneum.	Then raise it up and then make the last incision near the heel.
Deinde extrahe eam ad sectionem quae est supra eam.	Then pull it out to the incision above it.
Et fac illud, donec extrahas eam ex sectione quae est superior, uel altior sectionibus omnibus, donec quando egreditur tota: tunc incide eam.	Do this until you pull it out of the top incision or any higher ones until it comes out fully; then cut it.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad extrahendum, et eleuandum: tunc intromitte acum cum filo forti duplo, et liga eam, et extrahe ipsam: aut intromitte sub ea Radium: et reuolue manum tuam ad omnem partem, donec egrediatur.	But if it does not obey you when pulling and raising, then insert a needle with a strong thread twice through it and tie it, then pull it out; or put a rod under it: turn your hand in all directions until it comes out.
Et caue, ne incidatur.	And take care not to cut it.
Nam si incidatur, fit difficile tibi eleuare eam ualde, et ingreditur super infirmum ex ea nocumentum.	For if you do cut it, it becomes difficult for you to raise it greatly, and it enters the patient from that harm.
Cum ergo extraxeris eam totam: tunc pone super locum uulnerum lanam submersam in uino et oleo rosato, aut oleo: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	So when you have extracted it all: then place over the wound a piece of wool soaked in wine and rose oil, or just oil; and tend it until it is healed.
Quod si Vitis est contracta, habens tortuositatem cui sit inuolutio ad partes, et non est sicut diximus secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut findas super eam ad omnem partem tortuositatis eius, et loca inuolutionis ipsius.	But if the vein is twisted, having a turn to the sides, and is not as we said straight: then you should cut over it on all sides of its twist, and the places of its folding.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncinis, donec eleues eam totam: et caue apud sectionem tuam super eam ne incidas uenam, aut uulneres: nam difficile fiet super te eleuare, uel extrahere eam.	Then suspend it with hooks until you raise it all; and take care at your cutting over it not to cut the vein or injure it: for it will be difficult for you to raise or extract it.
Conserua ergo prudentiam tuam.	Therefore, preserve your prudence.
Forma Incidentis quo sanatur Vitis.	The form of the occurrence by which a vein is healed.
Forma Vncini caeci.	Form of the blind incision.
Non est ei curuitas sicut reliquis Vncinis, neque est acutae extremitatis, ut non uulneret uenam: et est grossae flectuositatis, lenis: quoniam si esset subtilis, incideret uenam subtilitate sua: imo sit ei superflua grossitudo, sicut diximus.	It does not have the curvature of other incisions, nor is it sharp-ended so as not to wound the vein; and it is thick, curved, and soft: for if it were thin, its thinness would cut into the vein; rather let there be superfluous thickness to it, as we said.
De extractione Venae cruris.	On the extraction of the thigh vein.
Caput XCIII.	Chapter 93.
Haec Vena generatur in cruribus in terris calidis, sicut Alizegi, et terra Arabum, et in terris aridis, calidis, paucae teneritatis, id est, in quibus non nascitur herba, neque arbor.	This vein is generated in the legs in hot lands, such as Alizegi, and the land of the Arabs; and also in dry, hot lands with little moisture: that is to say, those where neither grass nor tree grows.
Et fortasse generatur in locis aliis corporis praeter crura.	And perhaps it generates in other parts of the body besides the legs.
Et generatio quidem eius est a putrefactione quae accidit sub cute, sicut accidunt intra corpora serpentes et uermes ascarides, et uermes generati inter cutem et carnem.	And its generation is indeed from the putrefaction that occurs beneath the skin, just as it happens within the bodies of snakes and roundworms, and worms generated between the skin and flesh.
Et signum incaeptionis euentus huius Venae est, quod accidit in crure inflammatio uehemens.	And the sign of the onset of this condition is that a severe inflammation occurs in the leg.
Deinde uesicatur locus.	Then the area should be cauterized.
Deinde incipit Vena exire ex loco illius uesicationis, quasi sit radix plantae, aut animal.	Then the vein begins to emerge from that place of cauterization, like the root of a plant or an animal.
Cum ergo apparet ex ea extremitas eius, tunc oportet ut inuoluas super ipsam frustum plumbi, cuius pondus sit ex drachma keil, usque ad drachmas II et noda ipsam: et dimitte plumbum suspensum ex crure.	When its end becomes visible, you should wrap around it a piece of lead weighing between one and two drachmas and tie it with string; then leave the lead hanging from the leg.
Quotiens ergo egreditur ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, inuolue illud in plumbo, et noda illud.	So whenever anything comes out of it to the outside, wrap that in lead and tie it up.
Quod si prolongatur multum, tunc incide partem eius, et inuolue residuum.	But if it extends for a long time, then cut off that section and wrap the remainder.
Et non incidas eam radicitus antequam egrediatur tota.	And do not cut it off entirely until it has completely emerged.
Quoniam si incidis, contrahitur, et ingreditur in carnem: et facit accidere apostema, et putredinem in loco, et ulcus malum.	For if you cut it off, it contracts and enters the flesh; this causes an abscess to form, as well as decay in that place, and a bad ulcer.
Quapropter oportet, ut suauiter tractetur, et extrahatur paulatim, donec egrediatur ex ultimo sui, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid in corpore: et ex hac quidem Vena egreditur in quibusdam hominibus quod est in longitudine sua quinque palmorum et decem.	Therefore it should be handled gently and drawn out little by little until it has emerged completely, leaving nothing of it inside the body; this vein emerges from some people to a length of five and ten palms.
Et iam peruenit ad me, quia exiuit uiro ex XX palmis.	He has now arrived with a wound that measures twenty palms in length.
Si autem inciditur tibi in hora medicationis tuae: tunc intromitte radium in foramine eius, et perfora eam foramine longo, cum corpore, donec euacuetur totum quod est in ea ex materia: et administra putrefactionem loci cum medicinis diebus aliquot.	But if it happens to you at the time of your treatment: then insert a rod into its hole and pierce it with a long hole, with a body, until all that is inside it has been evacuated; and apply the rotting of the place with medicines for several days.
Deinde cura ipsum curatione apostematum.	Then treat it with treatment for boils.
Et haec quidem Vena quandoque habet ramos multos, praecipue quando apparet in iunctura pedis, aut in pede ipso: et accidunt ei orificia multa, et egreditur ex omni orificio ramus.	And indeed this vein sometimes has many branches, especially when it appears at the ankle joint or on the foot itself; and it happens to have multiple openings, and a branch comes out from every opening.
Cura ergo ipsam, sicut diximus in diuisione, et cum eo quod praemissum est.	Treat it therefore as we have said above, and with what has been mentioned before.
¶ De sectione super Vermes generatos sub cute, et dicitur Aegritudo bouina.	On the operation for worms generated under the skin, which is called bovina disease.
Caput XCIIII.	Chapter 94.
Haec Aegritudo nominatur in quadam terra apud nos Aegritudo bouina: propterea, quia multotiens accidit bouibus, et est uermis paruus unus, qui nascitur inter cutem et carnem.	This disease is called bovina disease in a certain region among us; because it often happens to cattle and it is a small worm that is born between the skin and flesh.
Et uadit in corpore toto, ascendendo et descendendo: et ostenditur sensui apud ambulationem eius de membro ad membrum, donec disrumpit ubicumque disrumpit in cute locum, et egreditur.	And it penetrates the entire body, going up and down; and it can be felt during its movement from one limb to another until it bursts through wherever it ruptures a place on the skin and comes out.
Et generatio eius est ex putredine quorundam humorum.	And its generation is from the rotting of certain fluids.
Sicut accidunt uermes et serpentes, id est, lumbrici, et ascarides in uentre.	As happens with worms and snakes, that is, earthworms, and roundworms in the belly.
Et timetur ex malicia eius.	And it is feared because of its evil.
Quia quando ipse uadit in corpore, et eleuatur ad caput, et peruenit ad locum: tunc fortasse aperit in eo, et egreditur, et destruit oculum: et accidit illud multotiens.	Because when it enters the body and is elevated to the head, and reaches its place, then perhaps it opens up there and exits, destroying the eye; and this happens many times.
Cum ergo uis curare eum, et extrahere ipsum, tunc non fit illud nisi apud ambulationem eius, et apparitionem ipsius sensui.	How then do you want to cure him and extract it, then that won't happen unless during his walk and the appearance of its symptoms.
Oportet ergo, ut stringas quod est supra eum, et quod est sub eo cum ligamento constrictione forti.	It is therefore necessary to tie up what is above him and what is below with a strong binding ligature.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then cut above it and extract it.
Quod si profundatur in carne, et non inuenis ipsum: tunc pone super locum cauterium cum igne, donec moriatur.	But if it is buried in the flesh and you do not find it, then place a hot iron on the spot until he dies.
Et maius quod timetur, est corruptio eius, qua corrumpit oculum, sicut diximus.	And the greater fear is its corruption, which corrupts the eye, as we said.
Si autem uides eum iam peruenisse in capite prope oculum, tunc stringe sub eo supercilium strictura bona.	But if you see that it has already reached the head near the eye, then bind beneath it the eyelid with a good bandage.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then cut above it and extract it.
Et oportet ut utatur infirmus mundificatione sui corporis, cum medicinis soluentibus humores putridos malos.	And the patient must use cleansing of his body with medicines that dissolve harmful putrid fluids.
Et caueat sibi a cibis generantibus putrefactionem.	And he should beware of foods that cause putrefaction.
¶ De sectione super aegritudinem Nakir.	On the incision for Nakir's disease.
Caput XCV.	Chapter 95.
Haec aegritudo nominatur in terra nostra Nakir: et est dolor qui accidit in quibusdam membris: deinde permutatur de membro ad membrum.	This disease is called Nakir in our land, and it is a pain that occurs in some limbs, then shifts from limb to limb.
Et ego quidem iam uidi ipsum, secundum quod narro tibi.	And I myself have indeed seen it, as I am telling you.
Vocatus sum ad mulierem infirmam in quibusdam uillis.	I was called to a sick woman in some villages.
Et detexit brachium suum, et uidi inflationem paruam in uena funis brachii.	And I found her arm swollen, and I saw slight inflammation in the vein of the biceps tendon.
Et postquam remansi hora una, uidi unam inflationem incedere cum focili, sicut incedit uermis, ascendendo ad humerum eius uelocius quam esse potest: ut sit sicut argentum uiuum, quando currit de loco ad locum.	And after I stayed for an hour, I saw one inflammation advancing with little sparks, like a worm moves, ascending to her shoulder faster than it is possible; as if it were live silver running from place to place.
Recessit ergo dolor ex illo loco, et fixus est in humero.	The pain receded from that spot, and was fixed in her shoulder.
Deinde sedi hora una, et cucurrit in reliquum corpus, donec perueniret in brachium aliud.	Then I sat for an hour, and it rushed into the rest of her body until it reached her other arm.
Deinde narrauit mihi, quia reuoluebatur in toto corpore suo, secundum quod uidi.	Then she told me that it was revolving through her entire body, just as I saw.
Miratus sum ergo de uelocitate permutationis eius de membro ad membrum.	I was amazed at the speed of its transition from limb to limb.
Et ego quidem ante illud non uideram hanc aegritudinem oculis meis taliter secundum hunc modum.	And indeed, I had never before seen this illness with my own eyes in such a way.
Verumtamen uidi multos, qui inueniunt dolorem permutari de membro ad membrum: et non uidi ipsum oculis, sicut uidi eum in muliere.	However, I have seen many who find that their pain shifts from limb to limb; and I have not witnessed it with my own eyes as I did with this woman.
Et ego non cogito illud esse, nisi quod est propterea, quod mulier fuit ex illis qui sunt ex uillis sicci corporis detectarum uenarum: hinc ergo apparet sensui illa uentositas permutata.	And I do not think it is anything other than the fact that she was among those from dry villages whose veins are easily spotted; therefore, this shift in sensation appears windy to them.
Et est necesse, ut non appareant secundum hanc rationem in illis qui sunt deliciosi, et corporibus humidis, occultarum uenarum.	And it is necessary that this not appear according to this reasoning for those who are luxurious and have moist bodies with hidden veins.
Cum ergo uis curationem eius, et sentit patiens illud dolorem: tunc si est apparens tibi oculo, sicut diximus, tunc stringe supra ipsum, et sub ipso uelociter: et seca supra ipsum, donec egrediatur illa uentositas coartata: et cauteriza locum.	When you wish to cure her, and the patient feels this pain; then if it is visible to your eye as we have said, then squeeze firmly above it, and underneath it quickly; and cut over it until the windiness escapes, constrained; and cauterize the spot.
Si autem non uides ipsum oculis tuis: tunc cura ipsum cum excussione corporis, et cum eo quod expellit uentositates, et carminat eas cum pillulis foetidis, et pillulis de serapino, et similibus.	If you cannot see it with your own eyes: then treat it with a shaking of the body, and with that which dispels viscous substances, and let it purge them with foul pills, and with pills made from serapin, and similar substances.
¶ De extractione Sagittarum.	On the extraction of arrows.
Caput XCVI.	Chapter 96.
Sagittae diuersificantur secundum species suas, et secundum loca in quibus cadunt ex corpore.	Arrows vary according to their types, and according to the places in which they fall from the body.
Earum uero diuersitas est: quoniam ex eis sunt quae habent cuspides magnos, et paruos: et concauae, et surdae.	Their diversity is such that among them are some which have large barbs, and small ones: hollow, and solid.
Et ex eis sunt quae habent tres angulos.	And there are those which have three edges.
Et ex eis quibus sunt linguae.	And from these some have barbs.
Et ex eis quibus sunt astellae.	And there are those which have stars.
Illae uero quae sunt secundum membra in quibus cadunt, est secundum duos modos.	Those which fall according to the limbs into which they fall are of two kinds.
Aut enim membra sunt ex membris principalibus concauis, sicut cerebrum, et cor, et epar, et pulmo, et renes, et intestina, et uesica, et eis similia.	For either the limbs are from the hollow principal members, such as the brain, and heart, and spleen, and lungs, and kidneys, and intestines, and bladder, and similar organs.
Quando ergo cadit in aliquo horum membrorum, et apparent tibi signa mortis, quae ego narro tibi post, tunc oportet ut deuites extractionem illius sagittae ex eis, nam mors consequitur illum in quo est, in pluribus dispositionibus.	When it falls into one of these limbs, and you see the signs of death that I will tell you about afterwards, then you must avoid extracting that arrow from them, for death follows him in whom it is, in many situations.
Et quando non apparent tibi ista signa mala, et sagitta non est absconsa in profunditate membri, tunc extrahe ipsam, et cura uulnus.	And when these evil signs do not appear to you, and the arrow is not hidden deep within the limb, then extract it, and treat the wound.
Ex signis enim cerebri quando cadit in eo sagitta, et penetrat os, et egreditur siphac quod est super cerebrum, est: quoniam accidunt ex illo soda uehemens, et scotomia, et uertigo, et rubedo in oculis, et inflatio, et rubedo linguae, et spasmus, et permixtio intellectus, et uomitus cholerae.	For the signs from the brain when an arrow falls into it, and pierces the bone, and emerges from the fontanel which is above the brain, are: for violent pain occurs to him, and dimming of vision, and dizziness, and redness in the eyes, and swelling, and a red tongue, and spasms, and clouding of intellect, and vomiting of bile.
Et fortasse egreditur sanguis ex naribus, aut auribus.	And perhaps blood comes out through the nose, or the ears.
Et fortasse abscinditur sermo, et destruitur uox.	And possibly speech is cut off, and the voice is destroyed.
Et egreditur ex loco uulneris humiditas alba similis pulti.	And out of the place of the wound comes forth white moisture resembling pus.
Et exit ex eo simile aquositati carnis.	And from it emerges flesh of similar consistency.
Si ergo apparent tibi ista signa, tunc abstine a curatione, et extrahe sagittam si non egreditur.	If therefore these signs appear to you, then desist from the cure, and extract the arrow if it has not come out.
Signa autem sagittae quando cadit in corde, sunt: quod ipsa est prope mammillam sinistram: et sentit cum ea quasi ipsa sit fixa in re dura, non in re uacua.	The signs of an arrow having struck the heart are: that it is near the left nipple; and he feels with his hand as though it were fixed in something hard, not empty.
Et fortasse sagittae est motus similis motui pulsus: et currit ex uulnere sanguis niger.	And perhaps the arrow has a motion similar to the pulse; and black blood flows from the wound.
Et sequitur illud frigus extremitatum, et sudor frigidus, et syncopis.	And it is followed by coldness of the limbs, and cold sweat, and fainting.
Scias ergo, quod mors descendit procul dubio.	You should therefore know that death has surely set in.
Et signum sagittae quando uulnerat pulmonem, est exitus sanguinis spumosi ex uulnere: et uasa quae sequuntur collum, apostematur, et mutatur color infirmi.	And the sign of an arrow having struck the lung is the emergence of foamy blood from the wound; and the veins which follow around the neck become swollen, and the colour of the patient changes.
Et expirat spiritum magnum, altum: et quaerit attractionem aeris frigidi.	And he emits a great, deep sigh; and seeks to draw in cold air.
Quod si cadat sagitta in uelamen, quod est in pectore: tunc est prope costas paruas: et fit anhelitus magnus cum dolore uehementi, cum suspirio: et mouentur omnia membra humerorum.	If the arrow strikes the membrane that is in the chest, then it is near the lower ribs; and there is great panting with severe pain, together with a sigh; and all parts of the shoulders move.
Et si cadat sagitta in stomachum, tunc fortasse egreditur ex uulnere ex cibo aliquid indigestum.	And if the arrow strikes the stomach, then perhaps undigested food comes out from the wound.
Et si cadit sagitta in Ventrem, et figitur in eo: egreditur aliquid stercoris ex uulnere, aut zirbum, aut intestinum quod iam disruptum est.	And if an arrow falls into the belly and lodges there: some feces may exit from the wound, or a bladder, or intestines that have already been perforated.
Non est ergo spes in curatione eius, neque in extractione sagittae.	Therefore there is no hope of curing him, nor of extracting the arrow.
Quod si sagitta cadat in Vesicam, et egrediatur urina: et procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, et fortior sit dolor super infirmum: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	But if the arrow falls into the bladder and urine escapes from it: and something comes out to the exterior, and the pain is more intense above the wounded person: then you know that it is fatal.
Reliqua autem membra, sicut facies, et collum, et guttur, et spatula, et adiutorium, et spondiles dorsi, et furcula, et coxa, et crus, et eis similia ex membris saluantur secundum plures dispositiones: quando non inuenit sagitta arteriam, aut neruum: et non est sagitta uenenosa.	The remaining body parts, such as the face, neck, throat, shoulder blade, collar bone, spine, hip, leg and similar members can be saved according to many different treatments when the arrow has not struck an artery or nerve, and is not poisonous.
Et ego narro tibi quod uidi de esse harum sagittarum, ut significes per illud super curationem tuam.	And I tell you what I have seen regarding these arrows so that it may guide your treatment.
Quod est, quia cuidam uiro cecidit sagitta in lachrymali oculi eius, in radice nasi.	That is to say, an arrow fell into the eye of a man, at the root of his nose.
Extraxi ergo eam ipsi ex parte altera, sub adipe auris eius: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei in oculo eius nocumentum.	So I extracted it from the other side, beneath his ear fat; and he was cured without any damage to his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam Iudaeo, quae cecidit ei in adipe oculi sui sub palpebra inferiori: et sagitta iam occultata erat, et non consecutus sum ex ea nisi extremitatem paruam eius, cum qua adhaeret in ligno suo: et erat sagitta magna ex sagittis arcuum Turcorum, cum ferro leni, in qua non sunt aures.	And I extracted another arrow from a Jew which had fallen into the fat of his eye beneath his lower eyelid; and already it was hidden, but I could only grasp its small tip attached to its shaft: this arrow was large among Turkish archery arrows with a rounded head lacking ears.
Sanatus est ergo Iudaeus, et non accidit in oculo eius accidens malum.	So the Jew was cured without any bad accident happening to his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam ex gutture Christiani.	And I extracted another arrow from the throat of a Christian.
Et erat sagitta arabica, et est illa cui sunt aures.	The arrow was Arabic, and it belonged to him who has ears.
Secui ergo super ipsam inter duas guidegi: et iam submersa erat in gutture eius.	Therefore I secured the arrow between two guide wires above it, and by then it was already submerged in his throat.
Subtiliatus sum ergo cum ea, donec extraxi eam: et sanatus est Christianus.	I thus operated with care until I extracted it; and the Christian was cured.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam uiro quae ceciderat in uentre eius: et cogitauimus, quia moreretur ex ea.	And I extracted another arrow from the man who had fallen on it; and we thought he would die from that.
Postquam ergo praeterierunt ei triginta dies, et non mutatum est super eum aliquid ex dispositionibus eius, secui super sagittam: et ingeniaui super eam, et extraxi eam: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei accidens malum.	After thirty days had passed and nothing in his condition changed, I therefore secured the arrow above it; and I applied ingenuity to this [arrow] and extracted it; he was cured, and no misfortune befell him.
Et uidi uirum cui cecidit sagitta in dorso eius, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam.	And I saw the man who had fallen on an arrow in his back, and the wound over it was healed.
Postquam ergo fuit post septem annos, exiuit sagitta in radice coxae eius.	After seven years had passed, the arrow came out at his hip's root.
Et uidi mulierem cui cecidit in uentre suo sagitta, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam, et remansit sagitta intra ipsam: et non mutata est ex dispositionibus eius aliqua, et mulier non inuenit ei nocumentum in aliqua ex operationibus suis naturalibus.	And I saw a woman who had fallen on an arrow in her belly; and the wound over it was healed, and the arrow remained inside of her: and none of her conditions changed, nor did she find any harm to herself by any of her natural functions.
Et uidi uirum alium, cui cecidit sagitta in facie sua: et consolidatum est uulnus, et remansit, non inueniens ei multum dolorem: et similia istis multa.	And I saw another man who had fallen on an arrow in his face; and the wound was healed but it remained there without causing him much pain; and many similar things like this.
Et extraxi sagittam uiro ex principibus Regis, quae ceciderat ei in medio nasi sui, et iam declinauerat ad partem dextram parumper: et occultata erat sagitta tota.	And I extracted an arrow from the chief among the king's men which had fallen on him at the middle of his nose and already it bent a little bit towards the right; and all of the arrow was hidden.
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius post casum sagittae usque ad tres dies.	I was called to treat him after the arrow wound for three days.
Inueni ergo uulnus sagittae strictum ualde.	I found therefore that the arrow wound was very tight.
Inquisiui ergo eam cum tenta subtili, et non sensi eam: et ipse quidem inueniebat punctionem et dolorem sub aure sua ex parte dextra.	So I examined it with a thin probe, and did not feel it; yet he himself discovered the puncture and pain under his right ear.
Speraui ergo, quod erat illa punctio ex extremitate sagittae.	I hoped therefore that it was a puncture from the tip of the arrow.
Emplastraui ergo locum cum emplastro in quo erat uirtus attractiua, et digestiua, confidens apud me, quod apostemaretur locus, et appareret mihi signum sagittae, ut secarem super eam: et non accidit in loco accidens significans quod sagitta consecuta sit locum.	So I dressed the place with a plaster which had an attracting and digesting power, hoping that the spot would become sore and reveal to me the sign of the arrowhead so that I might cut over it; but nothing happened in this place to indicate that the arrow-head was there.
Assiduaui ergo cum emplastro super eum diebus multis: et non accidit accidens, et consolidatum est uulnus interim: et remansit infirmus de extractione eius spacio dierum, donec sensit sagittam die quodam intra nasum suum.	I kept dressing it for many days with the same plaster; and nothing happened, but meanwhile the wound healed up; and he remained weak from the extraction over a space of some days until one day he felt an arrow inside his nose.
Et narrauit mihi illud.	And he told me about it.
Posui ergo super illud uulnus medicinam acutam, corrosiuam diebus multis, donec apertum est: et cum tenta tentaui ipsum, et sensi extremitatem sagittae subtilem quae adhaeret in ligno.	I therefore placed a sharp corrosive medicine on the wound for many days until it was opened; and with the probe I probed inside it, and felt the thin end of the arrow-head which was sticking into some wood.
Deinde addidi in apertione uulneris per illam medicinam acutam, donec apparuit nobis uisibiliter extremitas sagittae: et praeteriit mihi cum eo spacium temporis circiter quatuor menses.	Then I added to the opening of the wound by means of that sharp medicine until the end of the arrow-head became visible to us; and this process took about four months.
Deinde postquam amplificatum est uulnus, et possible fuit mihi intromittere forcipes in ipsam, et mouere ipsam, et non obediuit ad exitum: tunc non cessaui subtiliare, et ingeniare super eam cum modis ingeniorum, donec coepi super eam die quodam cum forcipibus decenter factis, secundum quod ueniet forma eorum in fine capituli, donec extraxi eam.	Then after the wound had been made wider and it was possible for me to introduce a pair of forceps into it and move them about without success; I did not desist from contriving and planning means of extracting it with various instruments until one day I began upon it with a specially-made pair of forceps, which will be described at the end of this chapter, until I extracted it.
Deinde restauraui uulnus.	Then I healed the wound.
Et medici quidem iudicant, quod cartilago nasi non restauratur.	And indeed doctors judge that the nose cartilage does not heal.
Restauraui ergo ipsam, et consolidatum est uulnus, et sanatus est infirmas sanitate integra: nec nocuit ei aliquid omnino.	I therefore healed it, and the wound was consolidated, and the patient was cured completely; nor did anything harm him at all.
Et ego narro tibi qualitatem extractionis quarundam sagittarum: ut ponas illud regulam et significationem super illud quod non dixi.	And I tell you the process of extracting certain arrows, so that you may place that rule and its significance over what I have not said.
Quoniam partes huius artis et distinctiones earum non comprehenduntur cum narratione: neque comprehendit illud liber, et artifex prudens comparat cum pauco super multum: et cum eo quod est paesens, super illud quod est absens: et inuenit operationem nouam, et instrumentum nouum apud descensus rerum extranearum huius artis quando accidunt.	Since the parts of this art and their distinctions are not covered together with the narration; nor does a book comprehend it, and a prudent artisan compares little things to great ones: and what is present, to that which is absent; and finds new methods, and new instruments for the problems of unfamiliar cases in this art when they arise.
Dico ergo, quod sagittae non egrediuntur ex membris quibus sunt fixae, nisi secundum duos modos.	I say therefore that arrows do not come out of the members in which they are fixed unless according to two methods.
Aut per attractionem ex loco ex quo intrauit.	Or by pulling it from the place where it entered.
Aut contrario partis alterius.	Or by pushing from the opposite side of the other part.
Et illa quae egreditur unde intrauit, aut est sagitta procedens in loco carnoso: et attrahitur, et egreditur.	And that which comes out where it entered is either an arrow proceeding into a fleshy place; and it is pulled, and comes out.
Quod si non obedit ad exitum ex hora in qua cadit: tunc oportet ut dimittas ipsam aliquot diebus, donec putrefiat caro quae est in circumitu eius: et alleuietur attractio eius, et eius egressio.	If it does not obey and come out of the hour that it fell, then you must leave it for a few days until the flesh around it becomes rotten; and its pull is eased, and its exit.
Et similiter si figitur in osse, et non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc dimitte ipsam etiam aliquot diebus: et itera eam cum attractione et motione omni die, donec egreditur.	And similarly if it is fixed into a bone and does not obey you to come out, then leave it for some days too; and repeat pulling on it and moving it every day until it comes out.
Quod si non obedit tibi ad exitum post dies, tunc oportet ut perfores in circumitu sagittae in ipso osse ab omni parte cum terebro subtili, donec amplificentur sagittae.	If it does not obey you with an exit after a day, then you must perforate around the arrow on the very bone from all sides using a fine trephine until the arrows are enlarged.
Deinde attrahe eam, et extrahe ipsam.	Then pull it out, and extract it.
Si autem sagitta est fixa in capitis osse, et iam processit in uno uentrium cerebri, et apparent ex infirmo quaedam illorum accidentium quae dixi: tunc abstine ab attractione sagittae, et dimitte eam, donec aequetur esse eius post dies.	But if the arrow is fixed into the bone of the head and has already penetrated one ventricle of the brain, and there appear in the sick person some of those accidents which I mentioned, then desist from pulling out the arrow, and abandon it until its level becomes even after a day.
Nam si sagitta peruenit ad sifach, tunc mors non prolongatur ei.	For if the arrow reaches the Sifach, then death will not be prolonged for him.
Et si sagitta non est fixa, nisi in corpore ossis tantum, et non penetrat usque ad sifach: et remanet infirmus aliquot diebus, et non accidit ei ex illis accidentibus aliquid: tunc ingenia in attractione sagittae et extractione eius.	And if the arrow is not fixed except into the body of a bone only and does not penetrate all the way to the Sifach, and he remains sick for some days without any of those accidents happening to him, then exercise your skill in pulling out the arrow and extracting it.
Si autem est fixa ualde, et non obedit tibi ad attractionem: tunc administra terebella in circumitu sagittae, sicut narraui tibl: deinde cura locum, donec sanetur.	But if it is fixed very firmly and does not obey you to be pulled out, then apply the trephine around the arrow as I have described; afterwards treat the place until it heals.
Si autem Sagitta iam absconsa est in loco corporis, et occultatur et absconditur a sensu: tunc inquire eam cum tenta.	But if the arrow is already concealed within some part of the body where it escapes the sense of feeling, then search for it with a probe.
Si autem sentis eam, tunc attrahe eam cum quibusdam instrumentis quae conueniunt attractioni eius.	But if you feel it, then pull it out using some instruments that are suitable for pulling it out.
Si autem non potes super eam, propter constrictionem uulneris, et propter longitudinem sagittae in profundo: et non est illic os, neque neruus, neque uena: tunc finde super eam, donec amplificetur uulnus, et sit possibile extrahere sagittam.	But if you cannot manage it because of the tightness of the wound and because of the length of the arrow being deep inside; and there is no bone or nerve or vein in that place to prevent you: then wait over it until the wound widens, and it becomes possible to extract the arrow.
Quod si sunt ei aures quibus teneatur, tunc libera carnem fixam in eis ab omni parte, omni ingenio quo potes illud, et ingenia, si non potest super euasionem carnis in fractura aurium, et contorsione earum, donec euadat.	If there are ears to which it is attached, then free the flesh fixed on them from every side and by all means you can do so, and use tricks if you cannot without tearing away the flesh at the fracture of the ears, and twisting them until they come out.
Et tu quando administras extractionem Sagittae, in quocumque loco est, tunc utere contorsione manus tuae, cum forficibus ad partes omnes, donec facias eam euadere: et subtilia ultima subtilitate, ut non frangatur Sagita, et fiat difficilis tibi attractio eius, et ipsius extractio.	And when you perform the arrow extraction in any place it is located, then use your hand to twist and scissors for all parts until you make it come out: and with extreme caution so as not to break the arrow, which would make its retrieval difficult.
Quod si non potes super eam ex hora una, tunc dimitte eam diebus aliquot, donec putrefiant quae sunt in circumitu eius.	If you cannot remove it within an hour, then leave it for a few days until the tissue around it becomes rotten.
Deinde itera eam: alleuietur enim tuncia Si uero contrarietatem tibi facit fluxus sanguinis, tunc administra quod diximus ex curatione in capitulo suo: et custodi uirtutem tuam ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, aut chordae.	Then try again to remove it: the pain will have subsided by then. If the bleeding is a problem for you, then perform what we said regarding treatment in its own chapter. And take care with your skill so as not to cut an artery or nerve.
Et administra ingenium omni modo quo tibi possibile est euasionis Sagittae: et sit illud cum facilitate, et tranquillitate, uel tarditate, et firmitate, sicut narraui tibi.	And apply every trick you can to remove the arrow as easily and calmly as possible, with slowness and strength just as I have described it for you.
Et oportet, ut facias cum trahis Sagittam, ut infirmus sit secundum figuram, secundum quam fuit apud casum Sagittae in ipso.	And you must make sure that the patient is positioned during arrow extraction in just as they were when shot by it.
Quoniam est magis iuuatiuum.	Because it will be of greater benefit to them.
Si autem non est tibi possibile illud, tunc administra quod tibi est possibile ex figuris.	If that is not possible for you then apply what is possible according to the positioning of the patient.
Sagitta autem quae egreditur ex contrario partis alterius, aut iam procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora: aut facit gibbositatem extremitas Sagittae per sensum ex superiore parte cutis propinquae, et uides eam eminentem: seca ergo super eam, et sit sectio secundum quantitatem quod capiant in ea forcipes.	If the arrow is exiting from another part of the body or something has already emerged to the outside, or if you see that a bulge is forming at the end of the arrow through your senses on the upper side of nearby skin: cut above it and make an incision large enough to fit scissors into.
Deinde attrahe eam: ipsa namque fit facilis ad exitum.	Then pull it out; for it now becomes easy to remove.
Si uero retinetur in osse, tunc torque manum tuam secundum rotunditatem, donec imprimat Sagitta in osse, et amplificet sibiipsi: deinde trahe ipsam.	If it is retained within the bone, then turn your hand according to its curvature until the arrowhead embeds itself into the bone and widens; subsequently, pull it out.
Et si non: dimitte eam diebus aliquot: deinde itera eam, donec egrediatur.	And if not: leave it for several days; then try again until it exits.
Quod si lignum Sagittae est in ea, tunc impelle ipsam cum eo.	If the arrow shaft is within her, push it out with that too.
Si autem cecidit lignum, et uis administrare impulsionem: tunc intromitte ad eam instrumentum concauum, ut ingrediatur concauitas eius in caudam Sagittae: deinde impelle eam cum ipso.	If the shaft has fallen out but you wish to administer a push: then introduce into it an implement with a concave end so that its cavity may encompass the tail of the arrowhead; subsequently, push it along with the latter.
Si autem Sagita est concaua, tunc impelle eam cum instrumento intrante in ipsam.	If, however, the arrowhead is concave: push it along with an instrument entering into its concavity.
Sagitta enim alleuiatur per illud.	Indeed, for the latter will alleviate the pain of the arrowhead's exit.
Quod si Sagitta est toxicata, tunc oportet, ut concaues carnem totam, in qua est uenenum: si est tibi possibile illud.	If the arrowhead is poisoned, it is necessary to scoop out all the flesh containing the poison; if you are able to do so.
Deinde cura eam cum eo quod conuenit ad illud.	Then treat it with whatever is suitable for its healing.
Quod si Sagitta est cadens in pectore, aut in uentre, aut in uesica, aut in latere: et est propinqua ex eo quod tangis cum tenta, et possibile est tibi secare super eam: tunc seca, et caue ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, et extrahe eam.	If the arrowhead is lodged in the chest, or abdomen, or thigh, or side; and it can be reached with your probing fingers, and you are able to cut above it: then do so, being mindful of any veins or nerves that may lie nearby, and extract it.
Deinde sue uulnus, si uides, et cura illud, donec sanetur.	Then sew up the wound if you see fit, and treat it until it is healed.
Et haec est forma Forcipum, quibus extrahuntur Sagittae.	And this is the form of the forceps with which arrowheads may be extracted.
Sint extremitates similes rostro auis, quae factae sunt sicut ferra: quando capiunt super Sagittam, non dimittunt eam.	The extremities are like a bird's beak, which have been made like iron: when they grasp the arrowhead, they do not let it go.
Et fiunt ex eis species multae, magnae, et paruae, et mediae, secundum quantitatem magnitudinis Sagittae, et paruitatis eius, et amplitudinis uulneris, et constrictionis eius.	And they come in many shapes and sizes: large, small, and medium, according to the size of the arrowhead, its smallness, the width of the wound, and its tightness.
Forma Impellentis concaui.	The shape is that of an impelling concave.
Et forma Impellentis surdi.	And the shape is that of a deafening impulse.
Hoc est surdae extremitatis sicut Radius, ut alleuietur introitus eius in sagittam concauam, et impellatur cum eo.	This is the deaf extremity like a wedge, so as to ease its entry into the concave arrowhead and drive it with itself.
Huius extremitas impellentis concauae est concaua sicut penna auis: ut alleuietur introitus sagittae in ipsam et impulsio eius.	The extremity of this concave impulse is concave like a bird's feather, so as to ease the arrowhead's entry into it and its impelling force with itself.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum.	On venesection of veins.
Caput XCVII.	Chapter 97.
Uenae phlebotomandae, quarum cucurrit consuetudo in corpore, sunt triginta.	The veins that have become accustomed to venesection in the body are thirty in number.
Ex quibus in capite sunt sexdecim: duae Venae pulsatiles, quae sunt post aures, dictae duae Herbae: et duae Arteriae, quae sunt in duobus timporibus apparentes: et duae Venae quae sunt in duobus lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, quae dicuntur Aspicientes: et Vena praeparata in medio frontis: et uena quae est in extremitate nasi.	Of these, there are sixteen in the head: two pulsatile veins that are behind the ears, called the two Herbs; and two arteries that are visible in the two temples; and two veins that are in the two lacrimals of the two eyes, which are called Watchers; and a vein that is prepared in the middle of the forehead; and a vein that is at the end of the nose.
Et duae Guidegi, quae sunt in collo.	And two Guidegies, which are in the neck.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio superiore oris.	And two veins that are in the upper lip of the mouth.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio inferiore.	And two veins which are in the lower lip.
Et istae sunt uenae quae dicuntur Algecherich.	And these are the veins that are called Algecherich.
Et duae uenae quae sunt sub lingua.	And two veins which are under the tongue.
Venae autem quae phlebotomantur in brachiis, sunt quinque uenae in omni brachio.	Veins however that are phlebotomized in the arms, are five veins in each arm.
Vna earum est Cephalica, et est ex latere syluestri: et nominat eam uulgus uenam capitis.	One of them is the Cephalic vein, and it lies on the side of the wrist; and the common people call this the head vein.
Et Fusca.	And the second one is the Basilic vein.
Et est Media uena, et est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae: et nominat eam uulgus uenam corporis.	And the third one is the median vein, which branches from both the Basilic vein and the Cephalic vein; this common people call it the body vein.
Et Basilica, et est posita in latere domestico: et nominatur etiam Titillicaris.	And the Basilic vein is located on the inner side of the arm; it is also called the ulnar vein.
Et nominat eam uulgus uenam uentris.	And the common people call this belly vein.
Et Funis brachii, et est posita super focile: et est illa in qua phlebotomatur, et est illa quae apparet supra pollicem appatitione manifesta.	And the Brachial vein is situated on top of the forearm; this is the one that is phlebotomized and it appears above the thumb as a prominent bulge.
Et Saluatella: et est uena quae est inter annularem et minimum: et sunt ei duo rami.	And the superificialis vein; this is situated between the ring finger and little finger, and it has two branches.
Et in crure et in pede sunt tres uenae.	And there are three veins in the leg and foot.
Vna earum est quae est sub pollicis curuatura ex latere syluestri.	One of them is located underneath the curvature of the thumb on the outer side.
Et secunda est Saphena: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere domestico.	The second is the saphenous vein, which lies near to the heel on the inner side.
Et uena Nesse: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	The vein Ness: and its location is by the heel bone on the side of the silvester.
Et in crure alio sunt tres uenae similes illis.	And in the other calf there are three veins similar to those.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum uenarum post Aures.	Regarding bloodletting of two veins behind the ears.
Phlebotomiae uero duarum uenarum quae sunt post Aures, iuuamentum est ad catarros antiquos, et hemigraneam, et sahafati, et ulcera capitis mala antiqua.	Bloodletting of the two veins behind the ears is beneficial for chronic catarrh, headache, and old head ulcers.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eam est secundum quod narro.	And the quality of performing bloodletting is as I describe it.
Et est, ut radatur caput infirmi: et fricetur occipitium eius in loco duarum uenarum cum panno aspero fricatione bona.	And the patient's head should be shaved, then their occipital region is rubbed thoroughly at the site of the two veins with a coarse cloth and thorough friction.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareant duae uenae.	Then the patient should tighten their neck with a cord until the two veins appear.
Et loca earum sunt post Aures in duobus locis depressis capitis.	And their locations are behind the ears at two depressed areas of the head.
Quaere ergo eas digito tuo, et ubi sentis pulsum earum sub digito tuo, illic signa cum encaustro.	So probe for them with your finger, and wherever you feel their pulse under your finger, there mark it with the cauterizing iron.
Deinde accipe phlebotomum cultellarem, et est ille qui dicitur Incidens.	Then take up the lancet-type bloodletting tool, which is called the "Incising" one.
Deinde intromitte ipsum sub uena in cute, donec perueniat phlebotomus ad os.	Then insert it under the vein into the skin until the bloodletting cup reaches the mouth of the incision.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum uena et cute ad superiora, et incide uenam cum cute incisione incidente.	Then lift your hand with the vein and skin upwards, and cut the vein and skin in an incising motion.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quantitas duorum digitorum iunctorum, aut circiter illud: et fac exire ex sanguine quantum uis.	Let the length of the cut be about two joined fingers in quantity or around that; and make as much blood come out as you wish.
Deinde stringe eam cum puluillis, et dimitte eam, donec sanetur.	Then compress it with cloths and leave it until it heals.
Et iam praecessit in principio libri incisio earum, et ipsarum cauterizatio.	And now we have already discussed the incision of these at the beginning of the book, as well as their cauterization.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum Arteriarum in timporibus.	On the bleeding of two arteries in apoplexy.
Duarum uero Arteriarum quae sunt in duobus timporibus phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad hemigraneam antiquam: et sodam prauam, et obtalmiam assiduam: et cursum superfluitatum effusarum acutarum ad oculos.	The bleeding of two arteries in the temples is beneficial for old headache; bad eyesight; and persistent red eyes caused by a flow of excess humours.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est secundum quod narro tibi.	And the quality of bleeding these arteries is as I tell you.
Stringat infirmus collum suum multum, donec appareant duae uenae sensui apparitione manifesta: et demonstretur pulsus earum sub digito tuo.	The patient should firmly press their neck until two veins become visibly apparent and you can feel the pulsation of them under your finger.
Tunc enim signa cum encaustro.	Then mark these with an iron cautery.
Deinde eleua cutem desuper uenam ad superiora cum digito tuo indice, et intromitte phlebotomum incidentem desubtus, et eleua uenam ad superiora.	Then lift the skin above the vein with your index finger and insert a bleeding-lance from underneath, then raise the vein upwards.
Et incide eam, sicut fecisti in duabus uenis aliis: et fac currere ex sanguine secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	And cut it as you did with the other two veins, and let flow as much blood as your need requires.
Deinde solue coartationem infirmi, et pone digitum tuum super uenam hora una.	Then release the patient's compression and place your finger over the vein for an hour.
Postea pone super ipsam cotum et puluillos, et stringe ipsum desuper constrictione forti: et dimitte ipsam, donec sanetur.	Afterwards place a poultice over it and tightly compress the patient from above with strong binding; leave it until it heals.
