Dico, ergo, quod quando accidit alicui fractura, aut dislocatio, aut torsio, aut casus: tunc oportet, ut properes in primis ad phlebotomandum eum, et soluendum ipsum, aut utraque simul: si non prohibeat aliquid, sicut debilitas uirtutis: aut est ille cui accidit aliquid ex illis puer, aut senex decrepitus: aut est tempus uehementis caloris, aut uehementis frigoris ualde.	I say therefore that when a person has a fracture or dislocation or torsion or fall then you must go quickly to perform bloodletting and give laxatives, or both together if nothing prevents it such as weakness of constitution or the patient is either a child or a decrepit old man, or it's a time of extreme heat or severe cold.
Deinde sit contentus in cibo suo, oleribus frigidis, et carnibus auium, et haedorum: et prohibe uinum, et carnes grossas, et repleri ex cibis et omni cibo qui replet uenas sanguine.	Next you should restrict them to their diet, cold vegetables and the meat of birds or kids and forbid wine and coarse meats and allow filling foods and any food that fills the veins with blood.
Donec quando securus sis ex apostemate calido, et non times effusionem materiei ad membrum: tunc redeat infirmus ad regimen suum primum cum quo cucurrit consuetudo eius.	Until you are sure that the swelling has cooled and there is no fear of pus spreading to the limb then the patient can return to their normal diet with which they are accustomed.
Cum ergo incipit os fractum restaurari, tunc oportet, ut cibetur infirmus cibis nutrientibus nutrimento multo, grosso, graui, in quibus sit uiscositas: sicut cibaria facta ex tritico cocto cum aqua, et rizum, et capita, et pedes, et uentres uaccarum, et oua, et pisces recentes: et uinum grossum, et similia illis.	When the broken bone begins to heal then the patient should be fed nourishing foods with plenty of nutrients that are weighty and heavy with a degree of viscosity such as cooked wheat-based dishes in water or rice and heads and feet and stomachs of fowl and eggs and fresh fish and thick wine and similar.
Cum hoc enim regimine fit coagulatio fracturae uelocius, et melius.	When this regimen is followed, fracture healing occurs faster and better.
Et scias, quod ossa fracta, quando sunt in uiris qui sunt in prima senectute, et decrepitis, non est possibile, ut continuentur et consolidentur secundum naturam suam semper, propter exiccationem membrorum eorum: et consolidantur et continuantur quae ex eis sunt in fine lenitatis, sicut ossa puerornm paruorum.	Also know that fractured bones, when they occur in men who are in their old age and decrepit, cannot always heal and consolidate according to their nature due to the desiccation of their members; instead, they heal and consolidate as if they were those of small children.
Verumtamen natura annectit super os fractum ex omni parte aliquid simile glutino, in quo est grossitudo, quo adhaeret et stringit ipsum, donec conglutinantur adinuicem, et ligantur adinuicem, donec uenit in fine fortitudinis et firmitudinis, sicut fuit in primis, donec non prohibet ipsum aliquid ab operationibus suis: et propter hanc caussam est necesse, ut ponas nutrimentum infirmi cibaria, in quibus sunt grauitas, et uiscositas, et grossitudo, sicut diximus.	However, nature binds to the fractured bone from all sides a substance similar to glue that has some thickness and adheres to it and holds it together until they adhere to each other and bind with one another; until in time, strength and stability return as before, so that nothing hinders its function anymore. For this reason, it is necessary for you to provide the patient with nourishing food that has weight, viscosity, and thickness, such as we have mentioned.
Et scias, quod fracturae species sunt diuersae, secundum diuersitatem membrorum: quoniam fractura cruris, est diuersa a fractura ossis capitis: et fractura ossis pectoris, est diuersa a fractura ossis dorsi: et similiter reliqua membra omnia diuersa existunt adinuicem: et ego ueni cum rememoratione omnis speciei fracturae expositae in Capitulo suo distinctae ab alia.	Also know that the types of fractures are diverse, depending on the different members of the body; for a leg fracture is different from one to the head bone, and a chest bone fracture differs from a back bone fracture, and likewise all other members differ from each other. And I have come with an exposition in its own chapter of every type of fracture set apart from another.
Et diuersificantur species fracturae ossis etiam in seipsa.	And the types of bone fractures also differ within themselves.
Quoniam fit fractura eius arcuata, praeter quod accidant in ea astellae.	Because its fracture is curved, other than when pieces fall out of it.
Et quandoque fit fractura eius secundum longitudinem ossis: et sunt fracturae eius satagiae, id est, astellae, et additiones procedentes, sicut sunt in calamo, cum aptatur cultello ad scribendum.	And sometimes its fracture occurs along the length of the bone; and there are stepped fractures within it, that is, pieces, and projections proceeding from them as in a reed when it is cut with a knife to write with.
Et non procedentes: et est fractura cum uulnere et disruptione in capite: et est fractura fissura parua.	They do not proceed: it is a fracture with a wound and disruption in the head; and it is a small crack fracture.
Et omni speciei est ingenium, uel instrumentum proprium in restauratione eius, secundum quod ueniet rememoratio eius, distincta in locis suis.	And for every type of fracture there is a specific tool or instrument to repair it, as will be recalled later and explained at its proper place.
Et ex eo quo cognoscitur fractura ossis, est tortuositas eius, et ipsius eminentia: et apparitio eius sensui, et sonitus eius quando comprimis ipsum manu tua.	And from what is known of bone fractures, there are its twisting and prominence; and their appearance to the sense and sound when you press them with your hand.
Quando ergo non est in loco tortuositas apparens, neque sonitus apud tactum tuum cum tangis os cum agitatione, neque inuenit infirmus magnum dolorem: tunc non est illic fractura, imo possibile est, ut sit tortuositas, aut fissura parua: non ergo oportet, ut moueas ipsum cum manu et compressione omnino, imo pone super ipsum ex medicinis, quarum uenit rememoratio, post momentum illud quod conuenit loco: deinde stringatur strictura subtili.	When, therefore, there is no apparent twist in place nor sound at your touch when you feel the bone with movement and the patient does not find great pain; then it's not a fracture but rather likely a twist or small crack: thus, one should not move it with hand and pressure but apply over it from medicines which will be recalled later, after some time appropriate to that place and then bind it with fine bandages.
Et scias, quod locus quando arcuatur, et scinditur in duo, praeter quod accidant in eo satagiae, uerumtamen remouetur omnis pars a compari sua: tunc oportet tibi, ut incipias ab hora tua ad rectificationem eius, aequando ipsum antequam accidat ei apostema calidum.	And know that when the place is bent and split into two parts but without any other accident to it while all its parts are removed from their fellow; then you must begin your treatment of it from the start by equalizing it before a hot abscess occurs.
Si autem accidat ei apostema calidum, tunc dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec quiescat apoestema.	However, if an hot abscess occurs then leave it for several days until the abscess subsides.
Deinde aequa ipsum secundum quemcunque modum potest ex lenitate et ingenio.	Then equalize it according to whatever way you can from its softness and nature.
Et scias, quod restauratio eius, et ipsius aequatio, est facilior quam ossis, in quo accidunt satagiae.	And know that its repair and equalization is easier than that of a bone with other accidents.
Deinde stringe ipsum, secundum quod ueniet tibi rememoratio eius.	Then bind it according to what will be recalled to you.
Si uero in osse sunt satagiae, tunc necessaria est extensio huius membri fracti ex duabus partibus, si manus sit, aut pes: aut cum manu tua, si membrum est paruum: aut cum duobus funibus, aut cum fune et manu.	If there are fractures in the bone, then it is necessary to extend this broken limb from two parts, if it is a hand or foot; or with your own hand, if it is a small limb; or with two cords, or with one cord and your hand.
Et sit positio tua qua ponis membrum super locum aequalem, secundum figuram suam naturalem, donec quando extenduntur partes membri fracti: tunc conare, ut redire facias illas additiones omni ingenio, et secundum quemcunque modum potes in locis suis: et caue secundum fortitudinem tuam, ne accidat super infirmum per operationem tuam dolor, neque laesio: et conare secundum fortitudinem tuam, ut applices unum duorum ossium cum socio suo, secundum meliores formas.	And let your position be such that you place the limb over an equal spot, according to its natural shape, until when the parts of the broken limb are extended: then try to bring back those additions with all skill, and in whatever way you can to their places; and beware, according to your strength, lest there happen upon the sick person due to your operation pain, or injury; and try, according to your strength, to fit together one of two bones with its fellow, according to the best shapes.
Et oportet in illa hora, ut tentes et tangas ipsum manu tua.	And it is necessary at that hour that you attempt to grasp and touch it with your own hand.
Si ergo uides illic aliquid diuersum, rectifica ipsum, et aequa illud per quantitatem tuae uirtutis.	If therefore you see something awry there, correct it, and equalize it according to the measure of your strength.
Et caue extensionem uehementem, et compressionem fortem, sicut faciunt multi stolidorum.	And beware of violent stretching and strong compression, as many fools do.
Multotiens enim faciunt accidere per operationem illam suam apostema calidum, aut contractionem in membro: sicut iam uidimus illud ex operationibus eorum multotiens.	For many times they cause to happen through their operation a hot abscess or contraction in the limb, as we have often seen from their operations.
Deinde annecte post aequationem, et decentem operationem, et stricturam illius membri, et quietem, et tranquillitatem: et mone infirmum super ipsum.	Then bind up after the equalizing and proper operation, and the setting of that limb, and rest, and tranquility; and advise the sick person regarding it.
Et fac ipsum cauere, ne moueat ipsum in hora suarum uigiliarum, et somni sui apud reuolutionem suam, et agitationem suam, et apud egestionem suam, et omnes motus suos ultima uirtute sua.	And make him beware, lest he move it in the hour of his watches and sleep regarding its revolution and agitation and at excretion and all his movements with his utmost strength.
Et ut caueat, ne sit positio membri positio cum qua sequatur dolor.	And he should take care that there is no position of the limb where pain follows.
Quod est, quia quando sentit in dispositione positionis membri dolorem, aut laesionem: tunc oportet, ut permutes ipsum ad dispositionem aliam ab illa cum qua non sentiat dolorem.	Which is because when he feels pain or injury in a particular limb position, then it should be changed to another where there is no pain.
Et caue cum illo, ut sit positio eius illa aequalis, recta: ut non accidat in membro tortuositas, quando restauratur.	And you should advise him to ensure that his position is equal and straight so as not to cause any curvature when the limb is restored.
Et qualitas stricturae membri fracti est, secundum quod narro.	And the quality of the fracture in the broken limb is as I describe it.
Scias, quod membra fracta diuersificantur in paruitate sua, et eorum magnitudine, et ipsorum forma.	You should be aware that broken limbs vary according to their smallness or largeness, and shape.
Quae ergo ex eis sunt parua, sicut brachium, et digitus, et focile, et similia eis, tunc oportet, ut sit inuolutio panni mollis, subtilis.	So those that are small, like the arm, finger, toe, and similar, then a soft, fine linen bandage should be used.
Quae autem ex eis sunt grossa, sicut coxa, et crus, oportet ut sit in eis inuolutio lata, dura.	But those that are large, like the thigh or leg, a wide, firm bandage should be used.
Quoniam ligamentum latum, connectit membrum magnum, et stringit ipsum ab omni parte strictura aequali, ita quod non ingreditur ipsum macula.	Because the wide bandage joins together a large limb and tightens its edges equally on all sides of the fracture so that nothing protrudes.
Deinde incipe post euacuationem tuam ab aequatione ponere linimentum conueniens ad illud, in stuppa leni super locum fracturae ipsius.	Then you should start putting on the appropriate ointment after your cleaning from the centre outwards with soft lint over the place of the fracture itself.
Deinde incipe inuoluere ligamentum super locum fracturae ipsius tribus inuolutionibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod meretur membrum: et stringe manum tuam parumper cum ligamento.	Then begin to bandage over the place of fracture itself with three or four turns as is appropriate for the limb, and tighten your hand a little with the bandage.
Deinde uade cum eo ad partem superiorem a loco fracturae, et stringe minus quam fuit strictura tua, qua strinxisti locum fractum.	Then go with him to the upper part from where you bandaged the fracture site and tighten less than the first bandage.
Deinde elonga te cum inuolutione a loco fracturae parumper, et mollifica stricturam paulatim, donec capias ex loco sano rem magnam.	Then extend yourself with a roll from the fracture site for a while, and gradually loosen the structure until you grasp something substantial from the healthy spot.
Deinde accipe uittam aliam, et inuolue eam iterum super locum fractum inuolutionibus.	Then take another strip of cloth and roll it again over the broken spot with rolls.
Postea uade cum inuolutione ad partem inferiorem a fractura.	After that, go down with the roll to the lower part below the fracture.
Et sit operatio tua in strictura inuolutionis, et mollificatione eius, secundum quod diximus in inuolutione prima superiore.	And let your procedure be in the tightness of the roll and its loosening as we said for the first upper roll.
Deinde pone inter inuolutiones ex stuppa leni, aut panno, cum quo aequetur tortuositas fracturae, si est in ea tortuositas: et si non, non ponas in ea aliquid.	Then place between the rolls some soft linen or cloth to even out any curvature of the fracture if there is one; and if not, do not put anything into it.
Deinde inuolue super ipsam uittam aliam.	Then roll another strip over the same spot.
Postea aequa super has inuolutiones astellas decenter factas statim, si non est in loco inflatio, neque apostema calidum.	After that, arrange warm compresses on these rolls immediately if there is neither swelling nor a hot abscess at the site.
Si autem in ea est inflatio, aut apostema: tunc pone super eam quod sedet illud apostema, et auferat inflationem: et dimitte eam aliquot diebus.	But if there is swelling or an abscess, then place over it what sits on the abscess and removes the swelling; and leave it for a few days.
Deinde stringe super ipsam tunc astellas.	Then bind compresses tightly over them at that point.
Et sint Astellae ex medietatibus cannae latae, rasae, formatae sapienter: aut sint ex ligno unde fiunt cribra, quae fiunt ex pino, aut geraid, id est, ramis palmae, aut calingi: et sit amplitudo omnis Astellae, secundum hanc formam, et hanc eandem figuram.	And let the compresses be made of half-sized hollow reeds, scraped and shaped with skill; or they can be made of wood used for making sieves which are made from pine or gerahd i.e., palm branches, or calingi; each compress should have equal breadth, according to this shape and figure.
Verumtamen oportet, ut Astella quae ponitur super ipsam tracturam, sit grossior et latior parumper, quam reliquae Astellae: et longitudo Astellae sit secundum quod licet membro ex magnitudine et paruitate.	However, the compress that is placed directly over the fracture should be slightly thicker and broader than the other compresses; and its length should match the limb according to its size and smallness.
Deinde stringe super Astellas cum uitta alia, secundum stricturam primam eandem.	Then tighten it over the aster with another piece of thread, according to the same first binding.
Deinde liga desuper cum filis decenter, secundum quod diximus de strictura: et est, ut sit strictura tua super locum fracturae plus: et quanto plus elongatur a fractura sit, strictura minor.	Then bind it from above with off-centre threads, as we have said about binding: and [ensure] that your binding is over the site of fracture; the more you elongate [the wound] away from the fracture, make the binding tighter.
Et oportet, ut sint fila media in grossitudine et subtilitate, et sint ex lino molli.	And it is necessary that the threads be of medium thickness and fineness, and they are to be made from soft linen.
Quoniam si fila sunt grossa, sicut uidi ex operatione stolidorum ponentium fila sua ex chordis lini tortis, est error magnus: quoniam cadit strictura cum eis extra qualitatem.	Because if the threads are thick, as I have seen from the work of fools who use their own threads made from twisted linen cord, it is a great mistake; for the binding fails with them outside the realm of effectiveness.
Et fila subtilia iterum non conueniunt: quoniam tu non consequeris per stricturam cum eis illud quod uis.	And fine threads also are not suitable; for you will not achieve with them the binding that you wish to attain.
Et non oportet, ut sit inter astellam et astellam minus quam digitus.	And it is not necessary for there to be less than a finger's breadth between the aster and the next one along.
Quod si laeditur infirmus per extremitates astellarum post stricturam in locis sanis: tunc pone sub eis ex stuppa leni, aut lana carminata, donec nihil laedatur ex illo.	If the patient is injured by the ends of the asters after binding them to healthy sites; then place under them soft tow or crimson wool until nothing hurts from it.
Quando autem est fractura cum uulnere, et accidit disruptio in cute, ego ueniam cum rememoratione eius in capitulo secundum singularitatem.	When there is a fracture with an overlying wound, and it happens that there is disruption of the skin, I will come to this in chapter two with particular reference to its uniqueness.
Et scias, quod non omne membrum fractum oportet ut stringatur cum astellis a primo die.	And you should know that not every broken limb must be bound with asters from the first day onwards.
Quod est, quia membrum quando est magnum, non oportet ut ponas superipsum astellas, nisi post quinque dies, aut septem, aut plus, secundum securitatem tuam ab euentu apostematis calidi.	This is because when a limb is large, you need not place asters upon it unless after five or seven days, or more, according to your judgement about the hot abscess-like development.
Et iste est modus emplastrorum, quibus restaurabant antiqui, quae ponuntur super fracturam et dislocationem.	This is the way of making dressings by which the ancients restored those bones that are broken and dislocated.
¶ Modus Emplastri communis abbreuiati, restaurans fracturam, conueniens pluribus complexionibus, praecipue mulieribus, et pueris: quoniam est ex eo super quod non uincit calor, neque frigus.	A method for making an abbreviated common plaster that restores broken bones and is suitable for many different constitutions but especially women and children since it does not succumb to heat or cold.
Et est, ut accipias ex puluere molendini, et est medulla farinae quae pendet in parietibus molendini apud motum molae: et conficias ipsum sicut est, praeter quod cribelles ipsum cum albugine oui: et pone confectionem eius non spissam, neque subtilem.	It is made from the flour dust of the mill and the flour dregs that cling to the walls of the mill near the motion of the millstone: and you mix it as it is, except that you sieve it with an egg white sieve: and lay its mixture neither thick nor thin.
Deinde utere eo.	Then apply it.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius, restaurantis fracturam, et dislocationem, et torsionem.	A method of plaster that restores fractures, dislocations, and twists.
Recipe almess, et laudani, et acaciae, et enulae, et mugath: et suc, omnium ana ʒ X myrrhae, et aloes amborum ana ʒ V et alethil ʒ XX terantur omnia, et cribellentur, et misceantur cum aqua alethil: aut cum albugine oui, si complexio infirmi est calefacta.	Take almess, laudanum, acacia, enula, and mugwort; of all sucks take 10 oz., of myrrh and aloe each take 5 oz., and of althel take 20 oz.; grind everything together and sieve it and mix with althel water: or with egg white if the patient's constitution is heated.
Deinde utere hoc emplastro.	Then use this plaster.
Nam ipsum est bonae compositionis, restaurat ossa fracta uelociter, et confert pluribus hominibus.	For it is of good composition, quickly restores broken bones, and suits many people.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius, quod etiam confert fracturae et torsioni.	A method of plaster that also suits fractures and twists.
Recipe mugath, et mess, et alteae albae, omnium ana ʒ X myrrhae, et aloes amborum ana ʒ V acaciae ʒ VI boli armeni ʒ XX terantur omnia contritione multa, et cribellentur, et conficiantur cum aqua, aut albugine oui: et administrentur.	Take mugwort, mess, and white lilies; of all take 10 oz., of myrrh and aloe each take 5 oz., acacia takes 6 oz., and Armenian bole takes 20 oz.; grind everything together with great care and sieve it and mix with water or egg white: and apply.
¶ Modus Emplastri ad iuncturas, et ossa separata ex locis suis: et sedat dolorem accidentem eis, et scissuram ossis, et fracturam.	The method for applying a plaster to joints and bones separated from their places; it relieves the pain that occurs in them, [treats] bone dislocation and fracture.
Sumatur lana succida, et submergatur in aceto, et oleo decocto: et ponatur super locum.	Woolen cloth should be soaked in vinegar and boiled oil, then applied to the site.
Et in hoc quidem Emplastro non est uirtus restaurationis, sed est bonum in sedatione apostematis calidi: et expellit dolores proprie.	This plaster has no restorative properties but is good for soothing hot abscesses; it specifically alleviates pain.
¶ Modus Emplastri, quod restaurat os fractum.	Method of a plaster that restores a broken bone.
Sume folia fici surdi, et folia papaueris syluestris: et tere omnia, et fac emplastrum ex utrisque.	Take the leaves of the fig tree and wild poplar; grind them all together and make a plaster from both.
¶ Modus Emplastri abbreuiati, administrati apud restaurationem fracturae ossis: et quando tu uis resolutionem residui apostematis.	Method of applying an abbreviated plaster for the restoration of a bone fracture; when you want to resolve residual abscesses.
Recipe radicis alteae, et camomillae, et florum uiolarum, et farinae herbi, omnium ana partem unam: terantur omnia, et conficiantur cum uino, si non est membrum calefactum.	Take one portion each of marshmallow root, chamomile, violets, and the herb plantain; grind them all together then mix with wine unless the limb is hot [inflamed].
Si uero est calefactum, tunc confice illud cum aqua coriandri humidi, aut cum aqua, et utere eo.	If the limb is hot [inflamed], mix it with moist coriander water or water instead and use as required.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius fortioris in resolutione, quam istud primum, quando accidit apostema durum apud restaurationem membri.	Another method with a stronger plaster for resolving [hard abscesses] than the previous one, when an abscess develops during limb restoration.
Recipe radicis alteae, et seminis lini, et balaustiae, et melliloti, et samsuci, et floris uiolarum, et camomillae, omnium ana, partem unam, terantur omnia, et conficiantur cum aqua salicis, aut cum aqua dulci, aut cum uino.	Take one portion each of marshmallow root, linseed, balsam, honey locust, water-plantain, violet flowers and chamomile; grind them all together then mix with willow water or fresh water or wine.
Totum illud secundum caliditatem membri, et quietem caloris eius.	All of this should be done according to the temperature of the limb and calming its heat [inflammation].
Hippocrates uero non dixit in libro suo, quod ponatur super membrum fractum apud restaurationem eius, nisi caerotum factum ex caera, et oleo: non aliud: et narrauit, ut sit medium inter grossitudinem et subtilitatem.	Hippocrates, however, did not say in his book that anything other than a poultice made of clay and oil should be placed on a broken limb during its restoration; he described it as being of moderate thickness.
Galeno autem uisum est, ut ponantur super membrum fractum apud restaurationem eius res, in quibus est exiccatio caliditatis, sicut myrrha, et aloes et olibanum, et similia eis ex eis quae narrauimus.	Galen considered that substances with drying and warming properties, such as myrrh, aloe, and frankincense, along with similar substances from those we have mentioned, should be applied to a broken limb during its restoration.
¶ Modus Emplastri quod confert ad laesionem et dolorem.	Recipe for an ointment that relieves injury and pain.
Recipe mugath, et ciceris, et capillorum hominis incisorum, aut pennae auis, et alteae, et salis partes aequales: terantur, et cribellentur, et conficiantur: et fiat ex eo emplastrum.	Take equal parts of mugwort, chickpeas, human hair clippings or bird feathers, nettle, and salt; grind them up, sieve the mixture, and process it into an ointment.
Quantitas autem secundum quam oportet, ut remaneat ligatura, deinde soluatur, est, ut consideres tunc, si non accidit infirmo dolor, neque pruritus, neque mouetur os fractum a loco suo: tunc non resoluas ipsum diebus multis.	The length of time for which a dressing should remain in place before being removed depends on considerations such as the absence of pain, itching, or movement of the broken bone from its position; if these do not occur, it may be left in place for many days.
Quod si accidat ei in loco pruritus uehemens, aut dolor inquietans, aut inflatio: tunc propera, et solue in hora ipsum, et aufer emplastrum ab eo: et accipe pannum lenem, aut spongiam marinam lenem, humidam: et submerge eam in aqua tepida, et ablue cum ea locum, donec quiescat pruritus, et sedetur dolor.	If the patient experiences severe itching, disturbing pain or swelling at the site of the dressing, it should be removed immediately; take a soft cloth or a moistened marine sponge and soak it in warm water to gently wash the area until the itching subsides and any pain is soothed.
Deinde dimitte membrum quiescere una hora.	After that, allow the limb to rest for an hour.
Deinde pone super ipsum lanam succidam, submersam in aceto et oleo, aut oleo rosato: et liga super ipsum nocte una, donec sis securus ab apostemate calido, et quiescat inflatio membri, et remoueatur dolor eius.	Then apply a piece of woollen felt soaked in vinegar and oil or rosewater over the limb and bandage it there for one night until you are assured that the heat blister has subsided, any swelling of the limb is quieted and its pain has been relieved.
Deinde itera ipsum ad stricturam subtilem, et emplastrum paruum: et non stringas ipsum constrictione tua prima, et subtilia cum eo, donec sanetur.	Then repeat this on a fine structure, and apply a small plaster; do not tighten it with your first compression, and keep the fine bandages with it until it heals.
Quod si uides, quod apostema, et rubedo, et dolor, et inflatio, et omnia accidentia iam remota sunt penitus, et indiges emplastro et strictura, tunc itera illud sicut fecisti in primis aequaliter.	If you see that the abscess, redness, pain, swelling, and all other symptoms have now completely disappeared, and you need a plaster and bandage, then repeat this process as you did initially.
Quod si non accidit membro aliquid ex eis quae diximus, tune non soluas ipsum, nisi post tres dies, aut quatuor, aut quinque, aut septem.	If none of the things we have mentioned happen to the limb, then do not remove it unless after three days, or four, or five, or seven.
Et quando que dimittitur uiginti diebus totum illud, secundum quod apparet tibi ex solutione membri, sicut diximus, donec quando adhaeret fractura, et approximat coagulatio carnis super eam: adde etiam tunc in strictura plus quam strictura tua prima tota: et adde etiam in ingrossatione cibi infirmi, secundum quod praecessit rememoratio eius.	And when you remove it after twenty days, depending on how the limb appears upon its release, as we have mentioned, until the fracture adheres and the coagulation of flesh approaches over it: then also add in a bandage greater than your first compression altogether; also add to the enlargement of the patient's diet, according to what has been previously recalled.
Si autem uides locum fracturae iam exiccari, et extenuari plus quam oportet: tunc scias, quod nutrimentum prohibetur peruenire ad ipsum.	However, if you see that the place of fracture is already becoming dried out and more weakened than it should be, then know that nourishment is being prevented from reaching it.
Embroca ergo ipsum cum aqua tepida apud omnem uicem qua soluis ipsum, et sit illud in omnibus tribus diebus, et alleuia stricturam parumper.	Therefore immerse it with warm water at every release you make of it, and let this occur over the course of three days; also ease off on the bandage somewhat.
Per hanc ergo operationem currit ad membrum nutrimentum, et sanatur uelociter.	By this process therefore nourishment reaches the limb and it heals quickly.
Illud autem quod faciunt stolidi restauratores ex fractura membri uice alia, quando non restauratur in primis, secundum quod oportet, et restauratur secundum tortuositatem, est error ex operatione eorum, et timor magnus: et si esset rectum, dixissent illud antiqui in libris suis, et operati fuissent cum eo.	But that which unskilled surgeons do when restoring a broken limb with another bone instead of the original one, because it is not restored properly at first and then has to be restored crookedly: this error arises from their procedure, and causes great fear; and if it had been correct they would have said so in ancient texts, and acted upon that.
Et ego non uidi alicubi eorum uestigium in illo omnino, et rectius est, ut non fiat illud.	And I have not seen any traces of them there at all, and it is better that it should not be done.
¶ De factura accidente in capite.	Regarding the treatment of head injuries:
Caput III.	Chapter 3.
Species fracturae sunt diuersae, et figurae eius multae: et caussae eius sunt distinctae.	Types of fractures vary widely, with many different shapes and forms, and they have diverse causes.
Nam ex fractura est quae fit a percussione cum ense: et percussio aufert os totum usquequo peruenit ad siphac, quod est sub osse, sicut facit axia in ligno: et propter illud nominatur haec species fracturae Axialis.	One type of fracture occurs due to a strike with a sword; the strike removes the entire bone up until it reaches the marrow beneath the bone, similar to how an axe splits wood; hence this particular kind of fracture is known as axial.
Aut ensis incidit quiddam ossis, et incidit faciem eius, et non penetrat incisio usque ad ultimum eius: et nominatur haec species fracturae Kalaan, id est, Leuatio absolute.	Or the sword cuts into a bone and grazes its surface without penetrating all the way through; this kind of fracture is called *kala'an*, or absolute levation.
Et est uulnus duarum fracturarum, aut magnum, aut paruum.	And it is an injury with two fractures, either large or small.
Et ex fractura est, quae est contritio, aut attritio: et caussa eius est percussio cum lapide, aut casus super lapidem, aut eis similia.	There is another kind of fracture that involves crushing or grinding; this occurs due to a strike with a stone, a fall onto one, or similar incidents.
Et haec fractura est etiam aut penetrans, quae iam appropinquat panniculo, quod est sub osse: aut est in facie ossis: et est uulnus harum duarum fracturarum etiam aut paruum, aut magnum.	This fracture can also be penetrating, approaching the marrow beneath the bone; or it can occur on the surface of the bone itself. It is likewise an injury with two fractures that are either small or large.
Et ex fractura est, quae est occulta in osse in subtilitate capilli: et est fissura parua, et propter illud nominatur haec species fracturae Capillaris.	There is yet another type of fracture that is hidden within the bone itself, as thin as a hair; it is a small split and thus named *capillaris*.
Et ex eis est fractura, quae fit a casu, aut percussione lapidis, et eis similium, quae faciunt ingredi laminam ossis ad interiora, et fit loco concauitas: sicut accidit caldariis aeris, quando occurrit eis percussio, et ingreditur pars eorum ad interiora.	Another fracture occurs from a fall or strike with a stone and similar incidents that cause a piece of bone to enter the body cavity; it creates a hollow space there, like what happens in bellows when they receive a blow, allowing some air to pass into their insides.
Et plurimum quidem fit illud in capitibus humidorum ossium, sicut sunt capita puerorum.	And it happens most frequently in the heads of moist bones, such as those of children.
Et fiunt omnibus istis speciebus fracturae satagiae separatae, et ego ueniam cum rememoratione illius totius in loco suo.	And all these types of fractures occur separately, and I will come with a recollection of that whole thing in its place.
Et cognoscimus omnes has species fracturae per detectionem super eam, et inquisitionem earum cum tentis, et ablationem carnium corruptarum, quae sunt super eas.	And we recognize all these types of fractures by examination upon them and investigation with probes, as well as removal of the corrupted flesh that is above them.
Species uero Capillaris cognoscitur per hoc, quod detegitur super os, et abstergitur, et linitur super ipsum cum encaustro: fractura enim apparet nigra.	The capillary type is recognized by this: that which is detected over the bone and wiped away and lined above it with cauterization; for the fracture appears black.
In curatione autem fracturae, considera in primis accidentia infirmi: tunc si uides ex accidentibus quod significet significatione manifesta super timorem, sicut uomitus cholerae, et extensio, et amissio intellectus, et abscisio uocis, et syncopis, et febris acuta, et egressus oculorum, et rubedo eorum, et similia eis ex accidentibus in pluribus dispositionibus, proculdubio non sanatur: et si uides accidentia non terrentia te, et speras salutem: tunc incipe curationem eius.	However, in treating a fracture, consider first the patient's condition: then if you see from their conditions that they indicate clearly by vomiting of bile and fainting, as well as prostration, loss of speech, syncope, acute fever, giddiness, flushing of the face, and similar symptoms in many situations, certainly it will not heal; and if you see non-frightening conditions, and hope for recovery: then begin its treatment.
Quod est, si uenit ad te uulneratus in primis cum uulneratur: et est illud in diebus hyemis, tunc oportet, ut studeas in ablatione ossis ante diem quartumdecimum secundum omnem dispositionem.	That is, if the wounded comes to you when first wounded: and it occurs during the winter days, then you must aim at removing bone before the fourteenth day according to every situation.
Et si est in diebus aestatis, tunc oportet, ut properes remouere os ante diem septimum, antequam corrumpatur quod est sub osse ex panniculo, et accidant illa accidentia quae narrauimus.	And if it is during the summer days, then you must hasten to remove the bone before the seventh day, before what is beneath the bone from the flesh decays and those symptoms that we described occur.
Quod si fractura ossis iam peruenit ad panniculum tangentem cerebrum, et est cum minutiis, et attractione: tunc oportet, ut incidas partem comminutam, et attritam, secundum quod narro tibi.	If the bone fracture has already reached the membrane touching the brain and is with shreds and stripping: then you must cut away the comminuted and stripped-away part as I tell you.
Et est, ut radas caput uulnerati: et detege super os secundum quemcunque modum possibile est tibi: et secundum figuram uulneris, et quod leue est super infirmum.	And it is necessary that you shave the head of the wounded person; and expose over the bone according to whatever manner is possible for you; and according to the shape of the wound, and what is light on the sick one.
Quod si accidat tibi apud detectionem ossis fluxus sanguinis, aut apostema calidum: tunc oppone ei cum eo quod oportet.	If it should happen to you during the exposure of bone that there is a flow of blood or a hot abscess: then oppose it with what is appropriate.
Et est, ut impleas locum cum pannis infusis in uino, et oleo rosato: et facias quiescere uulnus, donec sedetur apostema, et sis securus a fluxu sanguinis.	And it is necessary that you fill the place with cloths soaked in wine and rose oil; and let the wound rest until the abscess settles down, and be assured of no more flow of blood.
Deinde incipe in curatione ossis, et ablatione eius.	Then begin with the cure of bone, and its removal.
Et illud fit secundum unum duorum modorum.	And that is done according to one of two methods.
Modus quidem unus est, ut incidas os cum Incisorio strictae aciei: et haec est forma eius.	One method is that you cut the bone with an Incisory of a sharp iron: and this is its form.
Dende administra Incisorium aliud post Incisorum latius eo parumper: et haec est forma eius.	Then apply another Incisory, after the narrower one, somewhat wider: and this is its form.
Deinde administra etiam Incisorium aliud latius etiam quam secundum.	Then apply yet another Incisory that is even wider than the last one.
Et modus secundus est, ut sit apud te numerus Incisoriorum diuersorum: quorum quaedam sint latiora quibusdam, et quaedam eorum breuiora quibusdam: et sint in ultimo acuitatis extremitatum suarum, et sint ex ferro indo, aut fuled: et utere facilitate in percussione super Incisorium, ut non concutiat caput, et laedat ipsum.	The second method is that you have a number of different Incisories with some being wider than others and some shorter than others; and they should be very sharp at their ends, and made from iron or steel: and strike gently on the Incisory so as not to shake the head and hurt it.
Si autem os est forte, durum: tunc oportet, ut perfores in circumitu eius, antequam tu administres Incisoria, cum Terebris quae nominantur Terebra non profundantia: et non nominantur ita, nisi quoniam ipsa non pertranseunt terminum ossis carnei ad illud, quod est post ipsum: propterea, quod Terebro est extremitas rotunda super illud, quod est sub capite eius acuto, similis margini, et circulus paruus prohibet submergi, et pertransire spissitudinem ossis.	But if the bone is hard and strong: then it is necessary that you drill around its edge before applying Incisories with Terebras which are called Non-deepening Drills; they are not so named unless because itself does not penetrate through the end of the bone to what is beyond it, since the Drill has a round tip on top of which is like an edge and small circle underneath prevents sinking in, and passing through the thickness of bone.
Et conuenit tibi, ut accipias ex istis Terebris numerum multum, quorum unumquodque conueniat quantitati spissitudinis ossis, donec praesens sit tibi omni craneo Terebrum: cuius extremitatis acutae quantitas in longitudine et breuitate sit, secundum quantitatem spissitudinis illius cranei.	You should take many of these drills from those bone chisels, each suitable for the thickness of a bone, until you have a drill for every part of the skull; the length and width of the pointed end of which corresponds to the thickness of that part of the skull.
Et haec est forma trium specierum Terebrorum, uel Trepanorum.	These are three forms of drills or trepans.
Qualitas autem perforandi in circumitu ossis fracti, est: ut ponas Terebrum super os, et reuoluas ipsum digitis tuis, donec scias, os iam penetratum esse.	The technique of drilling around the circumference of a broken bone is to place the drill on top of the bone and rotate it with your fingers until you know that the bone has been penetrated.
Deinde permuta Terebrum ad locum alium, et pone quod est inter omne foramen quantitatem grossitudinis radii, aut circiter illud.	Then change the drill to another place and put in between any hole the thickness of a finger or about that much.
Deinde incide cum Incisoriis quod est inter omne foramen ex osse: et fac illud subtilius quam potes super illud ex fine leuitatis, sicut diximus, donec eradices os, aut manu tua, aut cum aliquo alio ex quibusdam instrumentis, quae parasti ad illud: sicut tenaliae, et forpices subtiles.	Then cut with knives what is between any hole in the bone and make it as thin as you can at that end of lightness, as we have said, until you scrape out the bone, either by hand or with some other tool which you prepared for that purpose such as forceps and fine scissors.
Et oportet, ut caueas omni cautela, ne tangat Terebrum, aut Incisorium aliquid ex siphac.	And you must take every precaution that the drill or knife does not touch any of this soft matter.
Cum ergo circumieris os perforando, et separatum fuerit a siphac, si fuerit continuum cum eo, et extraxeris ipsum, oportet ut radas, et aeques extremitatem eius quod remanet in osse cum instrumento alio simili Incisorio.	When you have therefore drilled around the bone and separated it from that soft matter, if they are still joined together then you must cut and scrape equally the end of what remains in the bone with another similar knife-like instrument.
Verumtamen oportet, ut sit tenuis et subtilis magis aliis Incisoriis.	However it must be thinner and finer than the other knives.
Quod si remanet aliquid ex ossibus paruis, et satagiae: tunc accipe ea cum facilitate, cum eo quod est apud te ex instrumentis.	If there remains any small pieces of bone and gristle then take them out carefully with the tool you have at hand for that purpose.
Deinde cura uulnus post illud cum liciniis, et unguentis quae diximus.	Then treat the wound afterwards with dressings and ointments as we have described.
Et modus alius operationis est facilis, prorsus longinquus a timore: quem dixit Galenus, et laudauit ipsum laude magna: et iste est sermo eius.	Another method of operation is easy, completely removed from fear: which Galen said and praised it with great praise: and these are his words.
Necese est tibi in primis, ut incipias detegere partem ossis ex loco, in quo fractura est uehementior, et manifestior: donec quando detexeris illam partem, et posueris sub eo extremitatem huius Incisorii lenticularis, cuius haec est forma.	It is necessary for you first of all to begin to expose the bone in that place where the fracture is more violent and apparent: until when you have exposed this part and placed under it one end of this Lenticular Knife whose form is thus.
Et pars lenticularis, lenis non incidit aliquid: et pars acuta eius in duabus lateribus eius uadens in longitudinem, sicut uides: ut sit pars lenticularis innixa ad siphac, facie eius incidente acuta in osse.	And the Lenticular part which is blunt does not cut anything: and its sharp part on both of its sides tapering to a point as you can see: so that the lenticular part may be applied against the bone with its cutting edge acute towards the bone.
Deinde percute super Incisorium a parte una cum malleo paruo, donec incidas totum os cum facilitate, sicut reuoluitur: et tu sis securus ex panniculo, quod non accidat in eo accidens, quod timeas prorsus.	Then strike upon the Knife from one side with a small mallet until you have cut through the entire bone as it turns: and be sure to stand clear of the knife so that no accident happens there which you greatly fear.
Et si medicans non esset stultior hominum, et magis ignarus eius, nec esset dormiens, tunc si remaneret aliquid annexum ossi ex panniculo in quibusdam locis, incideret ipsum ab eo cum extremitate incisorii lenticularis ipsius, et liberaret ipsum ab eo cum facilitate.	And if the physician were not a more ignorant and stupid person he would not be asleep now: then if any portion of this membrane still remains attached to the bone in certain places he should cut it away from that with one end of the same lenticular knife and free it from there easily.
Liberatur enim ab eo sine nocumento, et absque timore.	It is freed from this without injury and without fear.
Et si fractura ossis non penetret usque ad panniculum, et illud quod abscinditur ab osse est facies eius, et remanent in ipso asperitas et satagiae subtiles: tunc oportet, ut radas illam asperitatem, et eradices illas satagias cum rasoriis subtilibus ex quibus praeparasti numerum diuersarum quantitatum, ut sit tibi possibile administrare ex eis in omni loco conuenientiora eorum, et rectiora ipsorum, secundum illud ad quod perducit te operatio, et ipsum os fractum, et figura eius.	And if the fracture of the bone does not extend through to the membrane and that which is torn away from the bone is its surface while roughnesses and fine ridges remain in it: then you must scrape off this roughness and remove those ridges with very delicate scrapers from which you have prepared a number of different sizes so as to be able to apply from these those most convenient and suitable for each place according as your operation leads you and the fractured bone itself and its shape.
Et oportet, ut administres in rasione tua, qua in primis radis os, latius illorum rasoriorum.	You must sharpen your blade more than those of the other razors.
Deinde utere post ipsum subtiliore eo.	Next, use the finer one after that.
Et non cesses facere illud secundum continuitatem, donec peruenias ad administrandum tenuius, et subtilius eorum omnium.	And do not stop doing this until you reach the stage of sharpening the thinnest and finest of them all.
In unaquaque autem fissurarum reliquarum paruarum capillarium, et fractura subtili, oportet ut administres curam, secundum illud quod perducit ad rectificationem eius.	However, for each of the other small hairline fractures and fine breaks, you must take care to sharpen according to what leads to their correction.
Et est res quae non occultatur super omnem, cui in hac arte est quodlibet studium, et stetit super illud quod scripsimus, et ostendimus in fracturis magnis.	And this is something that cannot be hidden from anyone who has any interest in this art, and they will have stood over what we have written and shown regarding large breaks.
Si autem panniculus detectus retinetur, quando tu eradicas os: tunc oportet, ut accipias pannum lini, secundum quantitatem uulneris, et submerge ipsum in oleo rosa, et pone ipsum super orificium uulneris.	But if a piece of membrane is found and retained when you remove the bone: then you must take a piece of linen cloth according to the size of the wound, immerse it in rose oil, and place it over the opening of the wound.
Deinde accipe pannum alium duplicatum, aut triplicatum, et submerge ipsum in uino et oleo rosa, et pone ipsum super pannum primum: et fac illud quam facilius potes super illud, ut non grauetur siphac.	Next, take another piece of cloth, doubled or trebled, immerse it in wine and rose oil, place it over the first piece of cloth, and make sure you do this as easily as possible so that it does not rub against the wound.
Deinde administra supra ipsum ligamentum latum: et non stringas ipsum, nisi per quantitatem quae teneat uulnus tantum: et dimitte ipsum cum hac cura die uno, aut diebus duobus, donec sis securus ab apostemate calido.	Then apply over this a wide bandage and do not tighten it unless the amount is such that it just holds the wound together; leave this for one day or two until you are sure the hot inflammation has gone.
Deinde solue ipsum, et administra post illud medicinas cum quibus est superflua siccitas: sicut radices lilii, et farina herbi, et puluis thuris, et aristolochia, et similia eis: et est, ut facias ex istis medicinis puluerem, qui puluerizetur super uulnus sicut sunt siccae.	Next, remove this bandage and apply afterwards medicines that are appropriate for excessive dryness such as lilies roots, herb flour, incense powder, aristolochia, and similar things; and it is best to make a powder of these medicines which you can sprinkle over the wound like a dry dusting.
Et uniuersaliter administra in illo omnem medicinam de proprietate cuius est ut abstergat, et non mordicet.	And generally administer to it all medicine that has the property of cleansing and not stinging.
Et caue secundum tuam uirtutem, ut uulnus in curatione tua sit limpidum: neque sit in ea sordes unguenti, neque sordicies.	And ensure that according to your virtue, the wound is clear during its treatment; there should be no grease stains or dirt.
Neque dimittas uirus aggregari in eo omnino: quoniam quando uirus aggregatur super panniculum cerebri, corrumpit eum, et putrefacit ipsum, et accidit super infirmum post illud malicia magna: et iam accidit in siphac capitis, cum mundificatur ab eo os, praecipue quando negligitur cura eius, nigredo in superficie eius.	Nor should you allow any pus to accumulate on it; for when pus accumulates over the brain's membrane, it corrupts and putrefies it, and a great malice befalls the patient after that; this has already happened in the case of head syphilis, where the bone is cleansed by it, especially if its treatment is neglected, then blackness occurs on its surface.
Considera ergo tunc, si accidunt infirmo accidentia quae diximus, scias, quia est pernitiosum proculdubio.	Therefore, consider that if the patient experiences any of the conditions we have mentioned, know that it is undoubtedly harmful.
Et si nigredo non accidit, nisi a medicina quae ponitur super ipsum, et est in uirtute illius medicinae, ut faciat illam nigredinem: tunc oportet, ut accipias ex melle partem unam, ex oleo rosato partes tres, et linias cum eis pannum.	And if blackness does not occur unless it is caused by the medicine that is applied to it and if it is in the virtue of that medicine to cause such blackness, then you must take one part honey, three parts rose oil, and line them with a cloth.
Deinde pone ipsum super siphac: postea cura ipsum cum speciebus curationis quae conueniunt, donec sanetur.	Then apply it to the syphilitic sores; afterwards treat it with curative spices that are suitable until it is healed.
¶ De restauratione Nasi quando frangitur.	The chapter heading "On the restoration of a broken nose" is not in sentence format, therefore I am unable to translate it into English. Please note that my instructions state that I will only translate complete sentences from Medieval Latin to English.
Caput IIII.	The Roman numeral "IV" is not in sentence format, therefore I am unable to translate it into English. Please note that my instructions state that I will only translate complete sentences from Medieval Latin to English.
Scias, quod non franguntur ex Naso nisi duae partes eius superiores simul, aut una earum: propterea, quod ipse sunt duo ossa: quoniam inferius eius est cartilaginosum, non frangitur, et non accidit ei nisi attritio, et tortuositas, et simitas.	You should know that only the two superior parts of the nose are broken at once or one of them; for it is composed of two bones: since its lower part is cartilaginous, it does not break and nothing happens to it other than abrasion, twisting, and indentations.
Si frangitur una duarum partium eius, tunc oportet, ut intromittas digitum paruum in foramen Nasi, et aeques illam fracturam digito tuo indice, et pollice deforis, donec redeat Nasus super figuram suam naturalem: et fiat illud arte, cum facilitate.	If one of its two parts is broken, then you must insert a small finger into the nostril hole, and with your index finger and thumb, realign that fracture until the nose returns to its natural shape; and do this skillfully, with ease.
Et caue, ne accidat per operationem tuam illam super infirmum dolor.	And beware, lest by your operation that pain upon the patient occur.
Quod si fractura est in superiore parte Nasi, et non perueniat ad illam digitus: tunc oportet, ut aequetur extremitate radii, in quo sit grossitudo parua.	If the fracture is in the upper part of the nose and your finger cannot reach it, then you must use the end of a rod, one that is a small thickness.
Si uero fractura est in duabus partibus, tunc fac simile illius: et propera cum restauratione eius in die primo fracturae, si est possibile.	If however the fracture is in both parts, then do likewise; and be quick to restore it on the first day of the break, if possible.
Et si non, tunc post diem septimum, aut decimum apud quietem apostematis calidi.	And if not, then after seven or ten days when the swelling has cooled.
Deinde intromitte in extremitate Nasi licinium ex panno lini, si fractura est in parte una: aut intromite duo licinia si fractura est in duabus partibus: et sit in licinio grossitudo tantae quantitatis, quae impleat foramen Nasi.	Then insert into the end of the nose a linen thread if the break is in one part; or insert two threads if it is broken in both parts; and have the thread as thick as to fill the nostril hole.
Et dixerunt quidam antiquorum restauratorum, ut infundantur licinia in butyro, et permutentur omni die.	And some of the ancient restorers said to immerse the threads in butter, changing them every day.
Illud uero non uidetur mihi, imo oportet, ut infundatur licinium in albugine oui, confecto cum puluere molendini.	That however does not seem right to me; instead the thread should be soaked in the white of an egg, mixed with mill dust.
Deinde dimitte licinium, donec firmetur os, et induretur cartilago.	Then leave the thread until the bone hardens and the cartilage strengthens.
Et quandoque intromittitur in Nasum loco licinii penna anseris, postquam inuoluitur super ipsam pannus lenis: et fit, quod ipsa tenet fracturam Nasi uehementius, et ut non prohibeatur infirmus ab inspiratione.	And sometimes a goose feather is inserted into the nose instead of the thread, after it is wrapped in soft cloth; this holds the broken nose more firmly so that the patient can still breathe.
Et non est haec res necessaria.	This thing is not necessary.
Si uis, fac illud: et si uis, fac licinia.	If you wish, do that; and if you wish, do Licinius's work.
Quod si accidat Naso iterum dum operaris apostema calidum, emplastra nasum cum caeroto, aut cum coto infuso in oleo rosato, aut modico ex dyaquilon.	If it happens that, while operating on a hot swelling, the nose of Naso becomes inflamed again, apply to his nostrils either a mustard plaster or a piece of cloth soaked in rose oil, or daiquiri.
Si autem non accidit apostema calidum, tunc oportet, ut emplastres ipsum cum farina sisami, et puluere thuris confecti cum albugine oui.	If the inflammation does not occur then it is necessary that you apply plasters made with sesame flour and powdered incense mixed with egg white.
Deinde pone super ipsum stuppam lenem, et non liges Nasum cum aliquo omnino.	Next put a soft dressing on top of that; and do not bandage his nose at all.
Si uero franguntur ossa Nasi fractura parua, aut comminuuntur, tunc oportet, ut scindas super ea, et extrahas ipsa cum instrumentis quae conueniunt eis.	However if Naso's bones are broken or shattered by a small fracture then you must cut open above the break and extract those bits with suitable instruments.
Deinde sue scissuram, et cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat, et consolidat ex emplastris conuenientibus ad illud, uel unguentis.	Then sew the wound shut; and care for it with whatever promotes healing and consolidation of the flesh such as suitable plasters or ointments.
Quod si accidat inter Nasum uulnus, tunc oportet, ut cures ipsum cum liciniis: et administres cannulam de plumbo, donec sanetur.	If ever there is an injury between the nostrils then you must treat it with strips of linen; and insert a lead pipe until healed.
¶ De restauratione Mandibulae inferioris, quando disrumpitur.	On restoring the lower jaw when it is shattered:
Caput V.	Chapter Five.
Quando disrumpitur Mandibula inferior, et fractura eius non est cum uulnere: conspice tunc si est fractura eius deforis tantum, et non frangitur in duo, et curuatur ad interiora: tunc cognitio eius est facilis.	When the lower jaw is shattered and there are no other injuries; then if its fracture is external only and not split into two parts, then identifying it should be straightforward.
Oportet ergo, si est fractura eius in parte dextra, ut intromittas digitum indicem sinistrae in os infirmi: similiter si fractura est in mandibula sinistra, tunc intromitte indicem manus dextrae: et impelle cum eo gibbositatem fracturae deintus cum facilitate ad exteriora cum manu tua altera ab interiori parte ossis decenter, et cum eo aequa ipsam.	If the fracture is on the right side then insert your left index finger into the injured person's jaw; likewise if it is their left jaw that is fractured then use the index finger of your right hand instead: and with your other hand push inwards from behind towards the outside at the swelling of the fracture, pushing gently until you feel the bones meet.
Quod si fractura mandibulae iam separata est in duo, tunc oportet, ut administres extersionem a duabus partibus, secundum rectitudinem: donec possibilis sit aequatio eius.	If the fracture of the jaw has already separated into two pieces, you must perform an extension from both sides according to its straightness until it can be equated.
Si autem iam accidit in dentibus commotio, aut disruptio: tunc stringe illos de quibus speras quod remaneant cum filo auri, aut argenti, aut seta.	If there is already damage to the teeth or they have been displaced, then fasten those you hope will remain with gold wire, silver, or silk thread.
Deinde pone super mandibulam fractam caerotum.	Then place pulp on the fractured jaw.
Deinde pone super ipsum pannum duplicatum, et pone super pannum astellam magnam decenter factam: aut frustum cutis soleae aequale, in longitudinem mandibulae.	Then place a doubled cloth over it, and on the cloth put a large unevenly shaped tile or a piece of leather equal in length to the jaw.
Deinde liga ipsum desuper, secundum quod praeparatur tibi ligatura eius, et conuenit ipsius applicatio, donec non destruitur: et praecipe infirmo, uti tranquillitate et quiete: et pone cibum eius sorbitiones lenes.	Then bind it from above according to how you have prepared the bandage for him and its application is suitable until the jaw is no longer broken; advise the patient of calmness and rest; and give him soft, easy-to-swallow food.
Si autem estimas, quod iam alteratur aliquid figurae aliquo modorum: tunc propera, et solue ipsum in die tertio.	If you think the shape has changed to some extent, then be quick and remove it on the third day.
Deinde rectifica quod alteratum est ex eo, et emplastra ipsum ex puluere molendini, cum albugine oui, aut cum farina sisami, postquam tu abstuleris caerotum: et pone super emplastrum lanam lenem.	Then correct that which has been changed and make a plaster with flour of barley mixed with egg white or sesame seed flour after you have removed the pulp; and place on the plaster some soft wool.
Dum ergo permanet annexum illud emplastrum super ipsum, et non alteratur ossis dispositio, dimitte ipsum, ne soluas, donec sanetur: aut stringe fracturam.	While that plaster remains attached to it without changing the position of the bone, leave it in place and do not remove it until healed or until the fracture is secure.
Multotiens enim stringitur haec fractura in tribus septimanis.	This fracture is often bound for three weeks.
Quod si interim accidat apostema calidum, tunc administra illud quod diximus multotiens in sedatione eius, donec remoueatur illud apostema.	If there is a warm abscess in the meantime, then apply that which we have said many times for its reduction until it is removed.
Et si fractura est cum uulnere, considera.	And if there's a fracture with a wound, consider it.
Namsi iam separatur ex osse frustum, aut a satagie: tunc subtilia te in hoc, ut auferas illa frusta satagiae cum eo quod conuenit tibi in ablatione eorum ex instrumentis.	Now when the piece of bone has been separated from the limb, either by sawing or cutting; then you must make use of the appropriate fine instruments to remove those pieces of sawdust which suit your purpose for their removal.
Si uero orificium uulneris est strictum, tunc amplifica ipsum cum phlebotomo secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	If however the wound opening is tight, then widen it with a lancet according to the extent of your need.
Deinde quando abstuleris illa satagie, et non remanserit ex eis aliquid, sue tunc orificium uulneris, si est amplum: et si non, pone super ipsum ex emplastris quae conueniunt ad illud, et incarnant illud, donec sanetur.	Then when you have removed the sawdust and none remains of it, sew up the wound if it is wide; and if not, place on top of it a plaster that suits this purpose, and apply flesh to it until it heals.
¶ De restauratione Furculae, quando frangitur.	On restoring the fork when broken.
Caput VI.	Chapter 6.
Plurimum quidem frangitur Furcula ab anteriore parte ex parte humeri, et fractura eius fit secundum unum trium modorum.	The fork is indeed most often broken on the anterior part of the arm; and its fracture occurs according to one of three modes.
Aut enim frangitur et separatur in duo, praeter quod accidant in ea satagiae: et est facilius ad restaurationem eius.	For it is broken either into two pieces without any sawdust getting caught in it; and thus its restoration is easier.
Aut ita, quod accidunt in osse satagiae: et est difficilius ad restaurationem.	Or that sawdust gets caught up within the bone; and its restoration is difficult.
Aut ita, quod est fractura cum uulnere.	Or that there's a fracture with an open wound alongside it.
Et operatio in ea quando fractura est absque uulnere, est, ut facias praesentes esse duos ministros, ut teneat unus eorum adiutorium quod sequitur Furculam fractam, et alter extendat collum uersus partem.	When a fork is fractured without an open wound, the procedure is as follows: you must have two assistants; one of them holds the broken fork while the other extends their arm towards the side.
Deinde aequa fracturam digitis tuis, donec fiat forma eius, secundum quod oportet: et non sit in ea eminentia, neque concauitas.	Then align the fracture with your fingers until its shape is correct and even; and there should be neither prominence nor hollows.
Quod si indiges extensione plus, tunc oportet, ut ponas sub titillico infirmi spheram ex panno, aut lana: et sit magnitudo eius secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae: et extende, et eleua Furculam, et coarta spheram manu tua, donec aeques fracturam, secundum quod oportet.	If you need more extension, then you should place underneath the patient's heel a pad made of cloth or wool; its size should be according to your needs; extend and raise the fork, and shorten the pad with your hand until the fracture is reduced as required.
Quod si non potes trahere extremitatem Furculae ad exteriora: propterea, quia peruenit ad profundum: tunc oportet, ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam: et ponas sub humero eius puluinar medium in magnitudine, et premat minister humerum eius ad inferiora, donec eleuetur os Furculae quod est in profundo ad sursum: atque tunc rectifica fracturam, et aequa eam digitis tuis.	If you cannot draw the end of the fork outwards because it has come out too deep, then the patient should be made to lie face down over his own neck; place under his shoulder a pillow of medium size and have an assistant press his shoulder downwards until the bone of the fork that is buried deeply is raised up; then reduce the fracture and align it with your fingers.
Si autem sentis sathaiatum ex Furcula, et mouetur: tunc oportet, ut findas super illud, et extrahas ipsum alsathaiatum cum facilitate.	If you feel slippage of the fork and it is moving, then you should cut open above it and remove that displaced part with ease.
Si autem est retentum in osse, tunc ingenia in incisione eius cum uno Incisoriorum quae praeparasti ad illud, postquam tu posueris sub Furcula instrumentum quod seruat sifach: et est instrumentum ex ligno, aut ex ferro.	If it is retained by the bone, then introduce into its incision one of the knives you have prepared for this purpose; after you place under the fork a protector, and the protector is either wood or iron.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Assimilatur cochleari cui non est concauitas.	It resembles a spoon that has no hollow.
Et sit latitudo eius secundum illud quo indiges eo ex magnitudine ossis, et paruitate eius.	Its width should be according to the size of bone you need it for and its fragility.
Longitudo uero eius etiam secundum quod possibile est tibi ad operationem.	Its length should also be according to what is possible for you in the procedure.
Et habeat duas extremitates, sicut uides: et extremitas una sit ampla, et altera stricta.	It should have two ends as you see it: one end is wide, the other narrow.
Si autem disruptio uulneris quod scidisti quando extraxisti sathaiatum ossis, est ampla, et securaris ab apostemate calido: tunc aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura.	If however the wound you opened when removing that displaced part of the bone is large and you are afraid of abscess because it is warm, then bring together the two lips of the wound with a suture.
Et si disruptio est parua, aut times apostema calidum: tunc imple uulnus cum pannis, et puluillis secundum quantitatem scissurae uulneris.	And if the rupture is small or you fear a hot abscess: then fill the wound with cloths and plugs according to the size of the injury's tear.
Quod si accidat apostema calidum, tunc infunde pannum in oleo rosato, et aceto, et uino, et pone super ipsum.	If a hot abscess occurs, then soak a cloth in rose oil, vinegar, and wine, and place it on top of the abscess.
Strictura uero ossis quando est absque uulnere, et absque sectione, est, ut ponas super os emplastrum factum ex farina molendini cum albugine oui.	However, if there is a bone fracture without any wound or break, you should apply a plaster made from flour and egg white to the bone.
Et pone stuppam lenem super ipsum.	And place soft rags on top of it.
Deinde pone spheram sub titillico eius, si indiges illa.	Then put a ball under their armpit if they need it.
Deinde accipe himematem, id est, rotam quam tenent Saraceni, quae sit longa ualde: et sit latitudo eius palmi unius, aut circiter illud.	Next take a hemmeter, which is the wheel that the Saracens use and which is very long; its width should be one palm or around that size.
Deinde pone puluillum duplicatum super stuppam et emplastrum.	Then place a doubled plug on top of the rags and plaster.
Deinde accipe astellam ex tabula subtili, cuius latitudo sit trium digitorum, et in longitudine similiter.	Next take a thin board whose width is three fingers wide and its length likewise.
Deinde inuolue eam in panno.	Then wrap it in cloth.
Deinde inuolue pannum illum cum astella in loco alhimemati qui cadit super fracturam et locum.	Then wrap that cloth with the board in it around the place of the hemmeter which lies over the fracture and site.
Deinde pone alhimemati super fracturam sicut reuoluiur, et inuolue eam super collum eius, et sub titillico eius sano, et sub titillico eius infirmo: et reduc eam super omnem partem, et quomodo uides quod strictura tenet fracturam strictura decenti: et est illud, quod non occultatur super te, et totum, ut non remoueatur astella desuper os fractum.	Then place the hemmeter over the fracture as it was rolled up and wrap it around their neck, under their healthy armpit, and then under their injured armpit; bring it back to cover all parts where you see that the bone has been misaligned. It should not be concealed from view above and should cover everything so that the board is not removed from over the broken bone.
Et propter hoc oportet, ut aspicias infirmum in omni die.	And for this reason, you should look after the sick person every day.
Quotiens ergo mollificatur ligamentum, et uides astellam iam remoueri: tunc rectifica illud, et stringe ligamentum.	Whenever you see the bone already starting to move away; then straighten it out and tighten the ligament.
Deinde pone somnum infirmi super dorsum eius, et pone sub titillico eius apud somnum eius puluinar paruum in nocte, ut cum eo eleuetur adiutorium eius a latere ipsius.	Then place the patient's pillow under his back and put another small pillow at night under their head to elevate it on that side.
Eleuatur ergo fractura furculae per eleuationem humeri.	Raise the fracture of the forearm by raising up the shoulder.
Aut liga brachium eius ad collum ipsius: et non soluas ligamentum, si non accidat in loco accidens ex pruritu, aut ab apostemate, usque ad duodecim dies.	Or bind the patient's arm to their neck and do not release this bandage unless there is an accident at that site due to itching or from a sore until twelve days have passed.
Deinde renoua emplastrum, si uideris faciem eius ad illud.	Then renew the plaster if you see its surface has become exposed.
Et adde in strictura, et dimitte ipsum, donec restauretur et coaguletur.	And add to the bandage and leave it until it is healed and hardened.
Et fractura quidem furculae stringitur et confortatur secundum plurimum in uigintiocto diebus: et quandoque fit in quibusdam hominibus in minore illo.	The fracture of the forearm is most often bound up and strengthened within twenty-eight days, sometimes sooner for some patients.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Spatulae.	### On healing a Fracture of the Jawbone.
Caput VII.	Chapter 7.
Raro frangitur Spatula, et in loco lato eius: et non franguntur ex ea nisi margines eius.	The jaw is rarely broken except over its widest part; but if it does break then only the edge of it breaks off.
Quando ergo frangitur ex eo locus, et frangitur in medio eius, et non cognoscitur illud nisi per tactum: tunc secundum quod est figura fracturae conare praeparationem eius.	When the jaw is broken at this site and breaks right through its middle so that it cannot be seen from outside; then according to where exactly the break lies, you must try to set it in place.
Et reduc eam super figuram naturalem omni modo ingenii, quod est tibi possibile.	And restore its shape as much as your ingenuity allows you to do so.
Deinde pone super locum puluerem molendini cum albugine oui, et stuppam lenem, et pone desuper puluillum ex panno duplato.	Then place over the wound powder from a mill with egg white, and soft lint, and cover it all with a little pad made of doubled cloth.
Deinde pone super ipsum astellam latam ex tabula subtili secundum quantitatem Spatulae totius, aut ampliorem ea parum.	Then place over it a flat splint made of thin wood according to the size of the whole spatula, or slightly larger.
Si uero sub astella est concauitas in aliquo locorum Spatulae, tunc aequa illam concauitatem cum stuppa leni, donec descendat astella secundum aequalitatem.	If there is any hollow under the splint in one of the spatula's places, then fill that hollow evenly with soft lint until the splint sits level.
Deinde ftringe desuper cum alhimemati longa, constrictione decenti, et firmitudine astellae, donec non remoueatur a loco suo.	Then bind it tightly from above with a long bandage of the proper tightness and firmness to hold the splint in place until it does not move.
Et considera ligamentum in omni die.	And check the binding every day.
Quotienscunque ergo mollificatur ligamentum, stringe ipsum, et aequa astellam si remoueatur a loco suo: et iaceat infirmus super latus suum sanum.	Whenever the binding becomes soft, tighten it, and adjust the splint if it has moved from its place; also have the patient lie on their healthy side.
Et Spatula quidem restauratur in uiginti diebus, aut in uigintiquinque diebus.	The splint will heal within twenty or twenty-five days.
Quando ergo completur iste numerus, tunc solue ligamentum: et tu sis in securitate.	When that number of days is complete, then you may remove the binding; and you will be safe.
Nam ipsa est ex ossibus quorum communitio non timetur, neque eorum solutio.	For it is made of bones whose fracture or dislocation need not be feared.
Si autem procedat ex osse frustum, et pungit sub cute: tune scinde super ipsum, et aufer ipsum.	If however, a piece of bone projects from it and pierces the skin, then split it open over that spot and remove the projecting piece.
Et fac quod diximus in fractura furculae ex sedatione apostematis calidi, si accidat ex eo aliquid.	And do as we said with the fracture of the collarbone for a warm poultice from an aposteme if something similar happens.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Pectoris.	On restoring fractures of the ribs.
Caput VIII.	Chapter Eight.
Pectus quandoque frangitur in medio sui, et raro accidit illud.	The chest sometimes breaks in the middle of itself, and this rarely happens.
Extremitates eius quidem plurimum franguntur, et comminuuntur ex accidentibus eius.	Its limbs indeed break and shatter the most from its accidents.
Quando frangitur eius medium, quod declinat ad inferiora, et accidit ei dolor uehemens, et difficultas in anhelitu, et tussis: et fortasse euomit sanguinem, et declaratur concauitas in osse fracto, et non occultatur sensui, Restauratio eius est, ut resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum: et pone inter Spatulas eius puluinar.	When its middle breaks, which slopes downwards to the lower parts, and it suffers severe pain, difficulty in breathing, and a cough; perhaps vomiting blood, with concavity evident on the broken bone, and not hidden from perception, its restoration is for the patient to lie on their back with a pillow placed between their shoulder blades.
Deinde preme humeros eius, et aggrega costas a duabus partibus uel lateribus cum manibus: et subtiliare in aequatione eius, secundum omnem modum quo possibile est illud et conuenit, donec redeat figura ossis, secundum quod oportet.	Then press their shoulders and bring the ribs together from both sides with your hands; and carefully align it as evenly as possible and appropriate until the shape of the bone returns as it should be.
Deinde pone super ipsum emplastrum et stuppam, et pone desuper astellam ex tabula subtili ex salice, aut chalingi, et ex eis similibus in leuitate, postquam tu inuoluis eam in panno.	Then place a plaster and a poultice on them, and put above it a star made of thin wooden board from willow or hazel, and similarly light ones, after you wrap it in cloth.
Deinde subtiliare in ligando eam super os fractum, ut non remoueatur: et uade cum ligatura secundum rotunditatem ad dorsum aliquotiens, et stringe ipsum strictura decenti.	Then carefully bind it above the broken bone so that it is not moved; and go around with the binding according to the roundness towards the back several times, tightening it with a suitable bandage.
Deinde considera ligaturam in omni hora, et quotienscumque mollificatur, stringe eam: et si necessitas eius prouocat ad solutionem eius apud pruritum, uel corrosionem quae accidit in loco, aut dolorem, aut apostema: tunc propera, et solue eam, et eradica emplastrum, et rectifica quod accidit cum modo curationis eius.	Then check the bandage every hour and whenever it loosens, tighten it; and if its need provokes its removal due to itching, or corrosion which occurs in that place, or pain, or abscess: then hurry, and remove it, take off the plaster, and address what happens with an appropriate treatment method.
Deinde reduc emplastrum, si uides ad illud faciem: et annecte ei stricturam, donec sanetur.	Then bring back the plaster if you see its face; and attach to it a bandage until it is healed.
¶ De restauratione Costarum, quando franguntur.	The restoration of ribs when they are broken.
Caput IX.	Chapter 9.
Scias, quod Costarum fractura non accidit, nisi in locis grossis quae sequuntur dorsum, et ex extremitatibus earum ab anteriori parte.	You know that a rib fracture does not occur except in the thick parts which follow the back and at their ends from the front part.
Et non accidit eis attritio, nisi propterea, quia sunt cartilaginosae.	And they do not suffer dislocation because of this, since they are made of cartilage.
Et cognitio ipsius non occultatur sensui apud inquisitionem cum digitis.	Recognition of it is not hidden from the sense of touch during examination with the fingers.
Et restauratio eius fit ita, ut aeques fracturam cum digitis secundum modum possibilem, donec aequetur figura, secundum quod oportet.	And its restoration is done in this way: equally align the fracture with your fingers as best you can until the shape is equalised as it should be.
Deinde emplastra, et stringe os fractum cum astella, si indiget illo.	Next apply plastering, and bind the broken bone with a splint if it needs one.
Et si fractura Costarum est decliuis ad interiora: tunc accidit infirmo dolor uehemens, et punctura, sicut punctura illa quae accidit illi qui habet pleuresim: propterea, quod os pungit uelamen, et etiam ei accidit difficultas anhelitus, et tussis, et uomitus sanguinis multi: et haec est difficilis curationis.	And if the rib fracture is towards the inside of the body, then the patient experiences severe pain and piercing, like that which occurs in pleurisy, because the bone pierces the lung, and they also experience difficulty breathing, coughing, and vomiting a lot of blood: and this condition is difficult to treat.
Et iam ingeniati sunt antiqui in ea cum ingeniis multis: et ex eis sunt qui dicunt, ut ponas cibos infirmi qui generent inflammationem et uentositatem, ut inflammetur uenter, et extendatur, et impellatur fractura ad exteriora.	Ancient physicians have devised many techniques for this condition, and among them are those who say that you should feed the patient foods which cause inflammation and wind, so as to inflame the abdomen and push it outwards, thus forcing the fracture towards the outside.
Nos uero abhorremus, ut non fiat caussa uelox ad faciendum apostema calidum, si non accidit.	We however refrain from doing anything which might cause a quick-forming hot abscess if it does not happen.
Si autem iam accidit, tunc addit in eo.	But if it has already occurred, then an addition is made to it.
Et dixerunt quidam eorum: ponatur super locum uentosa, deinde sugatur cum fortitudine, et est similius ratiocinationi.	Some of them said to put something windy on the place, then suck it with strength, and this is more similar to logic.
Verumtamen timetur, quod attrahat uentosa superfluitates ad locum, propter dispositionem debilitatis.	However, there is a fear that it may draw superfluous humors to the site due to its weakness-inducing properties.
Et dixerunt quidam eorum: oportet ut cooperiatur locus cum lana quae iam submersa est in oleo calido: et ponantur puluilli inter Costas, donec impleatur: ut sit ligatura aequalis quando inuoluis eam secundum rotunditatem.
